In addition, we cannot assess the impact of each factor on our business or the extent to which any factor, or combination of factors, may cause actual results to differ materially from those described in any forward-looking statements. -----

We are the European leader in the residential real estate services (“RRES”) market, providing services to both individuals (“business-to-consumer” or “B2C”) and businesses (“business-to-business” or “B2B”). We assist our residential and commercial customers at every stage of their property journey with competitive and comprehensive service offerings. Our RRES business is the leader in France, operating under the Foncia brand through a unique network of over 500 branches. We also hold leading positions in Switzerland and Germany and have a strong presence in Belgium and Luxembourg in which we operate under various brands through a network of over 100 branches. We have expanded our size and reach through bolt-on acquisitions and completed over 220 acquisitions since 2016. In addition to our successful M&A track record, our recent performance has been marked by achievements in operations, digitization, and our IT and communications infrastructure. We believe our success is the result of a unique integrated ecosystem of real estate services, which provides the opportunity for organic growth via cross-selling of additional services with recurring revenues and external growth through bolt-on acquisitions. We operate an integrated business model across a wide range of real estate services and divide our real estate services into the following businesses: - **Residential Real Estate Services (representing 60% of 2020 revenue) consisting of - **Joint Property Management (representing 30% of 2020 revenue) through which we are mandated by landlords to manage jointly owned building areas and equipment. - **Lease Management and Renting (representing 30% of 2020 revenue) through which we manage properties on behalf of landlords and assist landlords and tenants throughout their rental process. - **Real Estate Brokerage (representing 13% of 2020 revenue) through which we assist property owners and buyers throughout the real estate sales process. - **Ancillary Services (representing 6% of 2020 revenue) through which we provide services that are complementary to our RRES and Brokerage businesses, including insurance and inventories services. - **Digital Services (representing 4% of 2020 revenue) through which we operate services relying on digital platforms such as online real estate valuation and brokerage. - **B2B Services (representing 4% of 2020 revenue) through which we provide real estate services to our commercial and institutional customers, as well as adjacent real estate services such as insurance and diagnostics. - **International Services (representing 13% of 2020 revenue) through which we provide the full spectrum of real estate services through our international operations in Germany, Switzerland, Belgium and Luxembourg. -----

Subsubsection Title: Sector leadership focused on strongest economies in Western Europe providing competitive advantages
Subsubsection Text: We have established ourselves as a leader for residential real estate services in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg by delivering high quality, reliable and innovative services uniquely suited to the needs of our customers. As of August 2019, we were the number one player in the French real estate services market, with approximately 13% market share, according to an international report provider. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we managed approximately 1.8 million dwellings in France, which is approximately two times the number of dwellings managed by our next closest competitor according to publically available information for the year ended 2020. Outside of France, we hold leading positions in Switzerland and Germany and have a strong presence in Belgium and Luxembourg. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we operated over 100 branches in these countries, which collectively accounted for 13% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our scale, operations and service offerings provide us with a clear competitive advantage. Our centralized processes result in lower internal costs and enable improved customer service compared to our typically small, individual-owned competitors. Our comprehensive range of innovative services, such as FONCIA 24/7 (our assistance service for our joint property management customers), Prowen (our centralized energy service that reduces client costs on gas and electricity), and Assurimo, (our real estate insurance service), differentiate us from competitors. Our comprehensive network of over 500 branches covering all major French cities is one of the largest offerings in the market and results in close proximity to our customers and the dwellings that we manage; unique market positioning in negotiations with third-party repair and maintenance service suppliers resulting in decreased costs; and financial resources that allow us to expand our customer portfolio through acquisitions. We have been able to successfully enter markets through acquisitions and expanded our operating geography, despite the regulatory and technological requirements that create barriers to participation in the real estate services market. Our regional and national regulatory and real estate industry expertise and our leadership team’s extensive experience in the real estate services industry are key to meeting and complying with such requirements. Our strong reputation for quality and service and multi-branded strategy have also supported our ability to grow in existing markets and enter new markets.

Subsubsection Title: Loyal and diverse customer base and synergetic business model in a resilient market
Subsubsection Text: Our large and diversified client base, integrated ecosystem of residential real estate services and high customer retention rates drive a high level of recurring revenues (75% in the year ended December 31, 2020). We have grown our diversified customer base to approximately 1.5 million dwellings in our French Joint Property Management business and over 330,000 dwellings in our French Lease Management business as at December 31, 2020. Through our synergetic business model, we are able to cross sell our services to our diverse customer portfolio across our business lines, which in turn leads to further organic growth. For example, our proven ability to cross-sell is highlighted by the high penetration rates of Assurimo, our specialized property insurance brokerage unit (providing property insurance, homeowners’ insurance policies and brokerage services) through which we currently provide insurance services to 61% of our French Joint Property Management buildings. Similarly, we currently provide technical services to approximately 88% of our Lease Management customers through our dedicated business, Constatimmo. We believe that we are well positioned to target new customers, including B2B customers, given our knowledge regarding fulfilling requirements for our B2C customers. The addressable markets in which we operate are characterized by high outsourcing rates, with a high and stable portion of joint property or condominium owners (85% in France) under external management, as of August 2019 using services like our Joint Property Management business. Property owners tend to rely on expert services such as ours due to the volume of work and amount of legal and accounting know-how required to directly interface with tenants and other counterparties. Moreover, landlords rarely switch leasing managers during a tenancy, given the risks and costs involved in switching service providers and the limited potential benefit. We believe that through the integrated ecosystem of high-quality services we consistently provide we have established high customer retention rates, and long lasting customer relationships, certain of which last more than 20 years. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we lost only 3.5% and 8.4% of customers from our Joint Property Management and Lease Management businesses, respectively. Moreover, 36% of our customers from our Joint Property Management business in France entered into contracts of three or more years and 24% for two to three years for the year ended December 31, 2020. Due to our broad and diverse customer base, we are not reliant on any particular customer. ----- According to an international report provider, the French property management market is estimated to be €12.2 billion in August 2019, of which €5.3 billion is captured by property management companies, with the rest serviced in-house. The externally serviced property management market has grown by approximately 2% annually between 2014 and 2019. This stable growth has been driven by population dynamics and the construction of collective units. We continue to capitalize on opportunities to grow through acquisition of customer portfolios, cross-selling of related services to our large client base and the addition of new revenue opportunities for our existing services.

Subsubsection Title: Strong and predictable cash flow generation
Subsubsection Text: We have a track record of steady cash flow generation, driven by a high level of recurring revenues, which has enabled us to establish a history of consistent deleveraging. Our trend of improving EBITDA conversion rates has continued with a Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Conversion Rate, of approximately 76% for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to 71% for the year ended December 31, 2019. Despite our regular M&A activity, our discretionary spend on acquisitions provides us with flexibility to manage our cash flow and reduce our financial leverage. In addition, from 2016 to 2019, we reduced our total net leverage by approximately 0.6x on average per year. Further, our business requires limited maintenance capital expenditures, (accounting for approximately 6% of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2020), and is characterized by limited working capital requirements. Our revenue increased at a CAGR of 5.4% and was €961.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 up from €865.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Our margin resilience is supported by an adaptable cost structure for the more cyclical flow Brokerage business, as Brokerage salary costs include a significant variable portion that is indexed on commissions. Our Adjusted EBITDA Margin was 26.9%, 26.8% and 22.3% for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively. Our recurring, stable revenue is in part due to our complementary business profiles across our branches, experienced management and sales force teams, and fee-based services in connection with our Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Renting businesses which accounted for 69% of our revenue in France for the year ended December 31, 2020. In addition, our high proportion of recurring revenues (75% in 2020) and balanced portfolio of services split between stock and flow businesses with limited correlation have supported our resilience during adverse economic conditions, achieving a substantially stable performance in 2020 despite unprecedented government measures taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Subsubsection Title: Continuous investments in operational improvement through our innovative technology platforms reinforces our competitive position and provides sustainable efficiency gains
Subsubsection Text: We continuously invest in cutting edge technology in order to offer the best multi-channel services to our customers. Since 2017, we have upgraded a significant portion of our IT and communication infrastructure including utilizing a mix of integrated and outsourced solutions, transitioning to a single telecom provider, and streamlining our finance and human resources functions with Workday, which enabled us to quickly and effectively transition to a work-from-home environment during the COVID-19 pandemic. We have also leveraged our technological know-how combined with our knowledge of the real estate industry to design and launch a go-live version of our new ERP system, Millenium, which we have piloted at one of our branches in France in 2020. Millenium integrates all of our IT and resource planning functions into one database to better meet our customers’ needs and address internal business challenges. Millenium increases the digitization of our activities with the aim of helping customers by creating greater transparency and improving our operations with standardized, digital processes to increase efficiency and to improve the speed at which we can serve our customers. We believe our high levels of investment in IT for our corporate platform and customer interface service such as over recent years give us a competitive edge in the current environment. The digitization, standardization and automation offered by Millenium complement our already synergetic business model and will allow us to more quickly leverage our customer database to identify cross-selling opportunities leading to greater operating efficiencies and inter-business synergies. We believe that Millenium’s compatibility with big data, AI and IoT, will allow us to explore new business opportunities and provide access to a number of revenue-enhancing opportunities. For example, we are developing a new operational model called “Agency of the Future” which will utilize Millenium to reorganize the residential real estate services and aims at improving client satisfaction and reducing our customer churn rate, which we believe will, in turn, lead to greater opportunities for organic growth. In addition, we believe that the gains of Millenium and the development of Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €15 million in 2022. We have invested in, and will continue to invest in, technology to continually improve our internal ----- operations in order to provide our customers with product offerings that meet their needs and make us the number one choice among residential real estate service providers.

Subsubsection Title: Consolidation platform with proven track record of executing value accretive acquisitions to drive incremental EBITDA growth
Subsubsection Text: In addition to our organic growth, we maintain a successful, low-risk strategy of growth through small, bolt-on acquisitions. We completed 220 acquisitions from January 2016 to December 2020, which represented approximately €386.0 million of acquired revenues (including gross revenues for Leemo netted for commissions to agents in our financial accounts). In the year ended December 31, 2020, we made 61 acquisitions in our primary French market and in other geographies, representing approximately 60,000 new Lease Management dwellings and approximately 171,000 new Joint Property Management dwellings and approximately €111.0 million of acquired revenues. We completed 61 acquisitions which contributed to our Adjusted EBITDA that reached €286.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 as compared to €258.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. Consolidation is a natural trend in the highly fragmented markets we operate in, accelerated by increasing regulations, and we play a key role in the market by defining new quality standards and unrivalled execution processes. We have a strong M&A team, with a disciplined approach that is dedicated to identifying, diligencing, completing and integrating opportunistic acquisitions in our five geographical regions. Our long-standing integration experience, including a dedicated post-acquisition integration team, enables us to extract full synergy potential from acquired businesses, with both cross-selling and cost synergies. We have identified a number of potential targets in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg to continue growing and, importantly, reinforcing our leadership in the market.

Subsubsection Title: Highly experienced management team with proven execution capabilities and focus on growth and value creation
Subsubsection Text: Our management team, led by our Chief Executive Officer, Philippe Salle, have significant experience in the industry and proven track record of delivering business and revenue growth, executing investment plans, driving continuous improvement of our European enterprise and generating high returns on capital. Our management team comes from various industries and geographies and is supported by five heads of region, who have extensive experience in real estate and enable us to provide our customers with tailored expertise and service. We believe that the collective industry knowledge and leadership of our management team positions them well to continue our successful organic and external growth and execute our strategies. Further, our management team encourages growth through a focus on operational efficiency and innovation including through the management’s dynamic external growth policy that enabled us to, among others, establish our market leading presence in Germany, successfully divest our non-core businesses to focus on our core, synergetic businesses and more recently, by the ongoing overhaul of our IT infrastructure, including the development of Millenium and enabling our planned transition to our new operational model, “Agency of the Future.” This is demonstrated by the consistent increase in our revenues which increased at a CAGR of 5.4% and was €961.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 (€1,013 million excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic) up from €865.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018.

Subsubsection Title: Industry-leading technology to further reinforce our competitive advantage
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to providing the best real estate services offerings to our customers by investing in industryleading IT and data platforms, which in turn supports our market share gains. Our most recent digital innovation, Millenium, an in-house developed ERP system that is device-agnostic, cloud-based and driven by artificial intelligence, will allow us to fully digitalize all of our businesses and establish a highly personalized digital relationship with our customers. We believe that Millenium will also allow us to better, more efficiently serve our customers, cross-sell across our platforms and therefore capture greater market share from existing customers and generate business from new customers. Our IT and data platforms are subject to a process of continuous improvement and innovation, which we support with ongoing investments, such as the team of over 80 developers and specialized professional we hired to create Millenium. We believe that our robust investments in our IT and data platforms provide us with a significant competitive advantage, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic when businesses have been required to transition to a work-from-home environment. Additionally, our ongoing and historical use of big data, AI and IoT to create new business opportunities enables us to maintain a cutting edge development ----- program while minimizing the risks traditionally associated with experimentation. For example, we are in the process of developing our new operational model, Agency of the Future, which we believe will generate significant savings, mainly related to (i) staff costs synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and back-office functions to front-office employees and an increase in productivity and significant reduction of time spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains resulting from the digitization and automation of certain tasks that were previously done manually, such as reminder fees or the collection of postal charges. Since 2018, we have invested approximately €100 million into our IT projects, and we believe that the gains of Millenium and Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €15 million in 2022. We have developed, and continue to develop, innovative solutions based on emerging trends that are aimed at providing our customers with the highest quality, optimal solutions for their real estate needs. We are constantly looking for ways to improve our offerings and develop new solutions for our customers, which we expect to drive incremental growth and positively impact our revenue.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to drive organic growth and pursue targeted and opportunistic bolt-on acquisitions in core French market
Subsubsection Text: Our goal is to continue to deliver organic growth in France. We have been successful in achieving incremental organic revenue growth through active cross selling efforts across our ancillary services. We intend to continue to benefit from this growth through expanding our service offerings by introducing new business lines. In addition, we aim to reduce our customer churn rate further by improving client satisfaction, including as a result of the overhaul of our IT systems. In addition, we have made, and intend to continue to make, bolt-on acquisitions in our core French market and the other geographies in which we operate to supplement our organic growth, solidify our current market position and expand our presence. We have a strong track record of successfully identifying, completing and integrating opportunistic acquisitions. From January 2016 to December 2020, we completed approximately 220 acquisitions. We believe that our strong brand, broad platform and our dynamic infrastructure have allowed us to generate growth and operating cash flows through acquisitions. Recent examples of targeted acquisitions in France that have accelerated our growth and have allowed us to better address customer needs include Gérance de Passy and LoftOne, in our RRES business, Yxime and Perial in B2B and in the German B2B segment, Paul Immobilien and SogerTec. We intend to continue to further strengthen our strong position in the market by pursuing opportunistic acquisitions in our existing geographies to accelerate our growth, and we aim to do so by leveraging our internal expertise. We have an M&A team that is dedicated to identifying growth opportunities. Our team deploys a disciplined and systematic approach and focuses on opportunities that will enhance the offerings and services we provide in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg.

We have expanded, and plan to continue to expand, our geographic footprint in Europe, organically and through targeted and opportunistic acquisitions. We intend to leverage our expertise and know-how as well as our highly localized real estate providers to penetrate European markets where there is an unmet demand and an opportunity for further expansion, as evidenced by factors such as population dynamics and the construction of collective units, accompanied by increases in price and service level and a higher degree of outsourcing driven by regulatory changes. We strategically pursue new markets while remaining committed to expanding in France, Germany, Switzerland, Belgium and Luxembourg as these markets offer us proximity to existing customers and expansion opportunities in countries where we have established brand recognition. We also plan to enter European markets, where we believe local markets have strong fundamentals, such as the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Denmark, Scandinavian countries, Austria and various other Eastern European countries where we aim to become the market leader. Our expertise and solutions are scalable from region to region, and we believe that as we continue to expand, we can increase market share by deploying practices and strategies that have proven to be successful in other markets.

We are committed to ESG matters and providing a safe and healthy environment for all of our customers and employees. Our corporate social responsibility strategy is based on the following key commitments: supporting sustainable energy in the buildings and dwellings we manage, improving the well-being of our customers and our employees and ensuring fair and non-discriminatory access to housing and assisting local communities. Our ----- ESG initiatives are also focused on protecting the environment while also ensuring that our operations have minimal impact on the environment. We also aim to work with our clients, contractors and suppliers to improve efficiency, conserve natural resources and reduce waste and emissions. We focus on energy transition of buildings under management by developing services and solutions to enable our clients to renovate and finance their dwellings. In 2021, we aim to ensure that all of our building managers are systematically trained to lead such renovation projects, partner with clients and employees who demonstrate a commitment to the environment and reduce our carbon footprint.

On the Issue Date, the Issuers will issue the Notes offered hereby and use the proceeds of the Offering, together with drawings under the New Term Loan Facility: - to repay the Existing Senior Facilities, - to repay the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, - as funds earmarked for identified acquisitions anticipated to close during the first half of 2021, - to make a distribution to shareholders, and - to pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. The estimated sources and uses of the proceeds from the Offering are set forth in “Use of Proceeds.” The Offering and the application of the proceeds from the Offering, together with the entry by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and certain of its subsidiaries into the New Senior Credit Facilities Agreement and application of drawings thereunder, in each case as set forth under “Use of Proceeds,” are collectively referred to in this Offering Memorandum as the “Transactions.” See also “Description of Other Indebtedness—New _Senior Credit Facilities Agreement.”_

Founded in 1996, Partners Group is a global private markets investment management firm with USD 109 billion in assets under management in private equity, private real estate, private infrastructure and private debt as at December 31, 2020. The firm manages a broad range of customized portfolios for an international clientele of institutional investors. Partners Group is headquartered in Zug, Switzerland and has offices in Denver, Houston, New York, Toronto, São Paulo, London, Guernsey, Paris, Luxembourg, Milan, Munich, Dubai, Mumbai, Singapore, Manila, Shanghai, Seoul, Tokyo and Sydney. The firm employs around 1,500 professionals and is listed on the SIX Swiss Exchange (symbol: PGHN) with a major ownership by its partners and employees. It had a market capitalization of CHF 28.7 billion as at February 19, 2021. In private equity, Partners Group manages assets of USD 52 billion and has on behalf of its clients directly invested in more than 250 businesses since inception. The investment focus in private equity is on profitable companies with strong growth potential and value-add opportunities in six industry verticals. Partners Group pursues a diversified and global relative value approach across geographic regions and industries. Selected private equity investments include Techem, Rovensa, Ammega, SPi Global, Schleich, Cerba HealthCare, Global Logic and KinderCare Education. CDPQ is a long-term institutional investor that manages funds primarily for public and parapublic pension and insurance plans from the province of Québec, Canada. It receives money on deposit from its clients (known as “depositors”) and manages these funds while seeking optimal return on investment, in accordance with depositors’ investment policies. CDPQ is one of Canada’s largest institutional fund managers, with CAD 333 billion in assets as at December 31, 2020. It invests globally in major financial markets, private equity, infrastructure, real estate and private debt. CDPQ was constituted in 1965 by an act of the Québec National Assembly. -----

Based on our management accounts, we estimate that for the month ended January 31, 2021 compared to the month ended January 31, 2020, our revenue increased by approximately 7.3%, from approximately €74.7 million for the month ended January 31, 2020 to approximately €80.2 million for the month ended January 31, 2021. We estimate that our reported EBITDA for the month ended January 31, 2021 increased by approximately 7.8% from approximately €17.1 million for the month ended January 31, 2020 to approximately €18.5 million for the month ended January 31, 2021. As of January 31, 2021, we estimate that we had cash and cash equivalents of €63.8 million. While our operations have remained resilient throughout the COVID-19 pandemic and we are fully operational across all business areas, we expect some carry-over impact notably as a result of the November 2020 lockdown in France during which fewer property transactions took place, which will be reflected in our first quarter 2021 financial statements, in line with the customary three month lag between signing of brokerage transactions and revenue recognition upon closing. This impact is expected to primarily affect the results of our Joint Property Management (mainly on our additional fees) and Brokerage businesses. _Joint Property Management_ In the one month ended January 31, 2021, we estimate that our Joint Property Management business revenues increased by 7% compared to the one month ended January 31, 2020 to €25.3 million. For more information, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors _Affecting Results of Operations—COVID-19 pandemic impact on our business.” Brokerage Business_ In the one month ended January 31, 2021, we estimate that our Brokerage business revenues decreased by 3% compared to the one month ended January 31, 2020 to €9.9 million. This decrease was primarily related to the November 2020 lockdown in France and due to property viewings being limited as fewer customers purchased, rented or sold properties. We expect that the impact of the November 2020 lockdown will be reflected in our 2021 financial statements because we recognize revenue in our Brokerage business up to three months following the signing of a transaction. For more information, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—COVID-19 pandemic impact on our business.” The information presented above relating to our performance for the one month ended January 31, 2021 is derived from internal management accounts. This information has been prepared by management of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. It has not been audited, reviewed or verified, and it is not subject to any procedures by our auditors, and you should not place undue reliance on it. While we believe this information is preliminary, it is subject to change, and those changes could be material. This information may not be indicative of our performance in the remainder of the financial quarter, the financial year or any future period. See “Forward-looking Statements,” “Risk Factors” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” in this Offering Memorandum for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance._ -----

The information set forth in this summary does not contain all the information you should consider before making your investment decision. You should carefully read the entire Offering Memorandum, including the section “Risk Factors” and our consolidated financial statements and related notes included herein, before making your investment decision. This summary contains forward-looking statements that contain risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ significantly from future results as a result of factors such as those set forth in “Risk Factors” and “Forward-Looking Statements.”_

Section Title: CORPORATE STRUCTURE AND CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: The following diagram shows a simplified summary of our corporate and principal financing structure after giving effect to the Transactions. All entities shown below are 100% owned unless otherwise indicated. The chart does not include all entities in our group or all of the debt obligations thereof. For a summary of the debt obligations identified in this diagram, see “Capitalization,” “Description of the Senior Secured Notes,” “Description of the Senior Notes” and “Description of Other Indebtedness.” (1) The Senior Notes Issuer is indirectly controlled by funds managed and/or advised by Partners Group and holding together, indirectly, approximately 92.3% of the shares in the Senior Notes Issuer. The remaining 7.7% equity interests are held directly or indirectly by certain members of management. See “Principal Shareholders.” (2) The Senior Notes Issuer will issue €250 million aggregate principal amount of 5.000% Senior Notes due 2029. On the Issue Date, the Senior Notes will be senior obligations of the Senior Notes Issuer and will (i) rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Notes; (ii) rank senior in right of payment to any future indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Notes Issuer; (iii) be effectively subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of the Senior Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries that is secured by property and assets that do not secure the Senior Notes, or that secure such indebtedness on a priority basis (including, with respect to the Shared Collateral, obligations in respect of the Senior Secured Notes and the New Senior Credit Facilities Agreement), to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such indebtedness; and (iv) be structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Senior Notes Issuer’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Senior Notes, including obligations to trade creditors. (3) The Senior Secured Notes Issuer will issue €400 million aggregate principal amount of 3.375% Senior Secured Notes due 2028. On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be senior obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and (i) rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including any indebtedness under the New Senior Credit Facilities and certain hedging obligations, if any; (ii) rank senior in right of payment to all of the Senior Secured Note Issuer’s existing and future subordinated indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, including the Senior Notes; (iii) be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries and the Guarantors that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness; and (iv) be structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes, including obligations to trade creditors. (4) On or around the Issue Date, we will enter into the New Senior Credit Facilities Agreement. The New Senior Credit Facilities include the New Revolving Credit Facility, which provides for up to €437.5 million of senior secured credit borrowings and letters of credit and ancillary facilities, and the New Term Loan Facility in a principal amount of €1,275 million. We expect the New Revolving Credit Facility to be undrawn on the Issue Date. The New Senior Credit Facilities will be guaranteed by all of the Senior Secured Notes Guarantors on a senior basis, pari passu with the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees and senior to the Senior Notes Guarantees. The New Senior Credit Facilities will be secured by the Senior Secured Notes Collateral on a first-ranking basis, pari passu with the Senior Secured Notes. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—New Senior Credit Facilities Agreement” and “Summary Historical _Financial Information and Other Data—Summary Financial and Other Information—Summary Other Financial and Operating Data.”_ (5) On the Issue Date and subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will be guaranteed by the Issue Date Guarantors on a senior basis and senior subordinated basis, respectively. On the Issue Date, the Senior ----- Secured Notes will also be secured on a first priority basis by the Issue Date Senior Secured Notes Collateral and the Senior Notes will be secured on a first priority basis by an account pledge granted by the Senior Notes Issuer in respect of its material bank accounts and, on a second priority basis, by the Shared Notes Collateral. The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the security and the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations _and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests.” The security interests in favor of the_ Notes and the Note Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. (6) Within 180 days from (and excluding) the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially simultaneously with the guarantees granted in favor of obligations under the New Senior Credit Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes will be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors on a senior basis and senior subordinated basis, respectively. Within 180 days from (and excluding) the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and substantially simultaneously with the obligations under the New Senior Credit Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured by the Post-Closing Collateral. The Senior Secured Notes Collateral will also secure the New Senior Credit Facilities on a pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes. The Post-Closing Collateral includes, among other security, pledges over the shares of the Pledged Opcos. The Pledged Opcos do not provide a guarantee and the share pledge over such Pledged Opco does not constitute a debt obligation of the Pledged Opcos but rather a security interest in the shares of such entities and, upon enforcement, creditors could take control of the Pledged Opcos and sell the property and assets of such Pledged Opcos to satisfy their direct obligations and their indirect claims. As Noteholders are not direct creditors of the Pledged Opcos, the Noteholders’ claims are structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of any Pledged Opcos, including their obligations to trade creditors. The validity and enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the security and the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and _Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and Security Interests.” The security interests in favor of the_ Notes and the Note Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. For the year ended December 31, 2020, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Guarantors and the Pledged Opcos generated 54.3% of our consolidated EBITDA (and 33.8% excluding Pledged Opcos). As of December 31, 2020, our subsidiaries that will not guarantee the Notes had €7.4 million of indebtedness, excluding accrued interest, bank overdraft and deposits and guarantees received. (7) The Senior Notes Issuer as lender and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer as borrower may enter into a proceeds loan (the “Proceeds Loan”) for a principal amount equal to the principal amount of the Senior Notes on or about the Issue Date. -----

A Pledged Opco does not provide a guarantee and the share pledge over such Pledged Opco does not constitute a debt obligation of the Pledged Opco but rather a security interest in the shares of such entity and, upon enforcement, creditors could take control of the Pledged Opco and sell the property and assets of such Pledged Opco to satisfy its direct obligations and their indirect claims. As holders are not direct creditors of the Pledged Opco, the holder’s claims are structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of an Pledged Opco, including their obligations to trade creditors. On or around the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Note Guarantees thereof will be secured on a first priority basis by: - a share pledge granted by the Senior Notes Issuer in respect of shares held by it in the Senior Secured Notes Issuer; - an intercompany receivables pledge granted by the Senior Notes Issuer in respect of structural intercompany receivables owing to it by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer; - an intercompany receivables pledge granted by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer in respect of structural intercompany receivables owing to it by Foncia Holding; - an intercompany receivables pledge granted by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer in respect of structural intercompany receivables owing to it by Foncia Groupe; ----- - an account pledge granted by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer in respect of its material bank accounts; - a share pledge granted by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer in respect of shares held by it in Foncia Holding; and - a share pledge granted by Foncia Holding in respect of shares held by it in Foncia Groupe. (collectively, the “Issue Date Senior Secured Notes Collateral”). (collectively, “Post-Closing Collateral” and, together with the Issue Date Senior Secured Notes Collateral, the “Senior Secured Notes Collateral”). Senior Secured Notes ................. Prior to March 31, 2024, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will be entitled at its option to redeem all or a portion of the Senior Secured Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes, plus the applicable “make whole” premium described in this Offering Memorandum and accrued and unpaid interest, to, but excluding, the redemption date. On or after March 31, 2024, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will be entitled at its option to redeem all or a portion of the Senior Secured Notes at the applicable redemption prices set forth under the heading “Description of the Senior Secured _Notes—Optional Redemption,” plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the redemption date. Prior to March 31, 2024, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will be entitled at its option on one or more occasions to redeem no more than 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at the redemption price equal to 103.375% of the principal amount outstanding in respect of the Senior Secured Notes, provided that, inter alia, at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes (including the original principal amount of any additional Senior Secured Notes) remains outstanding. Prior to March 31, 2024, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes (including the original principal amount of any additional Senior Secured Notes issued) originally issued in each calendar year at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes so redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. Senior Notes ............................... Prior to March 31, 2024, the Senior Notes Issuer will be entitled at its option to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes, plus the applicable “make whole” premium described in this Offering Memorandum and accrued and unpaid interest, to, but excluding, the redemption date. On or after March 31, 2024, the Senior Notes Issuer will be entitled at its option to redeem all or a portion of the Senior Notes at the applicable redemption prices set forth under the heading “Description of the Senior _Notes—Optional Redemption” plus accrued and unpaid interest, to, but_ excluding, the redemption date. Prior to March 31, 2024, the Senior Notes Issuer will be entitled at its option to on one or more occasions to redeem no more than 40% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Senior Notes with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at the redemption price equal to 105.000%, provided that, inter alia, at least 50% of the original aggregate -----

principal amount of the Senior Notes (including the original principal amount of any additional Senior Notes) remains outstanding. In the event of certain developments affecting taxation which cause each Issuer to pay additional amounts, the relevant Issuer may redeem the relevant Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Redemption for Taxation _Reasons” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”_

Subsection Title: Change of Control .................... Upon the occurrence of certain events defined as constituting a change of
Subsubsection Text: control, each Issuer may be required to make an offer to repurchase all the outstanding Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest, to the date of purchase. A change of control will not be deemed to have occurred on one occasion if, pro forma for such change of control, certain consolidated total net leverage ratios calculated in accordance with the “Description of the _Senior Secured Notes” and “Description of the Senior Notes” are not_ exceeded as a result of such event. See “Description of the Senior Secured _Notes—Change of Control” and See “Description of the Senior Notes— Change of Control.”_ Tender Offers ...........................** In connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable series of outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the applicable Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuers or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes of such series that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of such Notes. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Optional Redemption” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Optional Redemption.”

Subsection Title: Certain Covenants ................... The Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Senior Notes Indenture,
Subsubsection Text: among other things, will restrict the ability of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Senior Notes Issuer, respectively, and their respective restricted subsidiaries, to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - create or incur certain liens; - make certain payments, including dividends or other distributions, with respect to the shares of each Issuer; - prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity; - make certain investments; - create encumbrances or restrictions on the payment of dividends or other distributions, loans or advances to and on the transfer of assets to each Issuer or its restricted subsidiaries; - sell, lease or transfer certain assets, including stock of restricted subsidiaries; ----- - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; - consolidate or merge with other entities; - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes; and - amend certain documents. Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain _Covenants” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants.”_ Transfer Restrictions ............... Subsection Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA Summary Financial and Other Information
Subsubsection Text: _The following tables present our summary consolidated financial information as of and for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018. The summary consolidated financial information as of and for each of the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 was derived from our Audited Financial Statements. An English language translation of our Audited Financial Statements as of and for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 is included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, together with a free English language translation of the audit reports thereon from our independent auditors, Deloitte & Associés and PricewaterhouseCoopers Audit. For a detailed description of the basis of presentation with respect to our historical financial information, see “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Data.” These Audited Financial Statements were prepared in accordance with IFRS as adopted by the European Union. We began applying IFRS 16 from January 1, 2019, using the modified retrospective approach, and our Audited Financial Statements for the year ended December 31, 2018 have not been restated and instead apply IAS 17 and interpretations issued by IFRIC and SIC. Certain other data, including as adjusted data included herein, are for information purposes only, and do not purport to present what our results of operations and financial condition would have been, nor do they project our results of operations for any future period or financial condition at any future date. In addition, while certain of the financial data set forth below have been derived on the basis of historical financial information prepared in accordance with IFRS, such financial data contains financial measures other than those in accordance with IFRS and should not be considered in isolation from or as substitutes for our historical financial information. Non-IFRS financial data has not been audited or reviewed by our auditors and should not be considered as an alternative to any measure of liquidity or performance derived in accordance with IFRS for the applicable periods. The summary consolidated financial and other information included below is not necessarily indicative of our future results of operations and should be read in conjunction with, and is qualified in its entirety by reference to, our Audited Financial Statements, including the notes thereto, an English language translation of which is included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. You should also read the tables below in conjunction with “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Data,” “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.”_

Subsubsection Title: Summary Consolidated Statement of Financial Position

Subsubsection Text: ----- (a) In the consolidated financial statements of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer for the year ended December 31, 2020, the consolidated statement of financial position as at December 31, 2019 and the consolidated income statement and cash flow statement for the year ended December 31, 2019 were restated to give effect to application of the definitive decision of the IFRS IC and subsequent position statement of the ANC on determining the lease terms of certain real estate leases. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of _Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Certain changes in accounting standards and accounting policies—2019 Restatement” and note 3.2 to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s_ audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020. (b) Data for 2018 has not been restated to reflect the impacts of the first-time application of IFRS 16. We began applying IFRS 16 from January 1, 2019, using the modified retrospective approach, i.e., with no restatement of comparative information. Under this approach, a liability is recognized at the transition date for the present value of any residual lease payments, against a right-of-use asset adjusted for the amount of any lease payments made at or before the lease commencement date. However, following additional analyses carried out in connection with the first-time application of IFRS 15 (related to revenue from contracts with customers), in the year ended December 31, 2019, we changed our accounting presentation of revenue arising from fees earned on deeds of sale. This led to the reclassification of the contracts to be classified as contracts where we act as agent, as opposed to contracts where we act as principal, as was previously the case, and the statement of profit and loss figures for the year ended December 31, 2018 have been restated accordingly and net profit (loss) from continuing operations attributable to non-controlling interests was adjusted to correct a minor presentation error. For further details see, “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Certain changes in accounting standards and accounting policies—2018 Restatement,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Results of Operations—Year ended December 31, 2019 compared to the year ended December 31, 2018” and note 2.7 to_ the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019.

Subsubsection Text: As adjusted senior secured debt[(7)] ........................................................ 1,675,000 – – As adjusted total debt[(8)] ........................................................................ 1,925,000 – – As adjusted total third party debt[(9)] ...................................................... 2,098,967 – – As adjusted total third party debt (including H1 Acquisition lease liabilities)[(10)] ...................................................................................... 2,107,967 – – As adjusted cash and cash equivalents[(11)]............................................. 51,664 As adjusted interest expense[(12)] ........................................................... 74,563 – – Ratio of as adjusted senior secured net debt to Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA ............................................................................. 5.1x – – Ratio of as adjusted total net debt to Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA ............................................................................................ 5.9x – – Ratio of as adjusted total third party net debt (including H1 Acquisition lease liabilities) to Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA ............................................................................................ 6.4x – – Ratio of Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA to as adjusted interest expense .............................................................................................. 4.3x – – (1) Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA is a non-IFRS measure. We define Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA as EBITDA adjusted for the IFRS-16 impact on leases at our French and international premises and includes IAS 17 adjustments for leasing for vehicles, copy machines and laptops, and also reflects the impact of certain asset disposals for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019. We adopted IFRS 16 on January 1, 2019. As a result, we experienced an increase in EBITDA of €40.2 million and €36.0 million for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively, due to rent costs no longer being incurred as operating expenses. Our EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2018 is already presented on a pre-IFRS-16 basis. We present Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA as additional information because we believe it is helpful to investors in facilitating comparability of our results across the periods presented and evaluating the performance of the underlying business. However, Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA is not a measure of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. (2) Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Margin and EBITDA Margin is calculated as Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA and EBITDA, respectively, divided by revenue for the relevant period. For the year ended December 31, 2019, for pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Margin, total revenue was adjusted for asset disposals. (3) EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA are non-IFRS measures. We define EBITDA as net profit before net loss from discontinued operations, Income tax expense, share of profit (loss) of equity-accounted companies, other financial income and expenses, net income from cash and cash equivalents, cost of gross debt, non-recurring operating income (expenses) and elimination of net additions to depreciation, amortization and impairment of assets. We define Adjusted EBITDA as EBITDA before asset disposal, completed acquisition, minority interest and COVID-19 impacts. We present EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA as additional information because we believe they are helpful to investors in highlighting trends and evaluating the performance of the underlying business. However, other companies may present EBITDA or Adjusted EBITDA differently than we do and therefore comparability may be limited. EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA are not measures of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to net profit as an indicator of our operating performance, profitability, liquidity or any other measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. The following table reconciles net profit (loss) for the period to EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA for the periods presented. -----
Net loss from discontinued operations ........................................ — — (1,601)

(a) Represents the estimated pro forma impact, relating to lost revenue, offset by a decrease in personnel and external charges, from the sale of Foncia Pierre Gestion, IPlus and Primalliance in the year ended December 31, 2019. (b) Represents the estimated pro forma impact of closed acquisitions during each of the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018. This adjustment corresponds to the estimated EBITDA of the target for the next 12 months, without double counting the results already included in the relevant period, based on its historical data. The number reflects the estimated impact of the churn and the full-year impact of the cost synergies linked to the integration in our operational model, which are calculated based on the historical churn and cost savings we have achieved with prior acquisitions. These figures are diligenced in connection with each acquisition and validated by our operational and regional teams who will integrate the target as part of their perimeter and track the performance against budgeted figures. Most of the acquisitions are integrated within three to six months and are then part of the organic perimeter of the Group. The types of synergies that are recognized in the first year following an acquisition, many of which are recognized on day one, typically include target management costs if they do not stay with the business, staff costs related to functions such as headquarters and accounting, advertising costs, non-recurring items such as recruitments fees and subcontracting, and accounting adjustments such as for taxes and leases, which we record below EBITDA. See “Risk Factors— _Risks Relating to the Senior Notes—The value of the Senior Notes Collateral securing the Senior Notes may not be sufficient to satisfy our obligations under the Senior Notes and such Senior Notes Collateral may be reduced or diluted under certain circumstances.”_ (c) Refers to our 50% owned subsidiary, Foncia Brette SA, which is consolidated in our Audited Financial Statements (without giving effect to intra-group transactions). (d) Our business has been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and related lockdowns. While our Joint Property Management and Lease Management businesses have been relatively resilient as our employees were able to service customers from a remote working environment; they did experience a slight fall in revenues due to impacts such as a reduction in transfer fees in Joint Property Management and disruptions with the postal service, which led to delays in sending invoices and receiving fees in Lease Management. We also experienced some offsetting effects such as government programs to supplement salaries for employees who were unable to work as well as a decrease in headquarter costs and performance bonuses. The following table presents the estimated impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on EBITDA across our businesses for the year ended December 31, 2020. For purposes of determining our Adjusted EBITDA, we have only included the €20.8 million estimated impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our recurring stock business lines as those are generally more stable and predictable. In addition, we also estimate that we experienced a €10.3 million impact on our Brokerage and Letting business lines, which are primarily non-recurring flow businesses. We calculated the adjustments by assessing our actual performance against our budgeted metrics for these business lines based on historic performance, while taking into account offsetting effects such as government programs and cost savings, as well as identifiable impacts unrelated to the COVID-19 pandemic. -----

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2020 Estimated COVID-19 Impact on Adjusted EBITDA (in thousands of euros)

Subsubsection Text: We have not adjusted our EBITDA for the impact of the Brokerage and Lettings business lines, which are our primarily non-recurring flow businesses. Our Brokerage business line was particularly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic during the first lockdown from March to May 2020. During this time, we were not able to recognize revenue due to the cessation of notary services, and the closure of our agencies and the limited ability for people to move led to a reduction in new transactions. As a result of the restrictions imposed during the second lockdown in France lasting approximately two months from October 30, 2020 (the “second lockdown”), the number of new transactions was impacted, but not as significantly, and notaries were allowed to work, which enabled us to recognize revenue during this period. The renting side of our Lease Management and Renting business is a transaction-based business that also experienced a decline in revenue when the French government largely prohibited people from moving to new properties during the initial lockdown and, to a lesser extent, during the second lockdown. Constatimmo, which performs diagnostic and inventory reviews, experienced a similar decrease in revenue as a result of fewer lettings and therefore fewer individuals requiring its services. For a more detailed description of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business, including the breakdown of lost revenue by business line, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key factors affecting _results of operations—COVID-19 pandemic impact on our business.”_ The above information and adjustments are based upon available information and assumptions that we believe to be reasonable. This information has not been audited, reviewed or verified by our statutory auditors in accordance with any generally accepted accounting standards and the resulting financial information, including our Adjusted EBITDA, are based on a number of assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties and subject to change. In particular, the adjustments take into account our estimated lost revenue as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic based on our internal budgets and historic performance. This information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial condition or results of operations in the absence of the COVID-19 pandemic for the periods presented, may not be comparable to our consolidated financial statements or the other financial information included in this offering memorandum and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA _Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them.”_ (4) Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA is a non-IFRS measure. We define Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA as Adjusted EBITDA after giving pro forma effect to the estimated impact of closed acquisitions in 2021, acquisitions with signed share purchase agreement expected to close in the first half of 2021, acquisitions under exclusivity expected to close in the first half of 2021, additional synergies from acquisitions (up to 18 months), capped transfer fees since June 1, 2020 and Agency of the Future / Millenium cost savings and efficiency gains. We present Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA as additional information because we believe it is helpful to investors in highlighting trends and evaluating the performance of the underlying business. However, other companies may present Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA differently than we do and therefore comparability may be limited. This information does not represent the results we would have achieved had each of the acquisitions or other transactions for which an adjustment is made occurred at the dates indicated. There is no assurance that items we have identified for adjustment as nonrecurring will not recur in the future or that similar items will not be incurred in the future. Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA is not a measure of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to net profit as an indicator of our operating performance, profitability, liquidity or any other measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. ----- The following table reconciles Adjusted EBITDA for the period to Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA for the period presented:

(a) Represents the pro forma EBITDA contributions of acquired entities that have closed in 2021, as if such acquisitions had closed at the beginning of the period. This adjustment corresponds to the estimated EBITDA of the target for the full year based on its historical data and includes the impact of estimated churn and the full-year impact of the cost synergies linked to each acquired company’s integration in our operational model, which are calculated based on the historical churn and cost savings we have achieved with prior acquisitions. These figures are diligenced in connection with each acquisition and validated by our operational and regional teams who integrate the target as part of their perimeter and track their performance against budgeted figures. Most of the acquisitions are integrated within three to six months and are then part of the organic perimeter of the Group. The types of cost synergies that are recognized in the first year following an acquisition, many of which are recognized on day one, typically include target management costs if they do not stay with the business, staff costs related to functions such as headquarters and accounting, advertising costs, non-recurring items such as recruitment fees and subcontracting and accounting adjustments such as taxes and leases, which we record below EBITDA. (b) Represents the pro forma impact of potential acquisitions where we have signed share purchase agreements and expect to close in the first half of 2021, as if such acquisitions had closed at the beginning of the period. This adjustment corresponds to the estimated EBITDA of the acquisition for the full year based on its historical data and includes the impact of the estimated churn and the full-year impact of the cost synergies linked to the integration in our operational model. These figures are calculated on the same basis as described in footnote (3)(a) above. (c) Represents the pro forma impact of potential acquisitions that we have under exclusivity arrangements and expect to close in the first half of 2021, as if such acquisitions had closed at the beginning of the period. This adjustment corresponds to the estimated EBITDA of the acquisition for the full year based on its historical data and includes the impact of the estimated churn and the full-year impact of the cost synergies linked to the integration in our operational model. These figures are calculated on the same basis as described in footnote (3)(a) above. Based on our M&A track record since 2016, we have a 95% success rate for closing an acquisition when we have a transaction under an exclusivity arrangement. However, there can be no guarantee that the same rate will materialize with respect to future acquisitions. For purposes of determining our Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, we have only included €7.1 million out of the €12.9 million estimated impact from the total number of acquisitions under exclusivity which are expected to close in the first half of 2021. (d) Represents additional further synergies and churn from acquisitions in the 12 to 18 months after the closing date, in addition to those already considered in pro forma EBITDA figures in the first 12 months. These synergies include cost synergies related to employee costs, rents, Millenium gains and other costs such as accounting, insurance, IT maintenance and legal costs, travel expenses and bank fees and revenue synergies related to, for example, insurance implementation, the GLI guarantee and crossselling opportunities between our different divisions. Our synergy estimates are based on a number of assumptions made in reliance on the information available to us relating to each individual acquisition and our judgments based on such information. The assumptions used in estimating synergies are inherently uncertain and are subject to significant business, economic and competitive risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those contained in the synergy benefit estimates. (e) Since June 1, 2020, transfer fees have been capped by the French government at €317 (excluding VAT) per transaction by the French government. We estimate this will decrease the average transfer fee by €80, which results in a yearly impact of a loss of €4.8 million on a full-year basis based on an estimated 60,000 transfer fee transactions. In order to offset this €4.8 million impact, we have set up initiatives to increase the penetration rate of DSP (“Pré Etat Daté”) services in our Joint Property Management business, which we estimate had a positive full-year impact of €2.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, which results in an overall impact of €2.1 million for the year. The adjustment of €875 thousand corresponds to the estimated negative impact of the decrease in transfer fees and gains from subsequent initiatives in first five months of 2020. (f) Represents the estimated gains from efficiencies from the Agency of the Future project by 2022, following the deployment of our new ERP system, Millenium. We are designing a new organizational model named Agency of the Future, which will be implemented following the roll-out of Millenium in 2022. As a result, we estimate gains, mainly related to (i) staff costs synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and back-office functions to front-office employees, an increase in productivity and reduction of time spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains resulting from the digitalization and automation of certain tasks previously done manually (such as collection of reminder fees or postal charges). We have quantified the impact of the plan by (i) identifying potential for productivity improvement, such as analyzing time spent by employees for their principal tasks in a select number of agencies and identifying potential for improved processes after implementing these projects, (ii) reinvesting and improving service quality by, for example, defining a goal for the joint property management and lease management business and the principal tasks of managers and assistants and quantifying the reinvestment necessary in specific roles in order to put this target organization in place and (iii) scaling of the network resulting from the options for improvement of processes and required reinvestment. For the year ended December 31, 2020, capital expenditures in connection with Millenium and Agency of the Future were €17 million. We anticipate capital expenditures of €19 million in the year ended ----- December 31, 2021 for the development and the deployment of Millenium. By the end of 2022, we estimate approximately €15 million in gains as a result of efficiencies due to Millenium and Agency of the Future, with approximately €20 million nonrecurring costs related to those gains. We believe that, we will experience additional gains in the following years, as a result of these projects. For more information, see “Business—Digital Transformation and IT Systems.” The above information and adjustments are based upon available information and assumptions that we believe to be reasonable. This information has not been audited. Any failure by us to successfully execute on our strategy to achieve for operational efficiency successfully could result in total costs and expenses that are greater than expected. For more information see, “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our _Business and Industry—Any failure by us to successfully execute on our strategy to achieve for operational efficiency successfully could result in total costs and expenses that are greater than expected.”_ (i) In evaluating Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, you should be aware that, as an analytical tool, it is subject to certain limitations. In particular, run-rate cost savings and synergies are unaudited and based on management estimates and assumptions (including the successful implementation of certain initiatives) and are forward looking in nature. We may not be able to achieve these cost savings and synergies in a timely manner or at all. As such, this information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties, including a wide variety of significant business, economic, and competitive risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in our estimates of cost savings and synergies. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial impact or results of these actions and initiatives for the periods presented and may not be comparable with our consolidated financial statements or the other financial information included in this Offering Memorandum, and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. If one or more of our underlying assumptions regarding these items proves to have been incorrect, these efforts could lead to substantially higher costs than planned and we may not be able to realize fully, or realize in the anticipated time frame, the estimated benefits from our cost-saving measures. This information does not represent the results we would have achieved had each of the acquisitions for which an adjustment is made occurred and been fully integrated at the beginning of the period. The EBITDA of each of the relevant acquired companies may not be representative of what the EBITDA of such entities would have been for the period, as the case may be, had the acquisitions for which an adjustment is made occurred and been fully integrated at the beginning of the period. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—The current outbreak of the novel coronavirus, or COVID-19, has caused severe disruptions in the global economy and financial markets which could adversely affect our business.”_ (5) Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA Margin is calculated Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, respectively, divided by Adjusted Revenue and Pro Forma M&A Adjusted Revenue, respectively, for the relevant period. This information has not been audited, reviewed or verified by our statutory auditors in accordance with any generally accepted accounting standards and the resulting financial information, including our Adjusted EBITDA, are based on a number of assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties and subject to change. In particular, the adjustments take into account our estimated lost revenue as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic based on our internal budgets and historic performance. This information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial condition or results of operations in the absence of the COVID-19 pandemic for the periods presented, may not be comparable to our consolidated financial statements or the other financial information included in this offering memorandum and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. The following summary of this Offering contains basic information about the Notes, the Note Guarantees and the Collateral. It is not intended to be complete and is subject to important limitations and exceptions. For additional information regarding the Notes, the Note Guarantees and the Intercreditor Agreement, including certain definitions of terms used in this summary, see “Description of the Senior Secured Notes,” “Description _of the Senior Notes” and “Description of Other Indebtedness—Intercreditor Agreement.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The success of our business is significantly related to general economic conditions and, accordingly, our business, operations and financial condition could be adversely affected by economic slowdowns, liquidity pressure, fiscal or political uncertainty and possible subsequent declines in property sales and leasing activities in one or more of the geographies or industry sectors that we serve.
Subsubsection Text: Periods of economic weakness or recession, rising interest rates, fiscal or political uncertainty, market volatility, declining employment levels, declining demand for residential or commercial real estate, falling real estate values, disruption to the global capital or credit markets or the public perception that any of these events may occur, may negatively affect the performance of our business.
