Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are the European leader in the residential real estate services (“RRES”) market, providing services to both individuals (“business-to-consumer” or “B2C”) and businesses (“business-to-business” or “B2B”), and have recently entered the commercial real estate services segment for B2B customers. In addition, we have established ourselves as a leader for real estate services in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg by delivering high quality, reliable and innovative products uniquely suited to the needs of our customers. We assist our residential and commercial customers at every stage of their property journey with competitive and comprehensive service offerings. We provide end-to-end assistance, from managing individual apartments and building areas jointly owned by apartment owners through our lease management and joint property management business lines, respectively, to providing renting, brokerage and digital and ancillary services such as insurance brokerage, technical diagnostic, and distribution and energy brokerage offerings through our other business lines. Our RRES business is the leader in France, operating under the Foncia brand through a network of approximately 134 and 131 branches dedicated to our RRES and Brokerage businesses, respectively, and 242 branches dedicated to both our RRES and Brokerage businesses, representing 84% of our revenue in France for the year ended December 31, 2020. We operate an additional 101 branches under various brands in Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our French RRES business, Brokerage business, ancillary services, Digital services, B2B services and international business generated 60%, 13%, 6%, 4%, 4% and 13% of our total revenue, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations, including the demand for rental properties and our Brokerage businesses, the ability of tenants to pay rent and the level of our costs and expenses, are impacted by economic trends and market conditions such as: - changes in interest and inflation rates, unemployment rates and the level of wages; - economic growth or decline; - demographics (population size, growth and composition of a residential property); - consumer confidence in the economy or the residential property market; - local or regional economic conditions in the markets we serve; - local and regional property inventory levels, the cost of land and land use restrictions; - credit market strength and the cost and availability of mortgage financing; ----- - mortgage underwriting standards or down payment requirements; - levels of foreclosure activity in the French, German, Swiss and Belgian markets, home ownership rates and consumer preferences; - political uncertainty or other geopolitical developments, pandemics or natural disasters; - global pandemics or natural disasters disrupting day-to-day operations and activities; and - man-made disasters that disrupt local or regional markets that we serve. These factors combined with the cyclical nature of the residential property market impact supply and demand, which in turn impact, among other things, residential property prices, Brokerage business commissions and the volume of Brokerage transactions. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and _Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Macroeconomic and market conditions.”_ We believe the diversified nature of our services between recurring and transaction-based activities, our geographic coverage including nationwide presence in France and certain other geographies and the scale of our business have provided some insulation from economic cycles and resiliency to negative market conditions. We classify our revenues as either “stock” (recurring) or “flow” (transaction-tied). Within each business line, there may be stock and flow components based on the various types of revenue streams. Our stock businesses consist of recurring revenues, which by their nature provide better long-term visibility and are less sensitive to the volume of housing transactions and economic cycles. Stock revenue generation is primarily composed of, in both residential and B2B businesses, our Joint Property Management fixed fee, Lease Management fee, including fees on collected rents and insurance broker fees and fees unique to our business such as our rent payment guarantee (“Garantie de loyers impayés” or “rent payment guarantee”) which we offered on 66% of our residential dwellings in France for the year ended December 31, 2020. For more information on our rent payment fees, see “—Rent payment and occupancy guarantees.” Our Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Renting businesses are examples of largely stock businesses producing a high share of recurring revenues. Notwithstanding the stability, stock businesses retain some sensitivity to changing economic or market conditions. For example, higher unemployment rates or potential decreases in wages or salaries may affect the average income of tenants or reduce their ability to pay rent and, if tenants do not make rental payments, we are unable to collect our fees which are taken by automatic deduction from rental payments. In addition, if tenants are unable to pay their rent, this could impact the property owner’s (i.e., our customers) ability to pay certain other fees and this non-payment could obligate us to make payments to the property owner under our rent payment guarantees. Where we have offered our rent payment guarantee, we bear the cost if a tenant fails to make a timely rent payment and these advances are not always recoverable. Our business model, however, aims to balance both stock and flow businesses to mitigate the impact of changing market conditions with a stable mix revenue derived from stock and flow businesses. In the year ended December 31, 2020, 62% of our revenue derived from stock businesses. Flow activities are those for which we charge transactional fees that are not automatically recurring, and are thus more dependent on the external factors listed above. Our Brokerage business is an example of a largely flow business where we only receive a fee upon the closure of a transaction and, therefore, it faces greater exposure to economic fluctuations than our stock businesses. Brokerage fees are limited to our real estate sales transactions. Other examples of flow activities include revenue generation composed of, for example, letting fees, Constatimmo (our technical due diligence and inventories services unit) activities related to brokerage and letting, some Joint Property Management variable fees, such as transfer fees, reminder fees and maintenance and repair commissions on third-party invoices. We generated 87% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020 in France. Although we operate nationwide in France and therefore benefit from diversification across a range of real estate services markets, we are particularly sensitive to the economic conditions and developments in France as well as potential regulatory changes, economic shocks, or social upheaval, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. See “—Compliance with laws and regulations.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We have historically expanded our operations through prudent, mostly small bolt-on acquisitions of contracts or businesses with properties under management. The real estate services market, particularly in France, is highly fragmented, providing opportunities to add scale, market presence and revenues by acquiring businesses, ----- centralizing costs and operating as part of our diversified portfolio. These acquisitions have been a driver of the growth in our geographic scale, breadth of offerings, revenue and profit margins. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we completed 61 acquisitions in both our primary French market and in our other geographies, representing approximately 60,000 new Lease Management dwellings (bringing our total to approximately 330,005) and approximately 171,000 new Joint Property Management dwellings (bringing our total to approximately 1,463,402) and approximately €111.0 million of acquired revenues. In addition, as part of our overall growth strategy, we proactively manage the composition of our portfolio. We take measures to increase efficiencies and profit and cash flows which include focusing on our RRES business offerings and occasionally disposing of certain assets that are less profitable. For more information on our business lines, see “Business—Overview.” Our results of operations are affected by the number of locations where we provide services and the geographies and market conditions in which those sites are located. As a result, our results for future periods may not be directly comparable to past periods because of the large volume of acquisition activity that we have undertaken. The following table reflects the number of properties we managed in our RRES lines for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our performance and results of operations have been, and will continue to be, affected by a number of factors, including external factors. Certain of these key factors that have had, or may have, an effect on our results are set forth below. For further discussion of the factors affecting our results of operations, see “Risk Factors.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Total Number of Properties RRES Lines** **2020** **2019** **2018
Subsubsection Text: We offer rent payment guarantees (“Garantie de loyers impayés” or “rent payment guarantee”) on individual dwellings to certain residential landlords in France for whom we provide property management services. We bear the cost of any unpaid rent and advance such rent to landlords. These advances are not always recoverable from the lessee and therefore represent a risk of non-recovery. However, due to our diligent selection and recovery processes as described below, we believe these rental guarantees offer an attractive business model and by underwriting these guarantees on our balance sheet, we believe we offer a differentiating and competitive service to customers that smaller players would not be able to deliver. Rent payment guarantees are incidental to the property management contracts and, while a tenant remains in the property, we account for the related payments as follows: - the rent guarantee related fees are recorded continuously in income over the period of the mandate, since they are deducted from rents in the same way as basic property management fees; and - when a tenant fails to make their rent payment and after they have vacated the property, we record a provision on our balance sheet that is calculated in accordance with IAS 37 to account for the loss. The amount of the provision we set aside increases in line with the age of the unpaid receivable. Provisions for rent payment guarantees are calculated by reference to late payments relating to current and former lessees, regardless of whether or not lessee statement of accounts (“Arrêtés des Comptes Locataires” or “ACL”) have been drawn up, taking into account the probability of collection (assessed on a statistical basis and regularly updated). From a cash flow perspective, we pay rent to the landlord when rent is due, regardless of whether rent is received from the tenant, and will take remedial measures to try to recover the payment from the tenant. Once a tenant leaves the property, we record for the direct loss. We also offer an occupancy guarantee (“Garantie d’occupation” or “occupancy guarantee”) to a small number of lessors to protect against vacant properties for up to six months if we are unable to find a tenant on selected apartments in new buildings. We typically only offer this occupancy guarantee in limited circumstances for highly desirable properties where we believe there is a low risk of loss. The provision for occupancy guarantees is calculated on a statistical basis by reference to the probable residual vacant period for properties currently vacant and subject to occupancy guarantees. The provision is estimated based on the firm’s average monthly rent. The maximum term of claims is 180 days. In December 2020, on average, 66% of our residential dwellings in France were covered by the rent payment guarantee and 12% of residential dwellings were covered by the occupancy guarantee. We believe we have a strong ability to assess credit risk when offering these guarantees and we undertake a detailed process to select eligible tenants and dwellings. We refer to the new, unpaid rents as a result of defaults under a guarantee each month as our new monthly aggregate of unpaid rent and the total sum of unpaid rents per month as our cumulative aggregate of unpaid rent. In December 2020, €124.7 million of rent revenues were covered by the rent payment guarantee, for which we experienced €3.5 million new unpaid rent (compared to a 2020 monthly average of new unpaid rent of €3.3 million) and the cumulative aggregate of unpaid rent was €27.7 million, including outstanding rent payments from previous years. ----- The chart below sets out unpaid rents (in EUR millions) for tenants who remained in their flat versus tenants who moved out of their flat from September 2019 to December 2020, under our rent payment guarantee: During the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, the cumulative aggregate of unpaid rent increased temporarily as it built up when we were unable to process disputes and evictions as a result of the initial lockdown restrictions in France, but we did not experience a significant increase in the overall amounts of new unpaid rent or defaults. The cumulative aggregate of unpaid rent also typically increases during the winter, from the first of November to the end of March, when we are prohibited from evicting people under French law. See “Regulation— _France—Eviction Laws and the Winter Truce—Winter Truce.” The below chart reflects this increase of the_ cumulative aggregate amount of unpaid rents (in EUR millions) for tenants who remained in their flat, under our rent payment guarantee, that temporarily increased during the COVID-19 pandemic: We take proactive measures to insulate our business from losses under both the rent payment guarantee and occupancy guarantee including through the stringent credit assessment that we undertake before providing these guarantees and our unpaid rental collection processes. Following an eviction and the transfer of the surrogative discharge from the landlord to us, we have a strong team that seeks to recover the unpaid rent from the defaulting tenant, including by legal means. We have historically recovered approximately 35% of the unpaid rent amount over the last three years, which is added to our statement of profit and loss as revenue. Therefore, given the regulatory regime that restricts when we can evict a tenant and the time it takes to collect unpaid rent, the risk associated with the guarantees has historically been related to the timing of cash flows, rather than lost revenue. However, any unrecoverable payments under these guarantees could result in a significant loss or have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. See “Risk Factors—Risks _Relating to Our Business and Industry—Low demand for housing generally or lease terminations and/or tenant defaults could adversely affect our fees and the income produced by the properties we manage, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.”_ -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Total Number of Properties RRES Lines** **2020** **2019** **2018
Subsubsection Title: COVID-19 pandemic impact on our business
Subsubsection Text: The global spread of the COVID-19 pandemic has continued to cause significant volatility, uncertainty and economic disruption. In order to comply with government-imposed social distancing recommendations, all of our premises (branches and head offices) were closed to the public during the initial lockdown (from mid-March to mid-May 2020 in France), as well as to employees, barring exceptional cases. We were most acutely impacted during this initial lockdown. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, we experienced direct impacts in the year ended December 31, 2020 on revenue, margins and operating cash flow, particularly related to the Brokerage business and, to a lesser extent, to the Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Renting businesses, and our other businesses as described below. Moreover, we typically recognize revenue in our Brokerage business up to three months following the closing of a transaction. Therefore, although our Brokerage business experienced an estimated impact from the second lockdown in the year ended December 31, 2020, the full impact is not expected to be reflected in our financial statements until 2021. _Consequences of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic_ The general lockdown measures imposed by the governments in the jurisdictions in which we operate effectively froze the property market from the middle of March to May 2020. In order to protect our workforce and maintain the continuity of our operations, we implemented preventative measures including allowing employees to work from home, permitting short-term working arrangements and providing exceptional travel certificates to certain employees to carry out minimum duties. See “—Business continuity plan.” These costs were all accounted as non-recurring operating income (expenses) due to their exceptional nature. Partially due to the success of the measures we have implemented, we believe we have been able to manage our operations and employee absenteeism, with minimal disruption. As the countries in which we operate progress through varying levels of restrictions and until activity resumes to normalized levels, we will continue to be impacted. The ultimate impact of the COVID-19 pandemic will depend on the severity and duration of the pandemic and the actions taken by governmental authorities and other third parties in response, each of which is uncertain, rapidly changing and difficult to predict. The following table sets forth an estimated breakdown of the full COVID-19 impact on our revenue and EBITDA for each of our businesses for the year ended December 31, 2020:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Total Number of Properties RRES Lines** **2020** **2019** **2018
Subsubsection Text: Joint Property Management - Dwellings under management (France) .......................................................................................... 1,463,402 1,394,206 1,287,611 Lease Management - Dwellings under management (France) ........... 330,005 326,154 311,888 Lettings - Number of lettings (France) .............................................. 59,288 64,341 64,976 We continually evaluate opportunities for acquisitions to improve market positions within our existing markets or potentially to enter into new markets. We have a strong M&A team, with a disciplined approach that is dedicated to identifying, diligencing, completing and integrating opportunistic acquisitions in our four geographical regions. We are likely to continue to undertake expansion projects in the future to support geographic growth and profitability and improve the breadth and quality of our service offerings. The number of acquisitions we undertake depends on the quality and pricing of potential targets available for purchase at a given time. Additionally, a key point of focus during our due diligence on a potential target, and the primary reason we decline to pursue a target after entering into a letter of intent, is the quality of their customer accounting. By law, we are required to have separate accounts for our Joint Property Management customers and if a target has poor customer accounting policies, it could lead to difficulties collecting customer balances, complying with applicable law or integrating such target’s systems into our own. The price paid for a particular acquisition depends in part on the target entity’s revenues and cost base, along with competition to acquire the business. Our results of operations are therefore impacted by the quality of our due diligence, as well as by our success in integrating any acquired businesses into ours and extracting synergies, gains and cost savings from such acquisitions. Following an acquisition, we integrate the companies into our existing group structure and consolidate all administrative functions, such as payroll, human resources, IT, procurement, sales and marketing, finance and treasury and other support functions, with our central headquarters. Acquisitions we complete may also lead to improved margins and customer retention through, among other measures, the offering of ancillary services to an expanding customer base in a wider geographic network and the leveraging of our scale to procure additional premium partnerships and favorable pricing terms in our utility contracts for our customers. These initiatives have contributed to the successful integration of the acquisitions that we have made and the realization of synergies from such acquisitions. As a result of integrating the acquired business into our existing business, we may also experience an increase in one-off costs such as IT and other integration costs, accounting costs, severance costs, real estate lease agreements termination penalties, potential retention bonuses for key employees, cost related to the rebranding or other expenditures. Therefore our results for the period during which an acquisition takes place may be affected by the inclusion of the results of the acquired business in our consolidated results from the date of their combination or acquisition. We have a track record of implementing a majority of synergies immediately following the acquisition and are able to quickly realize the impact of the synergies, gains and costs savings from the acquisition. However, it may take up to 18 months to realize our expected costs and efficiency gains for an acquired business. See “Summary Historical Financial Information _and Other Data—Summary Financial and Other Information—Summary Other Financial and Operating Data.”_ -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As a provider of residential and commercial real estate services, we are subject to a wide range of laws and regulations in each of the countries in which we operate, as well as the regulations of the European Union. We are subject to laws and regulations including those related to rental access and urban planning, rents we can charge, data protection, tax reduction schemes for rental property investors and reforms to housing, planning and digital technology. For example, the French government has introduced measures to protect individuals buying or renting an apartment within a professionally managed co-ownership building. The Access to Housing and Urban Renovation Law (“ALUR”), which was introduced in March 2014, imposed restrictions on the fees agents can charge for selling or letting property and required two dedicated bank accounts for each jointly owned property, thereby resulting in loss of interest income on customer accounts and a large administrative burden. The ALUR law also required a significant amount of extra documentation before the pre-contract (compromis de vente) can be signed, which increased the time between the initial offer and closing and thereby delaying our revenue recognition. In addition, it required publication of commissions when payable by the buyer and any resulting competition from low cost agents. Notwithstanding these requirements, we have experienced certain positive impacts from the imposition of the ALUR law. For example, it required landlords to register their buildings, which became a new fee-based service we began providing. Changes in, and compliance with, such laws and regulations may entail significant costs for us and can have an impact on our results of operations. For a description of certain material regulations applicable to our business, see “Regulation.” Failure to comply with applicable laws, regulations or rules, whether identified as a result of an investigation or otherwise, could lead to adverse publicity, harm our reputation or divert management time and other resources. In addition, non-compliance could result in disciplinary action, imposition of fines, the revocation of a license or authorization or the need to take remedial action. In particular, the loss of a license or authorization could mean that we are no longer able to carry out the business or activity for which we were previously authorized or licensed and any remedial action that may need to be undertaken could result in a significant cost. Finally, such laws, rules and regulations may subject us to more onerous conduct of business and administrative requirements, limit the types of fees or services we can charge and provide or otherwise alter the current regulatory or tax environment, each of which can have a significant impact on the manner in which we conduct our businesses. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our businesses, financial condition, results _of operations and prospects could be adversely affected by new laws or regulations or by changes in existing laws or regulations or the application thereof. If we fail to comply with laws and regulations applicable to us, or make incorrect determinations in complex tax regimes, we may incur significant financial penalties.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to actively manage our cost base by cost saving initiatives and enhancing operational efficiencies has been a significant factor affecting our results of operations and financial condition in the period under review. Our principal costs include staff costs and marketing and IT costs. For the year ended December 31, 2020, staff costs accounted for 55.9% of revenue. Our business (excluding brokerage activities) has a largely fixed cost base. Our fixed costs, which do not fluctuate with business volumes, consist primarily of salaries and wages (excluding variable commissions, employee profit shares and bonus arrangements), rental costs, most of our information technology (“IT”) costs, as well as other general costs. Our Brokerage business, which is more exposed to real estate services market cycles in which our employees are paid based on commission, operates primarily with variable costs, with approximately 26% of fixed costs for the year ended December 31, 2020. Since variable costs tend to fluctuate with business volumes, we will need to react quickly in the future by decreasing such costs if we forecast a potential downturn in business volumes or increase in such costs as the market recovers. The management of our cost base is an important factor impacting our results of operations and cash flow. We are able to initiate cost cutting measures when required, such as using temporary employees and limiting travel, entertainment and office expenses and reducing variable compensation. In addition, our management team sponsors a number of initiatives to improve efficiency and reduce fixed costs. For example, we launched a pilot version of Millenium, our new enterprise resource planning (“ERP”) system in March 2020 at one of our branches in France, and we expect for it to be completed at the end of 2021 or early 2022. We have invested significant resources in Millenium including a team of 80 developers and specialized professionals in order to build this innovative and advanced real estate platform. Our financial condition and results of operations are impacted by our ability to successfully implement Millenium and other initiatives to improve our operational performance. We believe that the improved standardization and digitization Millenium offers, will allow us to reduce administrative inefficiencies and achieve greater productivity. In parallel to the deployment of Millenium, we have been designing a new organizational model called Agency of the Future ----- which will be implemented following the roll-out of Millenium. Our vision for Agency of the Future sets out four key goals (i) industrialize tasks with low added value; (ii) distinguish ourselves thanks to our expertise in joint property management and rental management; (iii) have close proximity to our clients; (iv) reinforce our attractiveness for staff. As a result of this new organization model, we expect to generate significant cost and efficiency gains mainly related to (i) staff costs synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and back-office functions to front-office employees and an increase in productivity and significant reduction of time spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains resulting from the digitization and automation of certain tasks previously done manually (such as reminder fees or the collection of postal charges). We believe Millenium and Agency of the Future will enable us to achieve greater organization among our businesses allowing our employees to focus on customer satisfaction with the potential to lead to improved customer retention. In the coming years, we plan to fully digitize all business of our businesses, internal processes and our customer relationship management with Millenium. For the year ended December 31, 2020, capital expenditures in connection with Millenium and Agency of the Future were €17 million. We anticipate capital expenditures of €19 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 for the development and the deployment of Millenium. By the end of 2022, we estimate approximately €15 million in saving and gains as a result of efficiencies due to Millenium and Agency of the Future, with approximately €20 million non-recurring costs related to those gains. We believe that, we will experience additional gains in the following years, as a result of these projects. For more information, see “Business—Digital Transformation and IT Systems.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: For purposes of determining our Adjusted EBITDA, we have only included €20.8 million that represents the estimated impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our stock (recurring) business lines as those are generally more stable and predictable. Similarly, for the purposes of determining our Pro Forma Revenues, we have included €32.4 million that represents the estimated impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our stock (recurring) business lines. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Summary Financial and Other _Information—Summary Other Financial and Operating Data—Other financial data.” For purposes of_ determining our Adjusted EBITDA, we have excluded the €10.3 million estimated impact on our Brokerage and Letting business lines, which are primarily non-recurring flow businesses. Similarly, for the purposes of determining our Pro Forma Revenues, we have excluded the €18.7 million estimated impact on our Brokerage and Letting business lines. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We present _information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them.” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—The current outbreak of the novel coronavirus, or COVID-19, has_ ----- _caused severe disruptions in the global economy and financial markets which could adversely affect our business.”_ The renting side of our Lease Management and Renting business is a transaction-based business in which our fee is recognized upon the entry of the new tenant in the dwelling. The French government largely prohibited people from moving to new properties during the initial lockdown which impacted our ability to generate revenue during that period. Our Lease Management business continued to mostly function normally from an administrative perspective, but disruptions to the postal service did lead to delays in delivering customer invoices and receiving customer checks by mail. As the COVID-19 pandemic continues, there is also a risk, particularly in our commercial Lease Management business, that fees on unpaid rent will be difficult to collect on the scheduled timetable or at all. Commercial customers from our Lease Management business represent 5% of our Lease Management dwellings. Certain of our customers negotiated for, and we agreed to, a rent holiday or reduced rental payments for a fixed period after the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite some lost revenue, we believe these negotiations were more advantageous than initiating eviction proceedings and finding a new tenant in this market in the event a customer missed a rental payment. The collection of fees and rent from our residential Lease Management customers was also partially impacted in certain regions such as Marseille as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Our Brokerage business was virtually at a standstill during the initial lockdown beginning in March 2020 since we do not recognize revenue until after finalizing a transaction and physical visits of properties were not possible during this period. In addition, during this lockdown, real estate agents were not able to travel to sign mandates or make visits, and notaries were closed through May 2020. The cessation of notary services and prohibition on visits in particular resulted in limited production and revenue recognition during this lockdown. During the government lockdowns that followed, notaries were permitted to work and although in-person property viewings for customers remained limited or prohibited, real estate professionals were allowed to show properties via video chat. Therefore, while we were able to close transactions in the second lockdown which took place from October 30 to November 28, 2020, the ongoing lockdown restrictions had some impact on our revenue. Since the French government has determined that notaries can work through lockdown measures, it is unlikely we will experience a period of zero production in the future. However, the COVID-19 pandemic is rapidly changing as well as actions taken by governmental authorities and other third parties in response, and thus we cannot predict the impact it may have on our business, financial condition and results of our operations. Our Joint Property Management business was relatively resilient with minor impact to revenue as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic because our employees continued operations from a remote working environment in which they were able to successfully service customers. In addition, Joint Property Management business experienced a fall in revenue from incidental fees such as transfer fees since people were not moving as frequently, and fees for additional services. Joint property owners pay these additional fees as commission for a specific service they request for additional works. These fees are typically approved at the general assembly meetings of joint property owners, which were often delayed when in-person meetings were banned as a result of lockdown measures. However, these general assembly meetings are now primarily held online and the incurrence of these incidental fees has resumed. Our other businesses were impacted to varying degrees as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, Lodgis, our platform for letting furnished apartments, which largely targets temporary residents such as international students and professionals, experienced a large drop in revenue as a result of a significant decrease in the number of expatriate students and professionals moving to the countries in which we operate. For more information on Lodgis, see “Business—Overview.” Revenue for Constatimmo, which prepares diagnostic and inventory reviews before a tenant enters an apartment, is largely linked to the brokerage and renting market cycles so it experienced a similar decrease in revenue as a result of fewer lettings that require such review. For more information on Constatimmo, see “Business—Overview.” Through our Assurimo business, we offer specialized property insurance to joint property owners. The general assemblies of the joint property owners in France are typically key events at which we engage with these customers and market and contract for these insurance products. When lockdown restrictions largely prohibited in-person meetings and many of these events were postponed from March to May 2020, we experienced an initial drop in revenue in this business line, but it rebounded later in the year. Esset, our B2B business which comprises all lines of business with commercial and institutional customers, did not experience a significant ----- impact. However, revenue did decrease initially when we were not able to carry out renovation work in France due to lockdown restrictions in March 2020. Revenue for our Swiss and Belgian businesses experienced similar trends as those in France. Germany was less impacted than the other jurisdictions in which we operate, but also broadly followed analogous trends. Our resilience during the COVID-19 pandemic has been in part due to the initiatives implemented by our leadership team which included utilizing government assistance programs in France and Switzerland to supplement salaries for furloughed employees who were unable to work and implementing cost-saving measures such as reducing the number of contracts dedicated to individual properties and hiring temporary employees. Our business Efficity also received a cash loan with a state guarantee in the amount of €1.4 million for a period of one year. This loan was repaid in December 2020. In addition, unplanned cost-savings benefits were achieved as employee travel costs were eliminated due to travel restrictions imposed by the governments across all countries in which we operate and bonuses, which are linked to employee performance, were lower than budgeted. _The above information and adjustments are based upon available information and assumptions that we believe to be reasonable. This information has not been audited, reviewed or verified by our statutory auditors in accordance with any generally accepted accounting standards and the resulting financial information, including our Adjusted EBITDA, are based on a number of assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties and subject to change. In particular, the adjustments take into account our estimated lost revenue as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic based on our internal budgets and historic performance. This information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial condition or results of operations in the absence of the COVID-19 pandemic for the periods presented, may not be comparable to our consolidated financial statements or the other financial information included in this offering memorandum and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them.” Business continuity plan_ We implemented different procedures in order to address this unprecedented situation which were designed to protect the health of our employees but also to ensure that a minimum and critical level of business can continue. These procedures included: - Work from home for all employees whose work can be performed from home and who had the necessary tools available. - In RRES and our Brokerage businesses, an exceptional travel certificate was granted to managers so that they could carry out minimum duties alongside senior executives. An exceptional, occasional travel certificate subject to restrictions was issued to critical employees dealing, for example, with incoming correspondence, cash inflows and payments and handovers. - For employees facing increasingly difficult working conditions such as lettings negotiators, developers or real estate consultants, short-time working arrangements were put in place. We designed organizational and communication guidelines for businesses in order to optimize our organization during these exceptional circumstances using various procedures. We believe we were able to quickly adapt to the changing circumstances presented by teleworking and the COVID-19 pandemic without significant additional costs as a result of investments in IT and digitalization that we had undertaken in the past. As a precautionary measure, on March 19 and 24, 2020 we drew an aggregate amount of €190 million under our Existing Revolving Credit Facility to ensure liquidity as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic but have subsequently repaid such amounts. For more information regarding the impact the COVID-19 pandemic had on our business for the one month ended January 31, 2021, see “Summary—Recent Developments—Current _Trading.”_ -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Certain changes in accounting standards and accounting policies
Subsubsection Text: _IFRS-16_ On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16 (Leases), and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 on November 9, 2017, which has had a substantial impact on the financial statements of lessees of property and high value equipment – requiring that leases be placed on-balance sheet by recognizing a ‘right-of-use’ asset representing its right to use the underlying leased asset and a lease liability representing its obligation to make lease payments. In the income statement, this standard application results in an amortization and interest expenses recognition. These changes become effective from January 1, 2019. IFRS 16 has a substantial impact on the financial statements of lessees of property and high-value equipment, requiring that leases be placed on balance sheet by recognizing a “right-of-use” asset, representing the lessee’s right to use the underlying leased asset, and a lease liability, representing the lessee’s obligation to make lease payments. In the income statement, the application of this standard results in amortization and recognition of interest expense. The changes resulting from IFRS 16 became effective as from January 1, 2019. In accordance with IAS 8, we applied IFRS 16 using the modified retrospective approach in the consolidated financial statements of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019, with no restatement of comparative information for 2018. As a result, the financial information presented in this offering memorandum as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 does not give effect to the application of IFRS 16. In 2020, in light of the changes in lease accounting under IFRS 16, we initiated a strategic project aimed at reexamining (and if necessary re-estimating) the terms of lease arrangements. As a result of this change, the duration taken into account for the valuation of leases in France that were to be tacitly renewed was revised to be increased to three years, which can be explained by the imperatives in terms of continuity of the operations, which encourage the continuation of the initial lease, and our strategy based on external growth. _2019 Restatement_ In the consolidated financial statements of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer for the year ended December 31, 2020, the consolidated statement of financial position as at December 31, 2019 and the consolidated income statement and cash flow statement for the year ended December 31, 2019 were restated to give effect to application of the definitive decision of the IFRS IC and subsequent position statement of the ANC on determining the lease terms of certain real estate leases. This decision of the IFRS IC included interpretation guidelines for the determination of a lease term, in particular with regard to French commercial leases. ----- It includes a reminder that the lease term that when evaluating the debt associated with the lease is the period for which it is enforceable, a lease no longer being enforceable when the lessee and the lessor each has the right to terminate the lease without permission from the other party with no more than an insignificant penalty. It also provides a clarification that in order to determine how long a lease is enforceable and whether a penalty is insignificant under IFRS 16.B34, it is necessary to take into consideration the broader economics of the contract and not just contractual termination payments. The notion of a penalty thus must include any economic incentive to not terminate the contract. In its decision, the IFRS IC also noted the need for consistency between the lease term for a lease for the determination of the debt associated with the lease and the useful life of related non-removable leasehold improvements. Moreover, the French accounting standards setter (the Autorité des Normes Comptables or the “ANC”) published on July 3, 2020 a new position statement related to the determination of the lease terms of commercial leases known as “3-6-9 leases” (known as such because such leases are signed for at least nine years, with unilateral termination possible by the tenant after three or six years). This new position statement replaced a prior position statement dated February 16, 2018. In particular, in this update, the ANC concluded that the lease term should reflect the term for which the tenant is reasonably certain to continue the lease and that, when the legal length of the lease is nine years, this length is “generally nine years at the outset.” In 2020, we initiated a strategic project to re-examine (and, if necessary, re-estimate) the lease terms of our real property leases in light of the decision of the IFRS IC and the updated position statement of the ANC. As a result of the completion of this project, the lease term that was taken into account for the evaluation of real property leases in France that were to be tacitly renewed was revised upward to three years, based on imperatives in terms of continuity of operations, which encourage the continuation of the initial lease, and our particularly active and opportunistic real property strategy for the rationalization of our real property (including in particular as a result of several restructurings due to our external growth). We had previously applied nine months as a lease term in our 2019 financial statements when first applying IFRS 16 at January 1, 2019 (based on the soonest possible surrender date, taking into account a legally required six-month notice period after the end of the first quarter in the calendar year) and six months at December 31, 2019. In accordance with IAS 8, the impacts related to these changes in lease terms and that directly result of the application of the IFRS IC decision have been accounted for using the retrospective method. See note 3.2 to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020. We refer to the restatements described above as the “2019 Restatement.” For ease of comparative review, we present financial data reflecting the 2019 Restatement when comparing information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019 with information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020. _2018 Restatement_ In 2019, following additional analyses carried out in connection with the application of IFRS 15, initially adopted in 2018, we changed our income statement presentation of revenue arising from fees earned on deeds of sale. This led to a separate classification of revenue from contracts where we act as agent, as opposed to in aggregate with revenue from contracts where we act as principal as was previously the case. Furthermore, revenue from contracts where we act as agent is now presented net of the cost of fees in accordance with IFRS 15. Since this does not allow a meaningful comparison of consolidated revenue (and the related external charges) between the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2018, the statement of profit and loss figures for the year ended December 31, 2018 has been restated accordingly, leading to a negative impact of €14.9 million on revenue as presented and a similar positive impact on “Purchases consumed and external charges.” This change in presentation has no impact on recurring operating profit for 2018. In addition, net profit (loss) from continuing operations attributable to non-controlling interests was adjusted to correct a minor presentation error. See note 2.7 to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019. We refer to the restatements described above as the “2018 Restatement.” For ease of comparative review, we present financial data reflecting the 2018 Restatement when comparing information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2018 with information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2019. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The timing of acquisitions and disposals may impact the comparability of our results on a year-over-year basis. Our results include incremental revenues and expenses following the completion date of an acquisition. In addition, there is generally an initial adverse impact on net income from an acquisition as a result of preacquisition due diligence expenditures, transaction/deal costs and post-acquisition integration costs, such as fees from third-party advisors engaged to assist with onboarding and process alignment, retention and severance expense, early lease termination costs, and other integration expenses. We have historically used strategic and bolt-on acquisitions to increase our scale within existing capabilities and to expand our presence in new or existing geographic regions globally. We believe that strategic acquisitions will increase revenue, provide cost synergies and generate incremental income in the long term. _Recent Developments_ On December 31, 2020, we completed our acquisition of Loft-One, one of the largest property administration companies in the Southwest of France. We paid a temporary purchase price of €27.7 million, and we acquired 14,062 properties in rental management and 38,734 in condominium management. We believe that through this acquisition, we are emerging as the leader in the local market. On December 11, 2020, we completed our acquisition of OP Property Management (Office des Propriétaires), a management property company based in Brussels. We paid a total purchase price of €14.5 million, and we acquired four branches. We believe that this acquisition will further our goal of becoming a leader for real estate services in Belgium. Due to timing of these two acquisitions, we have not consolidated the results into our consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2020. However, our payment for this acquisition is reflected in our cash flow statement and their acquisition value appears as non-consolidated securities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We use certain key performance indicators, such as the number of dwellings under management, average revenue per dwelling, average tenant invoice per dwelling, number of lettings, letting fees per letting and number of sales, which in our view provide alternative measures with which to monitor our economic, financial and operating performance. For additional details on our key performance indicators, see “Summary Historical _Financial Information and Other Data—Summary Financial and Other Information—Summary Other Financial and Operating Data.” These measures are not indicative of historical operating results, nor are they meant to be_ predictive of future results. These measures are used to monitor our underlying performance and operations. Not all companies calculate these measures in an identical manner and therefore our presentation may not be consistent with similar measures used by other companies. See “Presentation of Financial Information and _Other Data.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue results from sales of services within the scope of the ordinary operations of consolidated subsidiaries, less revenue from intragroup transactions. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable, net of discounts and rebates, VAT and other taxes and duties. In accordance with IFRS 15, we recognize revenue when the amount thereof can be reliably measured, it is probable that future economic benefits will flow to us, and specific criteria are met by each of our businesses, as further described below. _Joint Property Management business_ From a contractual and legal perspective, our Joint Property Management business is mostly conducted through mandates, and fees are calculated on a flat-rate basis. In France, this flat rate includes all basic management services provided by the jointly owned property association, and excludes incidental services. All such services are treated as an overall performance obligation satisfied over time. In fact, these different services are associated with a single performance obligation, i.e., management of the jointly owned property association. Annual revenue from basic property management fees is therefore recognized on a percentage-of-completion basis (over time) based on actual amounts billed (costs are in line with the billed amounts). ----- Incidental services may be added to the basic management services and are invoiced based on an agreed rate for each such service, for example, additional meetings and visits, rules and regulations of the jointly owned property, physical and administrative management of claims, technical work and surveys, litigation and disputes. Transfer Fees are also invoiced directly to a landlord selling its property. Since each additional service represents a separate performance obligation, revenue is recognized when the service is performed. _Lease Management and Renting business_ In the lease management line of our Lease Management and Renting business, we act as agent for ownerslessors and fulfil a certain number of contractually defined obligations in this regard. These represent separate service obligations. Accordingly, revenue for each of these obligations is recognized separately. Revenue from services provided over time, such as routine management services and insurance is recognized on a percentageof-completion basis by reference to the frequency with which expenses are rebilled to the owners. Revenue from one-off services is recognized when those services are provided. In our lettings business, revenue is recognized at the time the inventory of the premises is conducted. We collect fees from owners and from lessees. _Brokerage business /Efficity_ Revenue in the transactions business is recognized upon signature of the notarized final sale agreement (acte _authentique), which is the date on which control is presumed to have been transferred. Client accounts_ Interest income generated on client funds, limited to rental cash deposits, is booked in revenue. _Assurimo_ Assurimo provides property insurance brokerage services. Revenue under comprehensive property insurance and comprehensive homeowners’ insurance policies is recognized over the term of the cover, since services in this brokerage business are provided on a straight-line basis. _Constatimmo_ Constatimmo carries out mandatory technical surveys on premises, as well as inventories of premises for lessees. Its revenue is recognized and measured when the related services are performed. _Seiitra_ Seiitra provides specialist IT property services and developed the Powimo software, which it markets through its software as a service (“SaaS”) solutions model. These property management tools offer the full suite of functionalities needed to keep accounting records for client accounts and to manage suspense accounts, jointly owned properties and rentals, as well as the budget of jointly owned property associations. Maintenance fees are recognized on a straight-line, percentage-of-completion basis, since the corresponding services are provided over time. _Esset Management_ Esset Management provides property management services (jointly owned property management and rental services) for B2B customers such as national and international insurance, real estate and financial institutions. Once contracts are signed and invoices are issued, revenue recognition follows IFRS 15. _Foncia Valorisation_ Foncia Valorisation provides investment strategy consulting and arbitrage (appraisals, lending, block/unit property sales) for institutional customers or wealthy families. Its revenue is recognized at the date the notarized final sale agreement is signed and is based on a percentage of the sale price. ----- _Leemo_ Leemo, a wholly owned subsidiary since 2017, is a listing service for properties for sale. It has developed a digital platform for property companies where it lists new real estate projects by different developers as well as certain older properties that are to be made available for sale to private and institutional investors. It derives its revenue from two main sources: - fees on sale agreements: amounts billed to developers and partially retroceded to business providers. Only the net margin is recognized in revenue; and - fees on bundles of services sold to developers without any retrocession requirements. Revenue from fees on sale agreements is recognized when the notarized final sale agreement is signed. Revenue from fees earned on bundles of services is recognized on a pro rata basis in the period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other operating income primarily comprises gains on client accounts, retrocessions of fees for the Assurance Privilège product in Assurimo’s comprehensive homeowner’s insurance portfolio, and miscellaneous net sub-letting income.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Purchases consumed and external charges comprises fees and services, cost of premises (in the year ended December 31, 2018 only), travel, subcontracting, insurance and guarantees, advertising, IT purchases and other costs, postage and telephone costs, supplies and documentation and other rental costs. This also comprised charges related to external personnel (e.g., interim staff or staff on secondment).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Taxes other than on income includes corporate property tax, tax on vehicles, corporate social solidarity contribution and miscellaneous other taxes other than income tax. We also included certain taxes on compensation in taxes other than on income (including transport tax, training levy, apprenticeship tax, tax on wages, payroll taxes and contributions to AGEFIPH (the French association for the employment of disabled people)).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Personnel costs include wages and salaries, payroll taxes, other personnel costs, employee profit-sharing and movements in post-employment benefits.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other operating expenses include directors’ fees, losses on non-recoverable receivables, royalties and other expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net additions to depreciation, amortization, impairment and provisions
Subsubsection Text: Net additions to depreciation, amortization, impairment and provisions include amortization of intangible assets; depreciation of property, plant and equipment; impairment of receivables; reversals of receivables impairment; impairment of inventories net of reversals; and various additions and reversals to provisions we have taken.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Recurring operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to our businesses, with the exception of items classified within “Non-recurring operating income (expenses).” Recurring operating profit (loss) is a performance indicator that may serve as a method for estimating recurring performance. It includes all items included in operating profit (loss), restated for any non-recurring items. Costs relating to business combinations or restructuring are excluded from recurring operating profit (loss). -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Non-recurring operating income (expenses) includes income and expense items that, owing to their nature, amount or frequency, cannot be considered as arising in the ordinary course of our operations and are therefore not reported in recurring operating profit (loss). Non-recurring items are limited, unusual and/or irregular items of a material amount and we classify these items into three main categories: (i) M&A non-recurring integrations charges, (ii) restructuring/transformation non-recurring charges and (iii) corporate non-recurring charges. These items include impacts of changes in the scope of consolidation, goodwill impairment, and amortization and impairment charged against trademarks and Syndic+ software. If material, non-recurring items also include the effects of certain unusual transactions such as capital gains and losses on disposals of non-current assets, restructuring fees, fees relating to major claims and disputes, and any other income or expenses likely to affect the comparability of recurring operating profit (loss) from one period to the next. For transactions directly related to external growth and projects to transform or restructure the business (particularly mergers and reorganizations), a detailed procedure is in place to identify, classify and validate any transactions of a non-recurring nature. This procedure gives a precise indication of transactions that meet the criteria to be recorded in this category.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to our businesses, irrespective of whether they are of a recurring nature or whether they result from one-off decisions or transactions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The cost of gross debt is equal to all financial expenses on borrowings.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The cost of net debt is equal to all financial expenses on borrowings, less financial income from cash investments.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other financial income and expenses includes foreign exchange gains (losses), net interest cost on pension and other employee benefit obligations, capital gains (losses) on financial disposals less costs to sell, net impairment of financial assets, gains (losses) on available-for-sale financial assets, net discounting costs and other miscellaneous costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Income tax expense for the year includes current and deferred income tax expense, which are recognized in the statement of profit and loss except when they relate to items recognized in other comprehensive income. We calculate our current taxes in accordance with the tax legislation applicable in the countries in which our earnings are taxable. Current tax expense is calculated on the basis of tax laws enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date in countries where our subsidiaries operate and generate taxable profit. However, management periodically reviews the positions adopted in tax returns for situations in which tax regulations are subject to interpretation. Where applicable, a provision is set aside based on the amounts payable to the tax authorities. Income tax expense includes the amounts reported by French subsidiaries in respect of the CVAE tax assessed on value added, since we consider this tax meets the definition of income tax set out in IAS 12 – Income Taxes. When they have not been set against income tax, income tax credits that are not included in the calculation of taxable profit and that are always refunded by the government are recorded as subsidies and reduce the expenses to which they relate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Share of profit (loss) of equity-accounted companies
Subsubsection Text: Associates are entities over which we exercise significant influence. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating policy decisions of the entity without controlling or jointly controlling ----- those policies. A joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to its net assets. Joint control of an arrangement only exists when decisions about the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. Profits, losses, assets and liabilities of associates or joint ventures are accounted for by the equity method in our consolidated financial statements. Under the equity method, the investment in an associate or joint venture is initially recognized at acquisition cost and subsequently adjusted for our interest in the profits, losses and other comprehensive income of the associate or joint venture. As of the year ended December 31, 2019, Pagardim was the only joint venture that we did not control and that we accounted for by the equity method, based on our 50% interest. This entity is immaterial. No material commitments were entered into with Pagardim and there are no material liabilities relating to this entity.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Year ended December 31, 2020 compared to year ended December 31, 2019
Subsubsection Text: The following table presents our results of operations for the year ended December 31, 2019 compared to year ended December 31, 2020:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (a) Our consolidated results for the year ended December 31, 2019 have been retrospectively restated for IFRS 16 Interpretations Committee implementation. See “—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Certain changes in _accounting standards and accounting policies.” Revenue_ Revenue increased by €18.0 million, or 2%, from €943.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €961.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to a €66.5 million increase due to acquisitions, a €13.6 million increase in digital revenues driven by Efficity, an increase in RRES revenues driven by a price effect of €2.3 million in Joint Property Management and €1.7 million in Lease Management but offset by a negative €4.3 million churn in Joint Property Management and Lease Management and a negative €4.8 million volume effect in Letting, an increase of €2.6 million due to the positive impact of FX EUR/CHF exchange rate, higher organic brokerage revenues due to revenue recognition, partially offset by a decrease of €51.1 million due to the COVID-19 pandemic and €18.4 million of activities disposal. For a breakdown of this revenue loss of €51.1 million by business line, see “—Key Factors Affecting Results of _Operations—COVID-19 pandemic impact on our business—Consequences of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.”_ ----- The following table sets forth a breakdown of revenue by business for the periods indicated. A discussion of the revenue per business is set forth below.

Subsubsection Text: Revenue for the RRES business in France increased by €8.6 million, or 1.5%, from €571.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €579.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was primarily driven by acquisitions, partially offset by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our Joint Property Management business. Revenue for the Brokerage business (French network) decreased by €4.3 million, or 3.4%, from €129.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €125.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenue for the digital business increased by €7.5 million, or 21.2%, from €35.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €42.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the performance of Efficity. Revenue for the other activities segment in France decreased by €11.1 million, or 11.2%, from €99.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €87.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily driven by the cessation of operations of our investor platform and Foncia Pierre Gestion and partially offset by an increase in the B2B business driven by the acquisition of Yxime. Revenue for our International business increased by €17.4 million, or 16.0%, from €108.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €126.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was primarily driven by acquisitions in Germany, partially offset by impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic, notably in Switzerland and Belgium. ----- _Other operating income_ Other operating income decreased by €0.7 million, or 11.3%, from €6.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €5.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to lower gains on client accounts. The following table sets forth a breakdown of other operating income for the periods indicated.

Subsubsection Text: (a) Our consolidated results for the year ended December 31, 2019 have been retrospectively restated for IFRS 16 Interpretations Committee implementation. See “—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Certain changes in _accounting standards and accounting policies.”_ (b) Data for 2018 has not been restated to reflect the impacts of the first-time application of IFRS 16. We began applying IFRS 16 from January 1, 2019, using the modified retrospective approach, i.e., with no restatement of comparative information. Under this approach, a liability is recognized at the transition date for the present value of any residual lease payments, against a right-of-use asset adjusted for the amount of any lease payments made at or before the lease commencement date. However, following additional analyses carried out in connection with the first-time application of IFRS 15 (related to revenue from contracts with customers), in the year ended December 31, 2019, we changed our accounting presentation of revenue arising from fees earned on deeds of sale. This led to the reclassification of the contracts to be classified as contracts where we act as agent, as opposed to contracts where we act as principal as was previously the case, and the statement of profit and loss figures for the year ended December 31, 2018 have been restated accordingly. For further details see, “—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Certain _changes in accounting standards and accounting policies—2018 Restatement” and “—Results of Operations—Year ended December 31, 2019 compared to the year ended December 31, 2018.”_ (c) In 2018, net loss from discontinued operations concerned the impairment of Somhome assets after the business was discontinued. _Revenue_ On a restated basis, revenue increased by €78.0 million, or 9.0%, from €865.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, to €943.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase in total revenue was mainly attributable to the impact of acquisitions carried out in 2019 for an amount of €73.2 million, an increase of €14.7 million in organic growth apart from our acquisitions and a positive currency effect of €2.5 million related to our business in Switzerland, with the average EUR/CHF exchange rate decreasing from 1.16 in 2018 to 1.11 in 2019 partially offset by negative impact of registration fees for an amount of €8.6 million. ----- The following table sets forth a breakdown of revenue by business for the periods indicated. A discussion of the revenue per business is set forth below.

Subsubsection Text: Revenue for the RRES business, including our Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Renting businesses, increased by €36.0 million, or 6.7%, from €535.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, to €571.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was mainly attributable to the increase in revenue from our Joint Property Management business by €22.2 million, or 8.6%, from €258.9 million to €281.1 million and the increase in revenue from Lease Management and Renting by €13.4 million, or 5.0%, from €270.3 million to €283.6 million. This increase was mainly driven by price effect in Joint Property Management and in Lease Management, partially offset by customer turnover in Joint Property Management and Lease Management, and a decline in market conditions for the rental activity in 2019. Revenue for the Brokerage business (French network) increased by €11.3 million, or 9.5%, from €118 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, to €129.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily driven by higher organic Brokerage revenues as the result of strong market conditions in volume and in pricing. Revenue for the digital business segment increased by €12.8 million, or 56.6%, from €22.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, to €35.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily driven by increased revenue from Efficity of €8.9 million notably due to the recruitment of new agents. Revenue for the other activities segment increased throughout the period under review by €0.4 million, or 0.4%, from €98.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, to €99.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily driven by higher revenue from Assurimo due to the increased number of buildings that we managed, partially offset by lower revenue deriving from the B2B segment. Revenue for our International business increased by €17.6 million, or 19.4%, from €91.0 million to €108.6 million. This increase was primarily driven by increased revenues in Switzerland, which were largely the result of a positive currency effect in Switzerland of €2.5 million. ----- _Other operating income_ Other operating income increased by €0.9 million, or 16.9%, from €5.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, to €6.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. The following table sets forth a breakdown of other operating income for the periods indicated.

Subsubsection Text: This increase in other financial income was driven by a decrease in other expenses in the year ended December 31, 2019, which mainly concerned fees due on the early repayment of the Second-lien ICA loan for €1.5 million. Additionally, discounting costs, net increased by €1.6 million from an expense of €0.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, to €1.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, which reflects the time value of housing loans and is attributable to the decrease in the discount rate used, from 1.57% in the year ended December 31, 2018 to 0.7% in the year ended December 31, 2019. ----- This increase in other financial income was partially offset since no foreign exchange gains were recognized in the year ended December 31, 2019. The foreign exchange gains in the year ended December 31, 2018 resulted from fluctuations in CHF up to June 29, 2018, the date on which the net investment hedge was recognized in respect of the loan granted to Foncia Switzerland by Foncia Group. Following this date, foreign exchange gains and losses arising on the loan have been taken to other comprehensive income (equity) under foreign currency translation reserves and therefore no longer impact profit or loss. _Income tax expense_ Income tax expense decreased by €12.5 million, or 83.5%, from €15 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, to €2.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019.
