Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our primary source of liquidity is cash flow from operations. Our cash needs relate primarily to capital and other expenditures for meeting debt service requirements and funding our working capital requirements, which are primarily costs related to our acquisitions. The components of our working capital are trade receivables and deferred income, trade payables and prepaid expenses, tax and employee related working capital. We believe that, based on our current cash flows, these sources of liquidity, together with existing available borrowings under the New Revolving Credit Facility, will be sufficient to fund our operations, capital expenditure and debt service for at least the next 12 months. We are highly leveraged and have significant debt service obligations. As of the Issue Date, after giving effect to the Transactions, we expect to have €2,099 million of indebtedness, comprising primarily of the Notes, the New Term Loan Facility and lease liabilities. We will also be able to borrow up to €437.5 million under the New Revolving Credit Facility. The availability of the Revolving Credit Facility is dependent upon certain conditions described further under “Description of Other Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.” The Indenture governing the Notes offered hereby will contain, and the New Senior Credit Facilities Agreement will contain, restrictive covenants that may limit our ability to finance our future opportunities and capital needs, or pursue business opportunities and activities. In addition, the New Revolving Credit Facility also requires us to comply with a leverage ratio, under certain circumstances, in order for us to continue to be able to draw funds under the Revolving Credit Facility. We may from time to time seek to retire or repurchase our outstanding debt through cash purchases, in open market purchases, privately negotiated transactions or otherwise. Such ----- repurchases, if any, will depend on market conditions, our liquidity requirements, contractual restrictions and other factors. Our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which in turn depends to some extent on general economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which are beyond our control, such as the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as the other factors discussed in “—Key Factors Affecting Results of _Operations” and “Risk Factors.” We cannot guarantee that our business will generate sufficient cash flows_ from operations or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs.

Subsubsection Text: (a) Cash and cash equivalents at the end of the period is defined net of bank overdrafts. _Cash flow from operating activities_ Our cash flow from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 amounted to an inflow of €171.6 million, primarily due to our EBITDA which amounted to €241.3 million, partially offset by non-recurring operating costs in the amount of €55.4 million primarily driven by the increased number of bolt-on acquisitions, negative change in working capital in the amount of €8.1 million and paid CIT / CVAE in the amount of €10.8 million. Our cash flow from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 amounted to an inflow of €183.4 million, primarily due to EBITDA in the amount of €251.9 million, partially offset by negative change in working capital in the amount of €7.7 million, by non-recurring operating costs in the amount of €46.7 million mainly driven by the increased number of bolt-on acquisitions and paid CIT / CVAE in the amount of €11.5 million. Our cash flow from (used in) operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2018 amounted to an inflow of €129.7 million, primarily due to EBITDA in the amount of €191.2 million, partially offset by negative change in working capital in the amount of €19.9 million due to a VAT credit improvement in 2017 and lower employee bonuses and profit-sharing and by non-recurring operating costs in the amount of €31.0 million primarily driven by the number of bolt-on acquisitions and paid CIT / CVAE in the amount of €5.9 million. _Cash flow from (used in) investing activities_ Our cash flow from (used in) in investing activities principally relates to bolt-on acquisitions of companies operating in our RRES businesses and capital expenditure (such as IT projects). Our cash flow from (used in) investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 amounted to an outflow of €211.1 million, primarily due to the intangible and tangible fixed assets expenditure in the amount of €57.6 million, acquisitions of companies primarily operating in our RRES businesses in the amount of €156.1 million. ----- Our cash flow from (used in) investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 amounted to an outflow of €118.8 million, primarily due to intangible and tangible fixed assets expenditure in the amount of €60.3 million and acquisitions of companies primarily operating in our RRES businesses in the amount of €70.5 million (this includes the disposal of non-RRES businesses). Our cash flow from (used in) investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2018 amounted to an outflow of €145.8 million, primarily due to intangible and tangible fixed assets expenditure in the amount of €51.7 million, acquisitions of companies primarily operating in our RRES businesses in the amount of €100.9 million. _Cash flow from (used in) financing activities_ Our cash flow from (used in) financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 amounted to an outflow of €6.7 million, primarily due to the payment of financial interests in the amount of €49.1 million, reimbursement of leases in the amount of €43.2 million and €120 million drawn under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility. Our cash flow from (used in) financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 amounted to an inflow of €16.4 million, primarily due to the payment of financial interests in the amount of €46.1 million, repayment of leases in the amount of €38.4 million, additional debt on the Existing Senior Facility B loan in the amount of €288 million, repayment of the Existing Second Lien in the amount of €110 million and additional debt and repayment of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility which netted to repayment of €40 million. Our cash flow from (used in) financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2018 amounted to an outflow of €9.0 million, primarily due the payment of financial interests in the amount of €44.3 million, payment of finance lease liabilities in the amount of €4.1 million, additional debt on the Existing Senior Facility B loan in the amount of €80 million, reimbursement of the Existing TLB in the amount of €77 million and additional debt and repayment of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility which netted to additional debt of €40 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The increase in working capital spend from the year ended December 31, 2019 to the year ended December 31, 2020 was related to an increase of the tax working capital of €5.0 million, an increase of the employee-related working capital of €27.2 million and an increase of the non-operating working capital of €10.0 million mainly due to remaining payments on acquisitions. Trade receivables increased by €2.9 million or 2.9% from December 21, 2019 to December 21, 2020 primarily due to changes in consolidation scope. DSO remained at approximately 38 days, which is an equivalent level to that of 2019. Trade payables increased by €4.9 million or 4.7% from December 21, 2019 to December 21, 2020, also primarily due to changes in consolidation scope. Tax working capital was comprised primarily of tax credits related to a former French tax credit for employment (the Crédit d’impôt pour la compétitivité et l’emploi or “CICE”) of €20.1 million, net VAT credits of €1.7 million and taxes assessed on compensation of €3.0 million. Employee-related working capital principally comprised of payables to personnel of €66.9 million, net payables to government social welfare agencies and earn-out debts of €28 million. The increase of ----- €27.2 million in employee-related working capital is mainly due to (i) an increase in payables to personnel of €10 million, (ii) an increase in net payable to government social welfare agencies of €2.5 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Under the provisions of the Hoguet law, property management companies must provide financial guarantees for funds held in client accounts. In accordance with this law, we provide financial guarantees to clients equal to the maximum amount of funds held on their account. These guarantees are presented under commitments given. Commitments given for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 were €2.3 billion, €1.9 billion and €2.1 billion, respectively, for these Professional Financial Guarantees and total commitments for the same periods were €6.1 billion, €5.5 billion and €5.7 billion, respectively, including property lease commitments, commitments under financing leases and pledges of certain collateral. Financial guarantees received from guarantors such as guarantee funds, insurance companies and banks are shown under commitments received. Total commitments received for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018 were €3.0 billion, €2.3 billion and €3.0 billion, respectively, including commitments under property lease commitments, commitments under financing leases and pledges of certain collateral.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In accordance with the laws and practices in each of the countries in which we operate, we participate in, or operate, benefit plans providing for the payment of post-employment benefits (including retirement benefits) to eligible current and former employees, retirees and their beneficiaries. Virtually all of our employees are entitled to pension benefits. In France, this takes the form of payments by us to the beneficiaries when the rights allotted vest, while in Switzerland, plans are managed by pension funds financed in compliance with the applicable government requirements and regulations. These plans may be funded by investments in various instruments such as insurance policies, equity instruments and bonds.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We conduct our property management business through mandates signed with customers, under which our companies are responsible for holding client funds. By law, all Joint Property Management accounts are segregated and each individual association must open a current account and a saving account for client funds. These funds consist of guarantee deposits received, rent and expenses and capital and renovation funds. As an agent, we undertake to hold client accounts and to recognize them in our statement of financial position using a specific account for each activity, such as property sales, rentals and management.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our interest rate risk exposure arises mainly on our borrowings. These borrowings are denominated solely in euros and are managed on a centralized basis. They are mainly indexed to three-month EURIBOR. The risk management policy is set by our management team. Cash flow surpluses and working capital requirements for our companies are centralized under a cash pooling agreement and managed by our treasury department. Our treasury department selects investment vehicles for cash surpluses – either for proprietary cash or client cash (excluding separate accounts) – within the framework set by the management policy, which prioritizes liquidity and security. Interest received is indexed to 3-month EURIBOR or is at fixed rates (term accounts). Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to various market risks, including interest rate and foreign exchange rate risks. Our treasury department is responsible for managing our exposure to market risk that arises in connection with operations and financial activities, including interest rate, foreign exchange rate, credit and liquidity, and credit risk management. The following sections discuss our significant exposures to market risk. The following discussions do not address other risks that we face in the normal course of business, including country risk and legal risk.

Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to two types of foreign exchange risk: - A foreign exchange risk on assets resulting from our shareholdings in our Swiss subsidiaries. Although this risk is measured, it is not subject to specific risk management as the investments are intended to be held over the long term. Our foreign exchange risk exposure on assets is not material. - A foreign exchange trading risk arising on commercial and financial transactions carried out by our companies in currencies other than their local currency. This risk arises solely on the business of Swiss subsidiaries and concerns the Swiss franc. Since the vast majority of local transactions are carried out in Swiss francs, this risk is not material.

The premium paid for this instrument amounted to €0.039 million. Given the current environment for interbank rates (negative 3-month EURIBOR), the fair value of this instrument is zero at December 31, 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of financial statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that may affect the measurement and presentation of certain assets and liabilities and any disclosures provided in respect of contingent liabilities at the end of the reporting period, as well as the reported amounts of income and expenses for the period. ----- Estimates and underlying assumptions are determined based on information available at the end of the reporting period and are reviewed on a regular basis in light of past experience and other factors deemed reasonable given the circumstances. These estimates serve as the basis for measuring the carrying amount of assets and liabilities that cannot be obtained directly from other sources. Where applicable, a sensitivity analysis may be performed if the estimates are material. Accordingly, actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates we make in preparing our consolidated financial statements are based on a going concern assumption and relate primarily to the items described below. _Measurements used in testing goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment for impairment_ The estimates and assumptions made to determine the recoverable amount of goodwill, intangible assets, and property, plant and equipment relate mainly to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. As with any estimate, the assumptions used in these calculations are partly based on uncertain factors and may therefore need to be adjusted in subsequent periods. The notes to the audited financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum set out the assumptions used to calculate future cash flows and determine the discount rates to be applied in measuring the recoverable amounts of these assets. Sensitivity analyses were also performed and are described in the same notes. _Measurement of leases_ IFRS 16 requires entities to use a significant degree of judgement as well as certain key estimates. These involve determining: - whether an option to extend or terminate a lease is reasonably certain to be exercised; - the lease term; - the appropriate discount rate to be used to calculate future lease payments; and - the specific selling price of any lease components and non-lease components contained in the contract. The main assumptions we use to prepare the audited financial statements are described in the notes to the audited financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. _Measurement of provisions_ We use the best estimate of our commitments and obligations to calculate the corresponding provisions. _Measurement of employee benefits_ We operate both defined contribution and defined benefit plans. Obligations under these plans are calculated using the projected unit credit method, which is based on assumptions regarding the discount rate, future increases in salary, employee turnover, life expectancy and the rate of increase in healthcare costs. The notes to the audited financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum set out the assumptions used to measure these obligations. We consider that the actuarial assumptions used are appropriate and justified in the current environment. However, the corresponding obligations may change if these assumptions also change. _Measurement of fair value (Level 1)_ We use fair value on a recurring basis in our statement of financial position to measure unlisted derivative instruments and cash and cash equivalents. _Measurement of recognized deferred tax assets and liabilities and tax expense_ Our tax position is based on our best estimate of future taxable earnings. ----- _Basis for determining the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of a business combination_ The estimates and assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount of these identifiable assets and liabilities relate in particular to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. Any changes in these assumptions could impact the recoverable amount. _Assessment of criteria for identifying discontinued operations_ In accordance with IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations, we are required to exercise judgement in determining whether an asset or group of assets meets the criteria to be classified as held for sale. IFRS 5 criteria are also used to identify any assets to be classified as discontinued operations. These assessments are reviewed at the end of each reporting period in light of changes in the relevant facts and circumstances. In the absence of IFRS guidance for a specific transaction, event or condition, we use our judgement to define and apply accounting policies that will result in relevant, fair and comparable information to ensure that the financial statements: - present a true and fair view of our financial position, financial performance and cash flows; - reflect the economic substance of transactions; and - are neutral, prudent and comprehensive in all material respects. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion and analysis of the results of operations and financial condition of Foncia Management for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018. See “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Data.” You should read this discussion in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements of Foncia Management and the accompanying notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum as well as the “Selected Historical Financial Information.” A summary of the critical accounting estimates that have been applied to Foncia Management’s consolidated financial statements is set forth below in “—Critical Accounting Judgments” This discussion also includes forward-looking statements which, although based on assumptions that we consider reasonable, are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual events or conditions to differ materially from those expressed or implied by the forward-looking statements. See “Forward-Looking Statements.” For a discussion of risks and uncertainties facing us as a result of various factors, see “Risk Factors.”_

Subsubsection Title: Lease management and joint property management
Subsubsection Text: Property management companies’ core offering is composed of lease management services and joint property management services. The lease management business includes i) residential property management (gestion locative), i.e. services for an apartment or a house, and ii) commercial property management, i.e. services for retail buildings, notably shops and restaurants. It refers to the assistance on the day-to-day operations of the property typically related to financial management, legal assistance, conflict handling, etc., for an individual residential unit (which may be a joint property or condominium). On the lease management level, property management companies take care of tenancy agreements, rent collection, account and reporting, tax and insurance claims, maintenance or legal compliance. The property management providers are appointed by the owner of the individual unit(s), typically a private landlord. Joint property management refers to the management of joint property (copropriété), i.e. the management of shared property of joint ownership associations, activities include financial management, structural support and legal assistance. In the joint property management segment, the services provided include organization of general assemblies, a pre-determined number of visits per year for inspection, coordination of maintenance efforts and accounting, bill payment, and building fee collection. The property management provider assumes the role of trustee (syndic) after appointment by the general assembly of joint owners. It is important to note that lease management and joint property management activities can overlap with each other and fall under joint property management for the joint property and lease management for the individual unit. Exhibit 1: property management providers’ types of clients ###### Individual residential unit (lease management) _Source: International report provider_ Owner occupied apartments Rented apartments Vacant/secondary apartments ###### Shared parts of a joined property (joint property management) ----- Property management companies provide residential real estate services to B2C and B2B clients. The business model has different maturity levels in different geographies, for instance, B2B property management services are far more developed in Germany than in France where this segment is still growing significantly, notably following the COVID-19 pandemic. _Main Customers_ Property management companies address a variety of customers that can be divided into three main groups depending on the type of services provided to them. Typical lease management customers are private landlords and family offices. Private landlords are private individuals with real estate portfolios varying in size. They own the majority of residential units and a very small portion of office and retail buildings. Family offices are individuals who own a real estate portfolio, mainly composed of apartments and to a lesser extent, office and retail buildings. Typical joint property management customers are joint ownership associations or their boards, representing owners of a single property containing multiple units, such as apartments buildings. Typical B2B clients are institutional investors that acquire and manage real estate portfolios such as Axa, Allianz, BNP Paribas or Swiss Life. These portfolios can be composed of apartments, office or retail buildings.

The property management business in France provides a wide range of services from core property management services (lease management and joint property management) to providing ancillary services to property owners.

In France, as of August 2019, the total market size for property management was estimated to be €12.2 billion, of which €5.3 billion (44%) was under external management. Exhibit 2: Composition of the French property management market (in 2019, in € billion) 10.3 2.2 8.1 Residential market Commercial market 12.2 1.9 6.9 Total market size Unserved market (Done in-house) Captured by PM companies Lease Management Joint Property Management _Source: International report provider_ In 2019, the residential market was the largest segment of the French property management market, estimated to be €10.3 billion (84% of the French property management market), of which the lease management had an estimated market size of €8.1 billion and joint property management had an estimated market size of €2.2 billion. The commercial market, estimated to be €1.9 billion (16% of the French property management market), includes the lease management service for offices, (representing 211 million square meters for an average annual rent price of €192 per square meters and an average property management fee of 3% of rent) and retail (representing 152 million square meters for an average annual rent price of €152 per square meters and an average property management fee of 3% of rent). The majority of the French property market is not captured by property management companies, with services instead being managed “in-house.” The market that is captured by property management companies has an estimated total market size of €5.3 billion (44% of the French property management market), and is shared between the lease management providers with an estimated market size of €3.4 billion market, (64% of the captured market) and the condominium management providers with an estimated market size of €1.9 billion (36% of the captured market). Based on penetration rates, property management companies benefit from a strong position in the commercial market, having penetrated 90% of both the market for lease management of ----- office and retail spaces. Their penetration is more balanced in the residential market where it varies widely by the type of customer. The penetration rates for institutional investors is 90% and for condominiums 85%, while private landlords and the secondary and vacant homes are yet to be captured as the penetration rates are low at 30% and 10%, respectively. _Lease management’s market penetration_ Exhibit 3: Penetration of the French residential housing market (in 2019, in million units) 35.8 (100%) Housing units not relevant for external property management Total building stock Owner-occupied dwellings _Source: International report provider_ Social and free housing Total addressable stock Non-penetrated units Penetrated units In 2019, the total residential stock building was comprised 35.8 million units. Among these units, roughly two thirds of total dwellings are either owner-occupied (17.0 million units), social housing or “free” housing (5.7 million units) and not addressable for external property management. Therefore, the total addressable residential stock buildings for property management companies is 13.1 million units or 37% of the total residential stock buildings. As of August 2019, property management companies have only captured approximately 2.8 million units or 21% of the residential total addressable market. The majority of the penetrated market are owned by private landlords (1.9 million units or 68% of the penetrated market), 200,000 penetrated units (9% of the penetrated market) are owned by institutional investors and 600,000 units (23% of the penetrated market) are secondary and vacant homes. _Joint property management’s market penetration_ Exhibit 4: Penetration of the French residential condominium market (in 2019, in million units) Housing units not relevant for 35.8 condominium management (100%) Property management 25.9 done in-house 9.9 8.4 (72%) (28%) (24%) 1.5 Total building Single Total addressable Non-penetrated Penetrated stock ownership stock units units _Source: International report provider_ In 2019, among the 35.8 million units of the French residential market, 25.9 million units were single ownership (72% of the residential total building stock), and not considered relevant for joint property management. The remaining 9.9 million units (28% of the residential total building stock) were condominiums and part of a joint ownership structure (copropriétés). These joint ownership structures include a mix of owned, rented, vacant and secondary dwellings (typically apartments). The vast majority (85%) of these joint ownership associations were managed by external property managers, meaning an estimated 8.4 million condominiums were under external property management, with the remaining 1.5 million units were to be captured by property management companies.

In Switzerland, as of August 2019, the total market size for property management was estimated to be €2.1 billion, of which €1.1 billion (52%) is under external management. ----- Exhibit 5: Composition of the Swiss property management market (in 2019, in € billions) 2.1 Residential market Commercial market Total market size Unserved market (Done in-house) Captured by PM companies _Source: International report provider_ In 2019, the residential market was the largest segment of the Swiss property management market, estimated to be €1.6 billion (77% of the total Swiss property management market). This segment comprised 4.5 million units owned by condominium owners, private landlords, public sector rental, housing companies, institutional investors and cooperative ownership. Property management companies do not yet hold a strong position in all the segments of the residential and commercial markets based on their penetration rates. In the commercial market, as of August 2019, property management companies have penetrated 80% of retail space and 40% of the office space segment. Similarly, property management companies have varying penetration rates among the various segments of the residential market. For example, 80% of properties were owned by institutional investors, 70% by condominium owners, 65% by real estate companies, 10% by public sector rentals, 10% by cooperative ownership properties and 30% by private landlords. Exhibit 6: Penetration of the Swiss residential market (in 2019, in million units) 3.4 (74%) Total addressable units 4.6 (100%) Total building stock Housing units not relevant for external property management 1.2 Single- or two family homes Property management done in-house 1.8 (52%) 1.6 Non-penetrated units Penetrated units _Source: International report provider_ In 2019, the total Swiss residential stock building was comprised 4.6 million units, of which roughly a quarter of total dwellings are single or two family homes (1.2 million units) and therefore, not addressable for the external property management business. Therefore, the total addressable residential stock amounted to 3.4 million units or 74% of the total residential stock building. Property management companies have captured half of the addressable market with 1.8 million units or 52% of the residential total addressable market. Penetration is the highest among institutional investors as well as construction and real estate companies and the lowest among housing cooperatives and the public sector, where property management is typically carried out in-house department.

In Germany, as of August 2019, the total market size for property management was estimated to be €10.0 billion in 2019, of which €3.7 billion (37%) is under external management. ----- Exhibit 7: Composition of the German property management market (in 2019, in € billion) 10.0 Residential market Commercial market Total market size Unserved market (Done in-house) Captured by PM companies _Source: International report provider_ In 2019, the residential market was the largest segment of the German property management market, estimated to be €8.0 billion (80% of the German property management market). This segment consisted of estimated 42.4 million units owned by owners associations, housing associations, public sector housing, private landlords and professional companies. The average revenue per unit was €263. The commercial market was estimated to be €2.0 billion (20% of the German property management market) and comprised office properties (representing 400 million square meters for an average annual rent price of €118 per square meters and an average property management fee of 2.7% of rent) retail spaces (representing 122 million square meters for an average annual rent price of €250 per square meters and an average property management fee of 2.4% of rent). Similar to France, the majority of this German property market was not captured by property management companies, with services instead being managed “in-house.” Property management accounted for €3.7 billion (37% of the German property management market) of the total addressable market. Companies benefit from a strong position in the commercial market having penetrated 75% of office space and 75% of the retail space. Penetration by property management companies was lower in the residential market, with penetration rates being equal or below to 50% for all sub-segments as follows: owners associations (50% penetration rate), private landlord (50%), professional companies (25%) and public sector housing (5%). Exhibit 8: Penetration of the German residential market (in 2019, in million units) 42.4 (100%) Total building stock Owner-occupied houses Housing units not relevant for external property Property management management 21.0                done in-house (50%) Houses owned by private landlords Owned by housing associations Total addressable units Non-penetrated units Penetrated units _Source: International report provider_ In 2019, the total German residential stock building was composed of 42.4 million units. Of these, half of total dwellings were not addressable for external property management which comprise of owner-occupied houses (13.7 million), houses owned by private landlords (5.4 million) or houses owned by housing associations (2.2 million). Therefore, the residential total addressable stock amounted to 21.0 million units (50% of the total residential stock building). In 2019, property management companies captured a quarter of the addressable market with an estimated 5.6 million units under management (27% of the residential total addressable market). Penetration was the highest among ownership associations and private landlords as the German Condominium Act applies for WEG management. -----

The size of the property markets differs depending on the country as well as the size of the addressable markets for property management companies. Property management companies’ penetration rates varies among the markets (residential vs. commercial) and the different types of owners.

_Brokerage refers to the management of sale or purchase transaction processes for customers, including property_ search services, estimations on rental income, advice and assistance with banking and administrative formalities and market analysis, buyer solvency assessments and other services.

In addition to the core offering and brokerage, property management companies also provide other ancillary services that may be broadly categorized as follows: - _Rental services, referring to the services aiming at minimizing the vacancy rates of the properties, such as finding new tenants, renegotiating tenancy agreements as well as property letting, sale of properties or buyer advisory; - _Technical building consulting, referring to the financial, legal and technical services related to building projects as well as maximizing the property value through e.g. energy optimization, and includes scrutiny technical advice and building process management, apartment renovations or energy consultancy; - _Facility services, referring to the facilitation or direct delivery of supporting services for properties and tenants aimed at ensuring stable operations, and gathering different activities such as janitor services, receptionists, canteen operation, cleaning, caretakers or gardeners; - _Property asset management, referring to the end-to-end assistance with the process of investing in properties including strategy, opportunity assessment, valuation and portfolio development, and includes services such as portfolio strategy and optimization, valuation and risk assessment or portfolio development; and - _Insurance advisory, referring to the (coordination of) providers of insurance services such as unpaid rent insurance, property insurance, liability insurance, and includes services such as offering of unpaid rent insurance, insurance consultancy or preferential supplier offers.

Subsection Title: Key growth drivers in the lease management and joint property management businesses
Subsubsection Text: As of August 2019, the addressable market of our lease management and joint property management businesses in France grew at an estimated 2% per annum between 2014 to 2019. In Germany and Switzerland, the addressable market for our lease management and joint property management businesses grew at an estimated 1.5% to 3% per annum between 2014 and 2019. The joint property management market is driven by three factors: pricing, building activities and outsourcing penetration for property management.

As of August 2019, prices for residential lease management are expected to grow between 1 to 2% per annum between 2019 and 2024 (excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic), although impact from recent and future housing reform regulations remains unclear. Pricing for lease management is typically fixed as a percentage of rent (ranging from 2 to 10%, and on average 6 to 8% of annual rent). While prices in terms of percentages have remained stable, rent for residential real estate grew at 0.7% per annum from 2013 to 2019, with a trend of increased acceleration in recent past (1.7% from 2018 to 2019). Recent developments make it difficult to estimate possible pricing scenarios in the near future. For example, rent limitation was re-enacted in Paris since July 2019, which set a 20% limit for premium over reference rent in each district, is expected to curb the upward trend for rent significantly. Furthermore, the impact of any future regulatory housing reforms is unclear. As shown by recent housing reforms, regulations can have significant impacts on rent price. This is in addition to the ongoing uncertainty of the impact of the general economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Prices for joint property management are expected to grow at 1 to 2% per annum between 2019 and 2024 (excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic), in line with inflation. Prices for joint property management range from approximately €100 to €400/unit and depend on a variety of factors, including size of the portfolio, included services, location and characteristics of the property. Prices have typically been increasing by 1 to 2% per annum between 2014 and 2019, in line with inflation. This trend is expected to continue However, this does not account for any disruptions that may stem from the general economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Prices for Commercial Lease Management are expected to stay flat between 2019 and 2024 (excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic), reflecting the competitive pressure from tendering process. Rent levels in the commercial segment vary significantly and pricing tends to be negotiated through a competitive tender process where price points are determined on a global level, based on the characteristics and requirements of the building(s) in the portfolio. In general, prices for commercial property management have remained rather stable between 2014 and 2019.

Building activities are expected to account for an estimated growth of 0.5 to 1% per annum between 2019 and 2024. Expenditure for residential building activity grew at an estimated 3% per annum from 2017 to 2019, and is expected to correct for recent boom years and decrease by 3% per annum from 2019 to 2021, thereby returning to 2016 levels. However, despite decreases in total expenditure, residential stock is expected to continue to grow towards 2022 at an estimated 1% annually. The share of addressable market for property management businesses (excluding social housing and owner occupied units) is expected to remain stable in the same period. Growth for joint properties is expected to be in line with overall residential building stock growth at approximately 1% till 2022. This remains subject to any impact that may stem from the general economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The property management market has seen an estimated annual growth rate of approximately 2%, from €4.82 billion in 2014 to €5.32 billion in 2019. Within the property management market, residential lease management grew at the fastest pace (growing from €1.49 billion in 2014 to €1.71 billion in 2019 with a CAGR of 2.8%), followed by joint property management (growing from €1.71 billion in 2014 to €1.90 billion in 2019 with a CAGR of 2.1%) and commercial lease management (growing from €1.61 billion in 2014 to €1.72 billion in 2019 with a CAGR of 1.3%). Between 2019 and 2024, the property management market in France is expected to grow an estimated rate of approximately 1 to 2% per annum, to reach €5.87 billion in 2024 (excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic). Continued growth is expected to be driven by the residential lease management segment and joint property management segment, with commercial lease management following historical trends. The growth outlook is expected to be driven by a larger number of addressable units and higher penetration of units owned by private landlords as a result of regulatory changes which have made it more difficult for private landlords to manage properties in-house. However, certain aspects of this expected growth may be decreased by uncertainties regarding the full price effect of recent regulatory changes and new entrants. ----- The private housing market in France has grown steadily since 2000 at a CAGR of 1.2% and as at 2019 had not been affected by the global financial crisis as shown below: Exhibit 9: Evolution of the French private housing since 2000 - apartments and rented individual houses (in million units) 9.9 10.0 10.2 10.3 10.4 10.5 10.7 10.8 10.9 11.0 11.1 11.2 11.3 11.5 11.6 11.7 11.9 12.0 12.2 12.4 2000 2001 2002 2003 2004 2005 2006 2007 2008 2009 2010 2011 2012 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 _Source: INSEE_

Penetration of property management outsourcing is expected to grow for residential lease management, mainly driven by an increase in private landlords engaging management services. The penetration rate (the degree to which property owners outsource property management rather than conduct activities in-house) for residential lease management varies significantly depending on the type of owners. Penetration within private landlords and secondary and vacant homes is relatively low at approximate 30% and 10% respectively as of 2019, whereas for institutional investors and commercial segment, the penetration rate is at approximately 90% as of 2019. As a result of more complex regulations (including PINEL, ALUR, ELAN), there has been a higher tendency among private landlords to outsource property management, as it has become increasingly difficult, time consuming and risky to keep property management in-house. These developments are expected to continue to cause some increases in penetration until 2024. This remains subject to any impact that may stem from the general economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Penetration for institutional investors and for the commercial segment is expected to remain stable given already elevated current levels. Secondary and vacant homes are often used for private or short-term purposes, thus penetration is expected to remain low. ----- Exhibit 11: Penetration of property management services (lease management) by types of ownership (2014-2024)

segments expected to remain the same over 3.7 the forecast period 3.9 2014 Growth 2014-'19 2019F 2020 & '21 2022F _Source: International report provider; Euroconstruct_ Expenditure on commercial building is expected to increase at 2% per annum until 2022, at a slightly slower pace than in the past few years, whereas expenditures on office building increase is expected to increase at 4% per annum until 2022, slowing down from previous levels of 8% per annum between 2015 to 2019. However, the expected growth of retail and office buildings addressable for external property management was minimal between 0.5 to 1% from 2014 to 2018. Before the COVID-19 pandemic, the commercial segment was expected to grow a little slower than residential at 0.5 to 1% between 2019 and 2024, in line with growth in the previous five years. This remains subject to any impact that may stem from the general economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, which is expected to undermine the growth of the commercial segment.

Historically, the property management market in Switzerland grew at an estimated 1.5 to 2% per annum, from €1.00 billion in 2015 to €1.07 billion in 2019, and is expected to grow at a similar pace in the near future, reaching €1.17 billion in 2024. This remains subject to any impact that may stem from the general economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Main drivers for growth of the sector in Switzerland are expected to be building activity (which is expected to grow at an estimated rate of 1.2% per annum between 2019 and 2024) and to a lesser extent outsourcing penetration (which is expected to grow at an estimated rate of 0.6% per annum between 2019 and 2024). Unlike in France, in Switzerland, the prices have been decreasing slightly between 2014 to 2019, driven by the decrease in percentages charged on the rent, despite increasing rent levels. In the near future, pricing in terms of percentage of rent is not expected to decrease at the same pace given the already low level. An additional upside could potentially be realized through ancillary services. Overall, prices are not expected to have a significant impact on the growth prospects for the property management market in Switzerland.

The property management market in Germany grew at an estimated rate of 3% per annum, from €3.24 billion in 2015 to €3.66 billion in 2019. In the near future, the market is expected to grow at approximately 2.5 to 3% per annum between 2019 and 2024, largely in line with historical levels, reaching €4.18 billion in 2024. This remains subject to any impact that may stem from the general economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Price increases are expected to be the main growth driver (approximately 1.1% per annum between 2019 and 2024), with some contributions from building activity (approximately 0.7% per annum between 2019 and 2024) ----- and to a lesser extent outsourcing penetration (approximately 0.3% per annum between 2019 and 2024). Prices have increased across residential and commercial segments in the recent past between 2015 and 2019, driven by mostly by increasing rent (especially for office spaces, driven by shortage). These trends are expected to continue in the near future. Unlike in France or Switzerland, outsourcing activity in the German market has not followed a clear trend and is not expected to do so in the short term. In Belgium and Luxembourg, the company’s current operations are relatively small compared to other markets limiting the impact of market growth trends on the overall business.

Foncia has operations in Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg. Between 2019 to 2024, the property management market is expected to grow at approximately 1.5 to 2% per annum in Switzerland and 2.5 to 3% per annum in Germany.

Subsection Title: Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the growth drivers
Subsubsection Text: Despite the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, the residential real estate services market had proven to be resilient during 2020, supported by reassuring factors that continued stable and growing momentum. In France, transactions slowed down during the first half of 2020 due to government confinement measures that were in place between March and May 2020. All real estate agencies and notaries were closed and, as a consequence, the steady growth of housing transactions halted during that period. In July 2020, the trailing 12 months sales volumes of existing properties came down to 983,000 units, compared to 1,075,000 units in January 2020. In comparison, in January 2018, sales volumes stood at 972,000 units. During the second half of the year, the transaction market recovered to reach one million units (over 12 months). In November 2020, the trailing 12 months transactions level was at 1,020,000 units, which was a decrease of 5% compared to the levels recorded in January 2020. Exhibit 12: Changes in the sales volumes of existing properties in the period 2000/2020 1,100,000 January ‘20: 1,075,000 November ‘20: 1,020,000 January ‘18: 972,000 1,000,000 900,000 May ‘06: 836,000 February ‘12: 834,000 July ‘20: 800,000 983,000 700,000 600,000 500,000 Dec-‘00 Dec-‘02 Dec-‘04 Dec-‘06 Dec-‘08 Dec-‘10 Dec-‘12 Dec-‘14 Dec-‘16 Dec-‘18 Dec-‘20 _Source: Notaires de France_ Over the same period, despite the relative absence of foreign investors in the French market (close to its lowest levels in 10 years), house prices continued their steady growth trajectory. In the second and third quarters of 2020, house prices were higher than in the previous quarters, by +1.2% and +0.7% respectively. When compared to 2019, year-on-year evolution of house prices during the second and third quarter were +5.4% and +5.0% respectively. In 2021, FNAIM, which represents Real Estate agents in France, predicted that house prices will continue to grow by +3.5% per annum in the near future. |Col1|January ‘18: 972,000 May ‘06: 836,000 February ‘12: 834,000 July ‘20: 983,000|Col3|Col4|Col5|Col6|Col7|Col8|Col9|Col10|Col11|Col12| |---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---| ||||||||||||| ||||||||||||| ||||||||||||| ||||||||||||| ||||||||||||| ||||||||||||| November ‘20: 1,020,000 February ‘12: 834,000 January ‘20: 1,075,000 1,000,000 500,000 Dec-‘06 Dec-‘14 Dec-‘18 Dec-‘04 Dec-‘12 900,000 700,000 ----- Exhibit 13: House price evolution – Metropolitan France – All dwellings _Source: INSEE_ Through 2020, leasing activity was halted due to several sanitary measures, constraining tenants’ ability to change their housing. During the first three quarters of 2020, according to INSEE, rent followed the same path as house prices. In the second and third quarter of 2020, the quarterly increases were +0.7% and +0.5%, respectively. The fourth quarter of 2020 saw a flattening of rent prices (at -0.1% quarter over quarter), however rent levels remain higher than what was observed by the end of 2019. Exhibit 14: Rent index evolution _Source: INSEE_ Finally, a new housing trend has emerged from the various constraining measures. There has been a shift among the urban population towards preferring greener areas as observed by Notaires de France. The experience of confinement and the already crowded urban hubs have pushed increasing numbers of homeowners and tenants to seek more rural properties, with gardens and greater interior space. This move from urban to sub-urban areas has also been reinforced by the possibility of undertaking and maintaining professional activities remotely. As a result, for real estate servicers, scale and the capillarity of their network became key to take advantage of this new housing habit. In summary, the residential segment has remained resilient through the COVID-19 pandemic while other segments of the real estate services market, such as offices or retail, have been negatively impacted by the proliferation of working from home practices or by the acceleration of e-commerce adoption due to government-ordered closure of certain physical shops. This resilience and relative outperformance has led intuitional investors to increase their exposure in residential assets, thus benefitting the B2B customer segment. -----

_The French lease management and joint property management markets_ The chart below reflects key players in the French market as of 2019 by number of dwellings under management: Exhibit 15: Key players in the French market by number of dwellings under management (in k units) 1,793 876 810 672 291 216 120 111 60 22 _Source: Based on latest figures available from public information and company fillings. Note that the figures are provided as of varying dates, based on latest figures available for each company and some key players are excluded due to lack of public information._ The French real estate services market is highly fragmented, with a few large players and a long tail of independent small and local providers. The increasing barriers to entry with regulations and growing technological requirements make it difficult for small players to remain competitive. _The French brokerage market_ The French brokerage market is highly fragmented, with few large players and a long tail of very small agencies. The main players can be divided into four main categories: - _Traditional real estate agency networks (physical) gather a network of several agencies. Most of them opt for franchising that enable them to develop quickly and inexpensively. Only six networks exceed 500 locations in France (Century 21, Foncia, Guy Hoquet’Immobilier, Laforêt Immobilier, Orpi and Stéphane Plaza Immobilier); - _Real estate agency networks (online), mainly carry out their activity online, enabling them to propose lower commission rates as they do not operate a network of physical agencies. The seven predominant networks are IAD, Safti, Capifrance, Propriétés-Privées.com, OptimHome, Efficity (a subsidiary of Foncia Group) and MegAgence; - _Independent online agencies offer fixed commissions and are challenging the codes of the real estate services market. Still few players (a dozen on the French market), these start-ups are essentially present in Île-de-France and in some large cities (Lyon, Bordeaux, etc.); - _Specialized agents for the luxury segment coming from dominant specialized agencies distinguished by a significant international presence. Predominant examples are Barnes and Emile Garcin. -----

The chart below reflects the key players in the Swiss market as of 2018 by property management per revenue: Exhibit 16: Key players in the Swiss market (in 2018, estimated property management revenue € millions) Market share 10% 6% 6% 4% 3% 2% 2% 2% 1% 1% 1% 14% 48% 100% 510 1070 150 65 48 25-40 25-40 15-30 15-30 16 10-20 12-16 66 100-120 150 Mid-sized players Small Total players _Source: International report provider_ The Swiss market is relatively fragmented, with a few large players and a long tail of small, local providers. The players can be divided into four main categories: - _Independent property management companies, including us, with core offering of property management services for both the commercial and residential segments, without a clear separation. They also provide brokerage and other services such as facility management. Other predominant examples of companies in this category are Privera and Averit; - _Institutionally owned property managers are large, nationwide companies, owned by institutional investors or real estate companies like Swiss Prime Site, SwissLife or Pensimo. They often offer property management services to third parties, in addition to managing their own portfolios, such as brokerage and other services (commercial letting or technical consulting). Predominant examples are Wincasa, Livit and Regimo; - _Local associates of international real estate advisors are originally Swiss property management companies that have partnered with an international real estate advisor, having often two local associates: one for French speaking Switzerland and one for German speaking Switzerland. They usually also offer brokerage services and other services. Predominant examples are Intercity and Real Estate AG; - _Small scale property management companies are small and local providers of property management, mainly targeting private investors and offering property management and coownership association services. They are typically family businesses or owner-operated companies with less than 10 employees, with most of the business focused on a single municipality or city. They represent almost 50% of the market. Predominant examples are Geminwo and Martaler. -----

The chart below reflects the key players in the German market as of 2017 by estimated residential property management revenue: Exhibit 17: Key players in the German residential property management market (in 2017, estimated residential property management revenue € millions) Market 0.8% 0.4% 0.4% 0.4% 0.3% 0.2% 0.2% 0.2% 0.2% 0.5% 96% 100% share 2,060 2,150 3 Top 10-20 companies Other Total players 12 _Source: International report provider_ There are no actors with significant scale in the German residential property management market and the top 10 hold a combined 4% market share. The players can be divided into four main categories: - _Property management companies, including us, with core offering of property management. Most of the larger players focus on commercial property management while having some residential units ‘on the side’. They also provide brokerage and other services such as facility management. Other predominant examples of companies in this category are ECE, DIM, IC Immobilien Gruppe, Treureal and Tectareal; - _Full-service real estate advisors operate internationally as “one-stop-shop.” They secure stable income streams. They also provide other services (asset management or facility management). Predominant examples are JLL, BNPP RE, CBRE and Cushman & Wakefield; - _Facility management-evolved companies, the core offering of which is facility management, moving gradually more into provision of property management to complement the low-margin facility management business with broader services. Predominant examples are Strabag, Apleona and Property First; - _Small-scale property management companies are small companies with “WEG-management” (acting according to the German Condominium Act (“Wohneigentumsgesetz” – WEG), which constitutes the basis for all legal regulations involving individual freehold ownership incl. the management of condominiums) as core business. They also provide property management and gradually move more into property management of commercial space. They are typically owner-operated, with an average of less than 10 employees with most of the business focused around a municipality or a city. They represent more than 80% of the market. Predominant examples are Jürgens Hausverwaltung GmbH and Kaldox Immobilien. -----

We are the European leader in the residential real estate services (“RRES”) market, providing services to both individuals (“business-to-consumer” or “B2C”) and businesses (“business-to-business” or “B2B”), and have recently entered the commercial real estate services segment for B2B customers. In addition, we have established ourselves as a leader for real estate services in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg by delivering high quality, reliable and innovative products uniquely suited to the needs of our customers. We assist our residential and commercial customers at every stage of their property journey with competitive and comprehensive service offerings. We provide end-to-end assistance, from managing individual apartments and building areas jointly owned by apartment owners through our lease management and joint property management business lines, respectively, to providing renting, brokerage and digital and ancillary services such as insurance brokerage, technical diagnostic, and distribution and energy brokerage offerings through our other business lines. Our RRES business is the leader in France, operating under the Foncia brand through a network of approximately 134 and 131 branches dedicated to our RRES and Brokerage businesses, respectively, and 242 branches dedicated to both our RRES and Brokerage businesses, representing 84% of our revenue in France for the year ended December 31, 2020. We operate an additional 101 branches under various brands in Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our French RRES business, Brokerage business, ancillary services, Digital services, B2B services and international business generated 60%, 13%, 6%, 4%, 4% and 13% of our total revenue, respectively. Our business lines include: - Residential Real Estate Services (“RRES”): - _Joint property management (our “JPM business”): In our Joint Property Management business, we are mandated by landlords to manage jointly owned building areas and equipment and to ensure compliance with joint ownership regulations. We are the French market leader in Joint Property Management, managing over 1,463,402 dwellings in France for the year ended December 31, 2020. We are generally hired by an apartment building homeowners’ board to provide common services to all residents under contracts that are typically one year in length, subject to renewal. Services in our Joint Property Management business include the administrative, financial and technical management of the building, works management, managing security staff and ensuring the maintenance of technical equipment such as elevators, heating and safety systems. We also coordinate the payment of common costs, transfer tasks, help brokers with the management of joint decisions, offer cost management services such as efficiencies with respect to energy, maintenance and heating costs, and provide asset appraisal services, as well as around-the-clock maintenance assistance. These fee-based services in our Joint Property Management business provide recurring and predictable revenue streams with revenue of €65.9 million. Through our growth strategy, which includes both acquisitions and organic growth initiatives, we have gone from managing 1,287,611 dwellings in France in 2018 to 1,463,402 dwellings in France as of December 31, 2020. - _Lease management and renting (our “LM&R business”): Through our Lease Management and Renting business, we manage properties on behalf of our ownerlessor customers (the lease management side of the Lease Management and Renting business) and assist landlords and tenants throughout their rental process, including the finding, screening and contracting of new tenants (the “renting” side of the Lease Management and Renting business). In Lease Management, we assist landlords with the day-to-day operations of the property, collect rent, offer financial reporting services and advice and organize necessary maintenance for the properties. We managed over 330,005 dwellings in France as of December 31, 2020, where we provided recurring services for these landlords under contracts that are typically one year in length. We also offer occupancy guarantee services to certain owner-lessors to provide guaranteed rental income should their lessees fail to make their rental payments or occupy the premise. See “—Lease Management and Renting” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of ----- _Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Rent payment and_ occupancy guarantees.” Our Lease Management and Renting_ business generated €283.6 million in revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020. Through our growth strategy, which includes both acquisitions and organic growth initiatives, we have increased the number of dwellings we manage in France from 311,888 for the year ended December 31, 2018 to 330,005 in France as of December 31, 2020. - Real estate brokerage (our “Brokerage business”): In addition to the recurring activity in our Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Renting businesses, we support our existing customers or other customers with their purchase or sale plans, by offering property search services, estimations on rental income, advice and assistance with banking and administrative formalities and market analysis, buyer solvency assessments and other services. Once a landlord mandates us to sell their apartment, this mandate covers the entire business process from buyer identification to cash collection. We closed over 13,763 transactions in the year ended December 31, 2020 and our Brokerage business generated €125.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. - Our other services include: - _B2B Services: Esset, our B2B business, comprises all lines of business with commercial and institutional customers. Our Esset business line includes Esset Management, our wealth management and consulting services for commercial and office properties firm, and Foncia Valorisation, which markets properties by blocks or lots. Our experience and expertise within multiple facets of the real estate services market allows us to provide a broad range of service offerings, including residential, commercial and corporate services, to these B2B customers. For example, we may provide services to an insurance institution, a B2B customer, that owns and rents residential apartments, commercial space and corporate office space and we are able to service their needs in each of these capacities. Our B2B business generated €34.5 million in revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020. In 2020, we acquired Yxime and Perial to strengthen this B2B business. - _Digital Services: Our Digital Services business includes our businesses that rely on a digital platform and is comprised of Efficity, Lodgis and Leemo. Efficity is an online real estate valuation and brokerage activity operated with a business model based on independent sales agents. Lodgis is a real estate agency specialized in renting and selling furnished units and Leemo is a digital platform selling newly built properties. Our Digital Services business generated €42.8 million in revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020. - _Additional Ancillary Services: We have developed a strong and diversified portfolio of other brands and businesses that offer services that are complementary to our RRES and Brokerage businesses in order to enhance the value we provide to customers on our platform. These additional complementary services primarily include our specialized property insurance brokerage unit (Assurimo), our technical due diligence and inventories services unit (Constatimmo), our business-specific IT services (Seiitra), marketing of properties by blocks or lots (Foncia Valorisation) and technical homeowner maintenance solutions which we launched in France in 2019 (Techway). Our complementary services businesses generated €53.3 million in revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020. We also offer RRES, Brokerage and other services in our international businesses in Switzerland, Germany and Belgium. For the year ended December 31, 2020, 87% of our revenues were derived in France, and 7%, 5%, and 2% of our revenues were derived in Switzerland, Germany and Belgium, respectively. For a further detailed description of our businesses, see “—Our Businesses.” We were founded in 1972 and have since established ourselves as the leading European RRES, with over 10,000 employees across Europe as of December 31, 2020. Our recent growth has been marked by achievements in operations, digitization, our successful M&A track record and our IT and communications infrastructure. We believe our success is the result of a unique integrated ecosystem of real estate services providing the opportunity for cross-selling of recurring and additional services and growth through bolt-on acquisitions. The ----- following diagram provides a breakdown of our revenue by business for the for the year ended December 31, 2020: (1) Lease Management and Renting revenues also include revenue generated from interest income on our customer accounts, Foncia Immo Neuf and Holiday Rental. (2) Ancillary Services revenues include intercompany sales. The RRES market in the jurisdictions in which we operate remains largely fragmented. According to a third-party report prepared in 2019 the French property management market was estimated to be worth approximately €12 billion (excluding rental services and brokerage), of which approximately €5.3 billion was under external management, along with an estimated €1.2 billion market for rental services. However, greater regulation in France and the increasing need to invest in the digitization of services has made it more difficult and time consuming for private landlords to keep property management in-house, leading to the increased outsourcing and penetration rate of properties under external management in the residential property management market. These trends towards increased regulation and digitization have also led to the growing consolidation of the highly fragmented market, enabling us to capitalize on small bolt-on, strategic acquisitions and increase our market positioning and scale. Our size provides us with a competitive advantage against smaller and local competitors as we can industrialize processes to better leverage our cost base, replicate best practices across our network to ensure consistent quality of service and adapt more easily to regulatory changes. As a result, we made 61 acquisitions in the year ended December 31, 2020, both in our primary French market and in other geographies, representing approximately 60,000 new Lease Management dwellings and approximately 171,000 new Joint Property Management dwellings and approximately €111.0 million of acquired revenues. We have a robust acquisition pipeline in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg and a strong team of approximately 28 employees and 10 trainees dedicated to post acquisition integration.

Subsubsection Title: Sector leadership focused on strongest economies in Western Europe providing competitive advantages
Subsubsection Text: We have established ourselves as a leader for residential real estate services in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg by delivering high quality, reliable and innovative services uniquely suited to the needs of our customers. As of August 2019, we were the number one player in the French real estate services market, with approximately 13% market share, according to an international report provider. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we managed approximately 1.8 million dwellings in France, which is approximately two times the number of dwellings managed by our next closest competitor according to publically available information for the year ended 2020. Outside of France, we hold leading positions in Switzerland and Germany and have a strong presence in Belgium and Luxembourg. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we operated ----- over 100 branches in these countries, which collectively accounted for 13% of our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our scale, operations and service offerings provide us with a clear competitive advantage. Our centralized processes result in lower internal costs and enable improved customer service compared to our typically small, individual-owned competitors. Our comprehensive range of innovative services, such as FONCIA 24/7 (our assistance service for our joint property management customers), Prowen (our centralized energy service that reduces client costs on gas and electricity), and Assurimo, (our real estate insurance service), differentiate us from competitors. Our comprehensive network of over 500 branches covering all major French cities is one of the largest offerings in the market and results in close proximity to our customers and the dwellings that we manage; unique market positioning in negotiations with third-party repair and maintenance service suppliers resulting in decreased costs; and financial resources that allow us to expand our customer portfolio through acquisitions. We have been able to successfully enter markets through acquisitions and expanded our operating geography, despite the regulatory and technological requirements that create barriers to participation in the real estate services market. Our regional and national regulatory and real estate industry expertise and our leadership team’s extensive experience in the real estate services industry are key to meeting and complying with such requirements. Our strong reputation for quality and service and multi-branded strategy have also supported our ability to grow in existing markets and enter new markets.

Subsubsection Title: Loyal and diverse customer base and synergetic business model in a resilient market
Subsubsection Text: Our large and diversified client base, integrated ecosystem of residential real estate services and high customer retention rates drive a high level of recurring revenues (75% in the year ended December 31, 2020). We have grown our diversified customer base to approximately 1.5 million dwellings in our French Joint Property Management business and over 330,000 dwellings in our French Lease Management business as at December 31, 2020. Through our synergetic business model, we are able to cross sell our services to our diverse customer portfolio across our business lines, which in turn leads to further organic growth. For example, our proven ability to cross-sell is highlighted by the high penetration rates of Assurimo, our specialized property insurance brokerage unit (providing property insurance, homeowners’ insurance policies and brokerage services) through which we currently provide insurance services to 61% of our French Joint Property Management buildings. Similarly, we currently provide technical services to approximately 88% of our Lease Management customers through our dedicated business, Constatimmo. We believe that we are well positioned to target new customers, including B2B customers, given our knowledge regarding fulfilling requirements for our B2C customers. The addressable markets in which we operate are characterized by high outsourcing rates, with a high and stable portion of joint property or condominium owners (85% in France) under external management, as of August 2019 using services like our Joint Property Management business. Property owners tend to rely on expert services such as ours due to the volume of work and amount of legal and accounting know-how required to directly interface with tenants and other counterparties. Moreover, landlords rarely switch leasing managers during a tenancy, given the risks and costs involved in switching service providers and the limited potential benefit. We believe that through the integrated ecosystem of high-quality services we consistently provide we have established high customer retention rates, and long lasting customer relationships, certain of which last more than 20 years. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we lost only 3.5% and 8.4% of customers from our Joint Property Management and Lease Management businesses, respectively. Moreover, 36% of our customers from our Joint Property Management business in France entered into contracts of three or more years and 24% for two to three years for the year ended December 31, 2020. Due to our broad and diverse customer base, we are not reliant on any particular customer. According to an international report provider, the French property management market is estimated to be €12.2 billion in August 2019, of which €5.3 billion is captured by property management companies, with the rest serviced in-house. The externally serviced property management market has grown by approximately 2% annually between 2015 and 2019. This stable growth has been driven by population dynamics and the construction of collective units. We continue to capitalize on opportunities to grow through acquisition of customer portfolios, cross-selling of related services to our large client base and the addition of new revenue opportunities for our existing services. -----

Subsubsection Title: Strong and predictable cash flow generation
Subsubsection Text: We have a track record of steady cash flow generation, driven by a high level of recurring revenues, which has enabled us to establish a history of consistent deleveraging. Our trend of improving EBITDA conversion rates has continued with a Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Conversion Rate, of approximately 76% for the year ended December 31, 2020, compared to 71% for the year ended December 31, 2019. Despite our regular M&A activity, our discretionary spend on acquisitions provides us with flexibility to manage our cash flow and reduce our financial leverage. Further, our business requires limited maintenance capital expenditures, (accounting for approximately 6% of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2020), and is characterized by limited working capital requirements. Our revenue increased at a CAGR of 5.4% and was €961.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 up from €865.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Our margin resilience is supported by an adaptable cost structure for the more cyclical flow Brokerage business, as Brokerage salary costs include a significant variable portion that is indexed on commissions. Our Adjusted EBITDA Margin was 26.9%, 26.8% and 22.3% for the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively. Our recurring, stable revenue is in part due to our complementary business profiles across our branches, experienced management and sales force teams, and fee-based services in connection with our Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Renting businesses which accounted for 69% of our revenue in France for the year ended December 31, 2020. In addition, our high proportion of recurring revenues (75% in 2020) and balanced portfolio of services split between stock and flow businesses with limited correlation have supported our resilience during adverse economic conditions, achieving a substantially stable performance in 2020 despite unprecedented government measures taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Subsubsection Title: Continuous investments in operational improvement through our innovative technology platforms reinforces our competitive position and provides sustainable efficiency gains
Subsubsection Text: We continuously invest in cutting edge technology in order to offer the best multi-channel services to our customers. Since 2017, we have upgraded a significant portion of our IT and communication infrastructure including utilizing a mix of integrated and outsourced solutions, transitioning to a single telecom provider, and streamlining our finance and human resources functions with Workday, which enabled us to quickly and effectively transition to a work-from-home environment during the COVID-19 pandemic. We have also leveraged our technological know-how combined with our knowledge of the real estate industry to design and launch a go-live version of our new ERP system, Millenium, which we have piloted at one of our branches in France in 2020. Millenium integrates all of our IT and resource planning functions into one database to better meet our customers’ needs and address internal business challenges.
