Millenium increases the digitization of our activities with the aim of helping customers by creating greater transparency and improving our operations with standardized, digital processes to increase efficiency and to improve the speed at which we can serve our customers. We believe our high levels of investment in IT for our corporate platform and customer interface service such as over recent years give us a competitive edge in the current environment. The digitization, standardization and automation offered by Millenium complement our already synergetic business model and will allow us to more quickly leverage our customer database to identify cross-selling opportunities leading to greater operating efficiencies and inter-business synergies. We believe that Millenium’s compatibility with big data, AI and IoT, will allow us to explore new business opportunities and provide access to a number of revenue-enhancing opportunities. For example, we are developing a new operational model called “Agency of the Future” which will utilize Millenium to reorganize the residential real estate services and aims at improving client satisfaction and reducing our customer churn rate, which we believe will, in turn, lead to greater opportunities for organic growth. In addition, we believe that the gains of Millenium and the development of Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €15 million in 2022. We have invested in, and will continue to invest in, technology to continually improve our internal operations in order to provide our customers with product offerings that meet their needs and make us the number one choice among residential real estate service providers.

Subsubsection Title: Consolidation platform with proven track record of executing value accretive acquisitions to drive incremental EBITDA growth
Subsubsection Text: In addition to our organic growth, we maintain a successful, low-risk strategy of growth through small, bolt-on acquisitions. We completed 220 acquisitions from January 2016 to December 2020, which represented approximately €386.0 million of acquired revenues (including gross revenues for Leemo netted for commissions ----- to agents in our financial accounts). In the year ended December 31, 2020, we made 61 acquisitions in our primary French market and in other geographies, representing approximately 60,000 new Lease Management dwellings and approximately 171,000 new Joint Property Management dwellings and approximately €111.0 million of acquired revenues. We completed 61 acquisitions which contributed to our Adjusted EBITDA that reached €286.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 as compared to €258.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. Consolidation is a natural trend in the highly fragmented markets we operate in, accelerated by increasing regulations, and we play a key role in the market by defining new quality standards and unrivalled execution processes. We have a strong M&A team, with a disciplined approach that is dedicated to identifying, diligencing, completing and integrating opportunistic acquisitions in our five geographical regions. Our long-standing integration experience, including a dedicated post-acquisition integration team, enables us to extract full synergy potential from acquired businesses, with both cross-selling and cost synergies. We have identified a number of potential targets in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg to continue growing and, importantly, reinforcing our leadership in the market.

Subsubsection Title: Highly experienced management team with proven execution capabilities and focus on growth and value creation
Subsubsection Text: Our management team, led by our Chief Executive Officer, Philippe Salle, have significant experience in the industry and proven track record of delivering business and revenue growth, executing investment plans, driving continuous improvement of our European enterprise and generating high returns on capital. Our management team comes from various industries and geographies and is supported by five heads of region, who have extensive experience in real estate and enable us to provide our customers with tailored expertise and service. We believe that the collective industry knowledge and leadership of our management team positions them well to continue our successful organic and external growth and execute our strategies. Further, our management team encourages growth through a focus on operational efficiency and innovation including through the management’s dynamic external growth policy that enabled us to, among others, establish our market leading presence in Germany, successfully divest our non-core businesses to focus on our core, synergetic businesses and more recently, by the ongoing overhaul of our IT infrastructure, including the development of Millenium and enabling our planned transition to our new operational model, “Agency of the Future.” This is demonstrated by the consistent increase in our revenues which increased at a CAGR of 5.4% and was €961.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 (€1,013 million excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic) up from €865.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2018.

Subsubsection Title: Industry-leading technology to further reinforce our competitive advantage
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to providing the best real estate services offerings to our customers by investing in industryleading IT and data platforms, which in turn supports our market share gains. Our most recent digital innovation, Millenium, an in-house developed ERP system that is device-agnostic, cloud-based and driven by artificial intelligence, will allow us to fully digitalize all of our businesses and establish a highly personalized digital relationship with our customers. We believe that Millenium will also allow us to better, more efficiently serve our customers, cross-sell across our platforms and therefore capture greater market share from existing customers and generate business from new customers. Our IT and data platforms are subject to a process of continuous improvement and innovation, which we support with ongoing investments, such as the team of over 80 developers and specialized professional we hired to create Millenium. We believe that our robust investments in our IT and data platforms provide us with a significant competitive advantage, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic when businesses have been required to transition to a work-from-home environment. Additionally, our ongoing and historical use of big data, AI and IoT to create new business opportunities enables us to maintain a cutting edge development program while minimizing the risks traditionally associated with experimentation. For example, we are in the process of developing our new operational model, Agency of the Future, which we believe will generate significant gains, mainly related to (i) staff costs synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and back-office functions to front-office employees and an increase in productivity and significant reduction of time spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains resulting from the digitization and automation of certain tasks that were previously done manually, such as reminder fees or the collection of postal charges. Since 2018, we have invested approximately €100 million into our IT projects, and we believe that the gains of Millenium and Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €15 million in 2022. ----- We have developed, and continue to develop, innovative solutions based on emerging trends that are aimed at providing our customers with the highest quality, optimal solutions for their real estate needs. We are constantly looking for ways to improve our offerings and develop new solutions for our customers, which we expect to drive incremental growth and positively impact our revenue.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to drive organic growth and pursue targeted and opportunistic bolt-on acquisitions in core French market
Subsubsection Text: Our goal is to continue to deliver organic growth in France. We have been successful in achieving incremental organic revenue growth through active cross selling efforts across our ancillary services. We intend to continue to benefit from this growth through expanding our service offerings by introducing new business lines. In addition, we aim to reduce our customer churn rate further by improving client satisfaction, including as a result of the overhaul of our IT systems. In addition, we have made, and intend to continue to make, bolt-on acquisitions in our core French market and the other geographies in which we operate to supplement our organic growth, solidify our current market position and expand our presence. We have a strong track record of successfully identifying, completing and integrating opportunistic acquisitions. From January 2016 to December 2020, we completed approximately 220 acquisitions. We believe that our strong brand, broad platform and our dynamic infrastructure have allowed us to generate growth and operating cash flows through acquisitions. Recent examples of targeted acquisitions in France that have accelerated our growth and have allowed us to better address customer needs include Gérance de Passy and LoftOne, in our RRES business, Yxime and Perial in B2B and in the German B2B segment, Paul Immobilien and SogerTec. We intend to continue to further strengthen our strong position in the market by pursuing opportunistic acquisitions in our existing geographies to accelerate our growth, and we aim to do so by leveraging our internal expertise. We have an M&A team that is dedicated to identifying growth opportunities. Our team deploys a disciplined and systematic approach and focuses on opportunities that will enhance the offerings and services we provide in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg.

We have expanded, and plan to continue to expand, our geographic footprint in Europe, organically and through targeted and opportunistic acquisitions. We intend to leverage our expertise and know-how as well as our highly localized real estate providers to penetrate European markets where there is an unmet demand and an opportunity for further expansion, as evidenced by factors such as population dynamics and the construction of collective units, accompanied by increases in price and service level and a higher degree of outsourcing driven by regulatory changes. We strategically pursue new markets while remaining committed to expanding in France, Germany, Switzerland, Belgium and Luxembourg as these markets offer us proximity to existing customers and expansion opportunities in countries where we have established brand recognition. We also plan to enter European markets, where we believe local markets have strong fundamentals, such as the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Denmark, Scandinavian countries, Austria and various other Eastern European countries where we aim to become the market leader. Our expertise and solutions are scalable from region to region, and we believe that as we continue to expand, we can increase market share by deploying practices and strategies that have proven to be successful in other markets.

We are committed to ESG matters and providing a safe and healthy environment for all of our customers and employees. Our corporate social responsibility strategy is based on the following key commitments: supporting sustainable energy in the buildings and dwellings we manage, improving the well-being of our customers and our employees and ensuring fair and non-discriminatory access to housing and assisting local communities. Our ESG initiatives are also focused on protecting the environment while also ensuring that our operations have minimal impact on the environment. We also aim to work with our clients, contractors and suppliers to improve efficiency, conserve natural resources and reduce waste and emissions. We focus on energy transition of buildings under management by developing services and solutions to enable our clients to renovate and finance their dwellings. In 2021, we aim to ensure that all of our building managers are systematically trained to lead such renovation projects, partner with clients and employees who demonstrate a commitment to the environment and reduce our carbon footprint. -----

We were incorporated in 1972 and have since expanded our business with subsequent acquisitions of real estate services businesses in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg and we are focused on improving our technological capabilities in order to optimize our efficiency and overall business offering. From January 2016 to December 2020, we have completed approximately 220 acquisitions, primarily within Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Renting. Our external growth strategy and development of ancillary service offerings has been a key driver to our historical growth. The following are the key milestones in our corporate history following our foundation: 1973 - 1993 Development of an advanced computerization solution for rental management and lettings and management of jointly owned properties, adapted to the expectations of local real estate agents. Launch of the first bolt-on acquisitions program aiming at expanding Foncia’s presence in France. 2000 - 2006 International development of the group with the acquisitions of residential real estate service companies in Switzerland, Germany and Belgium. 2013 Further development in Belgium with the acquisition of Trevi Group. Acquisition of Tagerim’s property administration division (representing 17 agencies and approximately 500 employees). August 2014 Acquisition of Efficity. July 2016 Funds advised and managed by Partners Group, leading a consortium including Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec (“CDPQ”) and CIC Capital Corporation, signed a Share Purchase Agreement to acquire 100% of the shares of Foncia from Bridgepoint and Eurazeo. Completion of the sale took place on September 7, 2016. September 2016 Acquisition of Icade Property Management, which was folded into the Esset brand in December 2019. October 2018 Acquisition of Lodgis. October 2018 Strengthening of our position in Germany with the acquisition of Bautra’s Property Management business. September 2019 Organization of the first general meeting of joint property owners online with Fuze. March-May 2020 During the first pandemic lockdown and while the agencies were closed to the public, our teams remained available to assist customers using digital tools and ensuring business continuity. June 2020 Announcement of the beginning of our digital transformation in the management of jointly owned properties and rental management, to strengthen responsiveness, transparency and expertise in the service. September 2020 Creation of Foncia’s RRES premium division, to develop its premium offer for property management activities in France. December 2020 Acquisition of OP in Belgium and Luxembourg.

The residential real estate services in France, operating primarily under the Foncia brand, represented 60% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020, and 61% of our total revenue generated in France for ----- the year ended December 31, 2019. Revenue from this business primarily comprises (i) jointly owned property management fees, (ii) rental management fees (including rent payment and occupancy guarantee fees), and (iii) letting fees, which allow us to maintain stable revenues. _Management of Jointly Owned Properties_ In our Joint Property Management business, we assist our customers in managing common building areas, features and costs in their jointly owned properties by providing technical and accounting management. These management services include (i) providing information and communicating on a regular basis with the joint property owners, (ii) organizing and managing general meetings of joint property owners by preparing the agenda, summons, minutes, etc., (iii) managing the upkeep of the joint property as a whole, (iv) controlling costs by drawing up a budget, (v) obtaining bids from potential suppliers, (vi) providing a breakdown of joint property charges, (vii) collecting funds and amounts due for the joint property accounts, (viii) providing bookkeeping services, (ix) monitoring contract performance, and (x) providing mass procurement offers for joint property owners and leveraging our large purchasing power to offer attractive prices to our customers on expenses such as gas and other utilities. We also provide direct access to all Foncia services on a unique customer portal, MyFoncia, and offer around-the-clock customer service. From a contractual and legal perspective, our Joint Property Management business is conducted primarily through mandates. We take the role of trustee (syndic) after appointment by the homeowners’ board or general assembly of joint owners. We calculate fees on a flat-rate basis, which leads to relatively stable and recurring revenue. In France, this flat rate includes all basic management services provided by the jointly owned property association, including (i) preparing, convening and organizing general meetings, (ii) managing the joint owners’ council or general assembly (iii) managing the financial operations, including bill payments and collection of building fees, (iv) keeping the accounts of the jointly owned property association (v) managing the jointly owned property in compliance with its rules and regulations and (vi) carrying out periodic visits and inspections of the jointly owned property. We also receive additional incidental fees such as transfer fees when a landlord selling a dwelling requires a book balance report called a “transfer report,” reminder fees, fees on insurance-related claim management services, maintenance and repair commissions on third parties invoices and additional post office charges. These variable fees comprise 23% of our total Joint Property Management fees for the year ended December 31, 2020. All such services are treated as an overall performance. These different services are associated with a single performance obligation, i.e., the management of the jointly owned property association. Incidental services may be added to the basic management services and are invoiced based on an agreed rate for each such service. As of December 31, 2020, we had 1,463,402 dwellings under our management of jointly owned properties, generating a revenue of €290.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, representing 30% of our total revenue for the same period. _Lease Management and Renting_ Our Lease Management and Renting business is comprised of Lease Management and rental services. On the Lease Management side of the business, we manage an owner’s-lessor’s rented apartment and provide assistance on the day-to-day operations of the property, typically related to financial management, legal assistance and handling conflicts. We are appointed by the owner of the individual unit, typically a private landlord, and we act as agent for owners-lessors to fulfil a number of contractually defined obligations in this regard. These key services primarily include: (i) routine management services such as rent reviews and collection, annual adjustment invoice for expenses, and sending rent receipts and deposits to lessees, (ii) other one-off management services, including preparation of the lease contract, inventory of premises, compilation of documentation, management of claims, administrative filings and requests for subsidies, (iii) technical management services, such as coordinating on-site repairs, mandatory technical surveys and preparation of essential information documents for lessees, (iv) insurance against unpaid rent and (v) other insurance such as for vacant premises or property damage. Lease Management fees are comprised of a base fee for the contracted services described above and, in some instances, other additional fees such as fees in connection with helping file tax forms or fees related to rent payment guarantees. We offer rent payment guarantees (“Garantie de loyers impayés” or “rent payment guarantee”) to certain residential landlords in France for whom we provide property management services and an occupancy guarantee (“Garantie d’occupation” or “occupancy guarantee”) to a small number of lessors to ----- protect against vacant properties for up to six months if we are unable to find a tenant for selected apartments in new dwellings. In December 2020, approximately 66% of residential dwellings in France were covered by the rent payment guarantee, and approximately 12% of rentals are covered by the occupancy guarantee. We believe we have a strong ability to assess credit risk when offering these guarantees and undertake a detailed process to select eligible tenants and dwellings. We refer to the new unpaid rents as a result of defaults under the occupancy guarantee each month as “flow of unpaid rent,” and the total sum of unpaid rents per month as our “stock of unpaid rent.” In December 2020, €124.7 million of rent revenues were covered by the rent payment guarantee, for which we experienced €3.5 million unpaid rent (for a 2020 average new monthly aggregate of unpaid rent of €3.3 million) and the cumulative aggregate of unpaid rent was €27.7 million, including outstanding rent payments from previous years. Once rent is reported as unpaid, any payments to landlords under these guarantees are recorded in full as a provision on our balance sheet. By underwriting rent payment guarantees and occupancy guarantees on our own balance sheet, we believe we offer a differentiating and competitive service to customers that smaller competitors would not be able to deliver. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Rent payment and occupancy guarantees” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Low demand for housing generally or lease terminations and/or tenant defaults could adversely affect our fees and the income produced by the properties we manage, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.”_ As of December 31, 2020, we had 330,005 dwellings under management in our Lease Management and Renting business, generating a revenue of €283.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, representing 30% of our total revenue for the same period (this includes Foncia Immo Neuf, CAI and Holiday Rental). Revenues are driven by rent evolution, fees as a percent of rent (on units acquired), and add-on services and volumes are driven by apartments under lease management and tenant mobility rates. We operate primarily in the residential real estate services market, but manage certain commercial real estate properties through Esset. See “—Other _Services (France).”_ Through our renting services, we aim to minimize the vacancy rates of the properties by helping landlords find a suitable tenant and helping tenants find a property to rent. For landlords, we manage the sourcing, screening, and contracting of new tenants, and provide services such as posting advertisements on various real estate portals, showcasing their properties in Foncia branches and providing structured feedback on renting efforts. For tenants, we assist lessees with leasing rental properties and we receive one-off placement fees for these services. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we assisted with 59,288 rentals. Our services include access to a large number of rental home insurance packages and fixture inventory programs offered by professionals who are available on short notice.

We completed over 13,763 transactions across France in the year ended December 31, 2020 and support our customers with all aspects of their property sales or purchases. Once we receive a mandate, we follow the sale through to completion. Our services include property viewings and search services, advice and assistance with banking and administrative formalities, property appraisals, buyer solvency assessments, market analysis, assistance complying with regulatory requirements, and drafting sale agreements. Our Brokerage business is conducted primarily through mandates, exclusive or shared, and fees for such mandate in the event of a transaction are calculated on a flat-rate basis. This rate usually comprises an average of 5.18% of the selling price of the property. Revenue are recognized upon signature of the notarized final sale agreement (acte _authentique). For further discussion on notary execution, see “Regulation.”_ Our Brokerage business provides ample opportunities for cross-selling services, such as property appraisals, brokerage insurance, technical surveys, and inventories services provided by our other businesses. See “—Other _Services (France).” Our Brokerage business in France generated a revenue of €125.0 million for the year ended_ December 31, 2020, representing 13% of our total revenue for the same period.

Our other services are comprised of B2B businesses, Digital businesses, and our other businesses that provide ancillary services to our offerings with high penetration rates within our network. For example, Assurimo has a 61% penetration rate with our Joint Property Management buildings from providing property insurance, homeowners’ insurance policies and brokerage services. Assurimo connects our customers with insurance ----- companies, negotiates the terms of the contracts for these customers and handles claims on behalf of the insurance company. The table below provides a comprehensive summary of our other businesses:

We are the European leader in the RRES market, serving customers in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg. We maintain an integrated business model with operations across a wide range of businesses, with recognized brand names in the countries in which we operate. Our unique business model provides for cross-selling opportunities, which help us achieve recurring and predictable revenues and strong cash flows.

Assurimo Assurimo provides property insurance brokerage services. Constatimmo Constatimmo carries out mandatory technical surveys on premises, as well as inventories of premises for lessees through independent agents. Seiitra Seiitra provides specialist IT property services and develops software, to RRES professionals which it markets through the sale of software licenses. Prowen Prowen is a provider of energy to Joint Property Management customers, such as gas, electricity, and heating oil. Prowen aims to reduce the energy bill of Joint Property Management customers through collective energy purchasing, which allows us to offer cheaper prices to our customers. Foncia Valorisation Foncia Valorisation provides investment strategy consulting and arbitrage (appraisals, lending, and block/unit property sales) for institutional customers or wealthy families.

Efficity Efficity is a national network of independent real estate consultants and is a leader in online real estate valuation. Leemo Leemo is a listing service for properties for sale which provides facilitated connections between promoters, wealth advisors and property managers or brokers. Lodgis Lodgis is a listing service for furnished rentals.

Since 2003, we have expanded our services outside of France and in the year ended December 31, 2020, we generated 13% of our revenue in our international operations. We have acquired recognizable brands in Switzerland, Germany, Belgium, and Luxembourg, and have reached leading positions in these markets for our real estate services. Our average international headcount for employees in 2020 increased to 1,430, compared to 983 and 835 employees in 2019 and 2018, respectively. ----- The chart below provides a revenue breakdown of our international operations by country: 12% 53% 35% Switzerland Germany Belgium _Switzerland_ We entered the Swiss market in 2004 through the acquisition of the real estate services group, GECO. In 2015, we reinforced our position in the French-speaking region of Switzerland with the acquisition of Domicim, and we entered the German-speaking regions of Switzerland in 2019 through the acquisition of Gribi. As of December 31, 2020, we have 32 branches in Switzerland and all of our operations were managed under DBS Group which includes ten recognizable brands Domicim, Brolliet, Duc-Sarrasin, Elitim, Batiline, Facilitim, Immosure, Gribi, GUINNARD and Bruchez & Gaillard. While we offer all of our primary services in Switzerland, our Brokerage business is characterized by transactions on whole buildings (sales in blocs), rather than individual units. We are also involved in sales of new buildings for promoters. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our operations in Switzerland generated €67.3 million in revenue. _Germany_ We entered the German market in 2003 through the acquisition of FONCIA VOW Verwaltungsorganisation für die Wohnungswirtschaft GmbH & Co.KG. Our dynamic external growth policy enabled us to establish our presence in Germany, and our latest acquisitions include Vegis and Prazisa in June and July 2019, Sogertec in October 2020 and Paul Immobilien in September 2020. We operate under the Foncia Deutschland brand, with a presence in 57 branches and we are recognized as a leader in Joint Property Management in a highly fragmented market composed of relatively small local players. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our operations in Germany generated €44.0 million in revenue. _Belgium_ We entered the Belgium market under the Trevi brand, which we acquired in May 2013 through a reverse takeover that enabled us to retain a successful local management team. We have 12 branches in Belgium, which are primarily located in the greater Brussels area, as well as in Flanders. We believe we are one of the largest residential real estate services group in Belgium and now operate under the OP Brand. In December 2020, we acquired OP to strengthen our service offerings in Belgium. The acquisition of OP will allow us to enter the Luxembourg market through its branches in the country. For the year ended December 31, 2020, our operations in Belgium generated €14.8 million in revenue.

Esset Management Esset Management provides property management services (jointly owned property management and rental services) for B2B customers such as national and international insurance, real estate and financial institutions. Our other ancillary services, Digital businesses and B2B businesses generated revenues of €53.3 million, €42.8 million and €34.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, respectively.

Digital transformation is at the heart of our operations and we believe it will improve the efficiency of our operations and commercial development, while providing unique and differentiated services to customers. From ----- inception, we have appreciated the importance of creating an efficient platform in order to better serve our customers, and understand the dynamics of our market and improve our employees responsiveness and efficiency. IT systems impact virtually all aspects of our business, including record keeping, customer information processing and storage, data security, marketing and sales, compliance logistics, and practice and performance management. Our IT strategy is driven by the dual goals of promoting growth of our business while ensuring data security. Our most recent digital innovation is Millenium, our new enterprise resource planning (“ERP”) system that we developed in-house, and we launched a go-live version of it in March 2020 at one of our branches in France. We have invested significant resources in Millenium, including a team of 80 developers and specialized professionals in order to build this innovative and advanced real estate platform, and we aim to roll it out across our branches in France in 2022. Millenium includes numerous functionalities and unifies a number of our IT functions at our head office under one centralized database. It is managed by an experienced team of information specialists. Business applications for each of our activities have been developed with Millenium, including our Joint Property Management business, Lease Management and Renting business, and Brokerage Business, as well as our accounting department, support call center and web and mobile applications. Millenium is equipped with an application interface program, which is a technology that allows for a direct access to other software solutions, startups, and business partners. For example, Millenium is connected to Kyriba, an online platform for viewing bank transaction in real time, which we use to manage our Joint Property Management cash transactions involving approximately 116,000 bank accounts. Millenium also functions with Docapost, an online, information technology company, which we utilize to collect and scan checks, and send and receive approximately 8.8 million letters and invoices per year. Millenium will provide, among other features, (i) increased digitization of activities, including the ability to use online signatures and receive digital payments, (ii) greater transparency with our customers, as employee progress on customer matters can be seen in real time and customer calls are tracked using tickets, (iii) significant automation of the accounting activities, (iv) the ability to better leverage our customer database to create inter-business synergies in compliance with European GDPR regulations, and (v) standardized processes across our businesses and substantial efficiencies due to a high degree of automation. Millenium also includes MyFoncia, a web and mobile app platform designed to improve customer experience through automation, digitization, and improved productivity for our customers to use for all of their service needs. In parallel to the deployment of Millenium, we are in the process of designing a new operational model called Agency of the Future which will be implemented following the roll-out of Millenium in France in 2022. Agency of the Future will utilize Millenium to reorganize the residential real estate services and aims to improve client satisfaction, reducing our customer churn rate and, in turn, leading to greater opportunities for organic growth. See “Summary—Our Strengths—Continuous investments in operational improvement through our _innovative technology platforms reinforces our competitive position and provides sustainable efficiency gains.”_ In the coming years, we plan to fully digitalize all business lines, internal processes, and our customer relationship management. In addition, we aim to increase our use of big data, artificial intelligence and IoT and continue to further automate our accounting. We believe that the improved standardization and digitization Millenium offers, will allow us to reduce administrative inefficiencies and achieve greater productivity. In addition, we believe that Millenium will enable us to achieve greater organization among our businesses allowing our employees to focus on customer satisfaction with the potential to lead to improved customer retention. It may also lead to new business opportunities, which could include big data or machine learning and licensing opportunities.

The real estate sector is responsible for approximately 25% of greenhouse gas emissions in France and plays a decisive role in the fight against climate change. The environmental impact of a building is influenced by three factors, including: (i) the performance of the building itself; (ii) the management and the maintenance of its equipment; and (iii) occupant behaviors. Our objective is to improve our impact on the environment and our commitment is driven by these three factors. We are focused on promoting energy renovation, developing more sustainable building management by measuring the energy consumption of our park and setting targets to improve future performance, raising awareness, and supporting our customers in making better use of resources.

We have over 134 and 131 branches dedicated to our RRES and Brokerage businesses, respectively, and 242 branches dedicated to both businesses throughout France and over 101 branches in Switzerland, Germany, and Belgium and, by the nature of our activity, we aim to contribute to the economic development of the communities in which we operate. We wish to assume and reaffirm our role as a partner and supporter of our customers and other stakeholders at the local and national levels, and aim to accomplish this through a number of measures. For example, by strengthening and enhancing our territorial anchoring, focusing on our recruitment efforts, concentrating on our choice of and support from our suppliers and reinforcing our commitment as a good corporate citizen. We also seek to develop a dialogue with our stakeholders and improve our communication on topics of interest to our stakeholders.

We service the homes of more than 4.7 million people in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium and, more recently, Luxembourg. As a key local player, we are committed to sustainable housing improved well-being, and better living for our customers, tenants, residents, communities, and other stakeholders in the residential real estate sector. We achieve this through our corporate social responsibility strategy, which is based on three key commitments: supporting sustainable energy in the buildings and dwellings we manage, improving the wellbeing of our customers in ensuring fair and non-discriminatory access to housing and assisting local communities. ----- From this mission stems the responsibility to provide solutions to environmental and social issues in our sector, and to contribute to more sustainable lifestyles. We have developed a number of ESG initiatives that measure and aim to improve on annual basis. For example, track our carbon footprint and aim to reduce it each year. We also closely consider the impact that our clients, contractors and suppliers have on the environment and we aim to work with those who seek to improve efficiency, conserve natural resources and reduce waste and emissions. In addition, we focus on energy transition of buildings under management by developing services and solutions to enable our clients to renovate and finance their dwellings. In 2021, one of our goals related to corporate social responsibility is to ensure that all of our building managers are systematically trained to lead such renovation projects and partner with clients and employees who demonstrate a commitment to the environment.

Subsection Title: Well-being of our Customers and Employees
Subsubsection Text: The majority of our business lines have low customer concentration. Our Lease Management and Renting, and Brokerage businesses are focused almost exclusively on serving individual customers. Our Joint Property Management business is focused on serving condominium corporations, which are primarily individual entities, rather than on B2B master agreements with institutional property customers. Of our businesses, Esset has the highest customer concentration. Esset’s largest customer represented 9% of its total revenues for the year ended December 30, 2020.

Subsection Title: Well-being of our Customers and Employees
Subsubsection Text: In 2020, we employed approximately 9,145 full time employees in our operations in France and approximately 1,430 full time employees outside of France. Despite the macroeconomic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, we added 884 full-time, permanent employees to our headcount in 2020. The majority of our employees work full-time employees; however, we have increasingly relied on temporary employees, including hourly, parttime, and temporary workers, to better adapt to the seasonality of our business. ----- The following table shows the average number of employees as of December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018:

Subsection Title: Well-being of our Customers and Employees
Subsubsection Text: We are aware of the rapid changes in lifestyles and ways of living in Europe, and we aim to actively contribute to the improvement of the quality of life of our customers and our employees. This involves securing not only a healthy living and working environment, but also a better understanding of the societal transformations at work including developments in the digital space, new uses, and the development of associated responses. Finally, we believe a commitment to quality of life also implies implementing concrete actions against discrimination, particularly in terms of access to housing and the fight against absentee landlords.

Average headcount – France ............................................................ 9,145 8,708 8,181 Average headcount – International ................................................... 1,430 983 835 We believe our people are fundamental to our continued success, as their skills and dedication enable us to grow and lead the market. We invest, and will continue to invest, in the development of our employees. For example, we provide training on company policies such as data protection and privacy, health and safety, antidiscrimination, ethics, sustainability and anti-bribery, among others. In addition, we believe the implementation of Millenium will result in productivity and efficiency gains, such as the automation of processes and controls, that will lead to streamlined procedures and settings for our front office and administrative staff. We cooperate with local unions, employee representatives, health, safety and working conditions committee and work councils in France where these representative bodies are active. In these jurisdictions, we normally have framework agreements or other general agreements in place, which are agreed through discussions with the works councils and compliant with local labor laws. These agreements govern, among other things, working conditions, working hours and the definition of tariff groups. These agreements can be negotiated for a limited or unlimited term, and can be cancelled by either party in favor of renegotiation. These bodies have clearly defined powers and we are required to consult and inform their members on a periodic basis about the implementation of projects relating to the situation of our employees. We are also required to consult our work council for the acquisition we are contemplating and for the integration of our acquired businesses. As we typically complete multiple acquisitions every month, we have, therefore, agreed to meet with our work council on a monthly basis to specifically discuss potential acquisitions and the integration of the recently completed acquisitions. We believe we have good relationships with our employees, and open and constructive working relationships with such employee representation bodies across our various regions.

We have been, and may from time to time be, a party to legal disputes and administrative proceedings within the scope of our business activities. For example, we are currently involved in certain legal proceeding initiated against us for alleged losses brought on behalf of lessees related to over charges for receiving notices to pay. The court declared the association’s claim inadmissible. The claimant appealed the decision and this appeal is scheduled for March 2021. We have not recorded a provision for this matter. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we are not involved in any material claims, lawsuits, investigations, or proceedings, and there are no such material claims, lawsuits, investigations or proceedings threatened against us. See “Risk Factors—Risks _Relating to Our Business and Industry—We are subject to various litigation risks and may face financial liabilities and/or damage to our reputation as a result of litigation.”_

The French rental market is highly regulated. We are not subject to a specific regulatory framework that governs the operation of our business. However, our primary business offerings require that we comply with regulations affecting the real estate industry and maintain licenses in the various jurisdictions in which we operate and adhere to data protection standards. Like other market participants that operate in numerous jurisdictions and in various businesses, we must comply with a myriad of regulatory regimes. Some of the most significant regulations to which we are subject to include the European GDPR, the ALUR law, the ELAN the PINEL plan and the Hoguet law. For information about these regulations and their impact on our business, please see “Regulation.”

_France_ Our Paris offices serve as our group headquarters. They house our core group-wide and French operational, management and planning functions. We do not own any real estate and all of our properties are leased pursuant to leases on customary terms. In France, we had approximately 806 property leases, of which more than 30% are tacitly renewed, including our 134 and 131 branches dedicated to our RRES and Brokerage businesses and our 242 branches dedicated to ----- both businesses, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020. These contracts are managed using a dynamic approach directly in line with the operating performance of our branch network and real estate strategy. As at December 31, 2020, our key leases in France include the head office at Antony, Rue de Provence, Rue Raymond Losserand and Boulevard de Courcelles premises in Paris and the Esset Management’s premises at Courbevoie. _Switzerland, Germany and Belgium_ Our headquarters in Switzerland, Germany, and Belgium are located in Geneva, Berlin, and Brussels, respectively. Each office is responsible for the operations in their respective countries, excluding a few exceptions, such as M&A transactions. We do not own any real estate and all of our properties are leased pursuant to leases on customary terms. In Switzerland, Germany, and Belgium, we had approximately 260 property leases. As at December 31, 2020, our key leases outside of France are the Brolliet premises in Switzerland and the Vegis, Foncia Maiberger, and Foncia Deutschland premises in Germany. For a full discussion of our leases and accounting treatment, see “Management Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations— Certain changes in accounting standards and accounting policies—IFRS-16.”_

The real estate services market is highly fragmented, however, the industry has recently experienced a period of active consolidation marked by an increase in M&A activity and the emergence of larger companies. We compete for customers on the basis of customer service, service offerings, reputation, and the ability to tailor our services to the specific needs of a customer, and we believe our size and our unique, nationwide network sets us apart from our competitors. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We have _numerous local, regional and national competitors across all of our businesses and the geographies that we serve, and further industry consolidation, fragmentation or innovation could lead to significant future competition.” In France, our main competitors include Nexity, Citya, Square Habitat, and Credit Agricole_ Immobilier in the RRES market, BNP Paribas Real Estate and Nexity in the commercial property management market and Orpi, Century21, Citya, Guy Hoquet, and Laforet in the Brokerage market. In Switzerland, our largest competitors are Wincasa, Livit, and Privera, and in Belgium, we believe our largest competitor is Lamy (Nexity). In Germany, the largest market participant is ECE, focusing on the retail segment, followed by Strabag and Apleona with large commercial portfolios, and Capera, Treureal, and DIM on the residential side. For a further description of our industry and the competitive landscape in which we operate, see “Industry.”

We have registered several trademarks in France, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium, Luxembourg, and at the European Union Trademark Database. We regard our trademarks and other intellectual property as valuable assets in the marketing of our services, in particular, our “Foncia” trademark and the rights associated with our new Millenium ERP IP. However, as we operate distinct businesses and brands for our various service offerings and across geographies, we consider all of these core brands to be an integral part of our business, and we take appropriate action when necessary to protect them and, when necessary, enforce them. See “Risk Factors— _Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our brands and our reputation are key assets of our company, which will be affected by how we are perceived in the marketplace.”_

We have a number of insurance policies in place, including in connection with professional and civil responsibilities based on our role as a real estate services provider, premises damages, D&O, cyber, and ITrelated insurance. Some of our real estate servicing contracts require that we maintain certain levels of insurance. We believe we have adequate insurance coverage against material risks that are typically insured by similar companies with comparable risk exposure. Insurance coverage is regularly verified and adjusted when necessary; however, our insurance may not cover every potential risk associated with our business. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our insurance coverage may not be sufficient.”_ -----

_The market information presented in this section is taken directly or derived from the cited sources and extrapolations from third-party and publicly available data, including an industry report prepared by a leading consulting firm (an “international report provider”). Market data are inherently forward-looking and subject to uncertainty, and do not necessarily reflect actual market conditions. They are based on market research, which itself is based on market data sampling and judgments by the researchers about what types of products and competitors should be included in the relevant market. While we have compiled, extracted and reproduced market or other industry data from external sources, including third party or industry or general publications, the Issuers, the Guarantors or the Initial Purchasers have not independently verified such data. The market information derived from an international report provider was prepared in August 2019. Therefore, the market and industry data included below may not accurately reflect certain aspects of the current market and industry and should not be unduly relied upon. In particular, since the report was prepared prior to the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, it does not reflect the current or ultimate impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the industry. We do not intend to and do not assume any obligations to update any data, including industry and market data, set forth in this Offering Memorandum._ We are the European leader in the residential real estate services market, providing services to both individuals (“business-to-consumer” or “B2C”) and businesses (“business-to-business” or “B2B”), and have recently entered the commercial real estate services segment for B2B customers. We assist our residential and commercial customers at every stage of their property journey with competitive and comprehensive service offerings.

We are not subject to a specific regulatory framework that governs the operation of our business, although there are a number of regulations we must comply with as we deliver our primary service offerings to our customers. These regulations vary between one jurisdiction to another and also between our businesses. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our businesses, financial condition, results of operations and prospects could be adversely affected by new laws or regulations or by changes in existing laws or regulations or the application thereof. If we fail to comply with laws and regulations applicable to us, or make incorrect determinations in complex tax regimes, we may incur significant financial penalties.”_

We acquire and process personal data on customers and customers during the course of our activities and our databases contain personal data of customers and customers. Our ability to obtain, retain and process such personal data is governed by data protection and privacy regulations and guidance issued by, among others, the European Union, national regulators and, where applicable, recommendations and best practices developed by trade associations. The EU General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (“GDPR”)) became effective as of May 25, 2018. The GDPR provides a common framework for data protection and privacy and regulates the Processing and transfer of Personal Data in the European Union. In the course of our activities, we may be qualified as “Controllers,” or as “Processor,” as defined and governed by GDPR, depending on the services provided and the service agreement entered into. We established our compliance program with GDPR quite early and we comply with the GDPR obligations, and rights for individuals whose Personal Data we Process (“Data Subjects”), including, among others: - accountability and transparency obligations, requiring us to demonstrate and record compliance with the GDPR, including the maintenance of detailed records of Personal Data Processing activities; - appointment of a data protection officer, subject to the satisfaction of certain criteria; - requirements to Process Personal Data lawfully, fairly, and in a transparent manner, to Process Personal Data only to the extent necessary for the purposes required, maintain the accuracy of Personal Data, limit the retention of Personal Data for no longer than is necessary, and maintain appropriate technical and organizational security measures against unauthorized Processing or accidental loss, destruction or damage to Personal Data; - an obligation to provide clear notice of Personal Data Processing activities to Data Subjects, which must include, among other details: the identity of the Controller and the Processor; the nature and purpose of the Processing activities; the legal basis applicable to each Processing activity; the categories of Personal Data Processed, the recipients to whom the Personal Data are disclosed; the rights of the Data Subjects; and details of any cross-border transfers of Personal Data; - an obligation to include certain mandatory contractual terms in agreements with certain service providers which Process Personal Data on our behalf; - restrictions on the export of Personal Data to recipients located in countries outside of the European Economic Area; ----- - requirements to ensure, for each Processing activity, that either (i) there is a valid legal basis in place; or (ii) an exemption or derogation applies; - obligations to consider data protection issues with respect to the development of any new products or services which involve the Processing of Personal Data (“data protection by design”), and to ensure that by default, the amount of Personal Data Processed is limited to what is necessary in the context of the relevant Processing activity (“data protection by default”); - a requirement to undertake a data protection impact assessment with respect to Processing activities that are likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of relevant Data Subjects; - obligations to comply with the data protection rights conferred on Data Subjects including, in certain circumstances: a right of access to, and rectification of, Personal Data; a right to obtain restriction of Processing; a right to object to Processing; a right to request that Personal Data be transferred to another Controller; a right not to be subject to certain types of profiling or automated decision-making; and a right to request erasing Personal Data; and - an obligation to notify Personal Data Breaches to Supervisory Authorities without undue delay and no later than 72 hours after detection of the relevant Personal Data Breach, except where the Personal Data Breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of individuals, and an obligation to notify affected Data Subjects without undue delay, unless the Personal Data Breach is unlikely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of the affected Data Subjects. The GDPR has therefore strengthened the individual rights of individuals over their personal data and imposes strict requirements on companies processing personal data. In addition, the GDPR introduces fines for serious breaches of up to the higher of 4% of annual worldwide revenue or €20 million. The GDPR identifies a list of points to consider when determining the fine level to impose (including the nature, gravity and duration of the infringement). Data Subjects also have a right to compensation for financial or non-financial losses (e.g., distress) in certain circumstances. Data Subjects may bring complaints via the courts, or via Supervisory Authorities, or both, and in some circumstances may have a choice as to the EU Member State(s) in which they bring such claims. We accomplished a review of our data polices with the aim of minimizing data collection and storage so that only the appropriate amount of personal data required for any particular purpose is processed, and establishing protocols to destroy unnecessary datasets and anonymize data wherever possible. In addition, we have put in place and implemented rules, policies and procedures that we strive to maintain and improve, in order to ensure compliance with GDPR. These rules, policies and procedures are twofold: internal and external. These rules, policies and procedures, implemented at all levels of our business, apply to the processing of personal data, data storage, retention, preservation, maintenance, protection and management of personal data within the course of our business operations, as well as the transfer of personal data. Our legal team was intensely involved in the implementation of such rules, policies and procedures and reviewed our activities and operations to implement a legal framework that complies with the GDPR requirements. We believe that we are compliant in all material respects with applicable data protection regulations and we submitted all the relevant declarations to the national regulators, the CNIL (Commission Nationale de _l’Informatique et des Libertés) in France and the BfDI (Der Bundesbeauftragte für den Datenschutz und die Informationsfreiheit) in Germany and the APD (Autorité de protection des données) in Belgium. We have_ appointed a Data Protection Officer, who is registered with the relevant regulator and who is in charge of all aspects of GDPR for the applicable country and, in particular, maintains data processing registers. As used herein, “Personal Data” has the meaning set out in the GDPR, “Personal Data Breach” has the meaning set out in the GDPR, and “Processing” has the meaning set out in the GDPR, and the terms “Process” and “Processed” shall be construed accordingly. -----

As part of certain operations, we follow anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing standards set forth in the applicable local laws implementing Directive (EU) 2005/60/EC on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing. Our operations are also subject to requirements of local anti-money laundering laws. On May 20, 2015, Directive (EU) 2015/849 on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing, amending Regulation (EU) No 648/2012, and repealing Directive 2005/60/EC (the “4th AML Directive”) was adopted by the European Parliament and the Council. The 4th AML Directive enhances the current customer due diligence requirements and also imposes stricter sanctions with administrative fines of at least €5,000,000 or 10% of total annual turnover. Directive (EU) 2018/843 (the “5th AML Directive”), amending the 4th AML Directive, was adopted by the European Parliament and the Council on May 30, 2018 and since then Directive (EU) 2018/1673 (the “6th AML Directive”) has been introduced and went into effect for EU Member States on December 3, 2020.

The Hoguet law (Loi n°70-9 réglementant les conditions d’exercice des activités relatives à certaines opérations portant sur les immeubles et les fonds de commerce) was introduced in January 1970 and aimed at setting the legal framework for the profession of real estate agents in France and therefore applies to all of our employees who act as real estate agents on our behalf. The Hoguet law requires the execution of specific administrative formalities to be a professional real estate agent including: - holding a professional card (“carte professionnelle”) issued by the president of the territorial chamber of commerce and industry, which is subject to professional aptitude and morality conditions and is renewable every 3 years; - having a financial guarantee from a bank or professional organization for funds held in customer accounts and retaining professional liability insurance. In accordance with this law, we provide financial guarantees to customers equal to the maximum amount of funds held in their account. The customer’s deposit must be held in a third-party account and be guaranteed by a third party financial guarantor, such as Société de caution mutuelle des professions immobilières et foncières (SOCAF). This body guarantees reimbursement of any funds deposited with them for purchase. The name of the financial guarantor must be displayed in the agents office. Professional real estate agents must have a written mandate authorizing them to negotiate or enter into contracts on behalf of the owner or the property lessor. This mandate must therefore be finalized before any act of mediation or negotiation begins. This mandate must indicate the level of the fees or commission (honoraires) that will be payable and just who will pay it, the buyer or the seller. We maintain a register of such agreements with each agreement numbered and recorded in accordance with the Hoguet Law. Once the mandate is signed, the real estate agent is entitled to a commission in the event of the sale or lease of the property, subject to the mandate. The real estate agent’s right to commission is subject to multiple conditions and no sum of money may be demanded or remitted to the real estate agent before the transaction (i.e. sale, rental, etc.) is concluded and recorded in an act containing the commitment of the parties. The collection of a sum of money in violation of the Hoguet law is an offense punishable by up to two years’ imprisonment and a maximum fine of €30,000. -----

The ALUR law (Loi n°2014-366 pour l’accès au logement et un urbanisme rénové) was introduced in March, 2014 and aimed at improving access to housing and providing increased protection to tenants in the housing market within large cities and urban areas of France. The introduction of the ALUR law has had a number of effects in the way we conduct our operations across our core service offerings, including: - _Joint property management: The_ ALUR law imposes a mandatory obligation on us as joint property managers to register each joint property we manage with the national matriculation register if not yet registered and also requires us to create two dedicated bank accounts for each joint property we manage. The law also introduces model joint property agreements that are applicable in our joint property management service. - _Rental management and lettings: The ALUR law regulates which fees can and cannot be charged to tenants and how fees should be shared between tenants and landlords. Depending on the property’s location, it imposes a limit on the renting commission paid by tenants to an amount that must not exceed between €11-€15 per square meter. In addition to this fee cap, tenants can no longer be charged penalties for breaches to rental agreements or for rent payment notices. The law also introduced restrictions on the yearly rental escalations for residential properties in Paris. It also standardized certain administrative requirements for rental contracts through means such as model contracts and rental declaration forms for residential lettings.

The ELAN law (Loi n°2018-1021 _portant évolution du logement, de l’aménagement et du numérique) was introduced in November 2018 and aimed to build more housing, simplify standards, protect the most fragile tenants and to introduce digital transitions in the service of tenants. The law created a new lease called a “mobility lease,” which is a non-renewable lease between one to ten months for certain categories of tenants, such as students and trainees, with flexible termination terms that allow the termination of a lease by the tenant upon the provision of only one months’ notice. Within municipalities of more than 50,000 inhabitants, where there is an imbalance between the supply and demand of housing, the law also imposes an obligation on landlords to set their rent within a range defined by the authorities each year. The introduction of the ELAN law has had a number of effects in the way we conduct our operations across our core service offerings, as it created an incentive for short-term rentals which may reduce the predictability of our revenue.

The PINEL plan refers to multiple laws introduced since 2014, which aimed to design and promote the construction of new build properties in designated areas. The PINEL plan provided income tax deductions to private individuals who invested in these new build properties, provided the properties were put up for rent for at least six years. This plan has had a direct impact on fees that property managers can charge for their services. For example, it restricts the freedom of the landlord and tenant to contract with regards to expenses which cannot be recovered from tenants. Non-recoverable expenses include structural repairs and repairs under article 606 of the French Civil Code, taxes such as the “Territorial Economic Contribution” where the landlord is personally liable for payment and the management fees of the landlord linked to rents management. As a result, landlords are no longer able to recover fees from tenants for certain expenses for major repairs, regional economic contribution taxes and fees related to rental management. The PINEL plan also introduced rules governing commercial leases including rules limiting the ability of a landlord to impose rental increases and granting tenants a right of first refusal in the event of the sale of leased commercial property. The plan provides for the mandatory use of national indexes provided by the national statistics bureau of France (INSEE) for the calculation of revised rents for commercial activity premises and is applicable during the life of the lease.

Subsubsection Title: Eviction Laws and the Winter Truce
Subsubsection Text: _Eviction Laws_ On July 9, 1991 a new law (Loi n° 91-650 du 9 juillet 1991 portant réforme des procédures civiles d’exécution) introduced the eviction regime into the law of civil enforcement proceedings. This law introduces, in article ----- L411-1 of the Code of Civil Enforcement Procedures (code de procédure civile), the condition that an eviction can only take place by virtue of a court decision where the occupiers were notified. A tenant can be evicted for failure to pay the rent when due and also for breaches of lease agreements. In the event that the tenant fails to pay rent, the landlord is required to follow various mandatory steps, including filing of a payment instruction notice (Commandement de payer). This notice sets a time limit for a tenant to pay the outstanding rental and must delivered by a bailiff (huissier de justice). The time limits provided by this notice are two months for a residential lease and one month for a commercial lease. If the tenant fails to pay the rental arears within the stipulated time, the landlord can apply to the court for the cancellation of the lease. Upon the determination of the court proceedings, the court will often provide for an installment payment of the rent arrears and stipulate that the tenant voluntarily move out within a period of two months. The bailiff and the police will forcibly remove the tenant if the tenant fails to move out within this period. _Winter Truce_ The winter truce is the period during which any tenant eviction measure is suspended. This rule was introduced on July 9, 1991 (Loi n° 91-650 du 9 juillet 1991 portant réforme des procédures civiles d’exécution). The regime provides that a landlord can begin proceedings during the winter truce to seek to evict tenants who do not pay rent, or who refuse to leave after receiving the contractual notice period. However, eviction requires a court order from a judge, which can be appealed by the tenant. Once a final judgment is made, the landlord is able to give an eviction order to the tenant with a minimum notice period of at least two months for the tenant to vacate the leased premises (the length of this period will depend on the court order). Notwithstanding the foregoing, the eviction of the tenant cannot take place during the winter truce, which is in effect between November 1 and March 1 of the following year. In 2014, the ALUR law expanded the winter truce period to five full months, from November 1 to March 31 of the following year. This period was extended to July 10 as an exceptional measure for 2020 only, as part of the emergency measures taken by the French government in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

In France, the parties are free to enter into any agreed terms regarding rental deposits. The terms of the deposit should explain what the deposit is expected to cover. For example, the rental deposit terms can provide that the rent, repairs, service charge, dilapidations and rates are covered. These terms could also be widely drafted to cover any liabilities owed by the tenant at the end of the tenancy. The amount of the deposit is, in part, regulated by the law which provides that the maximum amount of the deposit for unfurnished properties will be one month, with no maximum for furnished properties. The rent deposit paid at the beginning of the tenancy must be refunded at the end of the rental period. The landlord or their representative has one month to refund the security deposit if the final inventory is consistent with the initial inventory and if there is no outstanding rent or tax to be paid. This period may be extended to two months if there are differences between the initial and final inventories. The time frame to refund the deposit begins on the day the tenant returns the keys for the premises (in person or by registered letter with acknowledgement of receipt). In the event the security deposit is not refunded, the outgoing tenant must send a formal demand to the landlord by registered letter with acknowledgement of receipt. If, despite this action being taken, the landlord refuses to refund the security deposit, the tenant can refer the case to the regional mediation commission (Commission _Départementale de Conciliation). If this mediation process proves unsuccessful, the tenant can then go before_ the small-claims court (juge de proximité) if the value of the claim is less than €4,000, or the district court (tribunal d’instance). If the amount of the security deposit exceeds €4,000, the tenant must send an assignation, which will be prepared and delivered by a bailiff to the landlord. -----

As a real estate business operating in France with a primary focus on residential real estate property management and real estate property transaction brokerage, we are subject to the general application of the laws and regulations provided below. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our _businesses, financial condition, results of operations and prospects could be adversely affected by new laws or regulations or by changes in existing laws or regulations or the application thereof. If we fail to comply with laws and regulations applicable to us, or make incorrect determinations in complex tax regimes, we may incur significant financial penalties.”_

Flamingo Lux II SCA is organized as a partnership limited by shares (societe en commandite par actions) under the laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, and is registered with the Luxembourg Trade and Companies’ Register under number B206769. It was incorporated on June 16, 2016. The business address for the Senior Notes Issuer is 46 A, avenue J.F. Kennedy, 1855 Luxembourg, Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. The Senior Notes Issuer is a holding company and the direct parent entity of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. It has no revenue-generating activities of its own and does not have any business operations, material assets (other than the shares it owns in the Senior Secured Notes Issuer) or liabilities (other than those incurred in connection with the Offering). Pursuant to Luxembourg law governing a partnership limited by shares and the Senior Notes Issuer’s articles of association, the Senior Notes Issuer’s affairs are managed by a General Partner (associé _commanditaire)._ Set forth below are the names, ages and titles of the General Partner and executive officers of the Senior Notes Issuer:

Foncia Management is organized as a simplified joint stock company (société par actions simplifiée) under the laws of France, and is registered in France under the sole identification number 820 204 766 RCS Nanterre. It was incorporated on October 11, 2016. The business address for the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is 13 Avenue Lebrun 92160 Antony, France. Pursuant to French law governing simplified joint stock company and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s articles of association, its affairs are managed by a President (président) and one or more managing directors (directeurs généraux) (collectively with the President, the “Management Board”). The Management Board of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is under the control of a supervisory board (conseil de _surveillance) (the “Supervisory Board”). For a discussion on the Supervisory Board, see “—Supervisory Board.”_ As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Finellas SAS. (a company directly controlled and managed by Mr. Philippe Salle) serves as President of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. For a biography of Mr. Philippe Salle, see “—Management Board.” Pursuant to the articles of association of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, when the President or a member of the Supervisory Board is a legal person, then such legal person shall be represented by his legal representative or any other natural person specially authorized to represent it. When a legal person is appointed President, its officers are subject to the same conditions and obligations and incur the same civil and criminal liabilities as if they were President in their own name of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, without prejudice to the joint and several liability of the legal person they manage. _Management Board_ The Management Board is composed of the President and the managing directors appointed by the Supervisory Board of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer for an indefinite period. Set forth below are the names, ages and titles of key Management Board members:
