The measures taken by governments to stem the spread of the virus had a far-reaching impact on the Group’s operating activities during the year. In particular, in order to comply with social distancing recommendations, all Foncia Group premises (branches and head offices) were closed to the public and to employees for much of the year. This directly impacted the Group’s revenue, margins and operating cash flows. The health restrictions limited activities relating to the transactions and lettings businesses, as well as incidental fees earned on jointly owned properties within and outside France. Despite these difficulties, all of the Group’s businesses managed to continue operating. As from the very outset of the crisis, the Group put in place a series of measures to ensure that it could continue to conduct its business and to protect the health of its employees (and clients) in compliance with government requirements: ✓ From a human resources and organisational perspective, homeworking was systematically introduced for all ###### employees whose work could be performed from home and who had the necessary tools available. ✓ From a financial management perspective, the Group swiftly took measures to cut costs and also reviewed its ###### investment programmes. These measures included:  keeping a close watch on service performance, freezing non-strategic investments and discontinuing any temporary employment contracts not deemed necessary to conduct the Group’s essential business;   maintaining a tight rein on administrative expenses. In this context, the Group incurred total costs of €1.8 million (sanitizing gels, masks, etc.) in the period to protect its employees, which were recorded within non-recurring operating items. Within the scope of exceptional tax measures introduced by the French government, the Group also requested the earlier refund of its tax receivables and adopted several short-time working arrangements allowed by the government in France and in Switzerland: ✓ In France, 2,419 employees were furloughed, primarily in the transactions, digital, and rental management businesses. Compensation for furlough schemes represented €6.1 million in the year.  ✓ In Switzerland, the Group was eligible for the Reduced Working Hours scheme (“RHT”), which allowed it to reduce or interrupt the working time of affected employees. Unemployment insurance covers 80% of the time not worked, thereby helping to avoid a loss in income for those concerned. Compensation for this measure represented CHF 1.3 million (€1.2 million) in the year. Aid received in respect of short-time working arrangements is treated as an operating subsidy within the meaning of IAS 20 and recognised as a deduction from personnel costs (see Note 5.5). In order to safeguard its independence, the Group did not apply for any government-backed loan (with the exception of the €1.4 million loan granted to its subsidiary Efficity, repaid in December 2020), and made all of its tax, social and operating payments as they fell due. In the context of the crisis, the Group reviewed the assumptions and estimates which were used as a basis for measuring certain statement of financial position and profit and loss items. As a result, it updated the financial forecasting assumptions for its CGUs which are used as the basis for its impairment tests. No impairment was recognised against the Group’s assets as a result of these tests. Note 4.1.2 provides more details on the impairment testing approach. ----- ###### Partial repayment of the shareholder loan On 13 November 2020, the Group repaid €16 million of its shareholder loan. Follow-up on the accounting treatment adopted for the Leemo/Primonial partial asset transfer By way of reminder, on 30 November 2018 Primonial acquired a 40% equity interest in Leemo (a wholly-owned Foncia subsidiary) via a partial asset transfer consisting of Primonial’s entire, stand-alone sales brokerage division for new and existing properties. Leemo issued a total of 33,624 preferred shares to Primonial as consideration for this transfer. Pursuant to IAS 32, since the basis on which the shares issued could be converted did not represent a fixed basis, the shares did not meet the definition of an equity instrument. Accordingly, they were classified within financial liabilities by default and included within non-current borrowings and debt for €7 million. Until the preferred shares are converted into ordinary shares, they are considered financial liabilities to be remeasured at fair value at each reporting date, with any changes in fair value taken to profit or loss. The fair value of the preferred shares is based on both the estimated value of Leemo and on the expected conversion ratio. The Group is therefore required to assess the convertibility (conversion ratio) for these preferred shares in 2021 based on data for 2020, which depends on changes in the respective contributions of the Foncia Group and Primonial to Leemo’s net revenue. The conversion ratio will be estimated in line with changes in the business contributed by both groups. In the event of an outperformance, Primonial could increase its interest in Leemo to 49%, or a maximum of 48,457 shares, via the transfer of additional ordinary Leemo shares. In the event of an underperformance, the Foncia Group would be eligible for cash compensation of up to €2 million and the shares would be converted at a rate of one ordinary share for one preferred share. Median scenarios also assume different conversion rates that could lead Primonial to hold between 40% and 49% of Leemo’s ordinary shares after the preferred shares have been converted. Based on 2020 revenue figures, Leemo’s performance was favourable to the Foncia Group and (once the financial statements have been approved in 2021), the Group can therefore consider that (i) the preferred shares will be converted at a rate of one preferred share to one ordinary share, and (ii) the Primonial group will be liable to pay the Foncia Group cash compensation of €2 million. On this basis, the €7 million financial liability was reduced to zero against an income entry within non-recurring operating items for €7 million, with €2 million in non-recurring accrued income recognised in respect of the compensation receivable from Primonial. In light of the level of business recorded following the transfer of the division by Primonial, the value of the client relationship was written down in full against a non-recurring expense in an amount of €7 million. NOTE 3. ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND METHODS General principles used to prepare the financial statements The accounting policies described in these notes have been applied consistently to all periods presented in the consolidated financial statements, with the exception of the amendments adopted as described in Note 3.2.3, effective as of 1 January 2020. The consolidated financial statements are prepared on a historical cost basis, except for assets held for sale and related liabilities, measured in accordance with IFRS 5, and certain financial instruments carried at fair value or amortised cost in accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9. The consolidated financial statements of Foncia Management at 31 December 2020 were adopted by the Supervisory Board at its meeting held on 2 March 2021, and will be submitted to shareholders for approval at the General Meeting on 23 March 2021. ----- ###### They are presented in thousands of euros and amounts are rounded up or down to the nearest thousand unless otherwise specified. Consequently, the sum of these amounts may differ slightly from the total amounts reported. Accounting standards 3.2.1. Application of the IFRIC IC’s final agenda decision on the term of certain leases In its 2019 financial statements, the Group had not finalised the analyses and modifications necessary to implement the IFRS IC’s November 2019 agenda decision on IFRS 16 lease terms. As a result, it had adopted a legal approach when calculating the enforceable term of its property leases, as permitted by the AMF in its recommendations for companies preparing their 2019 financial statements. The IFRS IC agenda decision provides clarification when calculating lease terms and applies to commercial leases in France among others: ➢ It reiterates that the lease term used to measure lease liabilities is understood as the enforceable period of the lease, since a lease is no longer enforceable when the lessee and lessor are each entitled to terminate the lease without the consent of the other party and without incurring “no more than an insignificant” penalty. Consequently, the lessor’s unilateral right to terminate the lease is not sufficient to determine the enforceable term of the lease. ➢ It also clarifies that in order to determine the enforceable period of a lease and assess whether a penalty is “no more than insignificant” within the meaning of IFRS 16.B34, companies should consider the broader economics of the lease contract and not only contractual termination payments. The notion of a penalty must therefore include all economic incentives not to terminate the lease. In its decision, the IFRS IC also reiterates that the lease term used to measure the lease liability must be consistent with the useful life adopted for non-removable leasehold improvements. On 3 July 2020, the Board of the French accounting standards-setter (Autorité des Normes Comptables – ANC) published a new position statement on calculating the term of “3-6-9”-type commercial leases in France. This new statement supersedes the statement issued on 16 February 2018. In this revised statement, the ANC concludes that the lease term should reflect the term during which the lessee is reasonably certain to continue the lease, and that when the legal term of the lease is nine years, the term of the lease is “generally nine years at inception”. On this basis, the Group launched a project in 2020 to review (and re-estimate, where appropriate) the terms of its property leases in light of the IFRS IC’s decision and the ANC’s revised position statement. This project led the Group to increase the lease term for its automatically renewable property leases in France to three years due to (i) the need for the business to continue operating which acts as an incentive to continue the initial lease, but also to (ii) the Group’s strongly proactive and opportunistic real estate strategy in streamlining its property portfolio (notably during restructuring operations resulting from its acquisitions). By way of reminder, the Group had adopted the legally defensible term of a lease in its 2019 financial statements, i.e., nine months at the date of first-time application of IFRS 16 (1 January 2019) and six months at the 31 December 2019 reporting date. Based on analyses performed by the Group of its other categories of leased assets, it did not identify the need to revise the lease terms. This is because the enforceable term of these other leases is generally aligned with the IFRS 16 lease term, since the economic penalties that would be incurred if the lease were to be terminated are insignificant or non-existent. ----- ###### In accordance with IAS 8 and in the absence of any transitional provisions to the contrary, any changes resulting from a final agenda decision issued by the IFRS IC are retrospectively applicable. Accordingly, the impacts of modifying lease terms as a direct result of applying the IFRS IC’s agenda decision were recognized in the statement of financial position with retroactive effect from:  the date of first-time application of IFRS 16 (1 January 2019) for leases in progress at that date;  the inception of the lease for new leases, or the date of modification for leases modified after 1 January 2019. The consolidated financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2019 were also restated retrospectively to reflect the application of this decision. These restatements are referred to throughout this document as “2019 (restated)”. Basis of preparation of financial information Pursuant to Regulation (EC) No. 1606/2002 of 19 July 2002 as amended by Regulation (EC) No. 297/2008 of 11 March 2008, the 2020 consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the international financial reporting standards (IFRS) and interpretations issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) as adopted by the European Union and applicable at the reporting date. Information for the comparative period was prepared in accordance with the same accounting policies.  The full text of the standards adopted by the European Union can be consulted on the European Commission’s website: https://ec.europa.eu/info/business-economy-euro/company-reporting-and-auditing/company-reporting_en Where there is no specific guidance from IFRS standards or IFRIC interpretations, the Group refers to other IFRS standards dealing with similar issues or to the Conceptual Framework, in accordance with IAS 8 – Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and Errors. At the end of the reporting period, there was no difference between the IFRS used to prepare these financial statements and the standards adopted by the IASB and applicable for the period presented. The Group does not apply IFRS standards that had not yet been adopted by the European Union at the reporting date. It chose not to early adopt the standards, amendments and interpretations not mandatorily applicable at the reporting date. The accounting policies and bases of measurement applied to prepare these consolidated financial statements are described in Note 3.4 below. The consolidated financial statements include the financial statements of Foncia Management, the entities it controls (subsidiaries) and the entities which are accounted for by the equity method. Changes in accounting standards Main IFRS standards, amendments and interpretations in force within the European Union and mandatorily applicable as of 1 January 2020 The accounting policies and bases of measurement used by the Group to prepare its consolidated financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2020 are identical to those used by the Group at 31 December 2019, except for the following standards and amendments, which are mandatorily applicable as of January 1, 2020: - Amendments to IAS 1 and IAS 8 – Definition of Material - Amendments to IFRS 9, IAS 39 and IFRS 7 – Interest Rate Benchmark Reform - Amendment to IFRS 3 – Definition of a Business - Amendments to References to the Conceptual Framework in IFRS Standards - Amendment to IFRS 16 – Covid-19-Related Rent Concessions. ###### The first-time application of these amendments did not have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements. Other standards, amendments and interpretations applicable after 31 December 2020 and not early adopted by the Group ❖ Standards, amendments and interpretations not yet adopted by the European Union but available for early adoption in 2020 - Amendments to IAS 1 – Classification of Liabilities as Current or Non-Current - Amendment to IAS 37 – Onerous Contracts – Cost of Fulfilling a Contract - Amendment to IFRS 3 – Updating a Reference to the Conceptual Framework - Annual Improvements to IFRS Standards 2018-2020 Cycle – Minor amendments: ###### ─ IFRS 9: Fees in the ‘10 per cent test’ for derecognition of liabilities ─ IFRS 41: Taxation in fair value measurements of biological assets ─ IFRS 16: Elimination of illustrative example 13 accompanying IFRS 16 ─ Amendment to IFRS 10 and IAS 28: Sales or contributions of assets between an investor and its associate/joint venture • Amendments to IFRS 4 – Extension of the Temporary Exemption from Applying IFRS 9 ❖ Standards, amendments and interpretations not available for early adoption - Amendments to IAS 16 – Property, Plant and Equipment – Proceeds before Intended Use - IFRS 17 – Insurance Contracts - Annual Improvements to IFRS Standards 2018-2020 Cycle – Minor amendments: ###### ─ IFRS 1: Measurement of translation adjustments Subject to their adoption, these standards, interpretations and amendments are mandatorily applicable for reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2021. The Group is currently analysing the potential impacts of applying the requirements set out in these texts for the first time. ----- ###### 3.2.4. Use of management estimates in applying the Group’s accounting standards In preparing its financial statements, the Group is required to make estimates and assumptions that may affect the measurement and presentation of certain assets, liabilities or contingent liabilities at the end of the reporting period, as well as the reported amounts of income and expenses for the period. Estimates and underlying assumptions are determined based on information available at the end of the reporting period and are reviewed on a regular basis in light of past experience and other factors deemed reasonable given the current circumstances. These estimates serve as the basis for measuring the carrying amount of assets and liabilities that cannot be obtained directly from other sources. The uncertainty caused by the Covid-19 health crisis has increased the significance of the estimates and assumptions used to prepare the 2020 financial statements. Where appropriate, the Group carried out sensitivity analyses on its key estimates, details of which are reported in the notes concerned. The estimates made by the Group in preparing its consolidated financial statements are based on a going concern assumption and relate primarily to the items described below. ▪ Recoverable amount of goodwill, other intangible assets and property, plant and equipment The estimates and assumptions made to determine the recoverable amount of goodwill, intangible assets, and property, plant and equipment relate mainly to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. Note 4.1.2 sets out the assumptions used to calculate future cash flows and determine the discount rates to be applied in measuring the recoverable amounts of these assets. Sensitivity analyses were also performed and are described in the same note. ▪ Measurement of leases IFRS 16 requires entities to use certain key estimates, which include:  whether an option to extend or terminate a lease is reasonably certain to be exercised;  the lease term;  the appropriate discount rate to be used to calculate future lease payments;  the specific selling price of any lease components and non-lease components contained in the contract. The main assumptions used by the Group to prepare its 2020 financial statements are described in Note 4.4.3. ▪ Measurement of assets and liabilities relating to post-employment plans The Group operates both defined contribution and defined benefit plans. Obligations under these plans are calculated using the projected unit credit method, which is based on assumptions regarding the discount rate, future increases in salary, employee turnover, life expectancy and the rate of increase in healthcare costs. Note 4.12 sets out the assumptions used to measure these obligations. The Group considers that the actuarial assumptions used are appropriate and justified in the current environment. However, the corresponding obligations may change if these assumptions also change. ▪ Basis for determining the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of a business combination The estimates and assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount of these identifiable assets and liabilities relate in particular to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. Any changes in these assumptions could impact the recoverable amount. ----- ###### In the absence of IFRS guidance for a specific transaction, event or condition, the Group uses its judgement to define and apply accounting policies that will result in relevant, fair and comparable information to ensure that the financial statements:  present a true and fair view of Foncia Group's financial position, financial performance and cash flows;  reflect the economic substance of transactions;  are neutral, prudent and comprehensive in all material respects. Detailed disclosures in this regard are provided in the notes to the consolidated financial statements. Basis of measurement 3.3.1. Basis of consolidation Details of the main consolidated companies at 31 December 2020 are provided in Note 13 “Scope of consolidation”. Controlled entities Companies directly or indirectly controlled by the Group are fully consolidated. Control exists when the Group is exposed to risks or is entitled to variable returns from its involvement with the entity in question and has the ability to affect those returns through its power over the entity. Control is analysed whenever facts and circumstances indicate that one or more of the inputs used to assess control has changed. A subsidiary is consolidated as from the date control is acquired, which is usually upon signature of the share transfer and disposal agreements (see “Accounting for ongoing acquisitions” below). Consolidation ceases when control is relinquished. Any interest in the subsidiary that is not directly or indirectly attributable to the Group is recognised within non-controlling interests. Profits and losses and each component of other comprehensive income relating to subsidiaries are allocated to owners of the parent and non-controlling interests, even if this results in non-controlling interests having a deficit balance. Changes in the percentage interest held in subsidiaries that do not lead to a change in control are treated as equity transactions, since the transactions take place between owners acting in their capacity as owners. The impact of these transactions is shown in equity net of tax and does not therefore impact consolidated profit or loss. These transactions are also shown in the statement of cash flows under cash flows relating to investing activities. Investments in equity-accounted companies (associates and joint ventures) Associates are entities over which the Group exercises significant influence. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating policy decisions of the entity without controlling or jointly controlling those policies. A joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to its net assets. Joint control of an arrangement only exists when decisions about the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. Profits, losses, assets and liabilities of associates or joint ventures are accounted for by the equity method in the Group’s consolidated financial statements. Under the equity method, the investment in an associate or joint venture is initially recognised at acquisition cost and subsequently adjusted for the Group’s interest in the profits, losses and other comprehensive income of the associate or joint venture. ----- ###### IAS 28 – Investments in Associates and Joint Ventures is applied in order to determine whether the Group’s investments in associates and joint ventures need to be tested for impairment. Where necessary, the total carrying amount of the investment (including goodwill) is tested for impairment in accordance with IAS 36 – Impairment of Assets. Acquisitions in progress or carried out late in the year Before acquiring shares in a property management company, the Group agrees to acquire the shares and typically pays 10% of the estimated price to the seller. This part payment is included in “Downpayments on acquisitions of securities” within non-current financial assets (see Note 4.5). The remaining 90% is booked under off-balance sheet commitments (see Note 9). Note that at this point in the transaction, the Group does not yet have control over the entity being acquired. Upon signing the share transfer or disposal agreement, the Group pays an additional 70% of the estimated price to the seller. The provisional purchase price is then included in equity investments, and the part payment already recognised is also reclassified to this caption. The acquired company is then consolidated. Following a review of the acquired company’s financial statements, the Group pays the remaining balance and adjusts the purchase price of the shares. In the case of acquisitions completed late in the year (generally in November or December), even though the acquired companies may be controlled by the Group, they are not consolidated until the following year, due to insufficient accounting information being available. The investment made is therefore temporarily carried in non-current financial assets at its acquisition cost (i.e., representing the fair value of the investment). The shares are included in “Investments in controlled companies pending consolidation” (see Note 4.5.). No other statement of financial position or profit and loss item is recorded. Non-consolidated investments Companies with the following characteristics are not included in the scope of consolidation: ▪ they are in the process of being wound up or are dormant; ▪ their business is not strategic for the Group. In accordance with IFRS 9, non-consolidated investments are carried at fair value through other comprehensive income. There are no material obligations or liabilities relating to these entities. 3.3.2. Elimination of intragroup transactions All intragroup transactions and balances as well as any income, expenses, gains and losses resulting from intragroup transactions and included in the carrying amount of assets are eliminated on consolidation. When a Group entity carries out a transaction with a joint venture or associate, the related gains and losses are recognised in the Group’s consolidated financial statements only to the extent of the interests held by third parties in the joint venture or associate. Foreign currency translation Presentation currency The consolidated financial statements are presented in euros, which is the Group’s presentation currency. Functional currency and translation of the financial statements of foreign companies A consolidated entity’s functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment in which it operates. In most cases, the functional currency is the local currency. However, certain entities must adopt a functional currency ----- ###### other than their local currency when that currency represents the currency of the major transactions carried out by the entity and accurately reflects its economic environment. The financial statements of foreign entities whose functional currency is different from the presentation currency of the Group’s consolidated financial statements are translated using the “closing rate” method, as follows: ▪ assets and liabilities are translated at the closing exchange rate; ▪ statement of profit and loss and cash flow items are converted at the average exchange rate for the period. The resulting currency translation differences are recognised directly in other comprehensive income within equity under “Translation adjustments”. Goodwill relating to foreign entities whose functional currency is not the euro are treated as assets acquired or liabilities assumed and therefore translated at the exchange rate prevailing at the end of the reporting period. As the Group does most of its business in the eurozone, only its Swiss subsidiaries prepare financial statements in a currency other than the euro. The following exchange rates were used to prepare the consolidated financial statements: 2020 2019 Equivalent to €1 Closing rate Average rate Opening rate Closing rate Average rate Opening rate CHF (Swiss Franc) 1.0802 1.0705 1.0952 1.0952 1.1138 1.1295 ###### The exchange rates used are the rates published by the Banque de France. Foreign currency transactions Foreign currency transactions are translated into euros at the exchange rates prevailing at the transaction date or at the hedged rate. At the end of the reporting period, monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency are translated at the closing exchange rate, with the resulting gains and losses included in foreign exchange gains and losses under other financial income and expenses in the statement of profit and loss. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are measured at historical cost are translated at the exchange rate at the transaction date. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are stated at fair value are translated at the exchange rate at the date on which fair value was determined. Loans granted to a foreign operation for which settlement is neither planned nor likely to occur in the foreseeable future are, in substance, part of the Group’s net investment in that foreign operation. Translation adjustments arising on monetary items that are part of a net investment in a foreign operation are recognised directly in other comprehensive income (equity) under “Foreign currency translation reserves”, and taken to profit or loss when the net investment is sold. 3.4.1. Business combinations and goodwill The Group uses the purchase method to account for its acquisitions of subsidiaries. The fair value of the consideration transferred reflects the fair value of the assets given, equity instruments issued and liabilities assumed or incurred by the acquirer at the date of exchange. Costs directly attributable to the business combination are expensed in the period in which they were incurred. On the first-time consolidation of a subsidiary or equity investment, the Group measures all identifiable items acquired at their acquisition-date fair value. The items are measured in the currency of the acquired company. In the event of ----- ###### deferred settlements, the future amounts payable are discounted to present value at the settlement date. The discount rate used is the same as that used to estimate the value of the assets. Fair value adjustments to assets and liabilities resulting from business combinations accounted for on a provisional basis (i.e., because the independent appraisals or ongoing additional analyses are incomplete) are recognised as retrospective adjustments to goodwill if they occur within 12 months of the acquisition (measurement period) and if they result from facts and circumstances existing at the acquisition date. Adjustments made after the measurement period are taken directly to profit or loss, unless they are made to correct an error, including in relation to deferred tax assets which, if recognised more than 12 months after the acquisition date, generate tax income. Goodwill arising on acquisitions of associates and joint ventures is included in the carrying amount of “Investments in equity-accounted companies”. Goodwill The residual difference representing the excess of the fair value of the consideration transferred plus any non-controlling interests in the acquired company over the acquisition-date fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed is recognised in the consolidated statement of financial position as goodwill. For each business combination, the Group may choose to account for non-controlling interests: - either at acquisition-date fair value, resulting in the recognition of goodwill on the non-controlling interests ###### (“full goodwill” method); - or based on the share of net identifiable assets of the acquired entity measured at fair value, in which case ###### goodwill is only recognised on the portion attributable to owners of the parent (“partial goodwill” method). Goodwill is not amortised but is tested for impairment at least annually, or more frequently if there is evidence that it may be impaired. The impairment testing approach is described in Note 3.4.5 “Impairment of assets” below. Impairment recognised against goodwill may not be reversed. Bargain purchases When the acquisition-date fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed of the acquired company exceeds the purchase price plus the amount of any non-controlling interests in the acquired company, the negative goodwill is taken immediately to profit or loss in the period of the acquisition, after verifying the procedure for identifying and measuring the various items included in its calculation. Transactions involving non-controlling interests Changes in non-controlling interests that do not result in gain or loss of control are recognised in equity. In particular, when additional shares are acquired in an entity already controlled by the Group, the difference between the purchase price of the shares and the additional share of consolidated equity acquired is recognised in equity attributable to owners of the parent. The consolidated carrying amount of the subsidiary’s identifiable assets and liabilities (including goodwill) remains unchanged. Contingent consideration and/or earn-out Contingent consideration or earn-outs relating to a business combination are measured at their acquisition-date fair value, even if it is deemed unlikely they will be paid. After the acquisition date, changes in the estimated fair value of contingent consideration/earn-outs result in an adjustment to goodwill only if they are made within the 12 months following the acquisition date (measurement period) and if they result from facts and circumstances existing at the acquisition date. In all other cases, any such changes are taken to profit or loss, unless the consideration transferred is an equity instrument. ----- ###### The revised IFRS 3 gives certain indications as regards the accounting for contingent payment arrangements with employees or selling shareholders. These arrangements may be part of the business combination or may be considered as separate from the acquisition agreement for the target entity. In certain acquisitions, earn-out payments were considered part of the consideration for post-acquisition services rendered and are therefore expensed in the periods concerned and in future periods. Business combinations achieved in stages (step acquisitions) In a business combination achieved in stages, the Group’s previously-held equity interest in the acquired company is remeasured at fair value through profit or loss on the date control was obtained. Goodwill at the date control is obtained is calculated as the fair value of consideration transferred (i.e., price paid) plus the fair value of the Group’s previously-held equity interest in the acquired company. Put options granted to non-controlling interests As part of certain transactions, the Group may put in place options contracts regarding consolidated investments. These may be call, puts or even reciprocal options, which may or not be contingent on certain conditions. Analysing these options contracts is often complex and requires a good understanding of the economics of the transaction carried out, along with the substance of the commitments binding the different categories of shareholder concerned. Options are therefore accounted for on a case-by-case basis in light of all known facts and circumstances. In granting a put option to non-controlling interests, the Group sells those non-controlling interests an option under which they can sell their shares. The non-controlling interests can exercise their put option, thereby requiring the Group to purchase the underlying shares at a specified exercise price and future date. In the absence of specific guidance from IFRS, these options are accounted for by the Group as follows:  The present value of the commitment at the reporting date is included within “Liabilities relating to put options on non-controlling interests”.  The corresponding non-controlling interests are cancelled. This accounting method does not affect the presentation of non-controlling interests in the statement of profit and loss. Pending completion of the work in progress at the IASB and IFRS IC, and in accordance with the AMF’s recommendations for companies preparing 2009 financial statements, subsequent changes in the value of the commitment are recognised in full by means of an adjustment to equity. When the put option is exercised, the Group derecognises the liability in respect of the deferred payment against the amount of cash effectively paid to the non- controlling interests. 3.4.2. Intangible assets Intangible assets are identifiable non-monetary assets with no physical substance. In accordance with IAS 38, intangible assets that are acquired separately are initially measured at cost when the future economic benefits attributable to the asset will flow to the Group and the cost of the asset can be measured reliably. Subsequent expenditure on intangible assets is included as part of the cost of those assets only if it increases the future economic benefits associated with the assets concerned. Other costs are expensed as incurred. Intangible assets acquired as part of a business combination that can be reliably measured, are controlled by the Group, and are separable or arise from legal or contractual rights are recognised at fair value separately from goodwill. ----- ###### Intangible assets are subsequently measured at cost less any accumulated amortisation and impairment losses. Intangible assets with a finite useful life (software and licences) are amortised on a straight-line basis over their expected useful lives: Client relationships: 18-21 years Software programs: 1-10 years Other intangible assets: 5 years Intangible assets with an indefinite useful life are not amortised. They are included with other assets within cash-generating units (CGUs) and tested for impairment using the discounted cash flow method at least once a year and whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired. When the recoverable amount of these assets calculated based on criteria prevailing at the acquisition date falls below their carrying amount, an impairment provision is recorded. Trademarks Identifiable trademarks are measured using a multi-criteria approach that takes into consideration both their reputation and profitability. The Group classified its main “Foncia” trademark, along with the “Lodgis” and “Trévi” trademarks in Belgium and the “Domicim”, “ Brolliet” and “Gribi” trademarks in Switzerland, as indefinite-lived intangible assets. Costs incurred in creating a new trademark or developing an existing trademark are expensed. Business software programs Software acquired is carried at cost (purchase price plus ancillary expenses). When allocating the purchase price, certain software programs may also be measured using the replacement cost approach. Client relationships Client relationships include the list of mandates managed by the Group’s companies. A mandate is an instrument by which a person (the principal) gives another person (the agent) the power to carry out or enter into one or more legal actions or agreements, in the principal’s name. France’s Hoguet law requires professional property agents to hold a written mandate in order to put properties up for sale or to let, and to manage jointly owned property. In the majority of cases, client relationships are acquired separately as part of purchases of business goodwill and are therefore measured at cost. Client relationships can also be identified within the context of major business combinations, when they meet the identification and materiality criteria (in particular, the Group transacts on a recurring basis with the client). In this case, the Group uses the excess earnings method to measure the relationship. It should be noted that given the large number of external growth transactions carried out by the Group, client relationships are only identified and measured for major acquisitions. Other intangible assets Other intangible assets mainly comprise the cost of acquiring new business. 3.4.3. Property, plant and equipment Property, plant and equipment are measured at their historical cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. ----- ###### The cost of an item of property, plant and equipment comprises its purchase price, including customs duties and non-recoverable taxes, and any costs directly incurred to bring the asset to working condition for its intended use. Any trade discounts and rebates are deducted from the purchase price. Subsequent expenditure is included in the carrying amount of property, plant and equipment or is recognised as a separate component where appropriate, if it is probable that the future economic benefits associated with the asset will flow to the Group  and the cost of the asset can be measured reliably. All other maintenance and repair costs are expensed as incurred, except for costs incurred to increase productivity or extend the useful life of an asset, which are capitalised. Property, plant and equipment are depreciated using the components approach over their estimated useful lives, taking into account any residual value. Straight-line depreciation is considered the method that best reflects the pattern in which the assets’ economic benefits are consumed by the Group: - Buildings: 20-50 years - Fixtures and fittings: 8-10 years - IT equipment: 4 years - Vehicle fleet: 5 years - Furniture: 10 years - Office equipment: 4 years ###### The residual values and useful lives of property, plant and equipment are reviewed at the end of each reporting period and adjusted where necessary. The carrying amounts of property, plant and equipment are tested for impairment when there is evidence that they may be impaired. Gains and losses on asset disposals are calculated as the difference between the sale proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset concerned. 3.4.4. Leases Group as lessee The Group has many leases in which it acts as lessee across its entire French and international branch network. Its leases are of many different types, but are mainly leases of property or vehicles. Pursuant to IFRS 16 – Leases, on entering into a contract, the Group analyses the contractual provisions to determine whether it has the characteristics of a lease. It verifies whether the lease transfers in substance the right to control the use of an asset for a specified period of time in exchange for consideration. If these characteristics exist, as soon as the asset is made available the Group recognises: ▪ a right-of-use asset, which represents its right to use the leased asset over the lease term; ▪ a lease liability (“IFRS 16 lease liability”), which represents the present value of its obligation to make lease payments. The Group applies the same method to account for all leases in which it acts as lessee, and has chosen not to use the practical expedients set out in IFRS 16 exempting short-term leases (i.e., leases with terms of 12 months or less) or leases of low-value underlying assets from the scope of the standard. ----- ###### The amount of the right-of-use asset comprises: ▪ the amount of the associated lease liability; ▪ plus:  any lease payments made at or before the commencement date,  any initial direct costs incurred to obtain the lease,  any estimated restoration costs to be incurred by the Group; ▪ less any lease incentives received. Right-of-use assets are subsequently measured at cost less any accumulated depreciation and any accumulated impairment losses. They are depreciated over the lease term or the useful life of the leased asset for accounting purposes, whichever is shorter. The lease liability represents the present value of: ▪ fixed lease payments (including in-substance fixed payments), less any lease incentives receivable; ▪ variable lease payments that depend on an index or a rate, initially measured using the index or rate at the commencement date; ▪ amounts expected to be payable by the Group under residual value guarantees; ▪ the exercise price of a purchase option if the Group is reasonably certain to exercise that option; ▪ penalties required for terminating the lease. Lease liabilities are subsequently measured by increasing the carrying amount to reflect interest on the lease liability (using the effective interest rate method) and by reducing the carrying amount to reflect the lease payments made. To determine the lease term, the Group analyses the contractual provisions of the lease, as illustrated below: The Group remeasures the lease liability (and adjusts the corresponding right-of-use asset accordingly), when: ▪ there is a change in the lease term or a change in the assessment of an option to purchase the underlying asset, in which cases the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using a revised discount rate; ▪ there is a change in future lease payments resulting from a change in an index or rate, or a change in the amounts expected to be payable under a residual value guarantee, in which cases the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using the initial discount rate; ▪ there is a change in the lease contract (lease modification) that is not accounted for as a separate lease, in which case the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using a revised discount rate. ----- ###### When the Group incurs a material obligation to restore the asset to the condition specified in the lease contract, the related costs are included as part of the cost of the right-of-use asset and the corresponding lease liability is increased accordingly. Group as lessor In certain specific businesses, the Group may enter into lease contracts as the lessor. This is notably the case for German subsidiary Vegis (acquisition carried out in January 2020), which sub-lets – mostly to students – accommodation which the company itself has leased. IFRS 16 first requires the contract to be identified as a sub-letting arrangement in accordance with provisions applicable to lessors, and then to determine whether that arrangement is a finance lease or an operating lease. Classification as a finance lease or an operating lease is based on the right-of-use asset obtained under the initial lease, and not on the underlying asset. To determine whether a lease is a finance lease or an operating lease, the Group performs an broad analysis to determine whether the contract transfers substantially all of the risks and rewards inherent to ownership of the leased asset to its client (the lessee). To perform this analysis, the Group determines whether: (i) the lease transfers ownership of the underlying asset to the client by the end of the lease term, (ii) the lease term is for the major part of the economic life of the underlying asset, and (iii) the present value of the lease payments amounts to substantially all of the fair value of the underlying asset. This will then determine the accounting treatment applicable to the initial lease and to any sub-letting income. The asset recorded in respect of the initial lease is not derecognised and continues to be depreciated. Lease payments collected from the lessee in the sub-letting arrangement are taken to revenue. Based on their contractual characteristics, all of the Group’s sub-letting arrangements meet the definition of an operating lease within the meaning of IFRS 16. The asset recorded in respect of the initial lease is not derecognised and continues to be depreciated. Lease payments collected from the lessee in the sub-letting arrangement are taken to revenue. 3.4.5. Impairment of assets Impairment of assets with finite useful lives Property, plant and equipment and intangible assets with finite useful lives are tested for impairment whenever there is evidence that they may be impaired. Impairment recognised in profit or loss against property, plant and equipment and intangible assets may be reversed. Impairment of assets with indefinite useful lives Goodwill and other intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are tested for impairment at least annually, or more frequently if there is evidence that they may be impaired. Cash-generating units For the purposes of these impairment tests, non-current assets that cannot be tested individually for impairment as they do not generate cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets, are grouped into cash-generating units (CGUs). Impairment tests are carried out on each CGU or group of CGUs at the lowest level at which goodwill is monitored by the Group. A CGU is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets for internal management purposes. ----- ###### The CGUs identified by the Group correspond to its major development and investment strategies. The Group has defined the following three cash-generating units: - Property Management France CGU, which includes the management of jointly owned properties, rental ###### management, lettings, the transactions business and client mandates; - Property Management International CGU, which includes the property management and transactions ###### businesses in Germany, Switzerland and Belgium; - Group of Services CGUs, which includes Constatimmo (brokerage for technical surveys), Assurimo (insurance ###### brokerage), Efficity (property appraisals website), FPM and Esset Management (BtoB property management), Prowen (brokerage specialised in energy purchases), Seiitra (property management software development), Tech-way (technical maintenance), Leemo (property platform), and Lodgis (furnished rentals). The Group decides whether or not to recognise an impairment loss by comparing the carrying amount of the assets and liabilities in a CGU or group of CGUs with their recoverable amount. Impairment indicators External indicators of impairment include changes in the general economic and financial environment, downtrends in local economic environments and changes in economic performance. These are analysed by the Group to determine whether the assets concerned should be tested for impairment more frequently. Method used to determine the recoverable amount An impairment loss is recognised in the statement of profit and loss when the carrying amount of an asset or CGU exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount of an asset or CGU is the higher of: - its fair value less the costs of disposal, representing the amount at which the Group could sell the asset (after ###### selling costs) in an arm’s length transaction between market participants at the measurement date; and - its value in use, representing the present value of the future cash flows expected to be derived from the ###### continuing use and ultimate sale of an asset or CGU based on the most probable assumptions adopted by management. Fair value net of the costs of disposal is calculated based on available information used to establish the best estimate of the selling price net of costs to sell in an arm’s length transaction between fully informed, consenting parties. Value in use of CGUs or groups of CGUs is determined based on post-tax cash flows resulting from business plans and a terminal value calculated by extrapolating data for the last year of the business plan. The assumptions used are based on the budgets and business plans prepared by management for each business. These budgets are the latest budgets approved at the date of preparation of the financial statements. Other assumptions affecting the calculation of the recoverable amount include the growth rate, operating margin, the discount rate and the tax rate (see Note 4.1.2). The discount rate used to discount post-tax cash flows to their present value reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset or CGU. Where there is no specific discount rate for the assets tested, the average cost of capital is used. The discount rates are post-tax rates and are applied to post-tax cash flows.  The recoverable amount calculated using post-tax discount rates is equal to that which would have been obtained using pre-tax rates applied to pre-tax cash flows, as required by IAS 36. ----- ###### Recognition of impairment losses If the carrying amount of the CGU exceeds its recoverable amount, the related assets are written down to the recoverable amount. The impairment loss is first allocated to goodwill and then to the carrying amount of the other assets of the CGU, in proportion to their carrying amount. This must not result in the carrying amount of an individual asset falling below the higher of its fair value, value in use and zero. Impairment losses are recognised in other non-recurring operating expenses and may not be reversed. Reversal of impairment losses Impairment losses recognised against goodwill cannot be reversed. Impairment losses recognised against assets other than goodwill may only be reversed if there is evidence that the impairment loss may have decreased or may no longer exist. The amount reversed is then based on revised estimates of the asset’s recoverable amount. The increased carrying amount of an asset attributable to the reversal of an impairment loss should not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined had no impairment loss been recognised for the asset. 3.4.6. Trade and other receivables Trade and other receivables are carried at amortised cost, corresponding to their face value less any impairment losses recorded in the statement of profit and loss. In view of its business activities, the Group is exposed to limited bad debt risk on its commercial receivables as the risk is concentrated mainly in the B2B business, which accounts for less than 4% of consolidated revenue. 3.4.7. Financial instruments The measurement and recognition of financial assets and liabilities is defined by IFRS 9 – Financial instruments. Financial assets Financial assets include financial investments, shares in companies acquired in the process of being consolidated, deposits and guarantees paid, other long-term receivables, derivative instruments with a positive fair value and cash and cash equivalents. IFRS 9 applies a single analytical framework to all financial assets in order to determine the classification and basis of measurement to be used for accounting purposes. More specifically: ✓ Financial assets at amortised cost Financial assets that will be recovered through repayments of contractual cash flows (i.e., repayments of principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding) are generally carried at amortised cost. Financial assets at amortised cost include operating financial assets, other loans and receivables and trade receivables. They are initially recognised at fair value and subsequently carried at amortised cost calculated using the effective interest rate method. In accordance with IFRS 9, financial assets at amortised cost are written down by the amount of any expected credit losses. Impairment losses relating to commercial receivables are recognised in recurring operating profit items, while those relating to other financial assets are recognised in financial expenses. ✓ Assets at fair value through other comprehensive income reclassifiable to profit or loss Financial assets that will be recovered both through repayments of contractual cash flows (i.e., repayments of principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding) and through sales of those assets are generally carried at fair value through other comprehensive income. Changes in the fair value of these assets are recognised directly in other comprehensive income, with the exception of interest income and dividends, which are included in other financial income and expenses. Changes in fair value are reclassified to profit or loss when the assets are sold. ----- ###### ✓ Assets at fair value through other comprehensive income This category includes downpayments to equity investments and investments in non-consolidated companies, and equity instruments that the Group has irrevocably elected to classify in this category. When these investments are sold, the unrealised gains and losses previously carried in other comprehensive income will not be reclassified to profit or loss; only dividends will be taken to profit or loss. Fair value corresponds to the market price for listed securities or to the estimated fair value for unlisted securities, as determined according to the financial criteria most appropriate to the particular situation of each investment. The fair value of equity investments whose price is not quoted on an active market is determined based on the latest known transactions involving these investments. ✓ Assets at fair value through profit or loss All other debt and equity instruments are carried at fair value through profit or loss. These include marketable securities with an underlying term of more than three months, other financial assets held for trading and purchased for sale in the near term, and financial instruments with a positive fair value that are not eligible for hedge accounting. These assets are measured at fair value, with changes in fair value taken to financial income and expenses. At the acquisition date, the Group determines the classification of financial assets into one of the IFRS 9 categories based on the characteristics of the instrument and the business model for managing the assets. The table below provides an overview of classification by financial asset category, along with the corresponding measurement approach:
