###### Financial liabilities Financial liabilities include borrowings and other payables as well as bank overdrafts. With the exception of trading liabilities and derivative instruments representing liabilities carried at fair value, borrowings and other financial liabilities are initially recognised at fair value less transaction costs, and subsequently at amortised cost calculated using the effective interest method. The effective interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts the estimated future cash payments or receipts through the expected life of the financial instrument or, as appropriate, through a shorter period, to the net carrying amount of the financial asset or liability. ----- ###### Trade payables and other liabilities meet the definition of financial liabilities at amortised cost as defined by IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments. These financial liabilities are initially recognised at nominal value, insofar as this represents a reasonable estimate of their fair value given their short-term nature. Derivative instruments The Group uses derivative instruments to hedge interest rate risks on floating-rate borrowings and foreign exchange risks. In accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9, derivative instruments are measured on the statement of financial position at fair value. Changes in the fair value of instruments not eligible for hedge accounting are recognised in profit or loss under other financial income and expenses. 3.4.8. Cash and cash equivalents Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash at bank and on hand, as well as short-term highly-liquid deposits with an initial maturity of three months or less and subject to an insignificant risk of changes in value. Short-term investments are measured at market value at the end of each reporting period, with any changes in market value taken to financial income and expenses. Investments in listed equities along with investments with an initial maturity of over three months and no early exit option are excluded from cash and cash equivalents and classified as current or non-current financial assets. Bank overdraft facilities are excluded from cash and cash equivalents and included in current borrowings and debit. Changes in the fair value of these instruments are recorded in profit or loss. For the purposes of the consolidated statement of cash flows, net cash and cash equivalents include the items defined above, net of short-term bank overdrafts. 3.4.9. Client accounts The Group conducts its property management business through mandates signed with clients, under which the companies are responsible for holding client funds. These funds consist of liquid assets received as guarantees, rent and expenses, joint ownership working capital and renovation funds, and funds received in connection with the transactions business. As an agent, the Group undertakes to hold client accounts and to recognise them in its statement of financial position using a specific account for each activity (property sales, rentals and management). The amount shown for client accounts within assets is equivalent to the amount shown for these accounts in liabilities. 3.4.10. Current and non-current provisions A provision is recognised when, at the end of the reporting period, the Group has a legal or constructive obligation to a third party resulting from a past event that is likely to give rise to an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits and can be measured reliably. Provisions may also be recognised for contingent liabilities arising on business combinations. In this case, they are initially recognised at fair value at the acquisition date. When the Group expects partial or full repayment of the provision, for example owing to an insurance policy, the repayment is booked as a separate asset but only if such repayment is virtually certain. When the effect of the time value of money is material, the amount of the provision reflects the present value of the expenditure expected to be required to settle the obligations, as calculated using a pre-tax discount rate reflecting current market assessments of the time value of money and, where applicable, the risks specific to the liability. ----- ###### Since provisions are calculated based on estimated future contingencies and expenses, they are measured taking into account the assumptions deemed most probable at the reporting date. Items giving rise to provisions (trade and employee disputes, etc.) are reviewed regularly to allow for any adjustments. Provisions include amounts accrued in respect of business, employee-related and/or tax (excluding income tax) risks and disputes arising in the ordinary course of operations, as described below: ✓ Employee-related provisions (disputes, lay-offs, etc.) At the end of each reporting period, a provision is recognised and adjusted in line with the risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Human Resources department on a case-by-case basis. ✓ Provisions for rent payment guarantees A rent payment guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Foncia with the management of their property. Foncia bears the cost of any unpaid rent and advances to owners. These advances are not always recoverable from the lessee and therefore represent a risk of non-recovery. Rent payment guarantees are incidental to the property management contracts (deriving from the del credere agreement) and are accounted for as follows: - the related fees are recorded continuously in income over the period of the mandate, since they are deducted ###### from rents in the same way as basic fees; - once rent is reported as unpaid, a provision is recorded, calculated in accordance with IAS 37. ###### The amount of the provision set aside by the Group increases in line with the age of the unpaid receivable. Provisions for rent payment guarantees are calculated by reference to late payments relating to current and former lessees, regardless of whether or not lessee statement of accounts (Arrêtés des Comptes Locataires – ACL) have been drawn up, taking into account the probability of collection (assessed on a statistical basis and regularly updated). ✓ Provision for occupancy guarantees An occupancy guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Foncia with the management of their property. The provision for occupancy guarantees is calculated on a statistical basis by reference to the probable residual vacant period for properties currently vacant and subject to occupancy guarantees. The provision is estimated based on the firm’s average monthly rent. The maximum term of claims is 180 days. ✓ Provision for URSSAF social security audits This concerns in-progress and completed URSSAF social security audits. A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the related risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Payroll department on a case-by-case basis. ✓ Provisions for risks on client accounts Provisions for risks on client accounts are designed to cover the non-collection risk on lost client accounts in debit, as well as other risks on client accounts. A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the risk exposure on client accounts, as assessed by the Group’s Client Operations department on a case-by-case basis. ✓ Provisions for third party and professional liability These provisions are recorded based on information provided by senior managers in charge of monitoring claims against their firm. The Audit, Legal and Accounting departments have the final decision in terms of whether or not to ----- ###### record a provision. If the claim is reported and covered by the liability insurance, the maximum provision will reflect the amount of the deductible (€15,000 as of 1 January 2014) or the amount of the estimated risk, whichever is lower. If the claim is not reported, the senior manager concerned sets the amount to be provisioned. ✓ Provisions for other disputes These provisions are intended to cover disputes, litigation and other foreseeable contingencies in connection with the Group’s businesses, along with miscellaneous contingencies and expenses. 3.4.11. Share-based payment and employee benefits Share-based payment In some circumstances, some of the Group’s employees may receive compensation in an arrangement involving a share-based payment. This was the case for an employee at Foncia Stark, who was a beneficiary of a free share plan (“AGA”). Due to the existence of a liquidity contract, this free share plan had been classified as a cash-settled plan within the meaning of IFRS 2. The cost of the services rendered had been recognised on a straight-line basis over the vesting period within production for own use, against an employee-related payable. Since the share-based payment was made to the beneficiary on 23 May 2020 for a cash amount of €200,000, the full amount of the related liability was extinguished at 31 December 2020. The capitalised costs will be amortised as from the date the “Millénium” project (development of new management software for the property management network) enters into service. At 31 December 2020, there were no other stock option or free share plans within the Foncia Group. Long-term incentive plans (LTIP) As part of its acquisition-led growth strategy and in order to accelerate its organisational realignment, in 2020 the Group appointed a new management team in Germany. The new management team will be responsible for developing the portfolio of mandates managed through selective acquisitions, and for the organizational and operational restructuring processes. In connection with this new appointment, the Group granted a long-term incentive plan with the following terms and conditions:  Grant date: 1 June 2020.  Reference period: 2 January 2020 to 31 December 2025.  Performance conditions: LTIP = % performance x equity value, with: (i) Equity value = Enterprise value - cash investments made in connection with acquisitions during the reference period  (ii) Enterprise value = 10 x increase in EBITDA during the reference period (iii) % performance = progressive rate (between 3% and 5%) based on revenue earned in 2025. In accordance with IFRS 2, the service cost is recognised on a straight-line basis over the vesting period against an employee-related payable. The fair value of this liability will be remeasured at each reporting date until the liability is settled, based on assumptions used in the budget. In 2020, the cost of this incentive plan represented €0.3 million, and is shown in non-recurring operating items. Pensions and other post-employment benefits ✓ Short-term benefits Short-term benefits include paid annual leave, paid sick leave, bonuses and other benefits (other than contract termination benefits), expected to be settled wholly before 12 months after the end of the annual reporting period ----- ###### during which the employee services are rendered. Short-term benefits are expensed in the period in which the corresponding services are rendered by the employee. Any amounts not paid at the end of the reporting period are carried in current liabilities. ✓ Post-employment benefits In accordance with the laws and practices in each of the countries in which the Group operates, Foncia participates in, or operates, benefit plans providing for the payment of post-employment benefits (including retirement benefits) to eligible current and former employees, retirees and their beneficiaries. Virtually all of the Group’s employees are entitled to pension benefits. In France, this takes the form of payments by the Foncia Group to the beneficiaries when the rights allotted vest, while in Switzerland, plans are managed by pension funds financed in compliance with the applicable government requirements and regulations. These plans may be funded by investments in various instruments such as insurance policies, equity instruments and bonds. Post-employment benefits are measured and recognised by the Group in accordance with IAS 19 – Employee Benefits, as described below. - Defined contribution plans ###### Defined contribution plans and multi-employer plans are expensed as incurred in the statement of profit and loss based on contributions. - Defined benefit plans ###### The cost of defined benefit plans is measured on an actuarial basis. The related obligations are calculated by independent actuaries using the projected unit credit method, based on the agreements in effect in each company. Obligations are determined by reference to assumptions that are revised each year and relate for example to length of service, life expectancy, salary inflation and employee turnover, and also take into account macroeconomic assumptions for the various countries in which the Group does business (e.g., discount rate and inflation rate). The assumptions used for 2020 are detailed in Note 4.12. A provision is recognised in the statement of financial position for the difference between the related projected benefit obligation (actuarial liability) and any plan assets as measured at fair value, and includes past service costs and actuarial gains and losses. If plan assets exceed the projected benefit obligation recognised, a non-current asset is recorded for the amount of the plans in the consolidated statement of financial position. A funding surplus (net defined benefit asset) is only recognised in the statement of financial position if its represents future economic benefits that will actually be available to the Group. When the calculation of the net benefit obligation gives rise to an asset for the Group, the amount recognised as an asset cannot exceed the present value of any economic benefits available in the form of future refunds from the plan or future reductions in contributions to the plan. Expenses under defined benefit plans comprise three components, accounted for as described below: - Service cost is recognised under personnel costs within operating profit. It includes service cost for the period, past service cost resulting from plan amendments or curtailments, which are recognised in full in profit or loss for the period in which they arose, and gains and losses arising on plan settlements. - Interest cost is recognised in other financial income and expenses and reflects the impact of discounting the obligations, net of the expected return on plan assets as measured using the discount rate applied to calculate those obligations. ----- ###### - Remeasurements of the net liability (or net asset) are included in other comprehensive income not reclassifiable to profit or loss, and do not impact the statement of profit and loss. They essentially comprise actuarial gains and losses, i.e., changes in the benefit obligation and in plan assets attributable to changes in assumptions and experience adjustments. Experience adjustments represent the difference between the expected impact of certain actuarial assumptions applied to previous measurements of the obligation and actual experience. ✓ Other long-term benefits Other long-term benefits are measured in accordance with IAS 19. The estimated cost of these benefits is recognised within non-current liabilities over the employees’ qualifying years of service. Actuarial gains and losses and past service costs attributable to amendments to an existing plan or the introduction of a new plan are taken immediately to profit or loss. In France, the collective bargaining agreement for the real estate industry stipulates that all active employees who so request are entitled to one month’s salary at every anniversary date: after 20, 30, 35 and 40 years of professional experience. Professional experience is considered overall and not as experience solely within the Group. However, the Group is only liable for the amount proportionate to the employee’s seniority in the Group. The Group’s obligation under long-service awards is assessed each year by an independent expert. The assumptions used for 2020 are detailed in Note 4.12. 3.4.12. Deferred tax Deferred taxes are recognised on temporary differences between the carrying amount of assets and liabilities and their value for tax purposes, using the tax rates expected to apply in the period in which the asset is realised and the liability settled, on the basis of tax laws that have been enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date. Deferred tax does not arise on: - the initial recognition of goodwill; - the initial recognition of an asset in a transaction that is not a business combination and affects neither the ###### accounting profit (loss) nor taxable profit (loss); - temporary differences related to investments in subsidiaries, to the extent that it is probable they will not ###### reverse in the foreseeable future. Tax on items recognised directly in equity or in other comprehensive income is recognised in equity or in other comprehensive income, respectively, and not in the statement of profit and loss. Deferred tax assets arising on temporary differences (after offsetting against deferred tax liabilities) or on tax losses and tax credits carried forward are only recognised to the extent that it is probable they will reverse and that the Group will generate future taxable earnings against which they can be utilised pursuant to local tax laws. The following are taken into account when assessing the Group’s ability to recover these assets: - forecasts of future taxable earnings; - taxable earnings in previous years. ###### Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset if there is a legally enforceable right to offset current tax assets and liabilities, and if they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority on the same taxable entity. ----- ###### 3.4.13. Trade payables and other current liabilities Trade payables and other current liabilities are liabilities to be settled or renegotiated within the ordinary operating cycle or within 12 months following the end of the reporting period. Trade payables and other liabilities meet the definition of financial liabilities at amortised cost as defined by IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments (see Note 3.4.7). These financial liabilities are initially recognised at nominal value, insofar as this represents a reasonable estimate of their fair value given their short-term nature. The value of items that will be paid over the long term is discounted. 3.4.14. Classification and measurement of financial assets and liabilities at fair value The fair value of all financial assets and liabilities is determined at the end of the reporting period, either for accounting purposes or for disclosure in the notes to the financial statements. Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. IFRS 13 sets out a three-level hierarchy for determining fair value: - Level 1: quoted (unadjusted) prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities. - Level 2: inputs other than quoted market prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or ###### liability, either directly (i.e., prices) or indirectly (i.e., price-based inputs). - Level 3: inputs relating to the asset or liability which are not based on observable market data (unobservable ###### inputs). The Group primarily uses fair value on a recurring basis in its statement of financial position to measure derivative instruments, cash and cash equivalents, available-for-sale financial assets, cash management financial assets and identifiable assets and liabilities acquired as part of a business combination. The fair values of financial assets and liabilities are disclosed in Note 4.18. 3.4.15. Assets classified as held for sale, businesses sold or in the process of sale and discontinued operations IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations sets forth the accounting requirements applicable to assets held for sale, along with the presentation and disclosure requirements for discontinued operations. IFRS 5 requires assets held for sale to be presented on a separate line of the consolidated statement of financial position for the lower of their carrying amount and their fair value less costs to sell, provided that they meet the definition of assets held for sale set out in the standard. When the Group is engaged in a sale process resulting in the loss of control of a subsidiary, the entire assets and liabilities of that subsidiary are classified as held for sale when their carrying amount will be principally recovered through a sale transaction rather than through continuing use, regardless of whether or not the Group retains a residual interest in the subsidiary after the sale. For this to be the case, the asset (or disposal group) must be available for immediate sale in its present condition and the sale must be highly probable. The assets and liabilities concerned are reclassified in assets held for sale and liabilities related to assets held for sale, and no offsetting is permitted. Businesses held for sale or discontinued are presented on a separate line in the statement of profit and loss for the periods presented, which shows post-tax profit or loss attributable to discontinued operations and the post-tax gain ----- ###### or loss on the disposal or the measurement to fair value less costs to sell of the assets or disposal groups comprising the business sold or in the process of sale. Operations that are abandoned or discontinued are defined as a component of an entity that represents a separate major line of business and meets the criteria for classification as an asset held for sale or has been sold by the Group. Similarly, cash flows attributable to abandoned or discontinued operations are presented on a separate line of the consolidated statement of cash flows for the periods presented. Under IFRS 5, profits or losses related to discontinued operations are also to be shown on a separate line of the consolidated statement of profit and loss, retrospectively for all periods presented. A discontinued operation can be defined as a component of an entity that either has been disposed of or is classified as held for sale and: ▪ represents a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations; ▪ is part of a single coordinated plan to dispose of a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations; or ▪ is a subsidiary acquired exclusively with a view to resale. 3.4.16. Presentation of the statement of profit and loss As permitted under IAS 1 – Presentation of Financial Statements, the Group has chosen to present operating expenses by nature. “Recurring operating profit (loss)”, “Operating profit (loss)”, “Cost of gross debt” and “Cost of net debt” in the statement of profit and loss and gains and losses recognised directly in equity are presented in accordance with the criteria set out in ANC Recommendation No. 2013-03 issued by the French accounting standards-setter (Autorité des Normes Comptables). 3.4.17. Revenue Revenue for the Group results from sales of services within the scope of the ordinary operations of consolidated subsidiaries, less revenue from intragroup transactions. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable, net of discounts and rebates, VAT and other taxes and duties. In accordance with IFRS 15, the Group recognises revenue when the amount thereof can be reliably measured, it is probable that future economic benefits will flow to the Group, and specific criteria are met by each of the Group’s businesses. ❖ Jointly owned property management business From a contractual and legal perspective, the Group’s jointly owned property management business is mostly conducted through mandates, and fees are calculated on a flat-rate basis. In France, this flat rate includes all basic management services provided by the jointly owned property association, and excludes incidental services such as: ▪ preparing, convening and organising General Meetings; ▪ managing the joint owners’ council; ▪ managing the financial operations and keeping the accounts of the jointly owned property association; ▪ managing the jointly owned property in compliance with its rules and regulations; ▪ carrying out periodic visits and inspections of the jointly owned property. ----- ###### All such services are treated as an overall performance obligation satisfied over time. In fact, these different services are associated with a single performance obligation, i.e., management of the jointly owned property association. Annual revenue from basic property management fees is therefore recognised on a straight-line basis over the period during which the services are provided. Incidental services may be added to the basic management services and are invoiced based on an agreed rate for each such service, for example, additional meetings and visits, rules and regulations of the jointly owned property, physical and administrative management of claims, technical work and surveys, litigation and disputes. Since each additional service represents a separate performance obligation, revenue is recognised when the service is performed. ❖ Rental management business In its rental management business, the Group acts as agent for owners-lessors and fulfils a certain number of contractually defined obligations in this regard. These mainly concern: ▪ routine management services, for example, rent reviews and collection, annual adjustment invoice for expenses, sending of rent receipts to lessees, and deposits; ▪ other one-off management services, including preparation of the lease contract, inventory of premises, compilation of documentation, management of claims, administrative filings, and requests for subsidies; ▪ technical management services, such as on-site repairs, mandatory technical surveys, and preparation of essential information documents for lessees; ▪ insurance against unpaid rent; ▪ other insurance such as for vacant premises or property damage. These represent separate service obligations. Accordingly, revenue for each of these obligations is recognised separately. Revenue from services provided over time, such as routine management services and insurance (falling outside the scope of IFRS 4) is recognised on a straight-line basis by reference to the frequency with which expenses are rebilled to the owners. Revenue from one-off services is recognised when those services are provided. ❖ Lettings Revenue is recognised at the time the inventory of the premises is conducted. The Group collects fees from owners and from lessees. ❖ Transactions business/Efficity Revenue on the transactions business is recognised upon signature of the notarised final sale agreement (acte authentique), which is the date on which control is presumed to have been transferred. ❖ Client accounts Interest income generated on client funds is booked in revenue. ❖ Assurimo Assurismo provides property insurance brokerage services. Revenue under comprehensive property insurance and comprehensive homeowners’ insurance policies is recognised over the term of the cover, since services in this brokerage business are provided on a straight-line basis. ❖ Constatimmo Constatimmo carries out mandatory technical surveys on premises, as well as inventories of premises for lessees. Its revenue is recognised and measured when the related services are performed. ----- ###### ❖ Seiitra Seiitra provides specialist IT property services and developed the Thetrawin software, which it markets through the sale of software licenses. These property management tools offer the full suite of functionalities needed to keep accounting records for client accounts and to manage suspense accounts, jointly owned properties and rentals, as well as the budget of jointly owned property associations. Maintenance fees are recognised on a straight-line basis, since the corresponding services are provided over time. ❖ Esset Management Esset Management provides property management services (jointly owned property management and rental services) for institutions. The accounting principles applied are the same as those explained above for the private property management business. ❖ Foncia Valorisation Foncia Valorisation provides investment strategy consulting and arbitrage (appraisals, lending, block/unit property sales) for institutional clients or wealthy families. Its revenue is recognised upon signature of the notarised final sale agreement and is based on a percentage of the sale price. ❖ Leemo Leemo, a wholly-owned Group subsidiary since 2017, is a listing service for properties for sale. It has developed a digital platform for property companies where it lists new real estate projects by different developers as well as certain older properties that are to be made available for sale to private and institutional investors. It derives its revenue from two main sources:  fees on sale agreements: amounts billed to developers and partially retroceded to business providers. Only the net margin is recognised in revenue.  fees on bundles of services sold to developers without any retrocession requirements. Revenue from fees on sale agreements is recognised when the notarised final sale agreement is signed. Revenue from fees earned on bundles of services is recognised on a straight-line basis over the period during which the services are provided. 3.4.18. Recurring operating profit (loss) Recurring operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, with the exception of items classified within “Non-recurring operating income (expenses)”. Recurring operating profit (loss) is a performance indicator that may serve as a method for estimating recurring performance. It includes all items included in operating profit (loss), restated for any non-recurring items.  Costs relating to mergers and acquisitions or restructuring are excluded from recurring operating profit. 3.4.19. Non-recurring operating income (expenses) This caption includes non-recurring income and expense items that, owing to their nature, amount or frequency, cannot be considered as arising in the ordinary course of the Group’s operations and are therefore not reported in recurring operating profit (loss). They include impacts of changes in the scope of consolidation, goodwill impairment, and non-recurring amortisation and impairment charged against trademarks and software. If material, non-recurring items also include the effects of certain unusual transactions such as capital gains and losses on disposals of non-current assets, restructuring fees, fees relating to major claims and disputes, and any other non-recurring income or expenses. ----- ###### It should be noted that for transactions directly related to external growth and projects to transform or restructure the business (particularly mergers and reorganisations), a detailed procedure is in place to identify, classify and validate any transactions of a non-recurring nature. This procedure gives a precise indication of transactions that meet the criteria to be recorded in this category. During this unprecedented year, the Group was required to purchase protective materials and equipment for its employees and clients. These Covid-19-related expenses are shown on a line within “Other expenses”, which is included in the calculation of non-recurring operating income (expenses). This accounting approach reflects the unusual nature of these expenses. 3.4.20. Operating profit (loss) Operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, irrespective of whether they are of a recurring nature or whether they result from one-off decisions or transactions. 3.4.21. Cost of net debt The cost of net debt is equal to all financial expenses incurred by the Group on borrowings and lease liabilities pursuant to IFRS 16, less financial income from cash investments. 3.4.22. Income tax Income tax expense for the year includes current and deferred income tax expense, which are recognised in the statement of profit and loss except when they relate to items recognised in other comprehensive income. The Group calculates its current taxes in accordance with the tax legislation applicable in the countries in which its earnings are taxable. Current tax expense is calculated on the basis of tax laws enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date in countries where the Group’s subsidiaries operate and generate taxable profit. However, management periodically reviews the positions adopted in tax returns for situations in which tax regulations are subject to interpretation. Where applicable, a provision is set aside based on the amounts payable to the tax authorities. Income tax expense includes the amounts reported by French subsidiaries in respect of the CVAE tax assessed on value added, since the Group considers this tax meets the definition of income tax set out in IAS 12 – Income Taxes. When they have not been set against income tax, income tax credits that are not included in the calculation of taxable profit and that are always refunded by the State are recorded as subsidies and reduce the expenses to which they relate. 3.4.23. Earnings (loss) per share Earnings (loss) per share corresponds to profit (loss) attributable to holders of ordinary shares divided by the weighted average number of ordinary shares outstanding during the reporting period (excluding treasury shares). 3.4.24. Operating segments The Group is not concerned by IFRS 8 – Operating Segments. Revenue is broken down by business in Note 5.1. 3.4.25. Statement of cash flows Consolidated cash and cash equivalents, changes in which are displayed in the statement of cash flows, are defined as the net balance of cash and cash equivalents, current bank overdraft facilities and bank credit balances repayable on demand that form an integral part of the cash management strategy. ----- ###### Changes in cash from operating activities are calculated based on operating profit (loss) adjusted for transactions with no cash impact. NOTE 4. NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED STATEMENT OF FINANCIAL POSITION Goodwill 4.1.1. Changes in the period At 31 December 2020, goodwill is carried within assets in the statement of financial position for €1,445.4 million. The main changes in the period can be summarised as follows: SPPI Hold-to-collect Amortised cost SPPI Other FV through PL ###### Financial liabilities Financial liabilities include borrowings, other financing and overdraft facilities, and derivative instruments with a negative fair value. With the exception of trading liabilities and derivative instruments representing liabilities carried at fair value, borrowings and other financial liabilities are initially recognised at fair value less transaction costs, and subsequently at amortised cost calculated using the effective interest method. The effective interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts the estimated future cash payments or receipts through the expected life of the financial instrument or, as appropriate, through a shorter period, to the net carrying amount of the financial asset or liability. Trade payables and other liabilities meet the definition of financial liabilities at amortised cost as defined by IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments. These financial liabilities are initially recognised at nominal value, insofar as this represents a reasonable estimate of their fair value given their short-term nature. ----- ###### Derivative instruments The Group uses derivative instruments to hedge interest rate risks on floating-rate borrowings and foreign exchange risks. In accordance with IFRS, hedge accounting may be applied to a hedging transaction provided that: - the hedge is documented (entity’s objectives, hedging strategy, identification of the components of the ###### hedging relationship, etc.); - the hedge is highly effective in offsetting changes in fair value or cash flows attributable to the hedged risk. ###### A hedge is highly effective if it meets all of the following hedge effectiveness criteria: - there is an economic relationship between the hedged item and the hedging instrument, - the credit risk is not of a magnitude that it dominates the value changes that result from the economic relationship, - the hedge ratio is the same as that resulting from the quantity of the hedged item that the Group actually hedges and the quantity of the hedging instrument that the Group actually uses to hedge that quantity of hedged item; - effectiveness can be measured reliably and is calculated in the context of continuing operations. ###### For the periods presented, no interest rate or foreign currency derivatives used by the Group are classified as hedging instruments. In accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9, derivative instruments are measured on the statement of financial position at fair value. Changes in the fair value of instruments not eligible for hedge accounting are recognised in profit or loss under other financial income and expenses. 3.4.11. Cash and cash equivalents Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash at bank and on hand, as well as short-term highly-liquid deposits with an initial maturity of three months or less and subject to an insignificant risk of changes in value. Short-term investments are measured at market value at the end of each reporting period, with any changes in market value taken to financial income and expenses. Investments in listed equities, investments with an initial maturity of over three months and no early exit option and restricted (i.e., blocked) bank accounts are excluded from cash and cash equivalents and classified as current or non-current financial assets. Bank overdraft facilities are excluded from cash and cash equivalents and included in current financial liabilities. Changes in the fair value of these instruments are recorded in profit or loss. For the purposes of the consolidated statement of cash flows, net cash and cash equivalents include the items defined above, net of short-term bank overdrafts. ----- ###### 3.4.12. Client accounts The Group conducts its property management business through mandates signed with clients, under which the companies are responsible for holding client funds. These funds consist of guarantee deposits received, rent and expenses, joint ownership working capital and renovation funds, and funds received in connection with the transactions business. As an agent, the Group undertakes to hold client accounts and to recognise them in its statement of financial position using a specific account for each activity (property sales, rentals and management). 3.4.13. Current and non-current provisions A provision is recognised when, at the end of the reporting period, the Group has a legal or constructive obligation to a third party resulting from a past event that is likely to give rise to an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits and can be measured reliably. Provisions may also be recognised for contingent liabilities arising on business combinations. In this case, they are initially recognised at fair value at the acquisition date. When the Group expects partial or full repayment of the provision, for example owing to an insurance policy, the repayment is booked as a separate asset but only if such repayment is virtually certain. When the effect of the time value of money is material, the amount of the provision reflects the present value of the expenditure expected to be required to settle the obligations, as calculated using a pre-tax discount rate reflecting current market assessments of the time value of money and, where applicable, the risks specific to the liability. Since provisions are calculated based on estimated future contingencies and expenses, they are measured taking into account the assumptions deemed most probable at the reporting date. Items giving rise to provisions (trade and employee disputes, etc.) are reviewed regularly to allow for any adjustments. Provisions include amounts accrued in respect of business, employee-related and/or tax (excluding income tax) risks and disputes arising in the ordinary course of operations, as described below:  Employee-related provisions (disputes, lay-offs, etc.) At the end of each reporting period, a provision is recognised and adjusted in line with the risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Human Resources department on a case-by-case basis.  Provisions for rent payment guarantees A rent payment guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Foncia with the management of their property. Foncia bears the cost of any unpaid rent and advances to owners. These advances are not always recoverable from the lessee and therefore represent a risk of non-recovery. Rent payment guarantees are incidental to the property management contracts (deriving from the del credere agreement) and are accounted for as follows: - the related fees are recorded continuously in income over the period of the mandate, since they are ###### deducted from rents in the same way as basic fees; - once rent is reported as unpaid, a provision is recorded, calculated in accordance with IAS 37. ###### The amount of the provision set aside by the Group increases in line with the age of the unpaid receivable. Provisions for rent payment guarantees are calculated by reference to late payments relating to current and former lessees, regardless of whether or not lessee statement of accounts (Arrêtés des Comptes Locataires – ACL) have been drawn up, taking into account the probability of collection (assessed on a statistical basis and regularly updated). ----- ######  Provision for occupancy guarantees An occupancy guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Foncia with the management of their property. The provision for occupancy guarantees is calculated on a statistical basis by reference to the probable residual vacant period for properties currently vacant and subject to occupancy guarantees. The provision is estimated based on the firm’s average monthly rent. The maximum term of claims is 180 days.  Provision for URSSAF social security audits This concerns in-progress and completed URSSAF social security audits. A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the related risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Payroll department on a case-by-case basis.  Provisions for risks on client accounts Provisions for risks on client accounts are designed to cover the non-collection risk on lost client accounts in debit, as well as other risks on client accounts. A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the risk exposure on client accounts, as assessed by the Group’s Client Operations department on a case-by-case basis.  Provisions for third party and professional liability These provisions are recorded based on information provided by senior managers in charge of monitoring claims against their firm. The Audit, Legal and Accounting departments have the final decision in terms of whether or not to record a provision. If the claim is reported and covered by the liability insurance, the maximum provision will reflect the amount of the deductible (€15,000 as of 1 January 2014) or the amount of the estimated risk, whichever is lower. If the claim is not reported, the senior manager concerned sets the amount to be provisioned.  Provisions for other disputes These provisions are intended to cover disputes, litigation and other foreseeable contingencies in connection with the Group’s businesses, along with miscellaneous contingencies and expenses. 3.4.14. Share-based payment and employee benefits Share-based payment A free share plan was set up for certain Foncia Stark employees, who will receive remuneration in the form of share-based payments. The main characteristics of this plan are as follows: - Grant date: 23 May 2018. - Date on which the continuing employment condition is assessed: 23 May 2020. - Vesting period for the shares: between 23 May 2018 and 23 May 2020. - Maximum number of shares awarded: up to 205,000 free shares in the company, representing 5.125% of its ###### share capital. - Maximum aggregate amount of the free share plan: €410,000. - The shares awarded are monetised through a new liquidity contract that prices the share using a calculation ###### formula. - Corporate social contribution (forfait social): 20% of the free share plan. ----- ###### Since a liquidity contract has been set up, the shares awarded to beneficiaries will be settled in cash. The free share plan therefore meets the definition of a “cash-settled” plan set out in IFRS 2. Consequently, the service cost is recognised on a straight-line basis over the vesting period of the rights, with a direct offsetting entry to employee-related liabilities. This service cost is reviewed each year in light of budget assumptions and employee turnover. At 31 December 2019, the free share plan only concerned one employee and 100,000 free shares, representing a maximum aggregate amount of €200,000. The other beneficiaries of the plan had left the company. The impact of the revised service cost was recognised in the statement of profit and loss, with a corresponding adjustment to employee-related liabilities. The net service cost for 2019 represents €20,000 on account of the provision accrued in 2018. This cost was included within capitalised production with an adjusting entry to employee-related payables. It will be amortised as from the date the “Millénium” project (development of new management software for the property management network) enters into service. There are no stock option or free share plans in place at Foncia Management. Pensions and other post-employment benefits  Short-term benefits Short-term benefits include paid annual leave, paid sick leave, bonuses and other benefits (other than contract termination benefits), expected to be settled wholly before 12 months after the end of the annual reporting period during which the employee services are rendered. Short-term benefits are expensed in the period in which the corresponding services are rendered by the employee. Any amounts not paid at the end of the reporting period are carried in current liabilities.  Post-employment benefits In accordance with the laws and practices in each of the countries in which the Group operates, Foncia participates in, or operates, benefit plans providing for the payment of post-employment benefits (including retirement benefits) to eligible current and former employees, retirees and their beneficiaries. Virtually all of the Group’s employees are entitled to pension benefits. In France, this takes the form of payments by the Foncia Group to the beneficiaries when the rights allotted vest, while in Switzerland, plans are managed by pension funds financed in compliance with the applicable government requirements and regulations. These plans may be funded by investments in various instruments such as insurance policies, equity instruments and bonds. Post-employment benefits are measured and recognised by the Group in accordance with IAS 19 – Employee Benefits, as described below. - Defined contribution plans ###### Defined contribution plans and multi-employer plans are expensed as incurred in the statement of profit and loss based on contributions. - Defined benefit plans ###### The cost of defined benefit plans is measured on an actuarial basis. The related obligations are calculated by independent actuaries using the projected unit credit method, based on the agreements in effect in each company. Obligations are determined by reference to assumptions that are revised each year and relate for example to length of service, life expectancy, salary inflation and employee turnover, and also take into account macroeconomic assumptions for the various countries in which the Group does business (e.g., discount rate and inflation rate). The assumptions used for 2019 are detailed in Note 4.13. ----- ###### A provision is recognised in the statement of financial position for the difference between the related projected benefit obligation (actuarial liability) and any plan assets as measured at fair value, and includes past service costs and actuarial gains and losses. If plan assets exceed the projected benefit obligation recognised, a non-current asset is recorded for the amount of the plans in the consolidated statement of financial position. A funding surplus (net defined benefit asset) is only recognised in the statement of financial position if its represents future economic benefits that will actually be available to the Group. When the calculation of the net benefit obligation gives rise to an asset for the Group, the amount recognised as an asset cannot exceed the present value of any economic benefits available in the form of refunds from the plan or future reductions in contributions to the plan. Expenses under defined benefit plans comprise three components, accounted for as described below: - Service cost is recognised under personnel costs within operating profit. It includes service cost for the period, past service cost resulting from plan amendments or curtailments, which are recognised in full in profit or loss for the period in which they arose, and gains and losses arising on plan settlements. - Interest cost is recognised in other financial income and expenses and reflects the impact of discounting the obligations, net of the expected return on plan assets as measured using the discount rate applied to calculate those obligations. - Remeasurements of the net liability (or net asset) are included in other comprehensive income not reclassifiable to profit or loss, and do not impact the statement of profit and loss. They essentially comprise actuarial gains and losses, i.e., changes in the benefit obligation and in plan assets attributable to changes in assumptions and experience adjustments. Experience adjustments represent the difference between the expected impact of certain actuarial assumptions applied to previous measurements of the obligation and actual experience.  Other long-term benefits Other long-term benefits are measured in accordance with IAS 19. The estimated cost of these benefits is recognised within non-current liabilities over the employees’ qualifying years of service. Actuarial gains and losses and past service costs attributable to amendments to an existing plan or the introduction of a new plan are taken immediately to profit or loss. In France, the collective bargaining agreement for the real estate industry stipulates that all active employees who so request are entitled to one month’s salary at every anniversary date: after 20, 30, 35 and 40 years of professional experience. Professional experience is considered overall and not as experience solely within the Group. However, the Group is only liable for the amount proportionate to the employee’s seniority in the Group. The Group’s obligation under long-service awards is assessed each year by an independent expert. The assumptions used for 2019 are detailed in Note 4.13. 3.4.15. Deferred taxes Deferred taxes are recognised on temporary differences between the carrying amount of assets and liabilities and their value for tax purposes, using the tax rates expected to apply in the period in which the asset is realised and the liability settled, on the basis of tax laws that have been enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date. Deferred tax does not arise on: - the initial recognition of goodwill; - the initial recognition of an asset in a transaction that is not a business combination and affects neither the ###### accounting profit (loss) nor taxable profit (loss); ----- - temporary differences related to investments in subsidiaries, to the extent that it is probable they will not ###### reverse in the foreseeable future. Tax on items recognised directly in equity or in other comprehensive income is recognised in equity or in other comprehensive income, respectively, and not in the statement of profit and loss. Deferred tax assets arising on temporary differences (after offsetting against deferred tax liabilities) or on tax losses and tax credits carried forward are only recognised to the extent that it is probable they will reverse and that the Group will generate future taxable earnings against which they can be utilised. The following are taken into account when assessing the Group’s ability to recover these assets: - forecasts of future taxable earnings; - taxable earnings in previous years. ###### Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset if there is a legally enforceable right to offset current tax assets and liabilities, and if they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority on the same taxable entity. 3.4.16. Trade payables and other current liabilities Trade payables and other current liabilities are liabilities to be settled or renegotiated within the ordinary operating cycle or within 12 months following the end of the reporting period. Trade payables and other liabilities meet the definition of financial liabilities at amortised cost as defined by IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments (see Note 3.4.10). These financial liabilities are initially recognised at nominal value, insofar as this represents a reasonable estimate of their fair value given their short-term nature. The value of items that will be paid over the long term is discounted. 3.4.17. Classification and measurement of financial assets and liabilities at fair value The fair value of all financial assets and liabilities is determined at the end of the reporting period, either for accounting purposes or for disclosure in the notes to the financial statements. Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. IFRS 13 sets out a three-level hierarchy for determining fair value: - Level 1: quoted (unadjusted) prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities. - Level 2: inputs other than quoted market prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or ###### liability, either directly (i.e., prices) or indirectly (i.e., price-based inputs). - Level 3: inputs relating to the asset or liability which are not based on observable market data (unobservable ###### inputs). The Group primarily uses fair value on a recurring basis in its statement of financial position to measure derivative instruments, cash and cash equivalents, available-for-sale financial assets, cash management financial assets and identifiable assets and liabilities acquired as part of a business combination. The fair values of financial assets and liabilities are disclosed in Note 4.19. ----- ###### 3.4.18. Assets classified as held for sale, businesses sold or in the process of sale and discontinued operations IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations sets forth the accounting requirements applicable to assets held for sale, along with the presentation and disclosure requirements for discontinued operations. IFRS 5 requires assets held for sale to be presented on a separate line of the consolidated statement of financial position for the lower of their carrying amount and their fair value less costs to sell, provided that they meet the definition of assets held for sale set out in the standard. When the Group is engaged in a sale process resulting in the loss of control of a subsidiary, the entire assets and liabilities of that subsidiary are classified as held for sale when their carrying amount will be principally recovered through a sale transaction rather than through continuing use, regardless of whether or not the Group retains a residual interest in the subsidiary after the sale. For this to be the case, the asset (or disposal group) must be available for immediate sale in its present condition and the sale must be highly probable. The assets and liabilities concerned are reclassified in assets held for sale and liabilities related to assets held for sale, and no offsetting is permitted. Businesses sold or in the process of sale are presented on a separate line in the statement of profit and loss for the periods presented, which shows post-tax profit or loss attributable to discontinued operations and the post-tax gain or loss on the disposal or the measurement to fair value less costs to sell of the assets or disposal groups comprising the business sold or in the process of sale. A business sold or in the process of sale discontinued operation is defined as a component of an entity that represents a separate major line of business and meets the criteria for classification as an asset held for sale or has been sold by the Group. Similarly, cash flows attributable to businesses sold or in the process of sale are presented on a separate line of the consolidated statement of cash flows for the periods presented. Under IFRS 5, profits or losses related to discontinued operations are also to be shown on a separate line of the consolidated statement of profit and loss, retrospectively for all periods presented. A discontinued operation can be defined as a component of an entity that either has been disposed of or is classified as held for sale and:  represents a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations;  is part of a single coordinated plan to dispose of a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations; or  is a subsidiary acquired exclusively with a view to resale. 3.4.19. Presentation of the statement of profit and loss As permitted under IAS 1 – Presentation of Financial Statements, the Group has chosen to present operating expenses by nature. “Recurring operating profit (loss)”, “Operating profit (loss)”, “Cost of gross debt” and “Cost of net debt” in the statement of profit and loss and gains and losses recognised directly in equity are presented in accordance with the criteria set out in ANC Recommendation No. 2013-03 issued by the French accounting standards-setter (Autorité des Normes Comptables). ----- ###### 3.4.20. Revenue Revenue for the Group results from sales of services within the scope of the ordinary operations of consolidated subsidiaries, less revenue from intragroup transactions. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable, net of discounts and rebates, VAT and other taxes and duties. In accordance with IFRS 15, the Group recognises revenue when the amount thereof can be reliably measured, it is probable that future economic benefits will flow to the Group, and specific criteria are met by each of the Group’s businesses.  Jointly owned property management business From a contractual and legal perspective, the Group’s jointly owned property management business is mostly conducted through mandates, and fees are calculated on a flat-rate basis. In France, this flat rate includes all basic management services provided by the jointly owned property association, and excludes incidental services such as:  preparing, convening and organising General Meetings;  managing the joint owners’ council;  managing the financial operations and keeping the accounts of the jointly owned property association;  managing the jointly owned property in compliance with its rules and regulations;  carrying out periodic visits and inspections of the jointly owned property. All such services are treated as an overall performance obligation satisfied over time. In fact, these different services are associated with a single performance obligation, i.e., management of the jointly owned property association. Annual revenue from basic property management fees is therefore recognised on a percentage-of-completion basis (over time) based on actual amounts billed (costs are in line with the billed amounts). Incidental services may be added to the basic management services and are invoiced based on an agreed rate for each such service, for example, additional meetings and visits, rules and regulations of the jointly owned property, physical and administrative management of claims, technical work and surveys, litigation and disputes. Since each additional service represents a separate performance obligation, revenue is recognised when the service is performed.  Rental management business In its rental management business, the Group acts as agent for owners-lessors and fulfils a certain number of contractually defined obligations in this regard. These mainly concern:  routine management services, for example, rent reviews and collection, annual adjustment invoice for expenses, sending of rent receipts to lessees, and deposits;  other one-off management services, including preparation of the lease contract, inventory of premises, compilation of documentation, management of claims, administrative filings, and requests for subsidies;  technical management services, such as on-site repairs, mandatory technical surveys, and preparation of essential information documents for lessees;  insurance against unpaid rent;  other insurance such as for vacant premises or property damage. These represent separate service obligations. Accordingly, revenue for each of these obligations is recognised separately. Revenue from services provided over time, such as routine management services and insurance (falling outside the scope of IFRS 4) is recognised on a percentage-of-completion basis by reference to the frequency with which expenses are rebilled to the owners. Revenue from one-off services is recognised when those services are provided. ----- ######  Lettings Revenue is recognised at the time the inventory of the premises is conducted. The Group collects fees from owners and from lessees.  Transactions business/Efficity Revenue on the transactions business is recognised upon signature of the notarised final sale agreement (acte authentique), which is the date on which control is presumed to have been transferred.  Client accounts Interest income generated on client funds is booked in revenue.  Assurimo Assurismo provides property insurance brokerage services. Revenue under comprehensive property insurance and comprehensive homeowners’ insurance policies is recognised over the term of the cover, since services in this brokerage business are provided on a straight-line basis.  Constatimmo Constatimmo carries out mandatory technical surveys on premises, as well as inventories of premises for lessees. Its revenue is recognised and measured when the related services are performed.  Seiitra Seiitra provides specialist IT property services and developed the Thetrawin software, which it markets through the sale of software licenses. These property management tools offer the full suite of functionalities needed to keep accounting records for client accounts and to manage suspense accounts, jointly owned properties and rentals, as well as the budget of jointly owned property associations. Maintenance fees are recognised on a straight-line, percentage-of-completion basis, since the corresponding services are provided over time.  Esset Management Esset Management provides property management services (jointly owned property management and rental services) for institutions. The accounting principles applied are the same as those explained above for the private property management business.  Foncia Valorisation Foncia Valorisation provides investment strategy consulting and arbitrage (appraisals, lending, block/unit property sales) for institutional clients or wealthy families. Its revenue is recognised at the date the notarised final sale agreement is signed and is based on a percentage of the sale price.  Leeemo Leemo, a wholly-owned Group subsidiary since 2017, is a listing service for properties for sale. It has developed a digital platform for property companies where it lists new real estate projects by different developers as well as certain older properties that are to be made available for sale to private and institutional investors. It derives its revenue from two main sources:  fees on sale agreements: amounts billed to developers and partially retroceded to business providers. Only the net margin is recognised in revenue.  fees on bundles of services sold to developers without any retrocession requirements. ----- ###### Revenue from fees on sale agreements is recognised when the notarised final sale agreement is signed. Revenue from fees earned on bundles of services is recognised on a pro rata basis in the period. 3.4.21. Recurring operating profit (loss) Recurring operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, with the exception of items classified within “Non-recurring operating income (expenses)”. Recurring operating profit (loss) is a performance indicator that may serve as a method for estimating recurring performance. It includes all items included in operating profit (loss), restated for any non-recurring items.  Costs relating to business combinations or restructuring are excluded from recurring operating profit (loss). 3.4.22. Non-recurring operating income (expenses) This caption includes income and expense items that, owing to their nature, amount or frequency, cannot be considered as arising in the ordinary course of the Group’s operations and are therefore not reported in recurring operating profit (loss). Non-recurring items are limited, unusual and/or irregular items of a material amount. They include impacts of changes in the scope of consolidation, goodwill impairment, and amortisation and impairment charged against trademarks and software. If material, non-recurring items also include the effects of certain unusual transactions such as capital gains and losses on disposals of non-current assets, restructuring fees, fees relating to major claims and disputes, and any other income or expenses likely to affect the comparability of recurring operating profit (loss) from one period to the next. It should be noted that for transactions directly related to external growth and projects to transform or restructure the business (particularly mergers and reorganisations), a detailed procedure is in place to identify, classify and validate any transactions of a non-recurring nature. This procedure gives a precise indication of transactions that meet the criteria to be recorded in this category. 3.4.23. Operating profit (loss) Operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, irrespective of whether they are of a recurring nature or whether they result from one-off decisions or transactions. 3.4.24. Cost of net debt The cost of net debt is equal to all financial expenses on borrowings, less financial income from cash investments. 3.4.25. Income tax Income tax expense for the year includes current and deferred income tax expense, which are recognised in the statement of profit and loss except when they relate to items recognised in other comprehensive income. The Group calculates its current taxes in accordance with the tax legislation applicable in the countries in which its earnings are taxable. Current tax expense is calculated on the basis of tax laws enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date in countries where the Group’s subsidiaries operate and generate taxable profit. However, management periodically reviews the positions adopted in tax returns for situations in which tax regulations are subject to interpretation. Where applicable, a provision is set aside based on the amounts payable to the tax authorities. Income tax expense includes the amounts reported by French subsidiaries in respect of the CVAE tax assessed on value added, since the Group considers this tax meets the definition of income tax set out in IAS 12 – Income Taxes. ----- ###### When they have not been set against income tax, income tax credits that are not included in the calculation of taxable profit and that are always refunded by the State are recorded as subsidies and reduce the expenses to which they relate. 3.4.26. Earnings (loss) per share Earnings (loss) per share corresponds to profit (loss) attributable to holders of ordinary shares divided by the weighted average number of ordinary shares outstanding during the reporting period (excluding treasury shares). Operating segments The Group is not concerned by IFRS 8 – Operating Segments. Revenue is broken down by business in Note 5.1. 3.4.27. Statement of cash flows Consolidated cash and cash equivalents, changes in which are displayed in the statement of cash flows, are defined as the net balance of cash and cash equivalents, current bank overdraft facilities and bank credit balances repayable on demand that form an integral part of the cash management strategy. Changes in cash from operating activities are calculated based on operating profit (loss) adjusted for transactions with no cash impact. ----- ###### NOTE 4. Leases Loans and receivables Amortised cost SPPI Hold-to-collect Amortised cost Assets at fair value FV through PL SPPI Other FV through PL through PL ###### Operating leases Payments made under operating leases are expensed in profit or loss on a straight-line basis over the lease term.
