In accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9, derivative instruments are measured on the statement of financial position at fair value. Changes in the fair value of instruments not eligible for hedge accounting are recognised in profit or loss under other financial income and expenses. ----- ###### 3.4.14. Current and non-current provisions A provision is recognised when, at the end of the reporting period, the Group has a legal or constructive obligation to a third party resulting from a past event that is likely to give rise to an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits and can be measured reliably. When the Group expects partial or full repayment of the provision, for example owing to an insurance policy, the repayment is booked as a separate asset but only if such repayment is virtually certain. Since provisions are estimated based on assumptions regarding future contingencies and expenses, the amount thereof is based partly on uncertain factors and may be adjusted in future periods. The impact of discounting is taken into account only if it is material. Items giving rise to provisions (trade and labour disputes, etc.) are reviewed regularly to allow for any adjustments. The amount accrued in provisions represents the Group’s best estimate of the net outflow of resources. Provisions may also be recognised for contingent liabilities arising on business combinations. In this case, they are initially recognised at fair value at the acquisition date. At the end of subsequent reporting periods, they are measured at the higher of the amount recognized in accordance with IAS 37 and the amount recorded on initial recognition, less any cumulative income recognised in accordance with IFRS 15. Employee-related provisions (labour disputes, lay-offs, etc.) At the end of each reporting period, a provision is recognised and adjusted in line with the risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Human Resources department on a case-by-case basis. Provisions for rent payment guarantees A rent payment guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Foncia with the management of their property. Foncia bears the cost of any unpaid rent and advances to owners. These advances are not always recoverable from the lessee and therefore represent a risk of non-recovery. Rent payment guarantees are incidental to the property management contracts (deriving from the del credere agreement) and are accounted for as follows: - the related fees are recorded continuously in income over the period of the mandate, since they are deducted ###### from rents in the same way as basic fees; - once rent is reported as unpaid, a provision is recorded, calculated in accordance with IAS 37. ###### The Group has set up a provision for risks relating to rent payment guarantees based on a progressive provisioning rate that increases in line with the age of the debt. Provision for occupancy guarantees An occupancy guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Foncia with the management of their property. The provision for occupancy guarantees is calculated on a statistical basis by reference to the probable residual vacant period for properties currently vacant and subject to occupancy guarantees. Provision for URSSAF social security audits A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the related risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Payroll department on a case-by-case basis. ----- ###### Provisions for risks on client accounts A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the risk exposure on customer accounts (debit accounts, etc.), as assessed by the Group’s Customer Operations department on a case-by-case basis. Provisions for third party and professional liability These provisions are recorded based on information provided by senior managers in charge of monitoring claims against the Group. The Audit, Legal and Accounting departments have the final decision in terms of whether or not to record a provision. Provisions for other disputes These provisions are intended to cover disputes, litigation and other foreseeable contingencies in connection with the Group’s businesses, along with miscellaneous contingencies and expenses. Update on the UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) dispute On 1 October 2014, UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) brought proceedings against Foncia Groupe before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance (regional court) seeking damages for losses allegedly suffered by lessees of Foncia-managed properties who were unduly charged for receiving notices to pay (avis d’échéance). More specifically, UFC is seeking payment from Foncia Groupe of an amount of €2.30 per month and per lessee over a period of five years and estimates the number of lessees concerned at 318,400, bringing the total damages to €44 million. In its defence, the Group argues that the French law of 6 July 1989 on residential lease agreements, upon the basis of which UFC filed its claim, made no provision for class actions at the time of the alleged offence; that no law existed preventing the company from charging lessees for receiving notices to pay; and that this was therefore a lawful practice. Oral arguments were exchanged before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance in March 2018. The decision handed down in May 2018 dismissed UFC’s claims on the grounds that they fell outside the scope of a class action. UFC has appealed this decision and the case is pending hearings before the Court of Appeal. The Group considers that no provision needs to be accrued in this respect in its financial statements at 31 December 2018. Update on the dispute with franchisees Certain franchisees brought proceedings against Foncia after having been notified that their contracts would not be renewed. They accuse the Group of wrongful termination and various breaches of the franchise agreements. Of the 19 initial lawsuits in 2014, Foncia either settled (most sensitive disputes), or won (before the lower court or on appeal) the cases. Only eight franchisees took their case to the Cour de Cassation (supreme court), which partially struck down the appeal rulings that had found in favour of Foncia. The eight cases therefore face a retrial before a court of appeal to which the case has been referred. The decisions are expected in early 2020. At 31 December 2018, the provision set aside in respect of these disputes represented €1.1 million. ----- ###### 3.4.15. Provisions for employee benefits Share-based payment As indicated in the “Highlights of the period” section, a free share plan was set up by Foncia Stark on 23 May 2018. The main characteristics of the plan along with the accounting treatment applied are explained in Note 2.4. There are no stock option or free share plans in place at Foncia Management. Pensions and other post-employment benefits Short-term benefits Short-term benefits (wages and salaries, payroll taxes, paid leave, etc.) are expensed in the period in which the corresponding services are provided by the employee. Any amounts not paid at the end of the reporting period are carried in current liabilities. Post-employment benefits In accordance with the laws and practices in each of the countries in which the Group operates, Foncia participates in, or operates, benefit plans providing for the payment of post-employment benefits (including retirement benefits) to eligible current and former employees, retirees and their beneficiaries. Virtually all of the Group’s employees are entitled to pension benefits. In France, this takes the form of payments by the Foncia Group to the beneficiaries when the rights allotted vest, while in Switzerland, plans are managed by pension funds funded in accordance with the applicable obligations and government regulations. - Defined contribution plans ###### Defined contribution plans and multi-employer plans are expensed as incurred in the statement of profit and loss. - Defined benefit plans ###### Defined benefit plans may be funded by investments in various instruments such as insurance policies, equity instruments and bonds. Pension obligations and expenses are calculated by independent actuaries using the projected unit credit method. This method is based on assumptions that are reviewed on a yearly basis, including the probability that the employee will remain in the Group until retirement, expected future salary trends, life expectancy and an appropriate discount rate for each of the countries in which the Group operates a pension plan. The assumptions used in respect of 2018 are detailed in Note 4.12. A provision is recognised in the statement of financial position for the difference between the related projected benefit obligation (actuarial liability) and any plan assets as measured at fair value, and includes past service costs and actuarial gains and losses. Expenses under defined benefit plans comprise three components, accounted for as described below: - Service cost is recognised in personnel costs. It includes service cost for the period, past service cost resulting from plan amendments or curtailments, which are recognised in full in profit or loss for the period in which they arose, and gains and losses arising on plan settlements. - Interest cost is recognised in other financial income and expenses and reflects the impact of discounting the obligations, net of the expected return on plan assets as measured using the discount rate applied to calculate those obligations. ----- ###### - Gains and losses on remeasuring the benefit obligation (plan asset) are recognised in other comprehensive income not reclassifiable to profit or loss, and essentially comprise actuarial gains and losses, i.e., changes in the benefit obligation and in plan assets attributable to changes in assumptions and experience adjustments. Experience adjustments represent the difference between the expected impact of certain actuarial assumptions applied to previous measurements of the obligation and actual experience. If plan assets exceed the benefit obligation, a financial asset is recorded up to the amount of the present value of future refunds from the plan or reductions in future contributions to the plan. Other benefits: long-service awards In France, the collective bargaining agreement for the real estate industry stipulates that all active employees who so request are entitled to one month’s salary at every anniversary date: after 20, 30, 35 and 40 years of professional experience. Professional experience is considered overall and not as experience solely within the Group. However, the Group is only liable for the amount proportionate to the employee’s seniority in the Group. The Group’s obligation under long-service awards is assessed each year by an independent expert. The assumptions used in respect of 2018 are detailed in Note 4.12. 3.4.16. Income tax Income tax for the period includes current and deferred taxes. Current and deferred taxes are recognised in the statement of profit and loss, except when they relate to items recognised in other comprehensive income. The Group calculates its current taxes in accordance with the tax legislation applicable in the countries in which its earnings are taxable. Current tax expense is calculated on the basis of tax laws enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date in countries where the Group’s subsidiaries operate and generate taxable profit. However, management periodically reviews the positions adopted in tax returns for situations in which tax regulations are subject to interpretation. Where applicable, a provision is set aside based on the amounts payable to the tax authorities. Deferred tax is recognised using the liability method on: - all temporary differences between the tax base and the carrying amount of assets and liabilities, excluding ###### goodwill; - tax loss carryforwards. ###### Deferred tax is calculated based on the tax rates (and tax laws) that have been enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date and are expected to apply when the deferred tax asset is realised or the deferred tax liability settled. Deferred tax assets arising on temporary differences or on tax losses and tax credits carried forward are only recognised to the extent it is probable that they will reverse and that the Group will generate future taxable profit against which they can be utilised. The following are taken into account when assessing the Group’s ability to recover these assets: - forecasts of future taxable earnings; - taxable earnings in previous years. ###### Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset when the entity has a right to set off a current tax asset against a current tax liability and when they relate to income taxes levied by the same tax authority on the same tax entity or on different tax entities when there is an intention to settle the amounts on a net basis. ----- ###### In accordance with the CNC (Conseil National de la Comptabilité – former French accounting standards-setter) position statement published on 14 January 2010, the Group has used its judgement in determining how to treat the CVAE (Cotisation sur la Valeur Ajoutée) tax assessed on value added in France. The Group considers that since the base for the CVAE tax is the difference between income and expenses, the tax falls within the scope of IAS 12. Accordingly, the CVAE tax is included under “Income tax benefit (expense)”. 3.4.17. Current liabilities Current liabilities are liabilities to be settled or renegotiated within the ordinary operating cycle or within 12 months following the end of the reporting period. Due to their short-term nature, the carrying amounts shown in the consolidated financial statements are reasonable estimates of their market value. The value of items that will be paid over the long term is discounted. 3.4.18. Classification and measurement of financial assets and liabilities at fair value The fair value of all financial assets and liabilities is determined at the end of the reporting period, either for accounting purposes or for disclosure in the notes. Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. IFRS 13 sets out a three-level hierarchy for determining fair value: - Level 1: quoted (unadjusted) prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities. - Level 2: inputs other than quoted market prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or ###### liability, either directly (i.e., prices) or indirectly (i.e., price-based inputs). - Level 3: inputs relating to the asset or liability which are not based on observable market data (unobservable ###### inputs). The Group primarily uses fair value on a recurring basis in its statement of financial position to measure derivative instruments, cash and cash equivalents, available-for-sale financial assets, cash management financial assets and identifiable assets and liabilities acquired as part of a business combination. The fair values of financial assets and liabilities are disclosed in Note 4.18. 3.4.19. Assets classified as held for sale and discontinued operations IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations sets forth the accounting requirements applicable to assets held for sale, along with the presentation and disclosure requirements for discontinued operations. A non-current asset or disposal group is held for sale when its carrying amount will be recovered principally through a sale transaction rather than through continuing use. For this to be the case, the asset (or disposal group) must be available for immediate sale in its present condition and the sale must be highly probable. The assets and liabilities concerned are reclassified in assets held for sale and liabilities related to assets held for sale, and no offsetting is permitted. Assets reclassified in this category are carried at the lower of their fair value less costs to sell and their carrying amount, i.e., at cost less accumulated depreciation/amortisation and impairment losses, and are no longer depreciated/amortised. A discontinued operation is defined as a component of an entity that represents a separate major line of business and meets the criteria for classification as an asset held for sale or has been sold by the Group. ----- ###### Discontinued operations are presented on a separate line in the statement of profit and loss for the periods presented, which shows post-tax profit or loss attributable to discontinued operations and the post-tax gain or loss on the disposal or the measurement to fair value less costs to sell of the assets or disposal groups comprising the discontinued operation. Similarly, cash flows attributable to discontinued operations are presented on a separate line of the consolidated statement of cash flows for the periods presented. A discontinued operation can also be defined as a component of an entity that either has been disposed of or is classified as held for sale and: ▪ represents a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations; ▪ is part of a single coordinated plan to dispose of a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations; or ▪ is a subsidiary acquired exclusively with a view to resale. 3.4.20. Presentation of the statement of profit and loss As allowed under IAS 1 – Presentation of Financial Statements, the Group has chosen to present operating expenses by nature. “Recurring operating profit (loss)”, “Operating profit (loss)”, “Cost of gross debt” and “Cost of net debt” in the statement of profit and loss and gains and losses recognised directly in equity are presented in accordance with the criteria set out in ANC Recommendation No. 2013-03 issued by the French accounting standards-setter (Autorité des Normes Comptables). 3.4.21. Revenue Revenue corresponds to proceeds from sales of goods and services within the scope of the ordinary operations of fully consolidated companies. All revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable, net of discounts and rebates, VAT and other taxes. In accordance with the new IFRS 15, the Group recognises revenue when the amount of revenue can be reliably measured, it is probable that future economic benefits will flow to the entity, and specific criteria are met by each of the Group’s businesses. Negotiation fees and commission (sales and rentals) are recognised in revenue when they are received or effectively due at the end of the reporting period. Interest income arising on client funds is also booked in revenue. 3.4.22. Recurring operating profit (loss) Recurring operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, with the exception of items classified within “Non-recurring operating income (expenses)”. Recurring operating profit (loss) is a performance indicator that may serve as a method for estimating recurring performance. It includes all items included in operating profit (loss) restated for any non-recurring items. Costs relating to business combinations or restructuring are excluded from recurring operating profit (loss). 3.4.23. Non-recurring operating income (expenses) Non-recurring operating income and expenses are recorded if a major event occurs during the reporting period that could distort the interpretation of the entity’s performance. Non-recurring items are limited, unusual and/or irregular items of a material amount and are detailed in Note 5 8 ----- ###### 3.4.24. Operating profit (loss) Operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, irrespective of whether they are of a recurring nature or whether they result from one-off decisions or transactions. 3.4.25. Cost of net debt The cost of net debt is equal to all financial expenses on borrowings, less financial income from cash investments. 3.4.26. Earnings (loss) per share Earnings (loss) per share corresponds to profit (loss) attributable to holders of ordinary shares divided by the weighted average number of ordinary shares outstanding during the reporting period (excluding treasury shares). 3.4.27. Segment reporting The Group is not concerned by IFRS 8 – Operating Segments. Revenue is broken down by business in Note 5.1. ----- ###### NOTE 4. It should be noted that the process of identifying the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of the acquisitions in 2020 of Yxime and Gérance de Passy was still in progress at 31 December 2020. Accordingly, the goodwill currently recognised is provisional. 4.1.2. 2020 impairment tests The assumptions used in the tests and the approach applied are described below. Impacts of IFRS 16 on the impairment testing approach IFRS 16 significantly overhauls the inputs used in impairment tests, including the net amount tested, debt and valuation multiples. It therefore requires entities to reconsider their testing approach. In this regard, several different approaches are consistently accepted by the regulators. The first, which complies with IAS 36, involves increasing the carrying amount of the CGU by the amount of the right-of-use asset, without taking into account the IFRS 16 lease liability. This approach represents a change of practice and introduces a degree of complexity into the calculation of value in use, since (i) cash flows relating solely to fixed lease payments or similar are excluded from the calculation insofar as they constitute the new lease liability, (ii) the cash outflows required to renew the right-of-use assets are to be estimated (future reinvestment flows affecting both the series of annual projections and the terminal value), and (iii) the discount rate is to be adjusted (estimated impact on the WACC of the new cost of capital/cost of debt ratio). The second approach is similar to the one described above and involves eliminating the lease liability from the carrying amount of the CGU and from the value in use. This approach leads to similar difficulties as those seen above. The third solution is to maintain the pre-IFRS 16 approach in terms of projecting future cash flows. Although the carrying amount of the CGU changes (increase in the value of the right-of-use asset net of the lease liability), the calculation of value in use is not affected:  projected cash outflows relating to lease payments remain unchanged for both the annual forecasts and for the terminal value;  the discount rate is determined by reference to pre-IFRS 16 inputs (no change in the cost of debt and the debt-to-equity ratio). The Group chose to maintain the third approach for its impairment tests in 2020. Calculation of the carrying amount of CGUs at 31 December 2020 Estimating the carrying amount of each CGU includes determining the value of the assets that may be directly attributed or reasonably allocated to the CGU and that will generate cash flows included in the calculation of value in use. However, the carrying amount does not include that of identified liabilities. In 2018, goodwill of €1,094.9 million arising on the acquisition of a controlling interest in Foncia Holding in September 2016 was allocated pro rata to the enterprise value of each CGU, as estimated based on the acquisition business plans for each CGU used within the scope of the purchase price accounting. ----- ###### Following the Group’s various acquisitions, goodwill allocated to each CGU can be analysed as follows:

###### Calculation of the recoverable amount of CGUs at 31 December 2020 In accordance with the Group’s impairment testing approach, and in the absence of observable fair values in an organised market, the recoverable amount of CGUs corresponds to their value in use, which is defined as the sum of their net cash flows based on the latest forecasts for each CGU, determined using: ▪ a business plan prepared by management based on growth and profitability assumptions, taking into account past performance, forecast changes in the economic environment, and expected market trends; |Goodwill|Col2| |---|---| |Property Holding company Management Services CGU International CGU Group CGU|| |Statement of financial position at 30 Sept. 2020 859 395 57 79 Allocation of holding company goodwill 620 223 15|1,390| |Goodwill by CGU 1,015 280 95|1,390| |Assets to be tested at 30 Sept. 2020|Col2| |---|---| |Property Holding company Management Services CGU International CGU Group CGU|| |Goodwill 1,015 280 95 Intangible assets 69 703 117 34 Property, plant and equipment 13 30 3 5 Deferred tax (205) 82 10 (1) Working capital (45) (88) 75 (43)|1,390 924 51 (115) (101)| |Assets to be tested before holding company allocation (168) 1,742 484 90|2,148| |Allocation of holding company assets 100% 0% 0%|100%| |Total assets to be tested 1,574 484 90|2,148| ----- ###### ▪ a terminal value calculated by capitalising normative cash flows obtained by extrapolating cash flows from the final year of the business plan, with a stable growth rate or a growth rate increasing steadily over the long term; ▪ expected cash flows discounted at a rate determined by reference to the weighted average cost of capital (WACC). The financial forecasts used in the impairment tests carried out at 31 December 2020 were prepared by management and cover a period of five years. They provide a consolidated view as well as a breakdown by CGU. It should be noted that all holding company expenses not allocated in the consolidated business plan were allocated in full to the Property Management France CGU. Corporate functions are managed at individual country-level for the Property Management International CGU and are considered not material for the Services CGU. The discount rate used is the weighted average cost of capital (WACC), calculated based on a sample of comparable European companies. A WACC was estimated for each foreign country and then for the entire Foncia Group based on a weighting of each country’s contribution to total EBITDA. On this basis, a single weighted discount rate of 8% was used for all of the Group’s CGUs. By way of reminder, a single weighted discount rate of 7.4% was used for all of the Group’s CGUs in 2019. This rate was adjusted in 2020 to reflect the changes in the economic climate.

###### A long-term growth rate of 2% was used for the tests. This rate was estimated using information provided by public databases such as the IMF and EIU (Economic Intelligence Unit), or by analysts’ reports on companies in the industry or on the economy more generally. A long-term growth rate of 1.8% was used for the tests in 2019. Assumptions relating to the health crisis and result of tests Although the health crisis represents a sudden, one-off event, it does not call the Group’s growth model into question. In drawing up its business plans, management expects the wider economic environment to gradually improve by the end of 2021. Based on these expectations, the impacts of the Covid-19 health crisis on business levels and on the profitability of its different CGUs were mainly taken into account in 2020 and to a lesser extent in 2021. Based on the impairment tests carried out, the value in use of each CGU exceeds the CGU’s carrying amount and as a result, no impairment needed to be recognised against the Group’s assets at 31 December 2020. In accordance with the requirements of articles L.823-9 and R.823-7 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce) relating to the justification of our assessments, we inform you of the following assessments that, in our professional judgement, were the most significant in our audit of the consolidated financial statements. These matters were addressed as part of our audit of the consolidated financial statements as a whole, approved in the context described above, and therefore contributed to the opinion we formed as expressed above. We do not provide a separate opinion on specific items of the consolidated financial statements. The Group tests goodwill and assets with indefinite useful lives for impairment on an annual basis, in accordance with the methods presented in notes 3.4.8 – Impairment of assets, and 4.1.2 – 2019 impairment tests. We examined the methods used by the Group to test for impairment, together with the cash flow forecasts and assumptions relied upon for that purpose. We further verified that the notes provide appropriate disclosures. As part of our assessments, we also ensured that the estimates used were reasonable. In accordance with the requirements of articles L.823-9 and R.823-7 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce) relating to the justification of our assessments, we inform you of the following assessments that, in our professional judgement, were the most significant in our audit of the consolidated financial statements. These matters were addressed as part of our audit of the consolidated financial statements as a whole, and therefore contributed to the opinion we formed as expressed above. We do not provide a separate opinion on specific items of the consolidated financial statements. The Group tests goodwill and assets with indefinite useful lives for impairment on an annual basis, in accordance with the methods presented in Notes 3.4.7 – Impairment losses on goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment and 4.1.3 – Assumptions used in the 2018 impairment tests, to the consolidated financial statements. We examined the methods used by the Group to test for impairment, together with the cash flow forecasts and assumptions relied upon for that purpose. We further verified that the notes provide appropriate disclosures. As part of our assessments, we also ensured that the estimates used were reasonable.

GENERAL PRESENTATION Information concerning the Foncia Management Group Foncia Management is a French simplified joint stock company (société par actions simplifiée) with a sole shareholder, subject to all regulations governing commercial companies in France, and in particular the provisions of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce). Its registered office is located at 13 avenue Lebrun, 92160 Antony, France. Description of Group businesses Foncia Groupe is a European leader in residential property services. It assists its clients at all stages of the property life cycle, with a comprehensive, integrated service offering that includes management of jointly owned properties, round-the-clock assistance, rental management, rentals, sales, purchases, holiday lettings, appraisals, insurance, technical surveys and energy brokerage. Foncia operates in France, Germany, Belgium and Switzerland. Information presented Statutory 2017 consolidated financial statements The Foncia Management Group (the “Group”) comprising Foncia Management and its subsidiaries, was created on 7 September 2016 further to the acquisition of a controlling interest in the Foncia Holding group. The Group prepared its consolidated financial statements for the first time for the period ended 31 December 2017. These financial statements covered: - 20 months of operations for Foncia Management, from its creation in May 2016 to 31 December 2017; - 16 months of operations for the Foncia Holding group, from its acquisition by Foncia Management on ###### 7 September 2016 to 31 December 2017. Since this does not allow a meaningful comparison with results of operations for an equivalent 12-month period, profit and loss data for the period ended 31 December 2017 are not used as comparative data. They are included for information purposes under “2017 (presented)”. Pro forma 2017 consolidated financial statements The pro forma 2017 results of operations include 12 months of operations for Foncia Management and the Foncia Holding group. The main accounting policies applied are the same as those applied to prepare the statutory consolidated financial statements of Foncia Management. However, the Group applied IFRS 15 on revenue recognition and IFRS 9 on financial instruments for the first time in 2018. Accordingly, the first-time application impacts have been separated out for 2017 to enable a meaningful comparison. The consolidated results of operations for the period ended 31 December 2017 have been restated to reflect the application of these standards as if they had been applied from 1 January 2017. These restated figures appear throughout as “2017 (restated pro forma)”. 2018 consolidated financial statements The 2018 consolidated financial statements reflect the statutory financial statements and do not contain any pro forma restatements. They have been prepared in accordance with international accounting standards and ----- ###### interpretations (IAS/IFRS) as adopted by the European Union and applicable at 1 January 2018. Consequently, they include the impacts of the first-time application of IFRS 15 and IFRS 9. NOTE 2. HIGHLIGHTS OF THE PERIOD External growth investments (acquisitions) and changes in the scope of consolidation The Group acquired 54 companies in the period, thereby continuing its acquisition-led growth. The companies concerned are mainly property management companies with the exception of Lodgis, whose furnished property rental business rounds out the Group’s commercial offering. None of these acquisitions are subject to any specific contingent consideration or earn-out clauses. GENERAL PRESENTATION Information concerning the Foncia Management Group Foncia Management is a French simplified joint stock company (société par actions simplifiée) with a sole shareholder, subject to all regulations governing commercial companies in France, and in particular the provisions of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce). Its registered office is located at 13 avenue Lebrun, 92160 Antony, France. Description of Group businesses Founded in 1972, the Foncia Group is Europe’s leading provider of residential property services, and had over 10,000 employees at 31 December 2019. The Group operates in France, Switzerland, Germany and Belgium, assisting its clients at every stage of their property journey with a comprehensive residential service offering. From choosing a first rental property to purchasing a home to live in, building up an estate or supplementing their income, the Foncia Group provides end-to-end assistance to its clients throughout their real estate projects. The Group’s core business is residential property management, in which it enjoys strong leadership in France thanks to a network of over 500 branches across the country. Its main activities in this sector are:  Management of jointly owned properties: Foncia is the French market leader, managing over 45,000 properties each year. The Group assists its clients in managing their jointly owned properties (management of security and maintenance staff, payment of common costs, management of joint decisions, coordination of payments from co-owners). It also offers its clients cost management (reduction of energy, maintenance and heating costs) and asset appraisal services, as well as round-the-clock assistance. Thanks to a major external growth (acquisitions) strategy, this business is currently enjoying fast-paced expansion.  Rental management and lettings: Managing over 350,000 properties each year across France, Foncia assists its owner-lessor customers in appraising their property and securing their rental income. Rent payment guarantee services provide owner-lessors with guaranteed rental income should their lessees fail to make their rental payments. The Group also assists lessees, with over 70,000 new rentals each year and 15,000 seasonal rentals. The Group has also diversified into the following businesses:  Property transaction intermediation: With over 15,000 properties available across France, the Group supports its clients with their purchase or sale plans:  Property search services  Advice and assistance with banking and administrative formalities  Property appraisals, buyer solvency assessments, technical due diligence, etc.  Additional complementary services such as:  Specialised property insurance brokerage (Assurimo)  Technical due diligence and inventories (Constatimmo)  Wealth management and consulting services for commercial and office properties (Esset Management)  Business-specific IT services (Seiitra)   Marketing of properties by blocks or lots (Foncia Valorisation)  Technical homeowner maintenance ----- ###### NOTE 2. HIGHLIGHTS OF THE YEAR External growth investments (acquisitions) and changes in the scope of consolidation The Group acquired 65 companies in 2019, thereby continuing its acquisition-led growth. The companies acquired were mainly property management companies. None of these acquisitions are subject to any specific contingent consideration or earn-out clauses. ###### However, the number of consolidated entities remains in check owing to the various restructuring operations carried out in the period. The list of consolidated companies is presented in Note 13. External growth investments (acquisitions) represented a total of €141.1 million in 2019 (securities and business goodwill). Additional goodwill arising on these acquisitions represented €144.6 million (see Note 4.1). Disposal of the Investor division 2.2.1. Sale of Iplus and Foncia Pierre Gestion On 28 November 2019, the Group finalised its planned disposal of Iplus, selling all of its shares in Foncia Plus for a total amount of €1.3 million. At the same date, the Group also sold its non-controlling interest in Espace LMNP to the majority shareholder for a sale price of €0.4 million. On 27 December 2019, the Group finalised the sale of its entire interest in the subsidiary Foncia Pierre Gestion, which specialises in the management of real estate investment trusts (SCPI), for a total amount of €69 million. At 31 December 2019, the Group had collected the full amount of the sale proceeds, presented within “Change in scope of consolidation” in the statement of cash flows (see Note 4.10.4). 2.2.2. Reclassification of Foncia Primaliance as held for sale Primaliance is a brokerage platform specialising in the distribution of shares in real estate investments trusts (SCPI) and funds (OPCI) and in investment support services. The Supervisory Board authorised the launch of a process to sell this business in summer 2019, considering it a non-core activity for the Foncia Group. |Analysis of scope of consolidation at 31 December 2019|Change (8)| |---|---| |31 Dec. 2019 31 Dec. 2018 Full consolidation 239 247|| |Of which acquisitions 54 Of which newly created companies 3 Of which disposals during the period 1 Of which mergers and asset contributions (“TUP”) in 2019 ( 2) 61|54 3 (2) (63)| |Equity method 1 1|| |Total – France 240 248|(8)| |Full consolidation 43 36 Of which acquisitions during the period 11 Of which mergers and asset contributions (“TUP”) in 2019 ( 3) 1 Equity method 1 Of which deconsolidations during the period 1|7 11 (4) (1) (1)| |Total – International 43 37|6| ||| |Total – Consolidated entities 283 285|(2)| ----- ###### It should be recalled that Primaliance had been restructured as part of REIP (formerly Iplus Diffusion) in December 2018. For the purposes of the sale, on 31 October 2019 management spun off Primaliance to recreate it as a subsidiary within Foncia Primaliance, transferring to it the entire amount of Primaliance business goodwill (transfer by REIP of the entire standalone Primaliance business to Foncia Primaliance with retroactive effect from 1 July 2019). Following the 1 August 2019 signing of an agreement in principle with a major asset manager in France and the subsequent confirmation by the third-party buyer of its interest in the operation, the parties signed the preliminary sale agreement on 6 March 2020. This agreement stipulates a provisional sale price of €4.6 million (plus the amount of net debt as of the date on which the deed of sale is signed), as well as contingent consideration of up to €0.5 million based on 2020 inflows. In accordance with IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations, the Group presents Foncia Primaliance’s current and non-current assets and liabilities on a separate line of the statement of financial position. Its net assets held for sale were measured at their fair value based on a sale price of €5.8 million. Subsubsection Text: ###### Debt restructuring Boosted by continued solid operating performances and favourable market conditions, on 1 April and 3 May 2019, the Group restructured its debt in order to secure additional sources of financing. Details of the debt restructuring are presented below, it being specified that none of the terms and conditions negotiated in these restructuring transactions substantially modify the initial terms of the debt. Based on an analysis of the renegotiated terms and conditions, the initial debt therefore remains unchanged.  Increase in the amount able to be drawn down under the revolving credit facility up to €220 million An additional €70 million is now available for drawdown under the revolving credit facility, bringing the total amount of the facility (including the authorised overdraft) to €220 million. The applicable terms and conditions for the facility remain the same, except for the maturity of the line, which has been extended by six months (i.e., until 7 March 2023). It should be noted that the maturity of the revolving facility changes in line with the maturity of the senior facility (it will always mature six months before that facility) |Disposal of the Investor division Foncia Pierre Foncia Foncia Plus (€ thousands) Gestion Primaliance|2019| |---|---| |Shareholders’ equity 5 103 201 6 493 Goodwill 38 529 15 707 16 616 Remeasurement adjustments Of which trademarks 6 000 3 100 Of which client relationships 5 780 2 982 Of which deferred taxes on trademarks and client relationships ( 3 418) ( 1 762) Cancellation of the Primaliance merger deficit ( 5 100) Neutralisation of business goodwill net of tax ( 1 159) Other IFRS adjustments ( 94)|11 797 70 852 9 100 8 762 ( 5 180) ( 5 100) ( 1 159) ( 94)| |Total equity 50 741 15 908 22 329|88 979| |Final sale price 68 991 1 263 Provisional sale price 5 820|70 254 5 820| |Book capital gains and losses on disposals 18 250 ( 14 645)|3 605| ||| |IFRS 5 adjustment (goodwill impairment) ( 16 509)|( 16 509)| ||| |Total profit and loss impacts (excluding tax) 18 250 ( 14 645) ( 16 509)|( 12 905)| ----- ###### The fees for this operation represented €650,000. In accordance with IFRS 9, they will be recognised over the residual term of the debt by adjusting financial expenses using the effective interest rate method. At 31 December 2019, the revolving credit facility had been repaid in full.  Subscription of a new €178 million tranche under the senior facility This new line is intended to refinance the full amount drawn under the revolving credit facility as well as the debt restructuring fees. The applicable terms and conditions for this new tranche are closely aligned with those of the term loan B (3.25% interest, maturing September 2023). The fees for this operation represented €3.1 million. and will be recognised over the residual term of the debt by adjusting financial expenses using the effective interest rate method.  Extended availability of the capex facility This facility is now available until 7 September 2022 (compared to 7 September 2020 prior to the restructuring). However, the maturity of the facility remains unchanged and aligned with the maturity of the term loan B (i.e., 7 September 2023). At 31 December 2019, no amounts had been drawn down under the capex facility.  Other amendments to the banking documentation  Application of IFRS 16 to the Group’s financial reporting and financial covenants.  The free-and-clear (“freebie”) basket under the senior facility now covers €210 million compared to €100 million previously, or 1x EBITDA PF LTM.  The senior leverage ratio increased from 5.25x to 5.5x. On 31 July 2019, the Group repaid the full €110 million on the second-lien loan, as well as any accrued interest up to that date. This early repayment was funded by the subscription of an additional senior facility tranche for the same amount, i.e., €110 million. The fees for this operation represented €0.8 million and will be recognised over the residual term of the debt by adjusting financial expenses using the effective interest rate method. Acquisition of an additional stake in the Initiative et Partenaire sub-group On 27 March 2015, the Group had acquired a 45% stake in the property management company Initiative et Partenaire (a former Foncia franchisee) and eight of its subsidiaries for €2.2 million. According to the terms of this acquisition, the historic shareholders had retained a 55% stake but had undertaken to sell all of their remaining shares to the Foncia Group within a three-year period. Reciprocal put and call options had been granted in respect of this transaction. On 22 May 2019, the Group exercised its call option and thereby acquired the additional 55% stake in the company for €3.2 million. This acquisition of an additional interest in the Initiative et Partenaire sub-group led to the reclassification of a negative amount of €0.5 million between non-controlling interests and equity attributable to owners of the parent. Earn-out payment relating to the acquisition of shares in Esset Management (formerly FIPM) An earn-out of up to €3 million was granted to the Icade group at the time of the acquisition of Icade Property Management (now Esset Management) on 31 July 2016. The earn-out was based on trends in revenue earned by ESSET with Caisse des Dépôts. This maximum €3 million earn-out had been included in the calculation of goodwill as a component of the purchase price. The final earn-out was settled in February 2019 for an amount of €2.9 million. ----- ###### Acquisition of an additional stake in BimData.io (MovetoBim) On 9 July 2019, the Group acquired an additional stake in BimData.io (MovetoBim) through a capital increase subscribed by its subsidiary Immophilae in an amount of €0.3 million. The Group’s interest in BimData.io is now 19.25%. Given the difficulty in compiling and sharing pertinent information, MovetoBIM, a start-up based in Lyon (France) has revisited asset management using Building Information Modelling (BIM) technology, offering asset managers a fully digital, collaborative alternative solution. Since the end of 2015, the company has made available its online tools leveraging BIM technology, a new benchmark in building design. Change in accounting presentation for Leemo revenue Following the additional analyses carried out by the Group in connection with the first-time application of IFRS 15, in 2019 the Group decided to change its accounting presentation of revenue arising from fees earned on deeds of sale. This led to the reclassification of the contracts concerned as contracts where it acts as agent, as opposed to contracts where it acts as principal as was previously the case. Due to this change in accounting presentation, the Group now shows billed amounts net of the costs of fee retrocessions in order to present only those fees attributable to the Group. Since this does not allow a meaningful comparison of consolidated revenue (and the related external charges) between 2019 and 2018, the statement of profit and loss figures for 2018 have been restated accordingly, leading to a negative impact of €14.9 million on revenue as presented. This change in presentation has no impact on recurring operating profit for 2018. It should be recalled that in accordance with IFRS 15, when a third party is involved in providing a separate service, the Group must determine whether it acts on its own behalf (i.e., as principal) or on behalf of another party (i.e., as agent). The Group therefore has to determine whether it controls the specified service before it is provided to the end customer, (for example, when it controls the way in which the third party provides the service). The agent/principal distinction is explicitly based on the notion of control. Based on an analysis of the substance of the contractual relationship between Leemo and business providers/developers, and in particular Leemo’s lack of flexibility in setting its prices, the Group has decided that Leemo acts as agent. NOTE 3. ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND METHODS General principles used to prepare the financial statements The accounting policies described in these notes have been applied consistently to all periods presented in the consolidated financial statements, with the exception of the standards adopted as described in Note 3.2.2, effective as of 1 January 2019, which include IFRS 16 c Leases. The consolidated financial statements are prepared on a historical cost basis, except for assets held for sale and related liabilities, measured in accordance with IFRS 5, and certain financial instruments carried at fair value or amortised cost in accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9. The consolidated financial statements of Foncia Management at 31 December 2019 were adopted by the Supervisory Board at its meeting of 23 April 2020 and will be submitted to shareholders for approval at the General Meeting on 29 June 2020. They are presented in thousands of euros and amounts are rounded up or down to the nearest thousand unless otherwise specified. Consequently, the sum of these amounts may differ slightly from the total amounts reported. ----- ###### Accounting standards 3.2.1. Basis of preparation of financial information Pursuant to Regulation (EC) No. 1606/2002 of 19 July 2002 as amended by Regulation (EC) No. 297/2008 of 11 March 2008, the 2019 consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the international financial reporting standards (IFRS) and interpretations issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) as adopted by the European Union and applicable at 1 January 2019. The full text of the standards adopted by the European Union can be consulted on the European Commission’s website: https://ec.europa.eu/info/business-economy-euro/company-reporting-and-auditing/company-reporting_en Where there is no specific guidance from IFRS standards or IFRIC interpretations, the Group refers to other IFRS standards dealing with similar issues or to the Conceptual Framework, in accordance with IAS 8 – Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and Errors. At the end of the reporting period, there was no difference between the IFRS used to prepare these financial statements and the standards adopted by the IASB and applicable for the period presented. The accounting policies and bases of measurement applied to prepare these consolidated financial statements are described in Note 3.4 below. The consolidated financial statements include the financial statements of Foncia Management, the entities it controls (subsidiaries) and the entities which are accounted for by the equity method. The financial statements of the Group’s subsidiaries are prepared over the same period as those of the parent company, i.e., 1 January to 31 December 2019, using consistent accounting policies. 3.2.2. Changes in accounting standards Main IFRS standards, amendments and interpretations in force within the European Union and mandatorily applicable since 1 January 2019 The accounting policies and bases of measurement used by the Group to prepare its consolidated financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2019 are identical to those used by the Group at 31 December 2018, except as described below. - IFRS 16 – Leases ###### This new standard entered into force on 1 January 2019 and introduces fundamental changes to lease accounting. IFRS 16 replaces IAS 17 and the related IFRIC and SIC interpretations. It no longer distinguishes between operating leases and finance leases. Accordingly, entities are required to recognise all lease obligations in their statement of financial position in line with the approach applicable to finance leases under IAS 17. More specifically, on entering into a lease contract, IFRS 16 requires recognition in the statement of financial position of a liability representing the present value of future fixed lease payments, against a right-of-use asset depreciated over the term of the lease (these rights and obligations were previously reported in off-balance sheet commitments for operating leases). The Group has chosen to apply IFRS 16 using the modified retrospective approach, i.e., with no restatement of comparative information. Under this approach, a liability is recognised at the transition date for the present value of any residual lease payments, against a right-of-use asset adjusted for the amount of any lease payments made at or before the lease commencement date. ----- ###### All impacts resulting from the first-time application of IFRS 16 were recognised against opening equity at 1 January 2019. The Group does not have any major lease contracts in which it acts as lessor, with the exception of certain intragroup leases, the accounting for which was not significantly impacted by IFRS 16. The amount of the lease liability is largely dependent on the assumptions used to determine the lease term and, to a lesser extent, the discount rate.  Under IFRS 16, the discount rate for each lease is to be determined by reference to the lessee’s incremental borrowing rate. In practice, given how the Group is organised financially, i.e., held or guaranteed almost exclusively by the three French holding companies, the Group adopted an incremental borrowing rate of 3.25% for all of its lease contracts (excluding vehicle leases), reflecting the Group’s own borrowing rate. This rate corresponds to the sum of the risk-free rate and the Group’s credit spread over the initial term of the syndicated loan (i.e., without considering the term). The value of the vehicle fleet in France is estimated based on the interest rate implicit in the leases, as supplied by Arval, i.e., 2.56%.  Barring exceptional cases, the lease term reflects the firm term of the lease, plus or minus the period covered by any extension or early termination options. For property leases in France and in particular automatically renewable property leases, the Group has adopted the legally defensible term of the lease, which reflects the nearest date at which the lease can be terminated without incurring any penalties, taking into account a six-month notice period starting at the end of the calendar quarter (i.e., a maximum nine-month term). The lease term is therefore nine months at the date of first-time application of IFRS 16 and six months at the date of preparation of the 2019 financial statements. It should be noted that following its meeting of 26 November 2019, the IFRS Interpretations Committee (IFRS IC) confirmed its position regarding the lease term and useful life of non-removable leasehold improvements. IFRS IC confirms that the economics of a lease contract rather than just its legal form should be used to determine the enforceable term of a lease. Owing to the late publication of this decision and the time needed to analyse and modify the corresponding estimates, this decision will be applied by the Group in 2020 (the legal approach was maintained to determine the term of property leases). The following other main assumptions and practical expedients were used by the Group:  Leases formerly classified as finance leases under IAS 17 continue to be accounted for as finance leases. To simplify, the residual useful life of these leases is calculated in the same way as under IAS 17.  The practical expedient exempting leases with a residual term of less than 12 months from the scope of IFRS 16 has not been adopted by the Group.  Restoration costs - Property leases: restoration costs are not calculated for property leases. As they are frequently negotiated with the lessor at the end of the lease, the costs cannot be reliably estimated. - Vehicle fleet: In France, the Group adopted an average cost of €700 per vehicle (cost plus 20% for private vehicles on which VAT cannot be recovered) in measuring the right-of-use asset corresponding to the residual value guarantee. This average cost was calculated based on a market estimate and taking into account the historical cost actually incurred when changing the automotive fleet at the beginning of 2019.  Variable lease payments or services related to the lease are not included when calculating the amount of the right-of-use asset or lease liability.  Deferred tax was recognised on the difference between the right-of-use asset and the lease liability falling within the scope of IFRS 16, in a similar way to that previously recognised for finance leases.  The useful lives of non-removable leasehold improvements have not been aligned with the useful lives of the related right-of-use assets ----- ###### The Group has a large number of leases across its entire French and international branch network. Its leases are of many different types, but are mainly leases of property or vehicles. Statement of profit and loss IFRS 16 changes the amount and presentation of expenses relating to leases previously classified as operating leases. Under IAS 17, operating lease expenses were included in operating expenses. Pursuant to IFRS 16, these expenses are split between financial expenses and a depreciation charge. IFRS 16 has no impact on the consolidated statement of other comprehensive income.
