(2,747) (1,189) (60)| ----- ###### In accordance with IFRS 16, repayment of the principal of the lease liability is included within cash flows from (used in) financing activities. Interest paid on the lease liability is also included within cash flows from (used in) financing activities, as allowed by IAS 7 and in accordance with the Group’s accounting policy. Consequently, net cash from operating activities for 2019 was €42.6 million higher than in 2018, while net cash used in financing activities increased by the same amount. Statement of financial position The new requirements under IFRS 16 lead to an increase in reported assets and liabilities. The recognition of right-of-use assets increases non-current assets by €131.5 million, while the recognition of lease liabilities increases total liabilities by €127.9 million, including a non-current portion of €94.7 million and a current portion of €33.3 million. The Group has chosen to present right-of-use assets and lease liabilities separately from its other assets and liabilities in the statement of financial position. - IFRIC 23 – Uncertainty over Income Tax Treatments ###### The Group has applied IFRIC 23 since 1 January 2019 and has therefore reviewed its uncertain income tax treatments. No impact was identified on the estimated amount of income taxes. - Amendment to IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments – Prepayment Features with Negative Compensation - Amendment to IAS 28 – Long-term Interests in Associates and Joint Ventures - Amendments resulting from Annual Improvements to IFRSs – 2015-2017 cycle - Amendment to IAS 19 – Plan Amendment, Curtailment or Settlement ###### The first-time application of these standards, amendments and interpretations does not have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements. Other new standards and guidance applicable after 31 December 2019 and not early adopted by the Group - IFRS 17 – Insurance Contracts - Amendments to IAS 1 and IAS 8 – Definition of Material - Amendment to IFRS 3 – Definition of a Business - Amendments to IAS 1 – Classification of Liabilities as Current or Non-Current - Amendments to References to the Conceptual Framework in IFRS Standards ###### These standards and amendments have been adopted or are in the process of being adopted by the European Union. Subject to their adoption, they are applicable for reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2020. The Group is currently analysing the potential impacts of applying the requirements set out in these texts for the first time. ----- ###### Use of management estimates in applying the Group’s accounting standards The preparation of financial statements requires the Group to make estimates and assumptions that may affect the measurement and presentation of certain assets and liabilities and any disclosures provided in respect of contingent liabilities at the end of the reporting period, as well as the reported amounts of income and expenses for the period. Estimates and underlying assumptions are determined based on information available at the end of the reporting period and are reviewed on a regular basis in light of past experience and other factors deemed reasonable given the circumstances. These estimates serve as the basis for measuring the carrying amount of assets and liabilities that cannot be obtained directly from other sources. Where applicable, a sensitivity analysis may be performed if the estimates are material. Accordingly, actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates made by the Group in preparing its consolidated financial statements are based on a going concern assumption and relate primarily to the items described below.  Measurements used in testing goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment for impairment The estimates and assumptions made to determine the recoverable amount of goodwill, intangible assets, and property, plant and equipment relate mainly to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. As with any estimate, the assumptions used in these calculations are partly based on uncertain factors and may therefore need to be adjusted in subsequent periods. Note 4.1.3 sets out the assumptions used to calculate future cash flows and determine the discount rates to be applied in measuring the recoverable amounts of these assets. Sensitivity analyses were also performed and are described in the same note.  Measurement of leases IFRS 16 requires entities to use a significant degree of judgement as well as certain key estimates. These involve determining:  whether an option to extend or terminate a lease is reasonably certain to be exercised;   the lease term;  the appropriate discount rate to be used to calculate future lease payments;   the specific selling price of any lease components and non-lease components contained in the contract. The main assumptions used by the Group to prepare its 2019 financial statements are described in Note 3.2.2.  Measurement of provisions The Group used the best estimate of its commitments and obligations to calculate the corresponding provisions.  Measurement of employee benefits The Group operates both defined contribution and defined benefit plans. Obligations under these plans are calculated using the projected unit credit method, which is based on assumptions regarding the discount rate, future increases in salary, employee turnover, life expectancy and the rate of increase in healthcare costs. Note 4.13 sets out the assumptions used to measure these obligations. The Group considers that the actuarial assumptions used are appropriate and justified in the current environment. However, the corresponding obligations may change if these assumptions also change. ----- ######  Measurement of fair value (Level 1) The Group uses fair value on a recurring basis in its statement of financial position to measure unlisted derivative instruments and cash and cash equivalents (see Notes 3.4.17 and 4.18).  Measurement of recognised deferred tax assets and liabilities and tax expense The Group’s tax position (see Notes 4.9 and 5.11) is based on its best estimate of future taxable earnings.  Basis for determining the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of a business combination The estimates and assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount of these identifiable assets and liabilities relate in particular to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. Any changes in these assumptions could impact the recoverable amount.  Assessment of criteria for identifying discontinued operations In accordance with IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations, the Group is required to exercise judgement in determining whether an asset or group of assets meets the criteria to be classified as held for sale. IFRS 5 criteria are also used to identify any assets to be classified as discontinued operations. These assessments are reviewed at the end of each reporting period in light of changes in the relevant facts and circumstances. In the absence of IFRS guidance for a specific transaction, event or condition, the Group uses its judgement to define and apply accounting policies that will result in relevant, fair and comparable information to ensure that the financial statements:  present a true and fair view of the Foncia Group’s financial position, financial performance and cash flows;  reflect the economic substance of transactions;  are neutral, prudent and comprehensive in all material respects. Detailed disclosures in this regard are provided in the notes to the consolidated financial statements. Basis of measurement 3.4.1. Basis of consolidation Details of the main consolidated companies at 31 December 2019 are provided in Note 13 “Scope of consolidation”. Controlled entities Companies directly or indirectly controlled by the Group are fully consolidated. Control exists when the Group is exposed, or is entitled, to variable returns from its involvement with the entity in question and has the ability to affect those returns through its power over the entity. Control is analysed whenever facts and circumstances indicate that one or more of the inputs used to assess control has changed. A subsidiary is consolidated as from the date control is acquired, which is usually upon signature of the share transfer and disposal agreements (see “Accounting for acquisitions ongoing at the end of the reporting period” below). Consolidation ceases when control is relinquished. Any interest in the subsidiary that is not directly or indirectly attributable to the Group is recognised within non-controlling interests. Profits and losses and each component of other comprehensive income relating to subsidiaries are allocated to owners of the parent and non-controlling interests, even if this results in non-controlling interests having a deficit balance. ----- ###### Changes in the percentage interest held in subsidiaries that do not lead to a change in control are treated as equity transactions, since the transactions take place between owners acting in their capacity as owners. The impact of these transactions is shown in equity net of tax and does not therefore impact consolidated profit or loss. These transactions are also shown in the statement of cash flows under cash flows relating to investing activities. Investments in equity-accounted companies (associates and joint ventures) Associates are entities over which the Group exercises significant influence. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating policy decisions of the entity without controlling or jointly controlling those policies. A joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to its net assets. Joint control of an arrangement only exists when decisions about the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. Profits, losses, assets and liabilities of associates or joint ventures are accounted for by the equity method in the Group’s consolidated financial statements. Under the equity method, the investment in an associate or joint venture is initially recognised at acquisition cost and subsequently adjusted for the Group’s interest in the profits, losses and other comprehensive income of the associate or joint venture. IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments is applied to determine whether investments in associates or joint ventures need to be tested for impairment. Where necessary, the total carrying amount of the investment (including goodwill) is tested for impairment in accordance with IAS 36 – Impairment of Assets. Accounting for acquisitions ongoing at the end of the reporting period Non-consolidated investments are classified as available-for-sale securities and mainly consist of shares in property management companies that will subsequently be consolidated. Before acquiring shares in a property management company, the Group agrees to acquire the shares and pays 10% of the estimated price to the seller. This part payment is included in “Downpayments on acquisitions of securities” within non-current financial assets. The remaining 90% is booked in “Off-balance sheet commitments” (see Note 9). Upon signing the share transfer or disposal agreement, the Group pays an additional 70% of the estimated price to the seller. The provisional purchase price is then included in equity investments, and the part payment already recognised is also reclassified to this caption. The acquired company is then consolidated. Following a review of the acquired company’s financial statements, the Group pays the remaining balance and adjusts the purchase price of the shares. Non-consolidated investments Companies with the following characteristics are not included in the scope of consolidation:  they are in the process of being wound up or are dormant;  their business is not strategic for the Group. In accordance with IFRS 9, non-consolidated investments are carried at fair value. There are no material obligations or liabilities relating to these entities. ----- ###### 3.4.2. Elimination of intragroup transactions All intragroup transactions and balances as well as any income, expenses, gains and losses resulting from intragroup transactions and included in the carrying amount of assets are eliminated on consolidation. When a Group entity carries out a transaction with a joint venture or associate, the related gains and losses are recognised in the Group’s consolidated financial statements only to the extent of the interests held by third parties in the joint venture or associate. 3.4.3. Foreign currency translation Presentation currency The consolidated financial statements are presented in euros, which is the Group’s presentation currency. Functional currency and translation of the financial statements of foreign companies A consolidated entity’s functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment in which it operates. In most cases, the functional currency is the local currency. However, certain entities must adopt a functional currency other than their local currency when that currency represents the currency of the major transactions carried out by the entity and accurately reflects its economic environment. The financial statements of foreign entities whose functional currency is different from the presentation currency of the Group’s consolidated financial statements are translated using the “closing rate” method, as follows:  assets and liabilities are translated at the closing exchange rate;  statement of profit and loss and cash flow items are converted at the average exchange rate for the period. The resulting currency translation differences are recognised directly in other comprehensive income within equity under “Translation adjustments”. Goodwill relating to foreign entities whose functional currency is not the euro are treated as assets acquired or liabilities assumed and therefore translated at the exchange rate prevailing at the end of the reporting period. As the Group does most of its business in the eurozone, only its Swiss subsidiaries prepare financial statements in a currency other than the euro. The following exchange rates were used to prepare the consolidated financial statements: 2019 2018 Equivalent to €1 Closing rate Average rate Opening rate Closing rate Average rate Opening rate CHF Swiss franc 1.0952 1.1138 1.1295 1.1295 1.1564 1.1643 ###### The exchange rates used are the rates published by the Banque de France. ----- ###### Foreign currency transactions Foreign currency transactions are translated into euros at the exchange rates prevailing at the transaction date or at the hedged rate. At the end of the reporting period, monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency are translated at the closing exchange rate, with the resulting gains and losses included in foreign exchange gains and losses under other financial income and expenses in the statement of profit and loss. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are measured at historical cost are translated at the exchange rate at the transaction date. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are stated at fair value are translated at the exchange rate at the date on which fair value was determined. Loans granted to a foreign operation for which settlement is neither planned nor likely to occur in the foreseeable future are, in substance, part of the Group’s net investment in that foreign operation. Translation adjustments arising on monetary items that are part of a net investment in a foreign operation are recognised directly in other comprehensive income (equity) under “Foreign currency translation reserves”, and taken to profit or loss when the net investment is sold. 3.4.4. Business combinations and goodwill The Group uses the purchase method to account for its acquisitions of subsidiaries. The fair value of the consideration transferred reflects the fair value of the assets given, equity instruments issued and liabilities assumed or incurred by the acquirer at the date of exchange. Costs directly attributable to the business combination are expensed in the period in which they were incurred. On the first-time consolidation of a subsidiary or equity investment, the Group measures all identifiable items acquired at their acquisition-date fair value. The items are measured in the currency of the acquired company. In the event of deferred settlements, the future amounts payable are discounted to present value at the settlement date. The discount rate used is the same as that used to estimate the value of the assets. Fair value adjustments to assets and liabilities resulting from business combinations accounted for on a provisional basis (i.e., because the independent appraisals or ongoing additional analyses are incomplete) are recognised as retrospective adjustments to goodwill if they occur within 12 months of the acquisition (measurement period) and if they result from facts and circumstances existing at the acquisition date. Adjustments made after the measurement period are taken directly to profit or loss, unless they are made to correct an error, including in relation to deferred tax assets which, if recognised more than 12 months after the acquisition date, generate tax income. Goodwill arising on acquisitions of associates and joint ventures is included in the carrying amount of “Investments in equity-accounted companies”. Goodwill The residual difference representing the excess of the fair value of the consideration transferred plus any non-controlling interests in the acquired company over the acquisition-date fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed is recognised in the consolidated statement of financial position as goodwill. For each business combination, the Group may choose to account for non-controlling interests: - either at acquisition-date fair value, resulting in the recognition of goodwill on the non-controlling interests ###### (“full goodwill” method); - or based on the share of net identifiable assets of the acquired entity measured at fair value, in which case ###### goodwill is only recognised on the portion attributable to owners of the parent (“partial goodwill” method). ----- ###### Goodwill is not amortised but is tested for impairment at least annually, or more frequently if there is evidence that it may be impaired. The impairment testing approach is described in Note 3.4.8 “Impairment of assets” below. Impairment recognised against goodwill may not be reversed. Bargain purchases When the acquisition-date fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed of the acquired company exceeds the purchase price plus the amount of any non-controlling interests in the acquired company, the negative goodwill is taken immediately to profit or loss in the period of the acquisition, after verifying the procedure for identifying and measuring the various items included in its calculation. Transactions involving non-controlling interests Changes in non-controlling interests that do not result in gain or loss of control are recognised in equity. In particular, when additional shares are acquired in an entity already controlled by the Group, the difference between the purchase price of the shares and the additional share of consolidated equity acquired is recognised in equity attributable to owners of the parent. The consolidated carrying amount of the subsidiary’s identifiable assets and liabilities (including goodwill) remains unchanged. Contingent consideration and/or earn-out Contingent consideration or earn-outs relating to a business combination are measured at their acquisition-date fair value, even if it deemed unlikely they will be paid. After the acquisition date, changes in the estimated fair value of contingent consideration/earn-outs result in an adjustment to goodwill only if they are made within the 12 months following the acquisition date (measurement period) and if they result from facts and circumstances existing at the acquisition date. In all other cases, any such changes are taken to profit or loss, unless the consideration transferred is an equity instrument. The revised IFRS 3 gives certain indications as regards the accounting for contingent payment arrangements with employees or selling shareholders. These arrangements may be part of the business combination or may be considered as separate from the acquisition agreement for the target entity. In certain acquisitions, earn-out payments were considered part of the consideration for post-acquisition services rendered and are therefore expensed in the periods concerned and in future periods. Business combinations achieved in stages (step acquisitions) In a business combination achieved in stages, the Group’s previously-held equity interest in the acquired company is remeasured at fair value through profit or loss on the date control was obtained. Goodwill at the date control is obtained is calculated as the fair value of consideration transferred (i.e., price paid) plus the fair value of the Group’s previously-held equity interest in the acquired company. 3.4.5. Intangible assets Intangible assets are identifiable non-monetary assets with no physical substance. In accordance with IAS 38, intangible assets that are acquired separately are initially measured at cost when the future economic benefits attributable to the asset will flow to the Group and the cost of the asset can be measured reliably. Subsequent expenditure on intangible assets is included as part of the cost of those assets only if it increases the future economic benefits associated with the assets concerned. Other costs are expensed as incurred. Intangible assets acquired as part of a business combination that can be reliably measured, are controlled by the Group, and are separable or arise from legal or contractual rights are recognised at fair value separately from goodwill. ----- ###### Intangible assets are subsequently measured at cost less any accumulated amortisation and impairment losses. Intangible assets with a finite useful life (software and licences) are amortised on a straight-line basis over their expected useful lives: - Client relationships: 18-21 years - Software programs: 1-10 years - Other intangible assets: 5 years ###### Intangible assets with an indefinite useful life are not amortised. They are included with other assets within cash-generating units (CGUs) and tested for impairment using the discounted cash flow method at least once a year and whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired. When the recoverable amount of these assets calculated based on criteria prevailing at the acquisition date falls below their carrying amount, an impairment provision is recorded. Trademarks Identifiable trademarks are measured using a multi-criteria approach that takes into consideration both their reputation and profitability. The Group classified its main “Foncia” trademark, along with the “Lodgis” and “Trévi” trademarks in Belgium and the “Domicim” and “Brolliet” trademarks in Switzerland, as indefinite-lived intangible assets. Business software programs Software acquired is carried at cost (purchase price plus ancillary expenses). When allocating the purchase price, certain software programs may also be measured using the replacement cost approach. Business goodwill and client relationships Client relationships include the list of mandates held by the Group’s companies. A mandate is an instrument by which a person (the principal) gives another person (the agent) the power to carry out or enter into one or more legal actions or agreements, in the principal’s name. France’s Hoguet law requires professional property agents to hold a written mandate in order to put properties up for sale or to let, and to manage jointly owned property. Client relationships are measured based on the excess earnings method. ----- ###### Other intangible assets Other intangible assets mainly comprise the cost of acquiring new business. Leasehold rights In light of the legal characteristics of commercial leases in France, leasehold rights (droits au bail) are considered to have an indefinite useful life and are not amortised. They were previously shown within intangible assets and are now included within right-of-use assets (see Note 3.2.2). The residual value of right-of-use assets is reviewed at least once a year. Assets for which the underlying leases have been terminated are systematically retired. 3.4.6. Property, plant and equipment Property, plant and equipment are measured at their historical cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. The cost of an item of property, plant and equipment comprises its purchase price, including customs duties and non-recoverable taxes, and any costs directly incurred to bring the asset to working condition for its intended use. Any trade discounts and rebates are deducted from the purchase price. Subsequent expenditure is included in the carrying amount of property, plant and equipment or is recognised as a separate component where appropriate, if it is probable that the future economic benefits associated with the asset will flow to the Group and the cost of the asset can be measured reliably. All other maintenance and repair costs are expensed as incurred, except for costs incurred to increase productivity or extend the useful life of an asset, which are capitalised. Property, plant and equipment are depreciated using the components approach over their estimated useful lives, taking into account any residual value. Straight-line depreciation is considered the method that best reflects the pattern in which the assets’ economic benefits are consumed by the Group: - Buildings: 20-50 years - Fixtures and fittings: 8-10 years - IT equipment: 4 years - Vehicle fleet: 5 years - Furniture: 10 years - Office equipment: 4 years ###### The residual values and useful lives of property, plant and equipment are reviewed at the end of each reporting period and adjusted where necessary. The carrying amounts of property, plant and equipment are tested for impairment when there is evidence that they may be impaired. Gains and losses on asset disposals are calculated as the difference between the sale proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset concerned. 3.4.7. Leases Pursuant to IFRS 16 – Leases, on entering into a contract, the Group analyses the contractual provisions to determine whether it has the characteristics of a lease. It verifies whether the lease transfers in substance the right to control the use of an asset for a specified period of time in exchange for consideration. If these characteristics exist, as soon as the asset is made available the Group recognises:  a right-of-use asset, which represents its right to use the leased asset over the lease term;  a lease liability which represents its obligation to make lease payments ----- ###### The Group applies the same method to account for all leases in which it acts as lessee, and has chosen not to use the practical expedients set out in IFRS 16 exempting short-term leases (i.e., leases with terms of 12 months or less) or leases of low-value underlying assets from the scope of the standard. The amount of the right-of-use asset comprises:  the amount of the associated lease liability;  plus:  any lease payments made at or before the commencement date,  any initial direct costs incurred to obtain the lease,  any estimated restoration costs to be incurred by the Group;  less any lease incentives received. Right-of-use assets are subsequently measured at cost less any accumulated depreciation and any accumulated impairment losses. They are depreciated over the lease term or the useful life of the leased asset for accounting purposes, whichever is shorter. The lease liability represents the present value of:  fixed lease payments (including in-substance fixed payments), less any lease incentives receivable;  variable lease payments that depend on an index or a rate, initially measured using the index or rate at the commencement date;  amounts expected to be payable by the Group under residual value guarantees;  the exercise price of a purchase option if the Group is reasonably certain to exercise that option;  penalties required for terminating the lease. Lease liabilities are subsequently measured by increasing the carrying amount to reflect interest on the lease liability (using the effective interest rate method) and by reducing the carrying amount to reflect the lease payments made. To determine the lease term, the Group analyses the contractual provisions of the lease, as illustrated below: ----- ###### The Group remeasures the lease liability (and adjusts the corresponding right-of-use asset accordingly), when:  there is a change in the lease term or a change in the assessment of an option to purchase the underlying asset, in which cases the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using a revised discount rate;  there is a change in future lease payments resulting from a change in an index or rate, or a change in the amounts expected to be payable under a residual value guarantee, in which cases the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using the initial discount rate;  there is a change in the lease contract (lease modification) that is not accounted for as a separate lease, in which case the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using a revised discount rate. When the Group incurs an obligation to restore the asset to the condition specified in the lease contract, the related costs are included as part of the cost of the right-of-use asset and the corresponding lease liability is increased accordingly. IFRS 16 offers a practical expedient to lessees whereby they may choose not to separate non-lease components from lease components, and instead account for each lease component and any associated non-lease components as a single lease component. The Group did not apply this practical expedient in its 2019 financial statements. 3.4.8. Impairment of assets Impairment of assets with finite useful lives Property, plant and equipment and intangible assets with finite useful lives are tested for impairment whenever there is evidence that they may be impaired. Impairment recognised in profit or loss against property, plant and equipment and intangible assets may be reversed. Impairment of assets with indefinite useful lives Goodwill and other intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are tested for impairment at least annually, or more frequently if there is evidence that they may be impaired. Cash-generating units For the purposes of these impairment tests, non-current assets that cannot be tested individually for impairment as they do not generate cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets, are grouped into cash-generating units (CGUs). Impairment tests are carried out on each CGU or group of CGUs at the lowest level at which goodwill is monitored by the Group. A CGU is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets for internal management purposes. The CGUs identified by the Group correspond to its major development and investment strategies. The Group has defined the following three cash-generating units: - Property Management France CGU, which includes the management of jointly owned properties, rental ###### management, lettings, the transactions business and client mandates. - Property Management International CGU, which includes the property management and transactions ###### businesses in Germany, Switzerland and Belgium. ----- - Services CGU, which includes Constatimmo (brokerage for technical surveys), Assurimo (insurance ###### brokerage), Efficity (property appraisals website), FPM and Esset Management (BtoB property management), Prowen (brokerage specialised in energy purchases), Seiitra (property management software development), Techway (technical maintenance), Leemo (property platform), and Lodgis (furnished rentals). The Group decides whether or not to recognise an impairment loss by comparing the carrying amount of the assets and liabilities in a CGU or group of CGUs with their recoverable amount. Impairment indicators External indicators of impairment include changes in the general economic and financial environment, downtrends in local economic environments and changes in economic performance. These are analysed by the Group to determine whether the assets concerned should be tested for impairment more frequently. Method used to determine the recoverable amount An impairment loss is recognised in the statement of profit and loss when the carrying amount of an asset or CGU exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount of an asset or CGU is the higher of: - its fair value less the costs of disposal, representing the amount at which the Group could sell the asset (after ###### selling costs) in an arm’s length transaction between market participants at the measurement date; and - its value in use, representing the present value of the future cash flows expected to be derived from the ###### continuing use and ultimate sale of an asset or CGU based on the most probable assumptions adopted by management. Fair value net of the costs of disposal is calculated based on available information used to establish the best estimate of the selling price net of costs to sell in an arm’s length transaction between fully informed, consenting parties. Value in use of CGUs or groups of CGUs is determined based on post-tax cash flows resulting from business plans and a terminal value calculated by extrapolating data for the last year of the business plan. The assumptions used are based on the budgets and business plans prepared by management for each business. These budgets are the latest budgets approved by the Supervisory Board at the date of preparation of the financial statements. Other assumptions affecting the calculation of the recoverable amount include the growth rate, operating margin, the discount rate and the tax rate (see Note 4.1). The discount rate used to discount post-tax cash flows to their present value reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset or CGU. Where there is no specific discount rate for the assets tested, the average cost of capital is used. The discount rates are post-tax rates and are applied to post-tax cash flows. The recoverable amount calculated using post-tax discount rates is equal to that which would have been obtained using pre-tax rates applied to pre-tax cash flows, as required by IAS 36. Recognition of impairment losses If the carrying amount of the CGU exceeds its recoverable amount, the related assets are written down to the recoverable amount. The impairment loss is first allocated to goodwill and then to the carrying amount of the other assets of the CGU, in proportion to their carrying amount. This must not result in the carrying amount of an individual asset falling below the higher of its fair value, value in use and zero. Impairment losses are recognised in other operating expenses and may not be reversed. ----- ###### Reversal of impairment losses Impairment losses recognised against goodwill cannot be reversed. Impairment losses recognised against assets other than goodwill may only be reversed if there is evidence that the impairment loss may have decreased or may no longer exist. The amount reversed is then based on revised estimates of the asset’s recoverable amount. The increased carrying amount of an asset attributable to the reversal of an impairment loss should not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined had no impairment loss been recognised for the asset. 3.4.9. Trade and other receivables Trade and other receivables are initially carried at fair value and subsequently measured at amortised cost, less any impairment losses recorded in the statement of profit and loss. 3.4.10. Financial instruments The measurement and recognition of financial assets and liabilities is defined by IFRS 9 – Financial instruments. Financial assets Financial assets include loans and receivables, liquid assets, financial assets relating to financing, other financial assets, derivative instruments with a positive fair value and cash and cash equivalents. IFRS 9 applies a single analytical framework to all financial assets in order to determine the classification and basis of measurement to be used for accounting purposes. More specifically:  Financial assets at amortised cost Financial assets that will be recovered through repayments of contractual cash flows (i.e., repayments of principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding) are generally carried at amortised cost. Financial assets at amortised cost include operating financial assets, other loans and receivables and trade receivables. They are initially recognised at fair value and subsequently carried at amortised cost calculated using the effective interest rate method. In accordance with IFRS 9, financial assets at amortised cost are written down by the amount of any expected credit losses. The impairment loss is recorded either in recurring operating profit or in other financial income and expenses.  Assets at fair value through other comprehensive income reclassifiable to profit or loss Financial assets that will be recovered both through repayments of contractual cash flows (i.e., repayments of principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding) and through sales of those assets are generally carried at fair value through other comprehensive income. Changes in the fair value of these assets are recognised directly in other comprehensive income, with the exception of interest income and dividends, which are included in other financial income and expenses. Changes in fair value are reclassified to profit or loss when the assets are sold.  Assets at fair value through other comprehensive income not reclassifiable to profit or loss This category includes investments in non-consolidated companies and equity instruments that the Group has irrevocably elected to classify in this category. When these investments are sold, the unrealised gains and losses previously carried in other comprehensive income will not be reclassified to profit or loss; only dividends will be taken to profit or loss. Fair value corresponds to the market price for listed securities or to the estimated fair value for unlisted securities, as determined according to the financial criteria most appropriate to the particular situation of each investment. Equity investments for which prices are not quoted on an active market and for which fair ----- ###### value cannot be reliably measured are carried by the Group at historical cost less any accumulated impairment losses.  Assets at fair value through profit or loss All other debt and equity instruments are carried at fair value through profit or loss. These include marketable securities with an underlying term of more than three months, other financial assets held for trading and purchased for sale in the near term, and financial instruments with a positive fair value that are not eligible for hedge accounting. These assets are measured at fair value, with changes in fair value taken to financial income and expenses. At the acquisition date, the Group determines the classification of financial assets into one of the IFRS 9 categories based on the characteristics of the instrument and the business model for managing the assets. (2,751)|1,328,569| ----- ###### 4.1.2. 2019 impairment tests The assumptions used in the tests and the approach applied are described below. Impacts of IFRS 16 on the impairment testing approach IFRS 16 introduces significant changes to the inputs used in impairment tests, including the net amount tested, debt and valuation multiples. It therefore requires entities to reconsider their testing approach. In this regard, several different approaches have been proposed by the regulators to assist entities in their transition to IFRS 16. The first, which complies with IAS 36, involves increasing the carrying amount of the CGU by the amount of the right-of-use asset, without taking into account the IFRS 16 lease liability. This approach represents a change of practice and introduces a degree of complexity into the calculation of value in use, since (i) cash flows relating solely to fixed lease payments or similar are excluded from the calculation insofar as they constitute the new lease liability, (ii) the cash outflows required to renew the right-of-use assets are to be estimated (future reinvestment flows affecting both the series of annual projections and the terminal value), and (iii) the discount rate is to be adjusted (estimated impact on the WACC of the new cost of capital/cost of debt ratio). The second approach is similar to the one described above and involves eliminating the lease liability from the carrying amount of the CGU and from the value in use. This approach leads to similar difficulties as those seen above. The third solution is to maintain the pre-IFRS 16 approach in terms of projecting future cash flows. Although the carrying amount of the CGU changes (increase in the value of the right-of-use asset net of the lease liability), the calculation of value in use is not affected: - projected cash outflows relating to lease payments remain unchanged for both the annual forecasts and for the terminal value; - the discount rate is determined by reference to pre-IFRS 16 inputs (no change in the cost of debt and the debt-to-equity ratio). As the practical complexity of the first two approaches could undermine the reliability of the calculations (insufficient hindsight regarding the adjustment of certain cash flow inputs), the Group chose to use the third approach for its impairment tests in 2019. Calculation of the carrying amount of CGUs at 31 December 2019 Estimating the carrying amount of each CGU includes determining the value of the assets that may be directly attributed or reasonably allocated to the CGU and that will generate cash flows included in the calculation of value in use. Goodwill of €1,094.9 million arising on the acquisition of a controlling interest in Foncia Holding in September 2016 (see Note 4.1.1 above) was allocated pro rata to the enterprise value of each CGU, as estimated based on the acquisition business plans for each CGU used within the scope of the purchase price accounting. The goodwill allocation resulted in the following: |Property Holding International Goodwill - €m Management Services CGU companies CGU France CGU Goodw ill (Foncia Management PPA) 1,094.9 784.2 42.9 267.8 Allocation resulting from DCF/CGU at 30 Sept. 2016 71.6% 3.9% 24.5%|Consolidated 1,094.9 100.0%| |---|---| |Total goodwill 784 43 268|1,095| ----- ###### For intangible assets identified during the purchase price accounting for Foncia Holding and subsequent material acquisitions, the allocation at 31 December 2019 is as follows (based on the carrying amount): • Property Management France CGU: €354.7 million to the Foncia trademark and €333.7 million to client relationships; • Property Management International CGU: €21.6 million to the Brolliet, Domicim and Trévi trademarks and €7.5 million to client relationships; • Services CGU: €41.6 million to the Foncia trademark and €42.9 million to client relationships. The holding company’s residual economic assets following the asset allocation shown above were allocated in full to the Property Management France CGU to reflect the cost allocation of the holding company used to draw up the business plans. Calculation of the recoverable amount of CGUs at 31 December 2019 In accordance with the Group’s impairment testing approach (see Note 3.4.7), and in the absence of observable fair values in an organised market, the recoverable amount of CGUs corresponds to their value in use, which is defined as the sum of their net cash flows based on the latest forecasts for each CGU, determined using:  a business plan prepared by management based on growth and profitability assumptions, taking into account past performance, forecast changes in the economic environment, and expected market trends;  a terminal value calculated by capitalising normative cash flows obtained by extrapolating cash flows from the final year of the business plan, with a stable growth rate or a growth rate increasing steadily over the long term;  expected cash flows discounted at a rate determined by reference to the weighted average cost of capital (WACC). The financial forecasts used in the impairment tests carried out at 31 December 2019 were prepared by management and cover a period of six years. They provide a consolidated view as well as a breakdown by CGU. It should be noted that all holding company expenses not allocated in the consolidated business plan were allocated in full to the Property Management France CGU. Corporate functions are managed at individual country-level for the Property Management International CGU and are considered not material for the Services CGU. The discount rate used is the weighted average cost of capital (WACC), calculated based on a sample of comparable European companies. A WACC was estimated for each foreign country, with the impacts of IFRS 16 eliminated ##### among the sample companies in order to obtain a pre-IFRS 16 segment financial structure. A WACC was then ###### calculated for the entire Foncia Group based on a weighting of each country’s contribution to total EBITDA. On this basis, a single weighted discount rate of 7.4% was used for all of the Group’s CGUs.

###### The activities of the Services CGU are closely linked to the activities of the Property Management France CGU and the Group therefore considers that these two CGUs are exposed to a comparable level of risk. A long-term growth rate of 1.8% was used for the tests. This rate was estimated using information provided by public databases such as the IMF and EIU (Economic Intelligence Unit). ----- ##### Results of impairment tests ###### The strategic plan used for the tests forecasts a rise in cash flow from operations and hence a significant increase in the terminal value included within value in use. Sensitivity analyses: As recommended by IFRS, the results of these impairment tests were verified by determining sensitivity to changes in certain inputs:  +/- 1% change in the long-term growth rate used in the business plan;  +/- 1% change in the discount rate (WACC);  normative EBITDA growth rate.  normative capital expenditure/depreciation and amortisation. The sensitivity analyses show no specific risk of impairment for the CGUs. ######  Property Management France CGU sensitivity analysis

###### However, the number of consolidated entities is slightly lower than in the previous period owing to the various restructuring operations carried out in 2018. The list of consolidated companies is presented in Note 13. External growth investments represented a total of €113.2 million in 2018 (securities and business goodwill), of which €108.2 million has been disbursed and €5 million recognized in current liabilities in respect of the outstanding purchase price balances. Additional goodwill arising on these acquisitions represents €81.1 million (see Note 4.1). Efficity In April 2018, the outstanding balance of the initial earn-out negotiated at the time of the Efficity acquisition in 2015 was allocated to its historic founders and managers in an amount of €4.5 million (€5.2 million had already been paid in 2017). To secure the founders’ and managers’ loyalty and their commitment to Efficity’s future development, the Group entered into a new agreement with them using a specific legal structure based on the creation of an intermediate holding company (Foncia Saturne) controlling Efficity’s entire share capital. The Group offered the aforementioned founders and key managers the possibility of reinvesting part of the proceeds from this earn-out in the holding company’s capital increase carried out for a total of €7 million (the historic founders invested €3 million, while the Group contributed €4 million). This reinvestment gives the founders the opportunity to realise a potential capital gain at the end of a four-year period, depending on future trends in the company’s operating performance. ----- ###### In light of the terms and conditions of the transaction driven by the Group’s interests, the acquisition was accounted for as an extension of the initial earn-out clause. The value of the initial earn-out was therefore recalculated (to the extent of the €3 million reinvested by the founders) at the date the new agreement was signed. ➢ Since the partner-founders are exposed to the risk that they may lose the capital invested if the “bad leaver” clause applies, non-recurring income of €3 million was recognized in the period. This income reflects the remeasurement of the initial earn-out liability (from €4.5 million to €1.5 million). ➢ Efficity continues to be fully consolidated, since the Group intends to retain sole control of the entity upon completion of the transaction. Leemo/Primonial partial asset contribution Overview of the transaction The Primonial and Foncia groups set up Leemo, a joint venture, to pool their respective skills and resources in terms of listing new and existing properties via their digital platform. On 30 November 2018, Primonial acquired a 40% equity interest in Leemo (the percentage interest is subject to change depending on certain criteria owing to the preferred shares issued in consideration of the contribution – see below) through a partial asset contribution consisting of Primonial’s entire, stand-alone sales brokerage division for new and existing properties. A 10-year shareholders’ agreement was signed with the Primonial group. Consideration for the contribution Based on an estimated value of €7 million for the division, consideration for the contribution consisted of 33,624 preferred shares each with a par value of €1, bringing Leemo’s share capital to 84,059 shares. The resulting contribution premium was €6,966,376. The contribution consisted mainly of intangible assets, which were measured by mutual agreement at €7 million. Conversion of preferred shares Besides carrying the same rights as ordinary shares, preferred shares may also be automatically converted into ordinary shares in 2021 in a proportion based on the “outperformance” achieved, as assessed according to changes in the respective contributions of the Primonial and Foncia groups to Leemo’s net revenue. An analysis of each group’s contribution could allow either (i) Primonial to increase its interest in Leemo to a maximum of 48,457 shares (49% of the share capital), or (ii) Foncia to collect up to €2 million in cash compensation. Accounting treatment applied Based on the majority shareholding in Leemo and the governance arrangements in place, the Group decided that it retained sole control of Leemo and that it would therefore continue to fully consolidate the company. The basis on which preferred shares may be converted also led the Group to consider that the financial asset adopted as consideration for the contribution (ordinary shares after conversion) did not represent a fixed basis for the exchange at 31 December 2018. Accordingly, it cannot demonstrate that a fixed number of ordinary shares will be offered as consideration for the aforementioned preferred shares. From the perspective of applicable accounting standards and IAS 32 in particular, this consideration prevents the preferred shares from being recognised as equity instruments. The preferred shares are therefore classified as financial liabilities by default. At 31 December 2018, considering that the “neutral” scenario was most likely, the liability was measured at 40% of Leemo’s enterprise value, i.e., €7 million, and was classified within non-current borrowings. ----- ###### Implementation of a free share plan by Foncia Stark Characteristics of the plan: - Grant date: 23 May 2018  - Date on which the continuing employment condition is assessed: 23 May 2020  - Vesting period for the shares: between 23 May 2018 and 23 May 2020 - Maximum number of shares awarded: up to 205,000 free shares in the company, representing 5.125% of its share capital - Maximum aggregate amount of the free share plan: €410,000 - The shares awarded are monetised through a new liquidity contract which prices the share using a calculation formula. - Corporate social contribution (forfait social): 20% of the free share plan The value of the free shares awarded represents discretionary compensation granted to employees. Since a liquidity contract has been set up, the shares awarded to beneficiaries will be settled in cash. The free share plan therefore meets the definition of a “cash-settled” plan set out in IFRS 2. Consequently, the service cost is recognized on a straight-line basis over the vesting period against a related liability. At 31 December 2018, the service cost amounted to €149,000 and was recognized within capitalised production with an adjusting entry to employee-related payables. It will be amortised as from the date the “Millenium” project (development of new management software for the property management network) enters into service. The service cost will be reviewed each year in light of budget assumptions and turnover. Debt restructuring On 18 July and 3 August 2018, the Group restructured its borrowings with its lenders in order to secure better interest terms. (i) Modification of the ICA tranche on 18 July 2018 - Reduction of 50 bps in the applicable margin: the “cash margin” is reduced from 7.5% to 7%, while the “PIK margin” is reduced from 8.5% to 8%.  - Elimination of the 3-month Euribor 1% floor: in the current negative interest rate environment, the E3M benchmark rate is therefore reduced to 0%.  - Elimination of applicable 2% penalties in the event of early repayment as from 18 July 2019. (ii) Partial repayment of the ICA loan on 3 August 2018 Repayment of €77 million of this loan. The related fees for early repayment amount to €1.5 million. (iii) Subscription of a new €80 million tranche (“B4”) of the senior facility The financing terms applicable to this B4 tranche are identical to those applicable to the B3 tranche renegotiated in March 2017 (see Note 4.11.3). The issuance fees for the new tranche amount to €1.25 million and will be recognised over the term of the facility by an adjustment to financial expenses at the effective interest rate as calculated at 3 August 2018 (3.68%). IFRS 9 accounting treatment From an accounting perspective, this restructuring is part of an overall initiative to optimise the Group’s borrowing costs. The modifications were therefore analysed as a whole to determine whether they are substantial and therefore ascertain the appropriate accounting treatment to be used. ----- ###### Based on this analysis, using both quantitative and qualitative tests, there were substantial modifications to the initial terms of the ICA loan. As a result, the initial accounting treatment was discontinued, with all related unamortised expenses charged to profit or loss in an amount of €4 million. The fees due on early repayment were immediately expensed in an amount of €1.5 million. Economic and Social Unit (UES) On 21 August 2018, in response to strong employee demand for a single and harmonized framework within which to exercise their duties, the Versailles Tribunal d’Instance recognised the existence of an Economic and Social Unit (Unité Économique et Sociale – UES) between the various legal entities belonging to the network comprising the Property Management France/Transactions businesses, plus Foncia Carrières et Compétences (124 companies at 21 August 2018). This decision signals the start of a new, inclusive modus operandi as the basis for implementing the Group’s growth strategy and securing the commitment of all employees within its network. ----- ###### NOTE 3. ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND METHODS General principles used to prepare the financial statements The accounting policies described in these notes have been applied consistently to all periods presented in the consolidated financial statements, with the exception of the standards adopted as described in Note 3.2.2, effective as of 1 January 2018, including those relating to the first-time application of IFRS 15 – Revenue from Contracts with Customers and IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments. The consolidated financial statements are prepared on a historical cost basis, except for assets held for sale and related liabilities, measured in accordance with IFRS 5, and certain financial instruments carried at fair value or amortised cost in accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9. The consolidated financial statements of Foncia Management at 31 December 2018 were adopted by the Supervisory Board at its meeting of 11 April 2019, and will be submitted to shareholders for approval at the General Meeting on 29 June 2019. They are presented in thousands of euros and amounts are rounded up or down to the nearest thousand unless otherwise specified. Consequently, the sum of these amounts may differ slightly from the total amounts reported. Accounting standards 3.2.1. Basis of preparation of financial information Pursuant to Regulation (EC) No. 1606/2002 of 19 July 2002 as amended by Regulation (EC) No. 297/2008 of 11 March 2008, the 2018 consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and interpretations issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) as adopted by the European Union and applicable at 1 January 2018. The full text of the standards adopted by the European Union can be consulted on the European Commission’s website: https://ec.europa.eu/info/business-economy-euro/company-reporting-and-auditing/company-reporting_en At the end of the reporting period, there was no difference between the IFRS used to prepare these financial statements and the standards adopted by the IASB and applicable for the period presented. The accounting policies and bases of measurement applied to prepare these consolidated financial statements are described in Note 3.4 below. 3.2.2. Changes in accounting standards Main IFRS standards, amendments and interpretations in force within the European Union and mandatorily applicable as of 1 January 2018 The accounting policies and bases of measurement used by the Group to prepare its consolidated financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2018 are identical to those used by the Group at 31 December 2017, with the exception of: - IFRS 15 – Revenue from Contracts with Customers ###### On 28 May 2014, the IASB published IFRS 15 – Revenue from Contracts with Customers, which impacts the timing of revenue recognition by the Group. IFRS 15 sets out a single model framework to account for revenue arising on contracts with customers. According to the fundamental principle of the new standard, revenue is recognised based on when the goods and services promised in the contract are provided to the customer, and for the amount of consideration to which an entity expects to be entitled in exchange. ----- ###### IFRS 15 sets out a five-step model framework for recognising and measuring revenue. The new standard, which replaces IAS 18, was not early adopted by the Group. It was applied retrospectively at 1 January 2018 using the simplified retrospective transition method, i.e., the cumulative effect of applying IFRS 15 is recognised at 1 January 2018 as an adjustment to the opening balance of equity. Accordingly, equity at 31 December 2017 has been restated for the impacts of IFRS 15. A summary of the impacts of IFRS 15 on each line of the statement of financial position is provided below. ###### In accordance with the simplified retrospective method, the Group recognised the cumulative effect of applying IFRS 15 as an adjustment to the opening balance of equity at 1 January 2018. IFRS 15 was only applied to contracts in force at 1 January 2018. Summary of the estimated impacts of applying IFRS 15 on pro forma profit (loss) for 2017 (12 months) In accordance with the simplified retrospective method, IFRS 15 is applicable only to contracts in force at the date of first-time application. This results in two non-comparable revenue figures: revenue as determined under IFRS 15 and revenue as determined under IAS 18. Accordingly, the Group has decided to also present the impacts that IFRS 15 would have had on profit (loss) for the 2017 reporting period, as compared with IAS 18. For comparative purposes, all data presented in relation to profit (loss) for the 2017 reporting period has been restated for the impacts of IFRS 15.
