From an accounting standpoint, the Group considers that wages and other fixed costs would have remained the same irrespective of the restated revenue, in the same way as transaction bonuses and premiums calculated on the basis of signed notarial deeds only. • Assurimo: Revenue is recorded over the term of the contract, since services in this brokerage business are provided on a straight-line basis. Up to 2017, revenue was chiefly recognised when customers were invoiced for insurance premiums (mostly at the end of the year). Revenue restated for IFRS 15 was calculated based on recognition on a straight-line basis applying a stable seasonality factor equal to 8% of total revenue. - IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments ###### On 24 July 2014, the IASB published a new standard on financial instruments replacing most of the existing provisions under IFRS, and particularly IAS 39. The Group did not early adopt IFRS 9. The requirements of the standard in terms of the classification, measurement and impairment of financial instruments are applied by the Group retrospectively, with no adjustments to information for comparative periods. • Phase 1: Classification and measurement of financial assets and liabilities IFRS 9 introduces new requirements for classifying and measuring financial assets and liabilities based on the entity’s business model and the applicable contractual terms. Under IFRS 9, all equity instruments should be measured at fair value in the statement of financial position, with gains and losses either taken to profit or loss or recognised through other comprehensive income in accordance with an option taken by the entity that cannot subsequently be revoked. In this case, only dividends will tend to be recognised in profit or loss. The Group has reviewed and measured its financial assets at 1 January 2018 in light of the facts and circumstances existing at that date, and considers that the first-time application of IFRS 9 would not have a material impact on the classification and measurement of the items concerned. The only impact is on the Group’s shareholdings in Swiss property companies and cooperatives, some of which were sold during the year. Classified as held to maturity under IAS 39 (and therefore carried at amortised cost), these shareholdings have been reclassified within equity instruments carried at fair value through other comprehensive income. In this respect, they were remeasured at 1 January in an amount of €685,000, with an adjusting entry posted to total equity. Concerning the measurement of financial liabilities, IFRS 9 introduces very few changes to the requirements that existed under IAS 39, and no impacts were identified as a result of the new standard in the 2018 financial statements. The Group had analysed its debt repricing operations in 2017 in light of the principles of IAS 39 but also taking into account the changes introduced by IFRS 9. Accordingly, the first-time application of IFRS 9 did not have any retrospective impact in the 2018 financial statements in this respect. • Phase 2: Impairment As a basis for financial asset impairment, IFRS 9 requires use of an expected loss model rather than the incurred loss model under IAS 39. The expected loss model requires entities to recognise expected losses on its receivables, with any changes in these losses to be recognised at the end of each reporting period in order to reflect changes in the credit risk since initial recognition. ----- ###### Since impairment is not material in the Group’s B-to-C business, no changes were made to the accounting policies used to recognise impairment provisions. The Group is exposed to limited bad debt risk on its commercial receivables as the risk is concentrated mainly in Foncia IPM’s operations, which accounts for less than 4% of consolidated revenue. • Phase 3: Hedge accounting The new requirements for general hedge accounting maintain the three hedging categories identified under IAS 39. IFRS 9 offers greater flexibility as regards transactions that may be eligible for hedge accounting, particularly in terms of instruments that may be designated as hedging instruments and the type of risks that may be hedged in a non-financial hedge. The hedge effectiveness test has also been revised and replaced by the notion of an “economic relationship” between the hedging instrument and the hedged item. The retrospective assessment of hedge effectiveness is no longer required. Broader disclosure requirements for entities in terms of risk management have also been introduced. The Group does not use instruments meeting the definition of hedging instruments for accounting purposes. - IFRIC 22 – Foreign Currency Transactions and Advance Consideration - Amendment to IFRS 2 – Classification and Measurement of Share-based Payment Transactions - Amendment to IAS 40 – Transfers of Investment Property - Amendments to IFRS 4 – Applying IFRS 9 “Financial Instruments” with IFRS 4 “Insurance Contracts” - Amendments resulting from Annual Improvements to IFRSs – 2014-2016 cycle ###### The first-time application of these standards, amendments and interpretations does not have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements. Other new standards and guidance applicable after 1 January 2019 and not early adopted by the Group - IFRS 16 – Leases ###### IFRS 16, the new standard on leases, was published on 13 January 2016 and will be effective for reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2019. IFRS 16 will replace IAS 17 and any related IFRIC and SIC interpretations. The new standard no longer applies a distinction between operating and finance leases. Accordingly, the Group will be required to recognise in its statement of financial position all of its lease obligations within the meaning of IFRS 16 in the same manner as currently required under IAS 17 for finance leases. The rights and obligations resulting from a lease contract will therefore be recognised in assets and liabilities, respectively, rather than in off-balance sheet commitments as is currently the case for operating leases. The Group will apply IFRS 16 for the first time at 1 January 2019 using a simplified retrospective approach, with no restatement of comparative figures. The Group has a large number of leases across its entire French and international branch network. There are many different types of leases, from property leases to vehicle leases. The first-time application of IFRS 16 will therefore have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements. To prepare for its first-time application of the standard, the Group has been functionally assisted by an external service provider in charge of leading and coordinating the project at the level of all affected divisions (finance, operations, property). The project has involved: - compiling data on leases for the France scope;  - reviewing the data compiled for the international scope;  - analysing data reliability based on a sample of different contract types; - validating the scope of application of the standard and its exclusions; ----- ###### - calculating the Group’s incremental borrowing rates;  - quantifying the impacts;  - identifying criteria and options affecting the measurement of lease assets. All leases concerned by the standard have now been identified and their data analysed. In 2019, around 705 property leases in France will be accounted for in accordance with IFRS 16, including 281 contracts which are automatically renewable. This figure does not include any new leases that may begin in 2019, including those resulting from acquisitions. The exemptions provided for by the standard as regards short-term leases (with a term of 12 months or less) and leases of low-value assets will not be applied. The Group is currently reviewing quantified estimates of the IFRS 16 impact. - IFRS 17 – Insurance Contracts - IFRIC 23 – Uncertainty over Income Tax Treatments - Amendment to IFRS 9 – Prepayment Features with Negative Compensation - Amendment to IAS 28 – Long-term Interests in Associates and Joint Ventures - Amendments resulting from Annual Improvements to IFRSs – 2015-2017 cycle - Amendment to IAS 19 – Plan Amendment, Curtailment or Settlement - Amendment to IFRS 3 – Definition of a Business - Amendments to IAS 1 and IAS 8 – Definition of Material ###### These standards, amendments and interpretations have been adopted or are in the process of being adopted by the European Union. Subject to their adoption, they are applicable for reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2019. The Group is currently analysing the potential impacts of applying the requirements set out in these texts for the first time. Use of management estimates in applying the Group’s accounting standards The preparation of financial statements requires the Group to make estimates and assumptions that may affect the measurement and presentation of certain assets and liabilities and any disclosures provided in respect of contingent liabilities at the end of the reporting period, as well as the reported amounts of income and expenses for the period. Estimates and underlying assumptions are determined based on information available at the end of the reporting period and are reviewed on a regular basis in light of past experience and other factors deemed reasonable given the circumstances. These estimates serve as the basis for measuring the carrying amount of assets and liabilities that cannot be obtained directly from other sources. Where applicable, a sensitivity analysis may be performed if the estimates are material. Accordingly, actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates made by the Group in preparing its consolidated financial statements are based on a going concern assumption and relate primarily to the items described below. ▪ Measurements used in testing goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment for impairment The estimates and assumptions made to determine the recoverable amount of goodwill, intangible assets, and property, plant and equipment relate mainly to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. ----- ###### As with any estimate, the assumptions used in these calculations are partly based on uncertain factors and may therefore need to be adjusted in subsequent periods. Note 4.1.3 sets out the assumptions used to calculate future cash flows and determine the discount rates to be applied in measuring the recoverable amounts of these assets. Sensitivity analyses were also performed and are described in the same note. ▪ Measurement of provisions The Group used the best estimate of its commitments and obligations to calculate the corresponding provisions. ▪ Measurement of employee benefits The Group operates both defined contribution and defined benefit plans. Obligations under these plans are calculated using the projected unit credit method, which is based on assumptions regarding the discount rate, future increases in salary, employee turnover, life expectancy and the rate of increase in healthcare costs. Note 4.12 sets out the assumptions used to measure these obligations. The Group considers that the actuarial assumptions used are appropriate and justified in the current environment. However, the corresponding obligations may change if these assumptions also change. ▪ Measurement of fair value (Level 1) The Group uses fair value on a recurring basis in its statement of financial position to measure unlisted derivative instruments and cash and cash equivalents (see Notes 3.4.18 and 4.18). ▪ Measurement of recognised deferred tax assets and liabilities and tax expense The Group’s tax position (see Notes 4.8 and 5.11) is based on its best estimate of future taxable earnings. ▪ Basis for determining the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of a business combination The estimates and assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount of these identifiable assets and liabilities relate in particular to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. Any changes in these assumptions could impact the recoverable amount. ▪ Assessment of criteria for identifying discontinued operations In accordance with IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations, the Group is required to exercise judgement in determining whether an asset or group of assets meets the criteria to be classified as held for sale. IFRS 5 criteria are also used to identify any assets to be classified as discontinued operations. These assessments are reviewed at the end of each reporting period in light of changes in the relevant facts and circumstances. In the absence of IFRS guidance for a specific transaction, event or condition, the Group uses its judgement to define and apply accounting policies that will result in relevant, fair and comparable information to ensure that the financial statements: ▪ present a true and fair view of the Foncia Group’s financial position, financial performance and cash flows; ▪ reflect the economic substance of transactions; ▪ are neutral, prudent and comprehensive in all material respects. Detailed disclosures in this regard are provided in the notes to the consolidated financial statements. ----- ###### Basis of measurement 3.4.1. Basis of consolidation The financial statements of the Group’s subsidiaries are prepared using the same accounting policies and over the same period as those of the parent company. Controlled entities Companies directly or indirectly controlled by the Group are fully consolidated. Control exists when the Group is exposed, or is entitled, to variable returns from its involvement with the entity in question and has the ability to affect those returns through its power over the entity. Control is analysed whenever facts and circumstances indicate that one or more of the inputs used to assess control has changed. A subsidiary is consolidated as from the date control is acquired, which is usually upon signature of the share transfer and disposal agreements (see “Accounting for acquisitions ongoing at the end of the reporting period” below). Consolidation ceases when control is relinquished. Any interest in the subsidiary that is not directly or indirectly attributable to the Group is recognised within non-controlling interests. Profits and losses and each component of other comprehensive income relating to subsidiaries are allocated to owners of the parent and non-controlling interests, even if this results in non-controlling interests having a deficit balance. Changes in the percentage interest held in subsidiaries that do not lead to a change in control are treated as equity transactions, since the transactions take place between owners acting in their capacity as owners. The impact of these transactions is shown in equity net of tax and does not therefore impact consolidated profit or loss. These transactions are also shown in the statement of cash flows under cash flows relating to investing activities. Investments in equity-accounted companies (associates and joint ventures) Associates are entities over which the Group exercises significant influence. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating policy decisions of the entity without controlling or jointly controlling those policies. A joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to its net assets. Joint control of an arrangement only exists when decisions about the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. Profits, losses, assets and liabilities of associates or joint ventures are accounted for by the equity method in the Group’s consolidated financial statements. Under the equity method, the investment in an associate or joint venture is initially recognised at acquisition cost and subsequently adjusted for the Group’s interest in the profits, losses and other comprehensive income of the associate or joint venture. IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments is applied to determine whether investments in associates or joint ventures need to be tested for impairment. Where necessary, the total carrying amount of the investment (including goodwill) is tested for impairment in accordance with IAS 36 – Impairment of Assets. Accounting for acquisitions ongoing at the end of the reporting period Non-consolidated investments are classified as available-for-sale securities and mainly consist of shares in property management companies that will subsequently be consolidated. ----- ###### Before acquiring shares in a property management company, the Group agrees to acquire the shares and pays 10% of the estimated price to the seller. This part payment is included in “Downpayments on acquisitions of securities” within non-current financial assets. The remaining 90% is booked in “Off-balance sheet commitments” (see Note 9). Upon signing the share transfer or disposal agreement, the Group pays an additional 70% of the estimated price to the seller. The estimated purchase price is included in equity investments, and the part payment already recognised is also reclassified to this caption. The acquired company is then consolidated. Following a review of the acquired company’s financial statements, the Group pays the remaining balance and adjusts the purchase price of the shares. Non-consolidated investments Companies with the following characteristics are not included in the scope of consolidation: ▪ they are in the process of being wound up or are dormant; ▪ their business is not strategic for the Group. In accordance with IFRS 9, non-consolidated investments are carried at fair value. There are no material obligations or liabilities relating to these entities. 3.4.2. Elimination of intragroup transactions All intragroup transactions and balances as well as any income, expenses, gains and losses resulting from intragroup transactions and included in the carrying amount of assets are eliminated on consolidation. When a Group entity carries out a transaction with a joint venture or associate, the related gains and losses are recognised in the Group’s consolidated financial statements only to the extent of the interests held by third parties in the joint venture or associate. 3.4.3. Foreign currency translation Presentation currency The consolidated financial statements are presented in euros, which is the Group’s presentation currency. Functional currency and translation of the financial statements of foreign companies A consolidated entity’s functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment in which it operates. In most cases, the functional currency is the local currency. However, certain entities must adopt a functional currency other than their local currency when that currency represents the currency of the major transactions carried out by the entity and accurately reflects its economic environment. The financial statements of foreign entities whose functional currency is different from the presentation currency of the Group’s consolidated financial statements are translated using the “closing rate” method. Under this method, assets and liabilities are translated at the exchange rates prevailing at the end of the reporting period, while profit and loss and cash flow items are translated at the average exchange rate for the period. The resulting currency translation differences are recognised directly in other comprehensive income within equity under “Translation adjustments”. Goodwill relating to foreign entities whose functional currency is not the euro are treated as assets acquired or liabilities assumed and therefore translated at the exchange rate prevailing at the end of the reporting period. ----- ###### Foreign currency transactions Foreign currency transactions are translated into euros at the exchange rates prevailing at the transaction date or at the hedged rate. At the end of the reporting period, monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency are translated at the closing exchange rate, with the resulting gains and losses included in foreign exchange gains and losses under other financial income and expenses in the statement of profit and loss. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are measured at historical cost are translated at the exchange rate at the transaction date. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are stated at fair value are translated at the exchange rate at the date on which fair value was determined. 3.4.4. Business combinations and goodwill In accordance with the revised IFRS 3, business combinations are accounted for using the acquisition method. According to this method, assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed that meet the recognition criteria under the revised IFRS 3 are measured at fair value. Goodwill is measured as the difference between the consideration transferred (purchase price plus the fair value of any previously-held interest and the value of any non-controlling interests) and the estimated fair value of the identifiable assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed. It is recorded under “Goodwill” in the statement of financial position. Goodwill is calculated on a provisional basis at the time of the acquisition and is adjusted within 12 months of the acquisition date. When the business combination is a bargain purchase, negative goodwill is identified. The corresponding gain is included in profit or loss in the period of the acquisition. For each business combination, the Group may choose to account for non-controlling interests: - either at acquisition-date fair value, resulting in the recognition of goodwill on the non-controlling interests ###### (“full goodwill” method); - or based on the share of net identifiable assets of the acquired entity measured at fair value, in which case ###### goodwill is only recognised on the portion attributable to owners of the parent (“partial goodwill” method). If the business combination is carried out in stages, the acquisition-date carrying amount of the previously-held interest in the acquired entity is remeasured to fair value at the acquisition date.  Any resulting gains or losses are taken to profit or loss. In the event of deferred settlements, the future amounts payable are discounted to present value at the settlement date. The discount rate used is the same as that used to estimate the value of the assets. Any adjustments to the potential price are estimated at acquisition-date fair value. The initial measurement may only subsequently be adjusted against goodwill if new information is obtained arising from facts and circumstances existing at the acquisition date and to the extent that the measurement is still provisional (maximum measurement period of 12 months). Any subsequent adjustments to the purchase price not meeting these criteria are included in liabilities or receivables, with an offsetting entry to profit or loss. During the 12-month measurement period, changes to the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed relating to recognised acquisitions are treated as retrospective adjustments to goodwill. After the end of the measurement period, changes to the estimated value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed are recognised in profit or loss, with no adjustment to goodwill. ----- ###### In accordance with the revised IFRS 3, costs directly attributable to the acquisition are expensed in the period in which they are incurred. The value of goodwill is reviewed each year and may also be impaired (see Note 3.4.7). Earn-out payment The revised IFRS 3 gives certain indications as regards the accounting for contingent payment arrangements with employees or selling shareholders. These arrangements may be part of the business combination or may be considered as separate from the acquisition agreement for the target entity. In certain acquisitions, earn-out payments were considered part of the consideration for post-acquisition services rendered and are therefore expensed in the periods concerned and in future periods. 3.4.5. Intangible assets Intangible assets are identifiable non-monetary assets with no physical substance. In accordance with IAS 38, intangible assets that are acquired separately are initially measured at cost when the future economic benefits attributable to the asset will flow to the Group and the cost of the asset can be measured reliably. Intangible assets acquired as part of a business combination are carried at fair value separately from goodwill. Intangible assets are subsequently measured at cost less any accumulated amortisation and impairment losses. Intangible assets with a finite useful life (software and licences) are amortised on a straight-line basis over their expected useful lives: - Client relationships: 18-21 years - Software programs: 1-10 years - Other intangible assets: 5 years ###### Intangible assets with an indefinite useful life are not amortised. They are included with other assets within cash-generating units (CGUs) and tested for impairment using the discounted cash flow method at least once a year and whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired. When the recoverable amount of these assets calculated based on criteria prevailing at the acquisition date falls below their carrying amount, an impairment provision is recorded. Trademarks Identifiable trademarks are measured using a multi-criteria approach which takes into consideration both their reputation and profitability. The Group classified its main “Foncia” trademark along with the “Trévi” trademark in Belgium and the “Domicim” and “Brolliet” trademarks in Switzerland as indefinite-lived intangible assets. Business software programs Software acquired is carried at cost (purchase price plus ancillary expenses). When allocating the purchase price, certain software programs may also be measured using the replacement cost approach. Business goodwill and client relationships Client relationships include the list of mandates held by the Group’s companies. A mandate is an instrument by which a person (the principal) gives another person (the agent) the power of proxy. France’s Hoguet Law requires ----- ###### professional property agents to hold a written mandate in order to put properties up for sale or let, and to manage property. Client relationships are measured based on the excess earnings method. Other intangible assets Other intangible assets mainly comprise the cost of acquiring new business. 3.4.6. Property, plant and equipment Property, plant and equipment are measured at their historical cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. The cost of an item of property, plant and equipment comprises its purchase price, including customs duties and non-recoverable taxes, and any costs directly incurred to bring the asset to working condition for its intended use. Any trade discounts and rebates are deducted from the purchase price. Subsequent expenditure is recognised in expenses, unless it improves the asset’s initial performance, prolongs its useful life, or reduces the operating costs previously determined. Depreciation is recognised on a straight-line basis over the assets’ estimated useful lives. In accordance with IAS 16, property, plant and equipment are recognised using the component approach, with each component depreciated separately over its useful life: - Buildings: 20-50 years - Fixtures and fittings: 8-10 years - IT equipment: 4 years - Vehicle fleet: 5 years - Furniture: 10 years - Office equipment: 4 years ###### Useful lives are reviewed each year and may be adjusted if expectations differ from previous estimates. Gains and losses on asset disposals are calculated as the difference between the sale proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset concerned. 3.4.7. Impairment losses on goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment The carrying amounts of non-current non-financial assets are reviewed at the end of each reporting period in order to identify any potential impairment: - goodwill and other intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are tested for impairment at least annually and ###### whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired; - all other assets are tested for impairment whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired. ###### External indicators of impairment include changes in the general economic and financial environment, downtrends in local economic environments and changes in economic performance. These are analysed by the Group to determine whether the assets concerned should be tested for impairment more frequently. For impairment testing purposes, goodwill is allocated to cash-generating units (CGUs ) or groups of CGUs expected to benefit from the synergies arising on the business combination.  The Group decides whether or not to recognise an impairment loss by comparing the carrying amount of the assets and liabilities in a CGU or group of CGUs with their recoverable amount. A CGU is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets for internal management purposes. ----- ###### The Group has identified the following three CGUs corresponding to its major development and investment strategies: - Property management companies – France - Property management companies – International - Other activities (service companies and other entities) ###### The recoverable amount of a CGU is the higher of its fair value (generally market price) less costs to sell and its value in use. Fair value less costs to sell is calculated based on available information used to establish the best estimate of the selling price net of costs to sell in an arm’s length transaction between fully informed, willing parties. Value in use as calculated by the Group generally corresponds to the present value of the future cash flows attributable to a CGU or group of CGUs, taking into account their residual value and based on the most probable assumptions adopted by management. The assumptions used are based on the budgets and business plans prepared by management for each business. These budgets are the latest budgets approved by the Supervisory Board at the date of preparation of the financial statements. Other assumptions affecting the calculation of the recoverable amount include the growth rate, operating margin, the discount rate and the tax rate (see Note 4.1). The discount rate used to discount post-tax cash flows to their present value reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset or CGU. Where there is no specific discount rate for the assets tested, the average cost of capital is used. The discount rates are post-tax rates and are applied to post-tax cash flows. The recoverable amount calculated using post-tax discount rates is equal to that which would have been obtained using pre-tax rates applied to pre-tax cash flows, as required by IAS 36. If the carrying amount of the CGU exceeds its recoverable amount, the related assets are written down to the recoverable amount. The impairment loss is first allocated to goodwill and then to the carrying amount of the other assets of the CGU, in proportion to their carrying amount. This must not result in the carrying amount of an individual asset falling below the higher of its fair value, value in use and zero. Impairment losses are recognised in other operating expenses and may not be reversed. 3.4.8. Financial assets The measurement and recognition of financial assets and liabilities is defined by the new IFRS 9 – Financial instruments. Unlike IAS 39, IFRS 9 applies a single analytical framework to all financial assets in order to determine the classification and basis of measurement to be used for accounting purposes. The four IAS 39 categories have been replaced by three categories, each associated with a specific measurement approach. More specifically: ✓ Debt instruments held in a business model whose objective is to collect contractual cash flows that are solely payments of principal and interest (SPPI) on the principal amount outstanding, are generally carried at amortised cost. ✓ Debt instruments held in a business model whose objective is achieved by both collecting contractual cash flows (whose contractual conditions give rise to cash flows that are solely payments of principal and interest [SPPI] on the principal amount outstanding) and selling financial assets, are typically carried at fair value through other comprehensive income. ✓ All other debt and equity instruments are carried at fair value through profit or loss. ----- ###### A summary of these new financial asset classification and measurement requirements is set out below:

###### It should be recalled that on 7 September 2016, Foncia Management acquired a controlling interest in the Foncia Holding group for an enterprise value of €1,832.9 million and a purchase price of €807.5 million, in light of existing bank debt at the date control was acquired. The final goodwill allocation was completed in 2018. Goodwill was allocated pro rata to the enterprise value of each CGU, as estimated based on the acquisition business plans for each CGU used in connection with the purchase price accounting (see Note 4.1.3 below). Changes in the scope of consolidation in 2018 generated €81.2 million in goodwill. ###### 4.1.3. Assumptions used in the 2018 impairment tests Impairment tests were conducted based on the financial statements at 30 November 2018, since figures for 31 December 2018 were not yet available at that date. The assumptions used in the tests and the method applied are described below. Calculation of the carrying amount of the CGUs at 30 November 2018 Estimating the carrying amount of each CGU includes determining the value of the assets that may be directly attributed or reasonably allocated to the CGU and that will generate cash flows included in the calculation of value in use. Goodwill of €1,094 million arising on the acquisition by Partners Group of a controlling interest in Foncia Holding in September 2016 was allocated pro rata to the enterprise value of each CGU, as estimated based on the acquisition business plans for each CGU used in connection with the purchase price accounting. The goodwill allocation resulted in the following:

Calculation of the recoverable amount of the CGUs at 30 November 2018 In accordance with the Group’s impairment testing approach (see Note 3.4.7), and in the absence of observable fair values in an organised market, the recoverable amount of CGUs corresponds to their value in use, which is defined as the sum of their net cash flows based on the latest forecasts for each CGU, determined using: ▪ a business plan prepared by management based on growth and profitability assumptions, taking into account past performance, forecast changes in the economic environment, and expected market trends; ▪ a terminal value calculated by capitalising normative cash flows obtained by extrapolating cash flows from the final year of the business plan, with a stable growth rate or a growth rate increasing steadily over the long term; ▪ expected cash flows discounted at a rate determined by reference to the weighted average cost of capital (WACC). The forecasts used in the impairment tests carried out at 30 November 2018 are taken from the consolidated “Low Case” business plans prepared by management in March 2018 covering a specified period of three years. These business plans were validated by the Board in March 2018 and presented to the Statutory Auditors in June of that year. The forecasts used were extrapolated through to 2022, to ensure that revenue, depreciation and amortisation approached normative levels. It should be noted that all holding company expenses not allocated in the consolidated business plan were allocated in full to the Property Management France CGU. Corporate functions are managed at individual country-level for the Property Management International CGU and are considered not material for the Services CGU. The discount rate used is the weighted average cost of capital (WACC), calculated based on a sample of six comparable European companies. A WACC was estimated for each foreign country based on their tax rates and the yield on their sovereign bonds. A WACC was then calculated for the entire Foncia Group based on a weighting of each country’s contribution to total EBITDA. On this basis, a single weighted discount rate of 7.4% was used for all of the Group’s CGUs.

A long-term growth rate of 1.8% was used for the tests. This rate was estimated using information provided by public databases such as the IMF and EIU (Economic Intelligence Unit). ##### Results of impairment tests ###### The strategic plan used for the tests forecasts a rise in cash flow from operations and hence a significant increase in the terminal value included within value in use. |Country WACC 2018 EBITDA WACC contribution France 7.4% 96.8% 7.2% Sw itzerland 7.1% 0.6% 0.0% Germany 7.2% 1.1% 0.1% Belgium 7.2% 1.5% 0.1%|WACC|2018 EBITDA|WACC contribution| |---|---|---|---| ----- ###### The table below presents the values in use obtained for the three CGUs, compared with the carrying amounts of their respective economic assets. €m Value in use Carrying amount  Difference Margin (%) Group CGUs 2,574.4 1,873.9 700.5 37.4% Property Management France CGU 1,809 1,344 464 35% Property Management International CGU 123 60 64 107% Services CGU 642 470 173 37% As the value in use of each CGU exceeds the carrying amount, no impairment needed to be recognised against the Group’s assets at 30 November 2018. The value of the assets to be tested for impairment at 31 December 2018 is €27 million higher than the value tested at 30 November 2018. In light of this, the results of the earlier impairment test are still relevant and no impairment needs to be booked at 31 December 2018. Sensitivity analyses and break-even points As recommended by IFRS, the results of these impairment tests were verified by determining sensitivity to changes in certain inputs: ▪ +/- 1% change in the long-term growth rate used in the business plan; ▪ +/- 1% change in the discount rate (WACC); ▪ normative EBITDA growth rate. The sensitivity analyses show no specific risk of impairment for the CGUs. ➢ Property Management France CGU: WACC: 9.4%/PGR: -0.4%/EBITDA margin: 20.6%

Holding (September 2016), the Foncia Group and Domicim trademarks were recognised at an amount of €405.3 million based on their valuations. The Group also estimated the value of the Brolliet trademark at CHF 13.7 million (i.e., €12.5 million at 31 December 2020), as well as the Lodgis and Gribi trademarks, at €2.3 million and €2.8 million, respectively. Concessions, patents and software Concessions, patents and software include the systems measured in connection with the purchase price accounting for Foncia Group at €5.2 million, as well as the management software used by Lodgis representing €1.3 million. It should be noted that the amortization plan for the remeasurement adjustment recognised in respect of the Thetrawin software (internally developed) was prospectively revised at 1 January 2020 in line with the Foncia Group’s migration to “Millénium”, slated for completion at the end of 2021. Investments in the period totalled €7.6 million and mainly concern Seiitra (€5.3 million) for upgraded Thetrawin modules (Powimo project) and regulatory modules (Thetrawin Legacy), along with Switzerland (€1.3 million), primarily IT capital expenditure at DBS Immobilier for €1.1 million. Other contributors to this item represent investments totalling €0.7 million and relate primarily to Germany. Other changes amounting to €6 million chiefly concern the capitalization of assets in progress by Foncia Groupe (ongoing IT projects), Foncia Management (Workday) and the German branch. Client relationships Client relationships include the fair value of the mandates held by Group companies, as estimated at the time of the September 2016 purchase price accounting for €460.8 million (carrying amount of €356.7 million at 31 December 2020), as well as client relationships relating to management and architectural activities at Brolliet, valued at €6.9 million in September 2016 (carrying amount of €5.4 million at 31 December 2020). Client relationships also include portfolios acquired since September 2016 as part of the Group’s acquisition-led growth strategy (jointly owned properties and managed rental properties). Other changes reflect the measurement of Sigla, Axium and Gribi client relationships for a total of €26.4 million. Investments in the period totalled €0.9 million and primarily relate to acquisitions of portfolios, in particular Immobiliers Setois, Mazelie and Ethic Gestion. Lastly, the Primonial client relationship recorded by Leemo was written down in an amount of €7 million, as the business has been loss-making since 2018 and its medium-term profitability outlook is particularly downbeat. Other intangible assets Other intangible assets essentially comprise the cost of acquiring new business. The €4.5 million increase in this item during the period reflects the capitalisation of the costs of acquiring new mandates, rebilled to other firms in the network. Decreases totalling €0.8 million relate to the retirement of these costs for lots that were not secured in the period. Intangible assets in progress Intangible assets in progress include various Group projects that can be capitalised. At 31 December 2020, the main contributors to this item are Foncia Groupe for €24.6 million in relation to IT projects, Foncia Stark for €33.3 million in relation to the development and roll-out of the Millenium software, and Seiitra for €4 million in relation to the Powimo project. Investments in the period primarily concern Foncia Groupe for €6.1 million and Foncia Stark for €16.2 million. ----- ###### Property, plant and equipment Change in Property, plant and equipment** Monetary Decreases/ Depreciation/ Translation Other

###### Most leases relate to Group business premises. These contracts are managed using a dynamic approach directly in line with the operating performance of the Group’s branch network and its real estate strategy. In France, around 789 property leases were included in this caption at 31 December 2020 (808 property leases at 31 December 2019), of which around 40% are automatically renewable. The main leases (in terms of rent) relate to the head office at Antony, Foncia Paris Rive Droite at 27 rue de Provence in Paris, Esset Management in Aubervilliers, and Foncia Paris Rive Gauche at rue Raymond Losserand and Boulevard de Courcelles in Paris. Changes in the period can be explained as follows: ➢ New leases signed in France for €28.2 million concern a total of 69 new contracts. However, the five main leases account for almost 67% of the increase in right-of-use assets. These include the new premises at 27 rue de Provence in Paris, representing €12.6 million in right-of-use assets. ➢ Changes in the scope of consolidation concern 94 property leases taken on from the various companies acquired in the period, notably Gérance de Passy (€2.2 million), Yxime (€1.5 million) and Prazisa in Germany (€1.1 million). It should be noted that within the scope of its systems development to support the roll-out of the “Millénium” project, in May 2020 the Group signed a framework agreement with BNP Paribas for the lease of Apple equipment (supplies in bundles comprising hardware, software and services, namely AppleCare for iphones, ipads and Macbooks). As the project began to be rolled out in July 2020, this led to an increase of €3.5 million in right-of-use assets at 31 December 2020. ###### 4.4.3. Assumptions used The value of IFRS 16 right-of-use assets and lease liabilities is largely dependent on the assumptions used to determine the lease term and, to a lesser extent, the discount rate. ➢ Lease terms generally correspond to the non-cancellable (i.e., contractual) periods of the lease. This is notably the case for leases of vehicles, photocopiers and IT equipment, for which no renewal option is generally taken into account. 22 976| |Impact of discounting|( 12 081)|( 4 124) ( 6 952) ( 1 005)| |Total lease liabilities|157 673|50 681 85 021 21 971| ----- #####  ###### For French property leases, the Group may consider any early termination options (i.e., at the end of the first or second three-year period), or an enforceable period that goes beyond the contractual period. This analysis is based on the prevailing operating and strategic environment at the reporting date and is reviewed each year by the Group’s Property division.  In the particular case of automatically renewable property leases in France, the Group now analyses the broader economics of a lease in determining its enforceable period pursuant to the IFRS IC’s agenda decision. A single reasonably certain term of three years is used to measure these leases. This estimate takes into account (i) the need for the business to continue operating which acts as an incentive to continue the initial lease, but also (ii) the Group’s strongly proactive and opportunistic real estate strategy in streamlining its property portfolio (notably during restructuring operations resulting from its acquisitions). ➢ Under IFRS 16, the discount rate for each lease is to be determined by reference to the lessee’s incremental borrowing rate. In practice, given how the Group is organised financially, i.e., held or guaranteed almost exclusively by the three French holding companies, the Group adopted an incremental borrowing rate of 3.25% for all of its lease contracts (excluding vehicle leases), reflecting the Group’s own borrowing rate. This rate corresponds to the sum of the risk-free rate and the Group’s credit spread over the initial term of the syndicated loan (i.e., without considering the term). The value of the vehicle fleet in France is estimated based on the interest rate implicit in the leases, as supplied by Arval, i.e., 2.56%. With regard to the other main assumptions and practical expedients: #####  ###### The practical expedient exempting low-value or short-term leases has not been adopted by the Group.  Leases previously classified as finance leases under IAS 17 were classified as finance leases at 1 January 2019. To simplify, the residual useful life of these leases is calculated in the same way as under IAS 17.  Restoration costs: - Property leases: restoration costs are only calculated for major new leases, since it is difficult to reliably estimate such costs for all of the Group’s leases, as they are frequently negotiated with the lessor at the end of the lease. - Vehicle fleet: In France, the Group adopted an average cost of €700 per vehicle (cost plus 20% for private vehicles on which VAT cannot be recovered) in measuring the right-of-use asset corresponding to the residual value guarantee. This average cost was calculated based on a market estimate and taking into account the historical cost actually incurred when changing the automotive fleet at the beginning of 2019.  Deferred tax is recognised on the difference between the right-of-use asset and the lease liability falling within the scope of IFRS 16, in a similar way to that previously recognised for finance leases.  Services provided in relation to the lease are included in the calculation of right-of-use assets and lease liabilities on a case-by-case basis and by category of underlying asset. In particular, for the lease contract with BNP Paribas concerning Apple IT equipment, the Group has chosen not to separate the lease components from the service components, and therefore to consider all payments as relating to the lease. Right-of-use assets and lease liabilities must be calculated for both leases of equipment and for any services component. It should be noted that the Group was not concerned by any lease concessions in the period. ----- ###### Non-current financial assets Change in Change in fair Other **Of which

###### Output and therefore input VAT (see Note 4.15) increased sharply in 2020, owing to the fact that certain internal transactions were not settled in the year. These positions will be reset in 2021 once the corresponding intra-group invoices have been paid. The €5.4 million decrease in CICE tax receivables is mainly attributable to the 2016 CICE tax receivable owed to Foncia Holding which was collected in 2020 in an amount of €5.8 million. Current accounts receivable at 31 December 2020 relate mainly to financing allocated by the Group to companies in the process of being acquired and therefore not consolidated (of which €12.6 million in current account advances granted to Loft One in connection with repayments of its bank debt). Other miscellaneous receivables include outstanding purchase consideration for €0.8 million along with the indemnity receivable from Primonial, for which the Group has accrued a provision amounting to €2 million (see Note 2.4 “Highlights of the year”). This item also includes receivables relating to the Assurance Privilège product for €1.8 million, and advances linked to client accounting (jointly owned properties and managed properties) for €0.8 million. ###### Capitalization of non-deducted financial expenses Deferred tax assets were recognised in the period in respect of carry-forwards of interest from the tax consolidation group within the scope of the EU Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (ATAD I), of which €3.9 million in respect of financial expenses not deducted in 2020 and €3.9 million in respect of financial expenses not deducted in 2019. These deferred taxes were recognised against the taxable temporary difference relating to the Foncia trademark for €354.7 million. Tax loss carry-forwards Tax loss carry-forwards within the tax consolidation group at 31 December 2020 are as follows (after utilisation in the current period): • Loss arising on tax consolidation: €12.9 million. This tax loss has been recognised in full in view of the high probability that sufficient future taxable profit will exist against which it can be utilised. • Proprietary tax losses of consolidated companies (arising prior to joining the tax consolidation group): €29.2 million, of which €28.9 million not recognised due to the improbability that sufficient future taxable earnings will be available against which the losses could be utilised (of which Foncia Holding for €8.9 million, IDHA for €4.8 million, Syndic+ for €2.8 million and Bourgeois Immobilier for €2.7 million). At 31 December 2020, deferred tax assets recognised in respect of tax loss carry-forwards chiefly concern tax consolidation arrangements (€3.3 million), proprietary tax losses of companies in the tax consolidation group (€0.1 million), Efficity (€0.9 million) and Yxime (€1.1 million). Deferred tax on temporary differences Deferred taxes on temporary differences mainly arise on provisions for employee profit-sharing and paid leave, acquisition-related fees, and the tax treatment of translation adjustments. Deferred tax on other adjustments Changes in deferred taxes on other adjustments are mainly attributable to changes in the scope of consolidation (€8.1 million) and reflect the cancellation of existing business goodwill in the individual statement of financial position of companies consolidated for the first time during the period. 1,767,762 621,444 ( 521,615) ( 43,213) 41,519 109,476 ( 27) 2,550 ( 1,791) 6,376 1,078|1,983,558| ----- ###### Bank borrowings The Group carried out several operations on its revolving credit facility (RCF) in 2020: • On 19 and 24 March 2020, the Group drew a total of €190 million on its facility (to secure the Group’s cash resources in the context of the Covid crisis). • In June 2020, it repaid the €190 million drawn, which was partially refinanced by two additional drawdowns: €60 million on 19 June 2020 and €30 million on 24 June 2020. These two drawdowns totalling €90 million were also repaid in September 2020. • Three additional drawdowns, amounting to €60 million (21 September 2020), €60 million (21 October 2020) and €100 million (23 November 2020) were made and later repaid, on 21 October, 23 November and 23 December 2020, respectively. • In all at 31 December 2020, the Group had utilised a total of €120 million of the revolving credit facility, including €20 million drawn on 18 December 2020 and €100 million on 23 December 2020. These two drawdowns will be repaid in January 2021. It should also be noted that the full 2018 CICE prefinancing credit was refunded in 2020 in an amount of €8.2 million. Changes in the scope of consolidation representing €8 million chiefly result from borrowings and debt taken on from Gérance de Passy (€3.3 million) and Foncia IAG (€1.5 million). Debt relating to Bourgeois Immobilier was repaid in the period in an amount of €1.1 million. To mitigate the economic and financial consequences of the Covid-19 crisis, Efficity contracted a government-backed one-year cash loan for €1.4 million. This loan was repaid ahead of maturity in December 2020. Liabilities relating to put options on non-controlling interests As described in the “Highlights of the year” section, on 25 February 2020 the Group exercised its call option on the Trévi group, acquiring 8% of the shares it did not already own in the group for a total purchase consideration of €2.7 million. The full amount of the liability relating to the put option granted to non-controlling interests was therefore reversed. Shareholder loan Interest on the shareholder loan is capitalised at a rate of 11.7%. The Group repaid €16 million of its shareholder loan on 13 November 2020. Update on the financial liabilities recognised in respect of the preferred shares issued within the scope of the Leemo/Primonial transaction: As described in the “Highlights of the year” section, the €7 million financial liability was reset to zero against income amounting to €7 million recorded in non-recurring operating items (see Note 2.4). 4.11.2. Subsection Title: Total provisions for retirement benefits and other 28,572** **5,681** **135** **( 2,928)** **927** **144** **557** **452** **33,541 employee benefits

Subsubsection Text: ###### The actuarial estimate of provisions for retirement benefits and long-service awards was based on the report drawn up by Mercer and Eactuary, the firms mandated to estimate post-employment benefit obligations for the entire Group. A provision is set aside for all outstanding obligations, estimated based on rights accrued and salary projections, taking into account mortality rates, employee turnover and a discount. For France, the increase in provisions for retirement benefits is mainly attributable to the service cost totalling €1.4 million, reflecting the increase in the net obligation resulting from the contributions of Foncia personnel in 2020. These actuarial gains are recognised in other comprehensive income within consolidated equity net of tax. The increase in obligations in respect of long-service awards can be chiefly explained by the service cost in 2020 (€0.7 million) and by the measurement of employee benefit obligations taken on as a result of the acquisitions of Yxime and Gérance de Passy (€0.2 million). The take-up rate for long-service awards was maintained at 100%. Obligations in respect of long-service awards are included within other long-term benefits in accordance with IAS 19. Any related actuarial gains and losses are taken to profit or loss in the period. In Switzerland, the increase in the net benefit obligation in the period is essentially due to the service cost of CHF 4.5 million (€4.2 million) as well as net actuarial losses amounting to CHF 0.4 million (€0.3 million). ###### Provisions for other disputes In France, this caption relates mainly to the provision for disputes with franchisees amounting to €0.5 million, and to the provision for the Corum dispute amounting to €0.6 million. Outside France, this caption chiefly concerns Switzerland (€1.8 million), where the miscellaneous long-standing risks are monitored by the local management team. ▪ Update on the dispute with franchisees By way of a reminder, in 2014 franchisees had brought proceedings against the Foncia Group after receiving notice that their contracts would not be renewed. They accused the Group of wrongful termination and various breaches of the franchise agreements. Of the 21 initial lawsuits, the Group either settled (most sensitive disputes), or won (before the lower court or on appeal) the cases. Only seven lawsuits are still in progress following the appeal to the French Supreme Court (Cour de cassation). In January 2020, an initial decision was handed down in favour of Foncia Franchise by the court of appeal to which the case was referred after the Supreme Court appeal, in which that court dismissed all of the franchisee’s claims (including those that had been successful in the first instance). However, the franchisee has re-filed an appeal to the French Supreme Court. Hearings are pending before the referral court of appeal for the six other lawsuits (hearings scheduled for between January and April 2021 unless postponed due to Covid-19). Six decisions are pending from the court of appeal, and one from the French Supreme Court. ▪ Update on the Corum dispute After having terminated its distribution agreement with Primaliance, Corum, a property manager, brought proceedings against Primaliance for trademark infringement for continuing to list the real estate investment trust (SCPI) Corum Origin on its website, www.primaliance.com. The dispute is in progress before the courts. The Group maintained its €0.8 million provision in this respect and did not transfer it to Primaliance when the latter was sold to Bienprévoir.fr. Following some procedural issues in 2019 and 2020, the case is still ongoing and a date for the oral arguments is pending. _ Initial date of claim._ ###### This caption mainly comprises a contingency provision recognised in relation to a tax dispute concerning VAT arising in connection with the acquisition of Esset Management in 2016 for a total amount of €0.3 million at 31 December 2020. This provision was adjusted in the year and an amount of €0.3 million was written back and recorded within non-recurring items. Provisions for rent payment guarantees The technical increase in these provisions in the period chiefly results from the extension of the “winter truce” (tenant protection period during winter months applicable in France) to July 2020, which automatically increased the average age of past-due amounts owed by current tenants and made it impossible for the Group to bring proceedings against those tenants. New bad debts arising in the period remained broadly stable. It should be recalled that the amount of the provision set aside by the Group increases in line with the age of the unpaid receivable. Provisions for rent payment guarantees are calculated by reference to late payments relating to current and former lessees, regardless of whether or not lessee statement of accounts (Arrêtés des Comptes Locataires – ACL) have been drawn up, taking into account the probability of collection (assessed on a statistical basis and regularly updated). Provisions for employee disputes In France, the provision remained stable in 2020 at €3.6 million, and concerned 101 lawsuits at end-December 2020 compared to 98 lawsuits at 31 December 2019. Out of the 101 lawsuits, 100 are in progress and 25 relate to amounts in excess of €0.1 million. ###### Earn-out liabilities An earn-out clause was set up in first-half 2018 with the founders and key managers of Efficity. The additional consideration payable is calculated based on the value creation generated by the business (EBITDA multiple). VAT Input and therefore output VAT (see Note 4.7) increased sharply in 2020, owing to the fact that certain internal transactions were not settled in the year. These positions will be reset in 2021 once the corresponding intra-group invoices have been paid. Outstanding purchase consideration payable At 31 December 2020, outstanding purchase consideration payable chiefly concerns Esset Management for €12 million (Yxime), Foncia Haut de France for €4.1 million (Sigla) and Foncia Toulouse for €2.9 million (Loft One). Deferred income This caption mainly concerns Assurimo for €16.5 million. In this insurance brokerage business, client premiums are mainly billed at the end of the year and relate to the following year, which is when they are paid. By way of reminder, revenue is recognised on a straight-line basis in accordance with IFRS 15, which explains the significant amount recorded in this caption. ###### Accounting for client accounts is a separate and autonomous form of accounting. At 31 December 2019, the balance of client accounts and “Article 55” transaction accounts therefore represents all of the transactions carried out for each client account. This balance totalled €554 million, reported under assets and liabilities in the statement of financial position at 31 December 2020. France’s ALUR law requires the use of separate accounts (opened in the name of the joint owners) for jointly owned properties comprising more than 15 main lots as from 1 April 2015. Accordingly, these separate accounts are not reflected in the statement of financial position. The ordinance dated 31 October 2019 now requires separate accounts to be established for all jointly owned properties by 31 December 2020 at the latest. All accounts have been opened, including some just before the end of the year. Consequently, the transfers to certain accounts have not yet been made. Note that the statement of financial position does not include any amount for Germany or Belgium, which only use separate accounts. Derivative instruments Derivative instruments** Change in fair

###### In 2020, the Property management business in France represents almost 60% of the Group’s total revenue. Revenue for the business was up €8.5 million (1.5%) in the period and reflects the following conflicting impacts: (i) the impact of acquisitions carried out in the year; (ii) the negative impact of the health crisis on the rental management business (essentially affecting amounts collected under commercial leases and incidental fees) as a direct result of the lockdown measures introduced in the second and fourth quarters of 2020), and on incidental fees earned on jointly owned properties (fees on transfer duties, reminders, renovation work and vacancies). Revenue for the Transactions business fell by €4.3 million, due mainly to the impact of the consecutive lockdowns introduced in view of the health crisis, with business volumes slowing sharply in April and May (first lockdown) and then again in November (branches closed) compared to the same period in 2019. business providers for support services, market research fees and accounting, legal and consulting assistance fees. Restructuring costs in France mainly concern the Métropole project, relating mostly to:  personnel costs including costs incurred in preparing negotiated termination agreements and costs related to new hires for certain specific projects;  IT and consulting costs incurred in respect of the Métropole project;  indemnities for early termination of certain leases along with removal costs. These lease modifications only concern automatically renewable commercial leases in France, and increase interest expenses on lease liabilities in 2019 by an amount of €294,000. ###### Debt issuance costs represent €34.6 million at 31 December 2020, and are recognised over the term of the debt by adjusting the effective interest rate. The effective interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts estimated future cash payments through the expected life of the financial liability to the financial liability’s carrying amount. Additional drawdowns of senior facility tranches B5 in May 2019 (€178 million) and B6 in July 2019 (€110 million) explain the €5.7 million increase in interest on senior facility B. Similarly, the €4.5 million decrease in interest expenses on the ICA second-lien loan is attributable to the Group having made the final repayment on this facility in July 2019. The new group opted for a tax loss carry-forward system along the lines of the former tax consolidation group, but with a broader scope. The income tax expense for 2020 is significantly lower than in 2019, at €0.3 million, due to the decline in the Group’s profits amid the wider economic downturn caused by Covid-19. ###### It should be recalled that since non-deducted financial expenses within the scope of ATAD I may be carried forward indefinitely, they were capitalised in the year (see Note 4.8 on deferred taxes). Only non-deducted financial expenses falling within the scope of the new Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (ATAD II) are classified as permanent differences. These new tax rules are applicable for reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2020 (transposition of ATAD II into French law) and concern “hybrid”-type arrangements that generate mismatches in tax treatments between two jurisdictions. As the shareholder loan between Flamingo Lux and Foncia Management falls within the scope of this Directive, 26.25% of interest expenses paid by Foncia Management were added back to profit for tax purposes during the year, i.e., €16.2 million in respect of 2020. |Breakdown of income tax expense 2020 2019 (€ thousands) Net income of consolidated companies ( 57,519) ( 25,682) Current tax expense excluding CVAE tax on value added ( 2,352) ( 7,374) CVAE tax on value added ( 10,397) ( 9,841) Deferred taxes 10,047 14,737 Profit before tax of consolidated companies ( 54,817) ( 23,204) Theoretical tax expense 25.83% 14,159 25.83% 5,994|Change (%)| |---|---| ||( 31,837) 124.0 % 5,022 (68.1 %) ( 556) 5.6 % ( 4,690) (31.8 %) ( 31,613) 136.2 %| ||8,166 136.2 %| |Impact of change in tax rate 242 15,769 Permanent differences ( 11,234) ( 7,797) Of which non-deducted financial expenses ( 4,186) ( 3,584) Of which earn-out provisions ( 4,361) ( 1,717) Of which gains (losses) on sales of securities ( 73) ( 1,393) Of which other permanent differences ( 2,614) ( 1,103) CVAE tax on value added ( 7,486) ( 7,086) Goodwill impairment ( 4,264) Tax loss carryforwards created but not recognised ( 821) ( 2,489) Tax loss carryforwards no longer recognised ( 1,482) Difference between Group and local tax rates 405 ( 463) Reclassification of provision for taxes ( 408) Additional contributions ( 79) ( 323) Utilisation of unrecognised tax loss carryforwards 786 395 Tax credits 537 85 Other 788 ( 407)|( 15,527) (98.5 %) ( 3,438) 44.1 % ( 602) 16.8 % ( 2,644) 154.0 % 1,320 (94.7 %) ( 1,511) 137.1 % ( 400) 5.6 % 4,264 (100.0 %) 1,668 (67.0 %) 1,482 (100.0 %) 868 (187.6 %) 408 (100.0 %) 244 (75.5 %) 391 99.0 % 452 529.6 % 1,196 (293.6 %)| |Income tax expense recognised ( 2,702) ( 2,476)|( 226) 9.1 %| ----- ###### Earnings (loss) per share The table below shows details of earnings and shares used to calculate earnings (loss) per share for all businesses:

NOTE 6. ASSETS CLASSIFIED AS HELD FOR SALE Foncia Primaliance was classified as held for sale in 2019. In accordance with IFRS 5, the Group had reclassified the company’s current and non-current assets and liabilities on separate lines of the statement of financial position at 31 December 2019. As presented in the “Highlights of the year” section, the Group finalised its sale of a 51% stake in Foncia Primaliance on 14 April 2020 for €2.3 million, along with the sale of its residual 49% stake on 22 July for €3.3 million. Foncia Primaliance was deconsolidated with effect from 1 January 2020. There were no operations held for sale at 31 December 2020. NOTE 7. RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS Transactions between Foncia Management and its subsidiaries are eliminated in consolidation and are not described in this note. Transactions between Foncia Management and Flamingo Lux II SCA in 2020 are detailed below. In the statement of profit and loss ▪ Interest expense on shareholder loans: €61,740,000 ▪ Services provided and recorded in non-recurring operating expenses: €2,000,000 In the statement of financial position ▪ Liabilities under shareholder loans: €566,032,000 ----- ###### NOTE 8. FINANCIAL RISK EXPOSURE Interest rate risk The Group’s interest rate risk exposure arises mainly on its borrowings. These borrowings are denominated solely in euros and are managed on a centralised basis. They are mainly indexed to 3-month Euribor. The risk management policy is set by management. Cash flow surpluses and working capital requirements for the Group’s companies are centralised under a cash pooling agreement and managed by the Group’s Treasury department. The Group’s Treasury department selects investment vehicles for cash surpluses – either for proprietary cash or client cash (excluding separate accounts) – within the framework set by the management policy, which prioritises liquidity and security. Interest received is indexed to 3-month Euribor or is at fixed rates (term accounts). At 31 December 2020, interest rate risks can be broken down by management outlook as follows, taking into account interest rate maturities applied to the asset/liability financing position:

Client accounts 554,011 - Term accounts (client funds) (161,078) + Net cash and cash equivalents 51,664 Client accounts 530,860 - Term accounts (client funds) (248,888) + Net cash and cash equivalents 84,764
- Credit line (1,872,732) + Interest rate cap 660,000 - CICE (8,852)

###### A sudden 1% increase in short-term interest rates applied to the net position of assets and liabilities affected by interest rate fluctuations at the end of the reporting period would result in a rise of €7,770,000 in financial expenses. In 2020, the Group still has hedges in place for its credit facilities with an underlying valued at €660 million following the cap set up to fix the maximum 3-month Euribor rate at 1%. Foreign exchange risk The Group is exposed to two types of foreign exchange risk: - A foreign exchange risk on assets resulting from the Foncia Group’s shareholdings in its Swiss subsidiaries: ###### although this risk is measured, it is not subject to specific risk management as the investments are intended to be held over the long term. At 31 December 2020, the Group’s foreign currency positions were as follows:

This risk arises solely on the business of Swiss subsidiaries and concerns the Swiss franc. Since the vast majority of local transactions are carried out in Swiss francs, this risk is not material. It should be noted that Foncia signed an amendment to the agreement for the loan granted by Foncia Groupe to its subsidiary Foncia Switzerland on 29 June 2018, eliminating all repayment clauses. Given that no repayments have been made and that no repayment plan has been set for the foreseeable future, this loan is now considered as a monetary item and as part of the net investment in Foncia Switzerland as quasi-equity, in accordance with IAS 21 – The Effects of Changes in Foreign Exchange Rates. Since this date, foreign exchange gains and losses arising on the loan have been included in other comprehensive income (equity) under foreign currency translation reserves. NOTE 9. ###### Under the provisions of the Hoguet law, property management companies must provide financial guarantees for funds held in client accounts. In accordance with this law, Foncia provides financial guarantees to clients equal to the maximum amount of funds held on their account. These guarantees are presented under commitments given. Commitments under property leases relate to the firm commitment undertaken by Foncia with respect to its premises. Commitments given on the acquisition of equity investments correspond to the amounts due to the sellers of the companies or business goodwill acquired, the ownership of which had not yet been transferred to the Group at the reporting date. Pledges of collateral correspond to commitments given in connection with the financing set up with the banking pool. In the context of the Foncia Holding group acquisition, the new financing set up and the renegotiated debt, the Group pledged securities to Natixis in its capacity as senior agent and senior collateral agent and to the lenders (BNP Paribas, Crédit Agricole Corporate & Investment Bank, ING Bank N.V., Unicredit Bank AG, London Branch and Natixis) as follows: - pledge of Foncia Holding shares held by Foncia Management; - pledge of Foncia Groupe shares held by Foncia Holding; ----- - pledge of shares in certain Foncia Groupe subsidiaries: ###### - Assurimo, - Constatimmo, - SEIITRA RESEAU, - Foncia Aquitaine, - Foncia Nord Pas de Calais, - Foncia Lyon, - Foncia Bouteille, - Foncia Chabaneau, - Foncia MPI, - Foncia Paris, - Foncia Saint Antoine, - Foncia Sogi Pelletier, - Foncia Turckheim, - Foncia Voltaire, - Foncia Toulouse, - Foncia Alsace - Foncia AD Immobilier, - Foncia Paris Rive Gauche, - Foncia Rouault, - Foncia Bolling le Batiment, - Foncia Vallée du Rhône - Foncia Michel, - Foncia Lille, - Foncia Normandie - Foncia Transaction France - Foncia Paris Rive Droite - Foncia Bordeaux - Foncia Lemanique - Foncia Montpellier - Foncia Marseille - Foncia Carrières et Compétences - Efficity - Foncia André - Foncia Suisse - Assurimo Paris shares held by Assurimo, As part of these same transactions, the following pledges were also made by the Group: - pledge of Foncia Management, Foncia Holding and Foncia Groupe bank accounts; ###### Financial guarantees received from guarantors (guarantee funds, insurance companies and banks) are shown under commitments received. NOTE 10. LITIGATION AND CONTINGENT LIABILITIES Update on the UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) dispute On 1 October 2014, UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) brought proceedings against Foncia Groupe before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance (regional court) seeking damages for losses allegedly suffered by lessees of Foncia-managed properties who were unduly charged for receiving notices to pay (avis d’échéance). More specifically, UFC is seeking payment from Foncia Groupe of an amount of €2.30 per month and per lessee over a period of five years and estimates the number of lessees concerned at 318,400, bringing the total damages to €44 million. In its defence, the Group argues that the French law of 6 July 1989 on residential lease agreements, upon which basis UFC filed its claim, made no provision for class actions at the time of the alleged offence; that no law existed preventing lessees being charged for receiving notices to pay; and that this was therefore a lawful practice. Oral arguments were exchanged before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance in March 2018. The decision handed down in May 2018 dismissed UFC’s claims on the grounds that they fell outside the scope of a class action. UFC has appealed the decision and the hearings before the court of appeal have been postponed to 11 March 2021. The Group considers that no provision needs to be accrued in this respect in its financial statements at 31 December 2020. NOTE 11. SUBSEQUENT EVENTS None. NOTE 12. In compliance with the engagement entrusted to us pursuant to your articles of association, we have audited the accompanying consolidated financial statements of Foncia Management for the year ended 31 December 2019. These financial statements were approved by the Board of Directors on 23 April 2020 on the basis of the information available at that date in the changing context of the Covid-19 health crisis. In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view of the assets and liabilities and of the financial position of the Group at 31 December 2019 and of the results of its operations for the year then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union. In compliance with the engagement entrusted to us pursuant to your articles of association, we have audited the accompanying consolidated financial statements of Foncia Management for the year ended 31 December 2018. In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view of the assets and liabilities and of the financial position of the Group at 31 December 2018 and of the results of its operations for the year then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union.

Subsection Title: Total acquisitions of intangible assets in the statement of** **45,407 cash flows
Subsubsection Text: ###### Trademarks At the date on which Foncia Management acquired a controlling interest in Foncia Holding (September 2016), the Foncia Group and Domicim trademarks were recognised at an amount of €414.2 million based on their valuations. The Group also estimated the value of the Brolliet trademark at CHF €13.7 million (i.e., €12.5 million at 31 December 2019). Changes in the scope of consolidation reflect the derecognition of the Foncia Pierre Gestion trademark, which had been valued at €6 million during the purchase price accounting for Foncia Management. Concessions, patents and software Concessions, patents and software include the systems measured in connection with the purchase price accounting for Foncia Management at €10.4 million, as well as the management software used by Lodgis representing €1.7 million. The Syndic+ software had been written down in full at end-June 2019 in an amount of €4.3 million (impairment recognised within non-recurring expenses). Investments in the period amounting to €2 million mainly concern the Swiss entities for €1.2 million (DBS Immobilier and Gribi). Other changes amounting to €32.7 million chiefly concern (i) the capitalisation of intangible assets in progress, including €17.6 million for the Seiitra network in respect of upgraded Thetrawin (Powimo project) and regulatory (Thetrawin Legacy) modules, and (ii) Foncia Groupe for €5.6 million in respect of miscellaneous ongoing IT projects. Business goodwill/client relationships At the time of Foncia Management’s purchase price accounting, the fair value of the Foncia Group’s client relationships was estimated at €460.8 million, breaking down between the Group’s three CGUs as follows: (i) Property Management France (excluding the transactions business): €396.2 million, (ii) Property Management International (Germany, Switzerland, Belgium): €2.2 million, and (iii) Services: €62.5 million. Following the acquisition of a controlling interest in the Brolliet group in September 2016, client relationships were valued at CHF 7.5 million (€6.9 million at 31 December 2019). Changes in the scope of consolidation representing €5.8 million reflect the derecognition of Foncia Pierre Gestion client relationships. Similarly, the Foncia Primaliance client relationship was reclassified within assets held for sale in an amount of €3 million. Investments totalling €1.3 million primarily relate to acquisitions of business goodwill within the scope of external growth transactions carried out in the period. |Amortisation/ Intangible assets
