The €5 million increase in this item during the period reflects the capitalisation of the costs of acquiring new mandates, rebilled to other firms in the network. Decreases totalling €1.5 million relate to the retirement of these costs for lots that were not secured in the period. Intangible assets in progress Intangible assets in progress include various Group projects that can be capitalised. At 31 December 2019, the main contributors to this item are Foncia Groupe for €22.5 million in relation to IT projects, Foncia Stark for €17 million in relation to the development of the Millenium software, and Seiitra for €2 million in relation to the Powimo project. Advances and downpayments  The net €0.7 million increase in advances and downpayments reflects external growth investments in business goodwill. ###### Most leases relate to Group business premises. These contracts are managed using a dynamic approach directly in line with the operating performance of the Group’s branch network and its real estate strategy. In France, around 808 property leases were included in this caption, of which more than 44% are automatically renewable. At 1 January 2019, the most important such leases relate to the head office at Antony, Esset Management’s premises at Aubervilliers, and the Boulevard Haussmann and Boulevard de Courcelles premises in Paris. Changes in the period can be explained as follows:  Changes in the scope of consolidation concern property leases taken on from the various companies acquired in the period, notably Sigla (€3.8 million), Bourgeois Immobilier (€1.9 million) and OTIM (€1.3 million).  Reductions in the lease term mainly relate to the derecognition of Esset Management’s Aubervilliers lease for €8.7 million (the company moved its premises to Courbevoie at the end of the year) and to the early derecognition of the Foncia Paris Rive Droite lease at 6-8 boulevard Haussmann in Paris for €4 million.  New leases for €32.9 million concern a total of 53 new contracts. However, the six main leases account for almost 64% of right-of-use assets. These include the lease of the Rue Raymond Losserand premises in Paris for €7.5 million and the lease of Esset Management’s new premises in Courbevoie for €6.7 million. For the vehicle fleet in France, the first-time application of IFRS 16 resulted in the reclassification of CIC lease contracts measured at €2.6 million under IAS 17 and the measurement of 188 Arval contracts for €1.7 million at 1 January 2019. New leases concern 860 new vehicles delivered by Arval in 2019, which had a €5 million impact on lease liabilities and right-of-use assets. loans discounted over a 20-year period totalling €7.5 million, and advances paid to owners in connection with pre-letting renovation work on their properties for €2.3 million. Changes in the period result primarily from the decrease in the discount rate from 1.57% in 2018 to 0.70% in 2019. Changes in available-for-sale securities Consolidated investments classified as available-for-sale securities mainly comprise shares in property management companies that will be included in the scope of consolidation. These recent acquisitions were made at fair value. There were no changes in fair value up to the end of the reporting period.

###### Receivables owed by the State chiefly concern CICE tax receivables for €25.3 million and VAT receivables in France for €45.8 million. Shareholder accounts receivable at 31 December 2019 relate mainly to financing granted by the Group to companies in the process of being acquired and therefore not consolidated. As from the date of first-time application of IFRS 16, prepaid expenses recorded in respect of leases have been eliminated in the statement of financial position since they are included as part of the carrying amount of right-of-use assets. At 31 December 2019, residual prepaid expenses mainly concern insurance costs (primarily the third party and professional liability premium), IT repair and maintenance costs and management fees paid to guarantee funds. ###### Deferred tax liabilities mainly arise from the recognition of intangible assets within the scope of the purchase price accounting for Foncia Management in September 2016. Changes in the year primarily reflect the 28.92% income tax rate used to determine deferred taxes under the liability method (compared to a rate of 25.83% previously). Changes in the scope of consolidation representing €2.9 million reflect the derecognition of deferred tax liabilities on the Foncia Pierre Gestion trademark and client relationships. Other non-monetary changes representing a negative amount of €3.3 million concern: (i) deferred tax liabilities recognised by Lodgis for €1 million following the finalisation of the purchase price accounting process and the recognition of a trademark and software for a total of €4 million; (ii) the reclassification of tax representing a negative amount of €1.6 million, recorded against deferred taxes on other adjustments. Changes in deferred taxes on other adjustments attributable to changes in the scope of consolidation for €6.9 million reflect the cancellation of existing business goodwill in the individual statement of financial position of companies consolidated for the first time during the period. Deferred taxes on temporary differences mainly arise on acquisition-related fees, provisions for employee profit-sharing and paid leave, and the tax treatment of translation adjustments. |Change in (18,969) (39) 119,089 6,113 (16,536) 6,537 25,780 (12)|1,754,425| ----- ###### As described in the “Highlights of the year” section, the Group carried out various transactions in the year involving its syndicated credit facility:  On 3 May 2019, it arranged a new senior facility B tranche for €178 million, intended to refinance the full amount drawn under the revolving credit facility, the authorised overdraft as well as the debt restructuring fees.  On 31 July 2019, it arranged an additional new senior facility B tranche for €110 million in order to refinance the full amount of the second-lien loan. The applicable terms and conditions for these new tranches are closely aligned with those of the term loan B. The characteristics of the Group’s main financing facilities are set out below in Note 4.12.3. The fees for these two operations represented €3.1 million and €0.8 million, respectively, and will be recognised over the residual term of the debt by adjusting financial expenses using the effective interest rate method.  The Group also extended the amount available for drawdown under its revolving credit facility by €70 million, bringing the total amount of the facility (including the authorised overdraft) to €220 million. The fees for this operation represented €650,000. At 31 December 2019, the revolving credit facility had been repaid in full. It should also be noted that the 2015 CICE prefinancing credit was refunded in 2019 in an amount of €7.8 million. Following the Group’s 22 May 2019 acquisition of the 55% stake in the Initiative et Partenaire sub-group that it did not already own, the €3.2 million liability representing the minority put was reversed against consolidated equity. Similarly, the earn-out on FIPM shares was cleared in February 2019 for €3 million. Update on the financial liabilities recognised in respect of the preferred shares issued within the scope of the Leemo/Primonial transaction By way of reminder, at 31 December 2018 these preferred shares were classified within financial liabilities by default and included within net debt for €7 million, since the basis on which the shares issued within the scope of the aforementioned transaction could be converted did not represent a fixed basis. At the end of each reporting period, the Group is required to assess the convertibility of these preferred shares in 2021, which depends on changes in the respective contributions of the Foncia Group and Primonial to Leemo’s net revenue. An analysis of each group’s contribution could allow either (i) Primonial to increase its interest in Leemo to a maximum of 48,457 shares (49% of the share capital), or (ii) the Foncia Group to collect up to €2 million in cash compensation. Based on 2019 revenue, the situation favours the Foncia Group. However, a conservative approach was adopted when preparing the 2019 financial statements and no receivable was recognised. ----- ###### 4.12.2. Subsection Title: Total provisions for retirement benefits and other 20,675** **3,670** **362** **(2,595)** **3,278** **339** **2,843** **28,572 employee benefits

Subsubsection Text: ###### The actuarial estimate of provisions for retirement benefits and long-service awards was based on the report drawn up by Mercer, the firm mandated to estimate post-employment benefit obligations for the entire Group. A provision is set aside for all outstanding obligations, estimated based on rights accrued and salary projections, taking into account mortality rates, employee turnover and a discount assumption. For France, the increase in provisions for retirement benefits is mainly attributable to the service cost totalling €1.3 million, reflecting the increase in the net obligation resulting from the contributions of Foncia personnel in 2019. Net actuarial gains of €0.5 million reflect: (i) an increase of €0.8 million in the obligation attributable to new beneficiaries resulting from companies acquired in 2018; (ii) a decrease of €0.3 million related to the revised turnover table based on actual employee turnover rates in the 2013-2018 period. It should be specified that in accordance with IAS 19, this table only reflects natural attrition and therefore excludes lay-offs and terminations by mutual agreement (rupture conventionnelle). These actuarial gains are recognised in consolidated equity net of tax. The increase in long-service awards essentially results from actuarial gains of €1 million. These actuarial gains are attributable to various factors, including: (i) €0.7 million related to experience adjustments (owing mainly to new beneficiaries resulting from companies acquired in 2018); (ii) €0.4 million related to the revised turnover table, which takes into account forced departures. The take-up rate for long-service awards has been set at 100%, as in 2018. Obligations in respect of long-service awards are included within other long-term benefits in accordance with IAS 19. In this respect, any actuarial gains and losses are to be taken to profit or loss in the period. Since these actuarial gains and losses result from exceptional events, they were included in non-recurring operating items. |Interest cost net of Contributions Change in Employee benefits Actuarial gains Exchange 31 Dec. 2018 Service cost the return on plan paid in the scope of (€ thousands) and losses differences assets period consolidation|31 Dec. 2019| |---|---| |France 13,944 1,277 207 (229) 541 (60) Belgium 33 Switzerland 5,847 2,393 55 (2,366) 2,738 339 2,903 Germany 851 100|15,679 33 11,908 951| |Total provisions for retirement benefits and other 20,675 3,670 362 (2,595) 3,278 339 2,843 employee benefits|28,572| |France 4,968 460 144 (501) 1,035 (11)|6,102| |Total provisions for long-service awards 4,968 460 144 (501) 1,035 (11)|6,102| ||| |Total employee benefits 25,643 4,130 506 (3,096) 4,313 339 2,832|34,673| ----- ###### In Switzerland, the increase in provisions over the period chiefly reflects the measurement of net benefit obligations relating to the acquired companies Gribi and Guinnard, representing €2.8 million and €0.1 million, respectively (127 employees at Gribi and 7 at Guinnard), along with €2.8 million in net actuarial losses resulting from: (i) an increase of €5.9 million in benefit obligations owing to the change in the discount rate from 0.90% to 0.20%; (ii) a decrease of €4.8 million in benefit obligations owing to a better-than-expected return on plan assets; (iii) an experience loss of €1.8 million. Calculation assumptions used Actuarial calculations are based on a number of long-term assumptions that are reviewed on an annual basis.

###### Changes in provisions for risks on client accounts Based on a detailed analysis of Esset Management client accounts, the Group adjusted the provisions it had accrued at the time of the 2016 acquisition, resulting in a reversal of €3.4 million, of which €2.9 million was recognised in non-recurring operating items. |Additions Utilisations Reversals (surplus) Change in Provisions Translation Other 31 Dec. 2018 scope of (€ thousands) adjustments changes Current Non-current Current Non-current Current Non-current consolidation|31 Dec. 2019| |---|---| |Provisions for risks on client 8,112 365 1,403 (76) (530) (687) (3,608) 19 1,155 394 accounts Provisions for third party and 6,059 1,081 245 (267) (223) (1,268) (844) 25 (378) professional liability Provisions for URSSAF social 1,802 26 1 (148) (504) security audits Provisions for other disputes 5,731 360 216 (5) (51) (451) (2,835) 55 847 (44) Provisions for occupancy 1,270 128 86 (73) (8) (190) (79) 2 3 (1) guarantees Provisions for tax contingencies|6,547 4,430 1,177 3,822 1,138| |Non-current provisions 22,980 1,960 5,067 (620) (780) (2,545) (7,962) 76 2,030 31|20,236| |Provisions for rent payment 3,489 760 178 (1,068) (32) (465) (147) 5 1 (1) guarantees Provisions for employee disputes 4,150 365 600 (271) (24) (1,196) (276) 1 228 (31)|2,720 3,546| |Current provisions 7,639 1,125 778 (1,339) (56) (1,661) (423) 5 229 (32)|6,266| |Total provisions 30,619 3,085 5,845 (1,959) (836) (4,206) (8,385) 82 2,259 (1)|26,502| ----- ###### Changes in provisions for other disputes The significant decrease in provisions for other disputes follows the reversal of provisions for Orpi and franchisee disputes, with an impact of €1.6 million and €0.8 million, respectively, on non-recurring operating items.  Update on the dispute with franchisees As a reminder, in 2014-2015 former franchisees had brought proceedings against the Foncia Group after receiving notice that their contracts would not be renewed. They accused the Group of wrongful termination and various breaches of the franchise agreements. Of the 21 initial lawsuits representing an aggregate €19.3 million, disputes with only seven franchisees were still ongoing at the reporting date, representing €4.5 million. At 31 December 2019, the provision set aside in respect of these disputes was reduced to €0.5 million. In January 2020, an initial decision was handed down in favour of Foncia Franchise, in which the court dismissed all of the franchisee’s claims (including those that had been successful in first instance). The six other disputes will be heard by the same court between end-May and end-June 2020.  Update on the ORPI dispute A preliminary agreement was negotiated with ORPI providing for the payment of €0.5 million in compensation to settle the dispute between four Foncia entities and ORPI. The related provision was written back in full at 31 December 2019. Changes in provisions for employee disputes Provisions for employee disputes concerned 98 lawsuits compared to 108 lawsuits at 31 December 2018. Out of the 98 lawsuits, 27 are in progress and relate to amounts in excess of €100,000. In all, the claims represent approximately €13.3 million. The resolution of employee disputes in the period resulted in expenses of €0.8 million and a write-back of €1.6 million from the provision. Changes in provisions for URSSAF social security audits This caption includes provisions for URSSAF audits that had been measured in the opening statement of financial position after a risk was identified on benefits in kind for €0.9 million. Since a portion of the reassessment risk has exceeded the statute of limitations, the Group partially wrote back this provision, with the resulting €0.5 million reversal recorded in non-recurring operating items. ----- ###### Trade and other payables Change in Change in Trade and other payables** Translation Assets classified Other

9,240 16,721 1,305| |Total other current liabilities 163,893 (3,546) 20,883 2,743 1|182,924| ----- ###### Client accounts and “Article 55” transaction (Hoguet law) accounts Accounting for client accounts is a separate and autonomous form of accounting. At 31 December 2019, the balance of client accounts and “Article 55” transaction accounts therefore represents all of the transactions carried out for each client account. This balance totalled €530.9 million, reported under assets and liabilities in the statement of financial position at 31 December 2019. France’s ALUR law requires the use of separate accounts for jointly owned properties comprising more than 15 main lots as from 1 April 2015. Accordingly, Foncia decided not to present separate accounts for its joint ownership association management activities in its statement of financial position. The ordinance dated 31 October 2019 now requires separate accounts to be established for all jointly owned properties by 31 December 2020 at the latest. As a result, funds held in respect of jointly owned properties are expected to decrease sharply in 2020. The statement of financial position does not include any amount for Germany or Belgium, which only use separate accounts. Of which derivative instruments (positive fair value) **7** 5 (12) ###### In accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9, which set out the rules for measuring and recognising financial instruments, instruments with a positive fair value are recognised in assets and those with a negative fair value are recognised in liabilities. Fair values of financial instruments are provided by the financial institutions with which the transactions are carried out. 4.18.1. Interest rate derivatives Further to its refinancing on 7 September 2016, the Group entered into an interest rate cap agreement on 7 December 2016 under the terms and conditions set out below: • Notional amount: €527.9 million • Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor • Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1% • Hedging period: 7 December 2016 to 6 December 2019. This hedge was no longer in force at 31 December 2019. On 19 October 2017, the Group also entered into an additional deferred interest rate cap agreement under the following terms and conditions: • Notional amount: €400 million • Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor • Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1.5% • Hedging period: 7 December 2019 to 6 December 2020 The historic premiums paid in respect of these two cap agreements totalled €915,000. On 24 May 2019, the Group entered into an additional interest rate cap agreement under the following terms and conditions: • Notional amount: €70 million (7 June 2019 to 9 September 2019), then €200 million (9 September 2019 to 7 September 2020) • Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor • Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1.25% • Hedging period: 7 June 2019 to 7 September 2020 The premium paid in respect of this cap agreement in 2019 totalled €5,000. Given the prevailing negative interbank interest rate environment, these derivative instruments have a fair value of zero in the 2019 financial statements. |Derivative instruments Change in fair 31 Dec. 2018 Increases (€ thousands) value|31 Dec. 2019| |---|---| |Currency hedging instruments Interest rate hedging instruments 7 5 (12)|| |Net derivatives position 7 5 (12)|| |Of which derivative instruments (positive fair value) 7 5 (12)|| |Net derivatives position 7 5 (12)|| ----- ###### 4.18.2. (1) Comparative information has been restated to reflect the change in accounting presentation for Leemo revenue (see Note 2.7). Due to this change in accounting presentation, the Group now shows billed amounts net of the costs of fee retrocessions in order to present only those fees attributable to the Group. Statement of profit and loss figures for 2018 have been restated, leading to a negative impact of €14.9 million on revenue as presented. ###### In 2019, the property management business in France represents almost 60% of the Group’s total revenue. Revenue from this business chiefly comprises rental management fees (including rent payment and occupancy guarantees), jointly owned property management fees and letting fees. In all, 88% of the Group’s business is generated in France. The significant growth in revenue between 2018 and 2019 reflects: (i) the impact of acquisitions carried out in 2019 for an amount of €73.2 million; (ii) an increase of some €2.3 million in organic growth; (iii) a positive currency effect of €2.5 million related solely to Switzerland, with the average EUR/CHF exchange rate decreasing from 1.16 in 2018 to 1.11 in 2019. |Revenue 2019 2018 restated(1) (€ thousands)|Change| |---|---| |Property Management 564,771 529,137 Of which rental management and lettings 283,649 270,252 Of which joint property management 281,122 258,885 Transactions (French network) 129,302 118,036 Digital business 35,354 22,582 Of which Efficity 27,803 18,957 Of which Lodgis 6,089 1,519 Of which Leemo 1,462 2,106 Other activities 101,430 101,108 Of which B2B 28,018 28,836 Of which Assurimo 24,193 22,939 Of which Constatimmo 17 13,294 Of which Seiitra 12,097 11,576 Of which Foncia Pierre Gestion 11,067 11,492 Of which Investor platform 6,504 6,721 Of which Valorisation 2,537 2,784 Of which Foncia Croissance 2,439 2,510 Of which Prowen 547 539 Of which other 475 417 Client accounts 4,053 3,655|35,634 13,397 22,237 11,266 12,772 8,846 4,570 (644) 322 (818) 1,254 259 521 (425) (217) (247) (71) 8 58 398| |Total – France 834,910 774,518|60,392| |Property Management 82,127 65,605 Transactions 21,513 17,811 Other activities 4,996 7,605|16,522 3,702 (2,610)| |Total – International 108,636 91,021|17,615| |Of which Switzerland 67,222 56,760 Of which Belgium 16,675 14,605 Of which Germany 24,739 19,656|10,462 2,070 5,083| |Total revenue 943,546 865,539|78,007| ----- ###### Other operating income

###### It should be recalled that following the acquisition of Foncia Holding by Foncia Management on 7 September 2016, a new tax group was formed, effective as of 1 January 2017. The new group opted for a tax loss carry-forward system along the lines of the former tax consolidation group, but with a broader scope. The tax group reported consolidated tax income of €2 million for 2019, notably reflecting the add-back of €13.9 million in non-deductible financial expenses (tax base) and the utilisation of €7.3 million in tax losses carried forward by the tax consolidation group (tax base). |Other financial income and expenses 2019 2018 (€ thousands)|Change| |---|---| |Foreign exchange gains (losses) ( 0) 573 Net interest cost on pension and other employee benefit (506) (336) obligations Capital gains (losses) on financial disposals less costs to 355 (2) sell Net impairment of financial assets (269) 100 Gains (losses) on available-for-sale financial assets 287 961 Discounting cost, net 1,088 (469) Miscellaneous 32 45 Other (762) (1,790)|(573) (170) 357 (369) (675) 1,557 (13) 1,029| |Other financial income and expenses 193 (963)|1,156| |Income tax benefit (expense) 2019 2018 (€ thousands)|Change| |---|---| |Current tax expense excluding CVAE tax on value added (7,372) (2,222) Of which income tax expense relating to the tax consolidation group (1,958) Of which reclassification of provision for Esset Management tax (408) Of which income tax expense excluding the tax consolidation group (2,903) (899) Of which income tax expense relating to foreign companies (2,103) (1,323) CVAE tax on value added (9,841) (8,955) Deferred taxes 14,737 (3,820) Of which impact of change in French tax rate (liability method) 15,769 15,640 Of which other impacts (1,032) (19,459)|(6,036) (1,958) (408) (2,004) (780) (886) 18,557 129 18,428| |Income tax benefit (expense) (2,476) (14,997)|12,521| ----- ###### Current income tax expense excluding the tax consolidation group essentially concerns Foncia Pierre Gestion for €1.2 million and Foncia Brette for €0.5 million. Current income tax expense for foreign companies relates mainly to Switzerland for €1.1 million and Belgium for €0.9 million. A provision for tax contingencies was set aside by Esset Management on 18 December 2019 after the company received notification from the French tax authorities of a tax reassessment related mainly to unjustified expenses. This provision has been reclassified within current income tax expense in accordance with IAS 12. Deferred tax income recognised in the year mainly relates to the decrease in the deferred tax rate in France, from 28.92% in 2018 to 25.83% in 2019. Tax loss carry-forwards Tax loss carry-forwards within the tax consolidation group at 31 December 2019 are as follows (after utilisation in the current period): • Loss arising on tax consolidation: €16.6 million. This tax loss has been recognised in full in view of the high probability that sufficient future taxable profit will exist against which it can be utilised. • Proprietary tax losses of consolidated companies: €20.7 million, of which €20 million were not recognised, mainly relating to Foncia Holding (€8.9 million), IDHA (€4.8 million) and Syndic+ (€2.8 million). New deductibility rules for financial expenses in France New rules applicable to reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2019 redefine the applicable framework for deductible financial expenses in France. The new rules are designed to implement Article 4 of the EU Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (ATAD) into French law. Financial expenses were previously deductible at a single rate of 75% (“rabot” rule). This single rate has been replaced by a new approach introducing a cap to be calculated for each company or each tax consolidation group, as applicable. Although the tax group is thinly capitalised on the basis of debt-to-equity rules, its debt-to-equity ratio is lower than that of the consolidated group. Accordingly, it deducted financial expenses at the statutory rate of 30% of its taxable EBITDA. By demonstrating its “financial independence” and therefore its eligibility for the safeguard clause, the tax consolidation group was granted an additional right to deduction representing up to 75% of net non-deducted expenses. Impact of the decrease in the income tax rate on deferred tax liabilities In line with the phased reduction in income tax in France through to 2022 (2020 budget), the Group cut its deferred tax rate for French entities to 25.83% from 28.92% previously. In accordance with IAS 12, adjustments related to this change in the tax rate are accounted for in a symmetrical manner and mainly included in profit or loss (when they relate to items themselves recognised in profit or loss). Taking into account a target tax rate for deferred tax bases resulted in a reduction of €15.8 million in net deferred tax liabilities and led to a corresponding increase in profit under the liability method. This significant decrease is attributable to a change in management’s assessment of projected cuts in this tax rate, finally agreed in 2018 after various postponements that had cast doubt on its introduction, and to the long-term timeframe for disposing of intangible assets. ----- ###### 5.11.2. FINANCIAL RISK EXPOSURE Interest rate risk The Group’s interest rate risk exposure arises mainly on its borrowings. These borrowings are denominated solely in euros and are managed on a centralised basis. They are mainly indexed to 3-month Euribor. The risk management policy is set by management. Cash flow surpluses and working capital requirements for the Group’s companies are centralised under a cash pooling agreement and managed by the Group’s Treasury department. The Group’s Treasury department selects investment vehicles for cash surpluses – either for proprietary cash or client cash (excluding separate accounts) – within the framework set by the management policy, which prioritises liquidity and security. Interest received is indexed to 3-month Euribor or is at fixed rates (term accounts). At 31 December 2019, interest rate risks can be broken down by management outlook as follows, taking into account interest rate maturities applied to the asset/liability financing position:
- Credit line (1,706,997) + Interest rate cap 470,000 - CICE (8,852)

###### A sudden 1% increase in short-term interest rates applied to the net position of assets and liabilities affected by interest rate fluctuations at the end of the reporting period would result in a rise of €8,791,000 in financial expenses. In 2019, the Group still has hedges in place for its credit facilities with an underlying valued at €470 million. The two caps in place fix the maximum 3-month Euribor rate at 1.5% and 1.25%, respectively. ###### Under the provisions of the Hoguet law, property management companies must provide financial guarantees for funds held in client accounts. In accordance with this law, Foncia provides financial guarantees to clients equal to the maximum amount of funds held on their account. These guarantees are presented under commitments given. Commitments under property leases relate to the firm commitment undertaken by Foncia with respect to its premises. Commitments given on the acquisition of equity investments correspond to the amounts due to the sellers of the companies or business goodwill acquired, the ownership of which had not yet been transferred to the Group at the reporting date. Pledges of collateral correspond to commitments given in connection with the financing set up with the banking pool. In the context of the Foncia Holding group acquisition, the new financing set up and the renegotiated debt, the Group pledged securities to Natixis in its capacity as senior agent and senior collateral agent and to the lenders (BNP Paribas, Crédit Agricole Corporate & Investment Bank, ING Bank N.V., Unicredit Bank AG, London Branch and Natixis) as follows: ----- - pledge of Foncia Holding shares held by Foncia Management; - pledge of Foncia Groupe shares held by Foncia Holding; - pledge of shares in certain Foncia Groupe subsidiaries: ###### - Assurimo, - Constatimmo, - Foncia Pierre Gestion, - SEIITRA RESEAU, - Foncia Aquitaine, - Foncia Nord Pas de Calais, - Foncia Lyon, - Foncia Bouteille, - Foncia Chabaneau, - Foncia MPI, - Foncia Paris, - Foncia Saint Antoine, - Foncia Sogi Pelletier, - Foncia Turckheim, - Foncia Voltaire, - Foncia Toulouse, - Foncia Strasbourg, - Foncia AD Immobilier, - Foncia Paris Rive Gauche, - Foncia Lille, - Foncia Rouault, - Foncia Bolling le Batiment, - Foncia République, - Foncia Michel, - Iplus Diffusion, - Assurimo Paris shares held by Assurimo, - Primaliance shares held by Iplus Diffusion. LITIGATION AND CONTINGENT LIABILITIES Update on the UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) dispute On 1 October 2014, UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) brought proceedings against Foncia Groupe before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance (regional court) seeking damages for losses allegedly suffered by lessees of Foncia-managed properties who were unduly charged for receiving notices to pay (avis d’échéance). More specifically, UFC is seeking payment from Foncia Groupe of an amount of €2.30 per month and per lessee over a period of five years and estimates the number of lessees concerned at 318,400, bringing the total damages to €44 million. In its defence, the Group argues that the French law of 6 July 1989 on residential lease agreements, upon which basis UFC filed its claim, made no provision for class actions at the time of the alleged offence; that no law existed preventing lessees being charged for receiving notices to pay; and that this was therefore a lawful practice. Oral arguments were exchanged before the Nanterre Tribunal de Grande Instance in March 2018. The decision handed down in May 2018 dismissed UFC’s claims on the grounds that they fell outside the scope of a class action. UFC has appealed the decision and the hearings before the Court of Appeal are scheduled for 23 April 2020. The Group considers that no provision needs to be accrued in this respect in its financial statements at 31 December 2019. NOTE 11. SUBSEQUENT EVENTS Signing of a preliminary agreement to sell Foncia Primaliance shares Following the 1 August 2019 signing of an agreement in principle with a major asset manager in France, the Group signed the preliminary agreement for the sale of Foncia Primaliance shares on 6 March 2020. Covid-19 epidemic Context The unprecedented public health crisis caused by the Covid-19 epidemic that has spread across the globe is affecting economies and businesses around the world and having significant impacts on all industries and geographic areas. Governments have taken steps to address the crisis. The impacts of the epidemic include:  direct and immediate impacts on certain business activities owing to the fall in demand for certain services;  widespread impacts such as the temporary closure of premises, disruptions in the supply chain, the unavailability of human resources and the potential liquidity difficulties of certain debtors;  more generally, a downturn in the economy as a whole, with considerable uncertainty as to the length and severity of the disruption. ----- ###### Consequences of the impacts of the Covid-19 epidemic on the financial statements at 31 December 2019 Based on the situation at 31 December 2019 (i.e., limited cases of the virus and the lack of any global health warning by the World Health Organization (WHO) at that date), the Group considers that the consequences of the public health and economic crisis caused by Covid-19 relate to the 2020 financial period and do not confirm a situation existing prior to 31 December 2019, insofar as the events create a situation that did not exist at 31 December 2019 and which does not compromise the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern (the most important measures of the business continuity plan put in place by management are presented below). Accordingly, the amounts reported at 31 December 2019 may not be adjusted. Consequences of the impacts of the Covid-19 epidemic on the Group’s businesses in 2020 In accordance with the decisions taken by the government in order to comply with social distancing recommendations, all Foncia Group premises (branches and head offices) are closed to the public until further notice, as well as to employees (barring exceptional cases). Real estate agents can no longer travel to sign mandates, make visits or meet with notaries. The general lockdown measures imposed on the French population have effectively frozen the property market and the transactions business is virtually at a standstill. Physical visits of properties are forbidden during the lockdown period and those that had been scheduled were cancelled. The rental market is also affected by the crisis, as the removal industry along with the utility vehicle rental business are severely disrupted, effectively blocking the departure and arrival of lessees. The rental management market can continue to function normally from a purely administrative perspective. There is little movement in rental properties. However, there is a significant risk that fees on unpaid rent will be collected later than expected, even though rent must still be paid by law. The jointly owned property management business remains and will remain fairly sheltered from the crisis, although it may generate an increased workload from an administrative, legal and commercial perspective. The chain of continuity for services continues to function, despite delays regarding joint ownership property charges. However, the Group expects a fall in revenue from incidental fees such as for transfers or renovation work. It should be noted that several ordinances have been issued by the French government to protect and support companies operating in the real estate sector. One of these ordinances concerns the guaranteed continuity of mandates for jointly owned property associations, even if they expire in the period from 12 March to 31 December 2020. Without compromising the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern, direct impacts are expected and have already been observed in 2020 on revenue, margins and operating cash flows relating to the transactions and lettings businesses and, to a lesser extent, to the French and international jointly owned property business. Business continuity plan  Human resources and organisation The different procedures put in place to address this unprecedented environment are designed to protect the health of employees but also to ensure that a minimum and critical level of business can continue, subject to changes in government regulations: • Homeworking has been introduced for all employees whose work can be performed from home and who have the necessary tools available. • More specifically, in its property management and transactions network, an exceptional travel certificate has been granted to managers so that they can carry out minimum duties alongside senior executives. An exceptional, occasional travel certificate subject to restrictions has also been issued to critical employees dealing, for example, with incoming correspondence, cash inflows and payments, and handovers. • For employees facing increasingly difficult working conditions such as lettings negotiators, developers or real estate consultants, short-time working arrangements have been put in place. ----- ###### Each department is currently finalising its own organisational and communications guidelines for these exceptional circumstances using various procedures.  Financing Out of prudence, the Group made two drawdowns on its revolving credit facility on 16 and 19 March 2020 for a total of €190 million in order to secure its liquidity. Certain due dates for payments under major leases have been pushed back in order to protect cash levels, particularly in the transactions business.  External growth strategy Wherever possible, the Group has pushed back corporate sale agreements due to be signed during the lockdown period to 1 June 2020 at the earliest. Subsection Title: Total acquisitions of intangible assets in the statement of 42,387 cash flows
Subsubsection Text: ###### Trademarks At the date on which Foncia Management acquired a controlling interest in Foncia Holding (September 2016), the Foncia Group and Domicim trademarks were recognised at an amount of €414.2 million based on their valuations. The Group also estimated the value of the Brolliet trademark at CHF €13.7 million (i.e., €12.1 million at 31 December 2018). Concessions, patents and software Concessions, patents and software include the systems measured within the scope of Foncia Management’s purchase price accounting at €16.2 million. Investments in the period amounting to €2.7 million mainly concern Foncia Groupe for €1.6 million. Other changes amounting to €17 million chiefly concern the capitalisation of intangible assets in progress for €13.8 million, along with a €2.4 million adjustment to amortisation charged against software included in Foncia Management’s purchase price accounting. Business goodwill/client relationships At the time of Foncia Management’s purchase price accounting, the fair value of the Foncia Group’s client relationships was estimated at €460.8 million, breaking down between the Group’s three CGUs as follows: (i) Property Management France (excluding the Transactions business): €396.2 million, (ii) Property Management International (Germany, Switzerland, Belgium): €2.2 million, and (iii) Services: €62.5m. Following the acquisition of a controlling interest in the Brolliet group in September 2016, client relationships were valued at CHF 7.5 million (€6.6 million at 31 December 2018). Investments totalling €5.6 million primarily relate to acquisitions of business goodwill over the period. Changes in the scope of consolidation representing €7 million reflect Primonial’s contribution of its entire stand-alone division as part of the business combination with Leemo (see Note 2.3 of “Highlights of the period”). Other intangible assets Other intangible assets essentially comprise the cost of acquiring new business. Subsubsection Text: ###### Fixtures and fittings Fixtures and fittings mainly relate to investments made in the branch network. The €4.7 million increase in the year relates mainly to work on the Métropole project in Toulon (€0.4 million), new branch openings in Marseille (€0.3 million) and Montpellier (€0.3 million), the relocation of Assurimo to its new premises in Lyon (€0.2 million), and miscellaneous work carried out in the branches. Other changes concern the commissioning of fittings work for the Foncia Groupe staff canteen (€1.2 million). Machinery and equipment Changes in machinery and equipment result mainly from the replacement of IT equipment within Foncia Groupe for €4.1 million, and from depreciation charged against this equipment amounting to €2.2 million for the period. Subsubsection Text: ###### In early December 2018, a change in financial lessor on vehicle leases led to the early derecognition of 144 vehicles out of the 987 restated in France. This transfer will continue until the end of first-half 2019. Since these leases do not meet the IAS 17 measurement criteria (sum of future lease payments over three years less than 90% of the residual value of the leased assets at the end of the lease term), they are not carried within assets on the statement of financial position. 4.3.3. ###### Consolidated investments classified as available-for-sale securities mainly comprise shares in property management companies that will be included in the scope of consolidation. These recent acquisitions were made at fair value. There were no changes in fair value up to the end of the reporting period. Other long-term investments mainly include shares in the real estate investment trust Cap’ Hebergimmo, along with historic shareholdings in Swiss property companies and cooperatives. The Group sold some of its Swiss holdings during the period for a price of €1 million. Proceeds from the sale are shown in the consolidated statement of cash flows under proceeds from disposals of non-current assets. As these investments were carried at amortised cost in accordance with IAS 39, the €685,000 disposal gain was recognized in equity pursuant to the first-time application of IFRS 9. Deposits and guarantees paid reflect the net value of guarantee deposits on leases amounting to €5.2 million and deposits paid to guarantee funds (SOCAF, FNAIM, GALLIAN) for €1.6 million. Other long-term receivables mainly include housing loans discounted over a 20-year period totalling €5.3 million, along with advances paid to owners in connection with pre-letting renovation work on their properties for €3.2 million. December 2018, deferred tax assets recognised in respect of tax loss carryforwards chiefly concern tax consolidation arrangements (€6.9 million), tax losses reported by companies in the tax consolidation group (€1.9 million) and Efficity (€2.8 million). The impact of the first-time application of IFRS 15 is an adjustment to the equity of the companies concerned totalling €31.1 million. However, this impact was deducted for tax purposes through an off-book deduction of the same amount (the amount had already been subject to tax in 2017). In the consolidated financial statements, the tax saving resulting from the first-time application of IFRS 15 was allocated to total equity in accordance with the simplified retrospective approach. Changes in the scope of consolidation representing €4 million on other adjustments concern deferred taxes arising on the neutralisation of business goodwill existing before the companies concerned were consolidated. (1,274)|1,531,326| ----- ###### On 3 August 2018, the Group repaid ahead of term its ICA loan in an amount of €77 million (see Note 2.5 of “Highlights of the period”). This repayment was financed by subscribing to a new €80 million tranche (“B4”) of its senior facility. The issuance fees for the new tranche amount to €1.2 million and will be recognised over the term of the facility by an adjustment to financial expenses at the effective interest rate as calculated at 3 August 2018 (3.68%). The initial accounting treatment was discontinued, with all related unamortised expenses allocated to the ICA loan (€4 million) charged to profit or loss under “Cost of net debt” (see Note 5.9). Since 15 March 2018, the Group has continuously drawn on its revolving credit facility as part-financing for its external growth investments (acquisitions). The Group also draws on its €30 million authorised overdraft facility when necessary. Liabilities relating to the put option granted to Trévi non-controlling shareholders (on 8% of the shares) and to the non-controlling shareholders of the Initiatives group and partners (on 55% of the shares) were remeasured based on actual 2018 figures against equity. Following the acquisition of an additional 25% stake in Somhome in March 2018, the €0.6 million liability relating to the put option granted to non-controlling interests was reversed against total equity. 4.11.2. Subsubsection Text: ###### At 31 December 2018, the actuarial estimate of provisions for retirement benefits and long-service awards was based on the report drawn up by Mercer, the firm mandated to estimate the post-employment benefit obligations for the entire Group. The decrease in provisions for retirement benefits and long-service awards in France is a result of the new IPM wage agreements that came into force. The decrease in the Group’s benefit obligation in Switzerland during the period mainly corresponds to the €2.5 million in past service costs (around 27% of the net benefit obligation at 1 January 2018), following the pooling of employees’ supplemental health, life and disability insurance plans into a single fund as opposed to many different collective funds as was previously the case. |Interest cost net of Contributions Change in Employee benefits Actuarial gains Exchange 31 Dec. 2017 Service cost the return on plan paid in the Past service cost scope of (€ thousands) and losses differences assets period consolidation France 15,038 1,195 203 (939) (1,365) (188) Belgium 33 Switzerland 9,112 2,762 51 (2,014) (2,530) (1,732) 198 Germany 880 11 (40)|31 Dec. 2018| |---|---| ||13,944 33 5,847 851| |Total provisions for retirement benefits and other 25,063 3,957 265 (2,953) (3,895) (1,960) 198 employee benefits|20,675| |France 5,651 439 69 (538) (679) 23 5|4,968| |Total provisions for long-service awards 5,651 439 69 (538) (679) 23 5|4,968| |Total employee benefits 30,714 4,396 334 (3,491) (4,574) (1,937) 198 5|25,643| ----- ###### The amount shown for the past service cost also follows a subsequent decision taken by the Board of the fund to reduce the pension conversion rate in order to ensure its long-term viability. This decision automatically reduces the long-term obligation, since pensions gradually decrease for the same level of paid-in contributions. The net decrease in obligations recognised in other comprehensive income in an amount of €1.7 million primarily results from the significant fall in headcount since 1 January 2018 (departure of 71 employees), and from the increase in the discount rate used from 0.7% to 0.9% (see below). ###### The provision for risks on client accounts is designed to cover the non-collection risk on lost client accounts in debit, as well as other risks on client accounts. The provision covers 80% of these client accounts. Following a detailed analysis of IPM client accounts, a net provision of €0.7 million was booked at 31 December 2018. IPM provisions accounted for almost half of provisions for risks on client accounts. Provisions for other disputes concerned 71 disputes at 31 December 2018. This enables the Group to determine the probable residual vacant period for properties currently vacant and subject to occupancy guarantees. The maximum term of claims is 180 days. The provision is estimated based on the firm’s average monthly rent. Provisions for rent payment guarantees are calculated by reference to late payments relating to current and former lessees, regardless of whether or not lessee statement of accounts (Arrêtés des Comptes Locataires – ACL) have been drawn up, taking into account the probability of collection (assessed on a statistical basis and regularly updated). Provisions for labour disputes concerned 108 lawsuits compared to 117 lawsuits at 31 December 2017. Out of the 108 lawsuits, 32 relate to amounts in excess of €100,000. In all, the claims represent approximately €10 million. The resolution of labour disputes in the period resulted in expenses of €1.1 million and a writeback of €1.9 million from the provision. Interest rate derivatives Further to its refinancing on 7 September 2016, the Group entered into an interest rate cap agreement on 7 December 2016 under the terms and conditions set out below: • Notional amount: €527.9 million • Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor • Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1% • Hedging period: 7 December 2016 to 6 December 2019 On 19 October 2017, the Group also entered into an additional deferred interest rate cap agreement under the following terms and conditions: • Notional amount: €400 million • Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor • Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1.5% • Hedging period: 7 December 2019 to 6 December 2020 The premiums paid in respect of these cap agreements totalled €915,000. 4.17.2. Foreign exchange derivatives To hedge some of the foreign exchange risk on the loan granted to its subsidiary Foncia Suisse, the Group had entered into hedging contracts through to end-December 2019. Further to the amendment to the loan agreement acknowledging the absence of any repayment date and the adoption of net investment hedge accounting as from 29 June 2018, the Group unwound all of its hedging positions. This transaction, which had no impact on profit or loss, led to a cash inflow of €787,000, recorded in the consolidated statement of cash flows under other cash flows from (used in) financing activities. At 31 December 2018, the Group no longer had any financial instruments hedging its foreign exchange risk. ----- ###### Measurement of financial assets and liabilities at fair value

###### The 1-bp decrease in the margin following the repricing in 2017 (0.75 bps lower at end-March and 0.25 bps lower on 20 December 2017) accounts for the €2.2 million decrease in interest on senior facility B. Lower interest costs on borrowings are linked to the partial early repayment made on 3 August 2018. Drawdowns made on the rollover credit facility since 15 March 2018 lead to much higher interest than in 2017. These interest expenses are partly offset by a decrease in commission on undrawn amounts. Issuance fees for the syndicated loan totalling €30.1 million at 31 December 2018 are recognised over the term of the loan by adjusting the effective interest rate. The effective interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts estimated future cash payments through the expected life of the financial liability to the financial liability’s carrying amount. (*) See Note 2.5 of “Highlights of the period”. ----- ###### Other financial income and expenses

Subsubsection Text: ###### It should be recalled that following the acquisition of Foncia Holding by Foncia Management on 7 September 2016, a new tax group was formed, effective as of 1 January 2017. The new group opted for a tax loss carry-forward system along the lines of the former tax consolidation group, but with a broader scope. In 2018, the tax consolidation group benefited from an off-book deduction of €29.9 million in respect of the IFRS 15 impact, recognised in equity in the individual financial statements. This amount had already been subject to tax in 2017. Based on the allocation by the holding company of deductible financial expenses and the deduction of the share of acquisition fees of Foncia Holding securities in an amount of €5.4 million, an additional tax loss of €5.6 million was generated in 2018. Within the tax consolidation group, tax loss carry-forwards at 31 December 2018 are as follows: • Loss arising on tax consolidation: €23.8 million (after a tax loss of €5.6 million generated in respect of 2018). This tax loss has been recognised in full in view of the high probability that sufficient future taxable profit will exist against which it can be utilised. • Proprietary tax losses of consolidated companies: €25.4 million, of which €18.6 million were not recognised, mainly relating to Foncia Holding (€8.9 million), IDHA (€4.8 million) and Foncia Développement (€2.8 million). ----- ###### It should be recalled that in 2017, the Group was eligible for relief in respect of the CVAE in the amount of €7 million, further to a claim filed (QPC). Excluding this relief, the CVAE expense for 2017 amounted to €5.1 million. Besides this impact, the €3.8 million increase versus 2017 is notably due to the sustained pace of the Group’s acquisition-led growth. FINANCIAL RISK EXPOSURE 8.1.1. Interest rate risk The Group’s interest rate risk exposure arises mainly on its borrowings. These borrowings are denominated solely in euros and are managed on a centralised basis. They are mainly indexed to 3-month Euribor. The risk management policy is set by management. Cash flow surpluses and working capital requirements for the Group’s companies are centralised under a cash pooling agreement and managed by the Group’s Treasury department. The Group’s Treasury department selects investment vehicles for cash surpluses – either for proprietary cash or client cash (excluding separate accounts) – within the framework set by the management policy, which prioritises liquidity and security. Interest received is indexed to 3-month Euribor or is at fixed rates (term accounts). At 31 December 2018, interest rate risks can be broken down by management outlook as follows, taking into account interest rate maturities applied to the asset/liability financing position: Credit risk € thousands Client accounts 557,899 - Term accounts (client funds) (176,027) + Net cash and cash equivalents 3,268 Assets 385,140 - Credit line (1,513,760) + Interest rate cap 527,850 - CICE (15,962) Liabilities (1,001,872) Net position (616,732) A sudden 1% increase in short-term interest rates applied to the net position of assets and liabilities affected by interest rate fluctuations at the end of the reporting period would result in a rise of €6,167,000 in financial expenses. In 2018, the Group still has hedges in place for its credit facilities with an underlying valued at €527,850,000. The cap in place fixes the maximum 3-month Euribor rate at 1%. |Credit risk € thousands|Col2| |---|---| |Client accounts - Term accounts (client funds) + Net cash and cash equivalents|557,899 (176,027) 3,268| |Assets|385,140| |Assets|385,140| |---|---| |- Credit line + Interest rate cap - CICE|(1,513,760) 527,850 (15,962)| |Liabilities|(1,001,872)| |Net position|(616,732)| |---|---| ----- ###### 8.1.2. Foreign exchange risk The Group is exposed to two types of foreign exchange risk: - A foreign exchange risk on assets resulting from the Foncia Group’s shareholdings in its Swiss subsidiaries. ###### Although this risk is measured, it is not subject to specific risk management as the investments are intended to be held over the long term. At 31 December 2018, the Group’s foreign currency positions were as follows: CHF thousands Assets 327,831 Liabilities 212,001 Net position before hedging 115,830 Forex hedging 0 Net position after hedging 115,830 Currency value 0.8854 Net position after hedging (equivalent value in € thousands) 102,556 Accordingly, the Group’s foreign exchange risk exposure on assets is not material. - A foreign exchange trading risk arising on commercial and financial transactions carried out by the Group’s ###### companies in currencies other than their local currency. This risk arises solely on the business of Swiss subsidiaries and concerns the Swiss franc. Since the vast majority of local transactions are carried out in Swiss francs, this risk is not material. It should be noted that currency options had been set up through to December 2019 to guarantee the CHF/EUR exchange rate with respect to the loans granted by Foncia Groupe to its subsidiary Foncia Suisse. On 29 June 2018, Foncia Groupe unwound its entire CHF 13.7 million forex hedge, generating proceeds of €787,000. Foncia in fact signed an amendment to the loan agreement between Foncia Groupe and Foncia Suisse on 29 June 2018, eliminating all repayment clauses. Given that no repayments have been made and that no repayment plan has been set for the foreseeable future, this loan is considered as a monetary item and as part of the net investment in Foncia Suisse as quasi-equity, in accordance with IAS 21 – The Effects of Changes in Foreign Exchange Rates. As from this date, foreign exchange gains and losses arising on the loan will be taken to other comprehensive income under translation reserves. |Assets Liabilities Net position before hedging Forex hedging Net position after hedging Currency value Net position after hedging (equivalent value in € thousands)|CHF thousands 327,831 212,001 115,830 0 115,830 0.8854 102,556| |---|---| ----- ###### NOTE 9. ###### Under the provisions of the Hoguet Law, property management companies must provide financial guarantees for funds held in client accounts. In accordance with this law, Foncia provides financial guarantees to clients equal to the maximum amount of funds held on their account. These guarantees are presented under commitments given. Commitments under property leases relate to the firm commitment undertaken by Foncia with respect to its premises. Commitments given on the acquisition of equity investments correspond to amounts due to the sellers of the companies or business goodwill acquired, the ownership of which had not yet been transferred to the Group at the end of the reporting period. Pledges of collateral correspond to commitments given in connection with the financing set up with the banking pool. In the context of the Foncia Holding group acquisition, the new financing set up and the renegotiated debt, the Group pledged securities to Natixis in its capacity as senior agent and senior collateral agent and to the lenders (BNP Paribas, Crédit Agricole Corporate & Investment Bank, ING Bank N.V., Unicredit Bank AG, London Branch and Natixis) as follows: - pledge of Foncia Holding shares held by Foncia Management; - pledge of Foncia Groupe shares held by Foncia Holding; - pledge of shares in certain Foncia Groupe subsidiaries: ###### - Assurimo, - Constatimmo, - Foncia Pierre Gestion, - Seiitra (Seiitra Réseau as from 23 March 2017), - Foncia Aquitaine, - Foncia Nord Pas de Calais, ----- ###### - Foncia Jacobins, - Foncia Bouteille, - Foncia Chabaneau, - Foncia MPI, - Foncia Paris, - Foncia Saint Antoine, - Foncia Sogi Pelletier, - Foncia Turckheim, - Foncia Voltaire, - Primaliance, - Pledge of Assurimo Paris shares held by Assurimo. As part of these same transactions, the following pledges were also made by the Group: - pledge of Foncia Management, Foncia Holding and Foncia Groupe bank accounts; - pledge of the Foncia Group’s trademarks; - pledge of certain receivables owed to Foncia Management (intercompany loan of 7 September 2016), ###### Foncia Holding (intercompany loan of 7 September 2016), Foncia Deutschland GmbH (intercompany loan of 14 December 2016), Foncia Suisse SA (intercompany loan of 14 December 2012), Trevi group (intercompany loan of 7 May 2013) and Foncia Groupe (amounts due by Foncia Groupe subsidiaries in connection with cash pooling arrangements). LITIGATION AND CONTINGENT LIABILITIES None. NOTE 11. SUBSEQUENT EVENTS Acquisitions Continuing its active policy of acquisition-led growth, in early 2019 the Group completed certain major acquisitions. ▪ GRIBI (Switzerland) As part of its strategy of expansion in Switzerland, on 1 March 2019 the Group completed a series of acquisitions of property management companies for a total purchase price of CHF 18.2 million. The transactions cover five companies belonging to the group owned by Mr Urs Gribi, active in property management (71%), transactions (17%) and retail and institutional brokerage services (11%). The acquisition will give the Group a central presence in Basel and Zurich, allowing it to deepen its footprint in German-speaking Switzerland. ▪ Other acquisitions in France Acquisition (€ thousands)_** Method Location date
